But this tells me they have good information and intelligence that these organizations have been acting on behalf of the Kremlin and that there\u2019s a direct line between them and the [Russian influence operations] that are a significant threat to our democracy.\u201d

|[

WASHINGTON
column2: Sept 11 (Reuters) - U.S. Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy on Monday put a temporarily hold on limits imposed by a lower court on President Donald Trump\u2019s order barring most refugees from entering the United States.
column3: Kennedy acted in response to the U.S. Justice Department\u2019s challenge to the part of a Thursday ruling by the San Francisco-based 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals that would let refugees from around the world enter the country if they have a formal offer from a resettlement agency.
column4: Without Kennedy\u2019s intervention
column5: the appeals court decision would have gone into effect on Tuesday. Kennedy\u2019s action gives the full Supreme Court time to consider the merits of the Trump administration\u2019s emergency request in full. Kennedy asked refugee ban challengers to file a response by noon (1600 GMT) on Tuesday.
column6: The administration did not ask the court to put on hold a separate part of the lower court ruling that exempted grandparents
column7: aunts
column8: uncles and cousins of legal U.S. residents from Trump\u2019s ban on travelers from six Muslim-majority countries.
column9: In the court filing
column10: the Justice Department said the 9th Circuit\u2019s decision on the refugee ban \u201cwill disrupt the status quo and frustrate orderly implementation of the order\u2019s refugee provisions.\u201d Up to 24
column11: 000 additional refugees would become eligible to enter the country than would be otherwise allowed
column12: according to the administration.
column13: The Justice Department\u2019s filing marked the latest twist in the ongoing legal fight over Trump\u2019s sweeping March 6 executive order that barred travelers from Iran
column14: Syria
column15: Libya
column16: Somalia
column17: Sudan and Yemen for 90 days
column18: a move Trump argued was needed to prevent terrorist attacks. The same order included a 120-day ban on refugees from around the world.
column19: The bans were challenged by Hawaii and other Democratic-led states
column20: the American Civil Liberties Union and refugee groups.
column21: Both provisions were blocked by lower courts but were partially revived by the Supreme Court in June
column22: which said the bans could be applied only to people without a \u201cbona fide\u201d relationship to people or entities in the United States.
column23: That prompted new litigation brought by Hawaii over the meaning of that phrase
column24: including whether written assurances by resettlement agencies obligating them to provide services for specific refugees would count as a bona fide relationship.
column25: The Trump administration said the assurances should not
column26: meaning such refugees would be barred.
column27: The appeals court also said his administration did not persuasively explain why the broader travel ban should be enforced against close relatives of people from the six specified countries. The Justice Department said in its filing on Monday it disagreed with that part of the decision but was not seeking to block it from going into effect.
column28: The broader question of whether the travel ban discriminates against Muslims in violation of the U.S. Constitution
column29: as lower courts previously ruled
column30: will be considered by the Supreme Court in October.
column31: States
column32: civil liberties advocates and others who challenged Trump\u2019s order in court argued that it violated federal immigration law and the Constitution\u2019s First Amendment prohibition on the government favoring or disfavoring any particular religion. Critics called it a discriminatory \u201cMuslim ban.\u201d
column33: Trump\u2019s March order replaced a broader January one that was blocked by federal courts.

No Place For Climate Change Deniers To Hide

|[

As the hurricanes and forest fires rage
column2: \xa0we know there are no Republicans or Democrats in lifeboats
column3: only survivors.\xa0And it is past time that we all turn towards the storm
column4: not away from it.\xa0
column5: But as I watched Governor Rick Scott advise Floridians to evacuate in the face of the fury of Hurricane Irma
column6: \xa0I wondered: Where are climate change deniers supposed to go?\xa0
column7: Should they evacuate to Houston
column8: where the victims of Katrina evacuated 12 years ago? No
column9: it is still recovering from Hurricane Harvey.\xa0
column10: Should they evacuate to Rosyln
column11: Washington
column12: a beautiful and welcoming tourist destination in my home state? No.\xa0As I write this
column13: \xa0Roslyn is under a Level 2 evacuation order in the face of the horrendous 26
column14: 000-acre Jolly Mountain fire.
column15: Should the Irma evacuees flee to Idaho
column16: a hotbed of climate denial?\xa0No
column17: almost the entire state is blanketed by threats of forest fires.
column18: How about being creative
column19: and evacuating eastward
column20: to the island paradise of Barbuda?\xa0No
column21: it is already battered and now preparing for the next of the battering rams of an enraged atmosphere
column22: Hurricane Jose.\xa0
column23: Climate change deniers are running out of places to hide\xa0\u2015 places to hide from hurricanes
column24: places to hide from forest fires
column25: \xa0and places to hide from scientific truth.\xa0Yet this did not stop Donald Trump\u2019s administrator of the Environmental Protection Agenc<wbr/>y
column26: Scott Pruitt
column27: \xa0from taking time to proclaim:\xa0\u201cTo have any kind of focus on the cause and effect of the storm vs.\xa0helping people
column28: or actually facing the effect of the storm
column29: is misplaced.\u201d
column30: Unfortunately for the Trump administration
column31: talking about climate change is always \u201cmisplaced.\u201d\xa0But the sad and dangerous fact is that climate change is altering our climate
column32: our weather and our future.\xa0These changes leave us precious little time in the future when climate change is not inflicting pain on someone
column33: somewhere.
column34: It is not mutually exclusive to care for and respond to those being most impacted by these disasters and at the same time hear the clarion call to take action that will keep these disasters from becoming even worse. It is why we will band together to do all we can for Texas
column35: and why we will be there for all Floridians
column36: even those like Rush Limbaugh who deny the clear science that climate change exposes us to increased risk of giant precipitation events
column37: rising sea levels
column38: \xa0and lethal forest fires.\xa0
column39: The reality is that the current administration never wants to address either the science
column40: or the public health
column41: or the economics of climate change. They can run
column42: but they cannot hide from Mother Nature.
column43: Simply piling sandbags and nailing up plywood over the windows is not enough. Simply collecting millions in private donations and giving billions from the federal government is not enough. Simply being moved by the incredible display of neighbors helping neighbors
column44: strangers putting their lives on the line for others and emergency responders leaving their own families to be there for the people they serve is not enough.
column45: Now is precisely the time for a national commitment
column46: when the winds are blowing and fires are burning.\xa0What we\u2019re starting to see is beyond the normal bounds of mere weather changes.\xa0
column47: So what does it mean to run toward the storm and not away from it?\xa0It means that when we run for office
column48: defeating climate change should be an absolute top priority.\xa0It means that we will call out the climate denial of our rivals
column49: not as some peripheral and modest comment but a fundamental flaw that should disqualify candidates from public office.\xa0It means that we will build our efforts around fighting climate change
column50: rather than appending it to our thoughts and plans.\xa0
column51: That passion must become an animating force in all we do. It must extend beyond parlor room debate. We can no longer look at climate change as a second-tier issue
column52: relegated to something confined to the environmental community. It must drive our policy and our politics in every realm and in every constituency and in every debate. In the next presidential debate it must be the defining topic
column53: not one ignored or sidelined
column54: and if the moderators don\u2019t ask about it
column55: candidates must insert it aggressively
column56: repeatedly and effectively.
column57: The floods and fires are not a time just for sorrow
column58: they must be a time for action.\xa0We must seize this moment to help the victims of these storms
column59: and we must seize this moment to take action on climate change.
column60: It is a small blue planet
column61:
but it is the only one we have.

column36: along with a farther-reaching program to shield undocumented parents of U.S. citizens from deportation. Lawyers in the Batalla Vidal case requested to amend their lawsuit to challenge the termination of DACA within hours of the Trump administration\u2019s announcement on Tuesday. \xa0
column37: A coalition of 15 states and the District of Columbia

column40: Both of the New York lawsuits allege that Trump\u2019s decision to end DACA was motivated by an intent to discriminate against Mexicans

column42: Democratic California Attorney General Xavier Becerra plans to file a fourth lawsuit in federal court in his home state disputing the decision to end DACA. \xa0
column43: The president has broad authority to undue the executive actions of previous administrations. But similar legal challenges largely blocked Trump\u2019s efforts to restrict virtually all visits from several Muslim-majority countries earlier this year.
column44: Whether or not the lawsuits are ultimately successful

column46: Trump has said he wants to work with Congress on a legislative solution for Dreamers in the six month window before many begin to lose their work permits and protections. Napolitano said she plans to continue to press members of Congress to solve the bill through law

column48: \u201cI believe that in this case the court should act

column50:
\u201cor in the alternative Congress should act and settle this matter for once and for all.\u201d

UPDATE: Sept. 11 \u2015\xa0In a reversal
column2: Equifax said in a statement\xa0Monday morning that the company wouldn\u2019t require credit card information from victims of the company\u2019s data breach who sign up for its free service.

column6: PREVIOUSLY:
column7: WASHINGTON \u2015 The credit monitoring company that let criminals steal personal information pertaining to nearly half the U.S. population is offering free credit monitoring to those affected \u2015 but there\u2019s a catch.
column8: Victims of the Equifax security breach who sign up for the company\u2019s \u201ccomplimentary\u201d service will only get one free year. After that
column9: unless they proactively cancel
column10: they may have to pay. The terms of use\xa0say customers must have internet access and a credit or debit card to sign up.
column11: \u201cWe will not bill You until the free trial period has expired and provided that You have not yet cancelled your trial membership
column12: \u201d say the terms
column13: dated Sept. 6. \u201cIn the event that You wish to continue Your membership beyond the trial period

column15: Robert Weissman
column16: president of the consumer watchdog Public Citizen
column17: said
column18: \u201cIt appears that the company thinks one of the worst data breaches in history is a marketing opportunity. Instead of trying to rip people off with new hidden charges and trick consumers to give up their rights it might be a better idea to actually remedy the harm.\u201d
column19: A spokesperson for Equifax did not immediately respond to a request for comment about the free service.
column20: Customers also must agree to settle disputes outside of court in an extremely business-friendly format known as arbitration.
column21: Consumer advocates describe the arbitration clause as a straightforward ripoff for the 143 million Americans whose Social Security numbers and addresses are now in the hands of criminals thanks to a breach earlier this year. Though it discovered the breach in late July
column22: Equifax publicly\xa0announced\xa0the news on Thursday.\xa0
column23: \u201cAt this point it\u2019s very clear that Equifax is trying to use this massive data breach as an excuse to profit
column24: which is just appalling behavior
column25: \u201d said Amanda Werner
column26: the campaign manager at Americans for Financial Reform. \u201cI can\u2019t even put into words how awful this behavior is.\u201d
column27: As Equifax explains in the terms of use
column28: customers using its products are subject to mandatory
column29: binding arbitration. \u201cBy consenting to submit Your Claims to arbitration
column30: You will be forfeiting Your right to bring or participate in any class action (whether as a named plaintiff or a class member) or to share in any class action awards
column31: including class claims where a class has not yet been certified
column32: even if the facts and circumstances upon which the Claims are based already occurred or existed.\u201d
column33: Weissman said that the arbitration clause attached to the free credit monitoring service covers only the credit monitoring service offered and not the overarching breach of data. Still
column34: if Equifax failed to inform a customer \u2015 a victim of the hack
column35: say \u2015 that their identity had been compromised and was being used without their knowledge
column36: by signing up for their free credit monitoring offer and thus agreeing to the arbitration clause
column37: they would have waived the right to sue over this failure outside of arbitration.
column38: However
column39: Equifax also requires consumers who have requested their credit score directly from the company in the past to have agreed to an arbitration clause that could cover the breach.
column40: \u201cIf you\u2019ve been an Equifax customer
column41: they will claim that you have agreed to an arbitration provision
column42: \u201d Weissman said.
column43: A company spokesman said the arbitration only applied to the free credit monitoring
column44: not the cybersecurity breach.
column45: Equifax
column46: along with Experian and TransUnion
column47: are the three largest companies that track credit histories of everybody who takes out a loan or signs up a credit card
column48: creating proprietary \u201cscores\u201d that help lenders evaluate a potential borrower\u2019s ability to pay.
column49: The companies are notorious for charging access for the information
column50: which by law is available to consumers for free once a year. Experian has been fined multiple times by the Federal Trade Commission for tricking consumers with false promises of \u201cfree\u201d credit reports that wound up costing money.
column51: Companies often require consumers to use their products or services if they waive their right to pursue class action lawsuits and enter into direct arbitration with the business if they seek a legal redress to a wrong.
column52: In the case of Equifax
column53: everyone who signs up for the free credit monitoring the company is offering to the 143 million people whose data has been compromised is waiving their right to join in a class action suit if something goes wrong with the credit monitoring.
column54: The insertion of arbitration clauses into dense terms of service contracts that consumers rarely read has exploded in the past six years. In 2011
column55: the Supreme Court upheld a forced arbitration provision inserted into AT&T contracts in a divided 5-4 ruling. This was one of many tightly divided decisions in recent years where the conservative majority on the court ruled in favor of corporate rights to force consumers into arbitration.
column56: In the face of the corporate tilt of the Supreme Court
column57: the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau
column58: the financial watchdog agency created by the 2010 Wall Street reform legislation
column59: recently announced a new rule against mandatory arbitration clauses disallowing class action lawsuits. But Republicans in Congress have vowed to strike the rule.
column60: The new CFPB arbitration rule is scheduled to take effect on Sept.\xa018. House Republicans
column61: however

column63: but have not yet voted on it. That legislation is not subject to a filibuster and would therefore only require 50 votes to pass in a chamber with 52 Republican senators.

column66: 000 cap on punitive damages for consumers who have been wronged. In an ironic twist
column67:
the House Financial Services Committee held a hearing on Loudermilk\u2019s bill on Thursday \u2015 the same day Equifax revealed the breach of consumer data.

column12: including Canada
column13: France and Australia. But it has long been viewed as a pipe dream in the United States
column14: where a <a href="http://www.kff.org/other/state-indicator/total-population/?currentTimeframe=0&sortModel=%7B%22colId%22:%22Location%22
column15: %22sort%22:%22asc%22%7D" target="_blank">plurality of people receive coverage from their employers.
column16: Baucus\u2019 endorsement of the idea speaks to just how dramatically the health policy debate has shifted within the Democratic Party in recent years \u2015 particularly since the 2016 presidential run of Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.)
column17: who made what he called \u201cMedicare for all\u201d a central issue of his campaign.
column18: Baucus was the subject of progressive frustration for his stewardship of the ACA
column19: also known as Obamacare. Critics argued that he held the bill in committee far too long in hopes of winning the support of moderate Republicans who did not end up voting for the final bill. The lengthy negotiation period he initiated gave Republicans much-needed time to mobilize opposition to reform
column20: according to Baucus\u2019 detractors.
column21: Obamacare itself relies on a hybrid model
column22: once favored by conservative policy experts
column23: that combines the creation of a new private
column24: individual insurance marketplace and an expansion of Medicaid.
column25: Given Baucus\u2019 history as a fiscal moderate active in the ACA\u2019s passage
column26: his positive remarks about single-payer could provide a boost to progressive activists agitating for its implementation.
column27: As Senate Finance Committee chairman
column28: Baucus ruled out consideration of single-payer from the beginning
column29: and declined to invite the testimony of single-payer advocates at hearings. The latter decision prompted disruptive protests from activists
column30: and Baucus later said that\xa0he regretted not engaging more with the policy\u2019s proponents.
column31: In September 2009
column32: Baucus also voted against two amendments that would have created a public health insurance option on the Obamacare individual insurance exchanges.
column33: Baucus kept single-payer off the table during the development of Obamacare because he believed the country was not ready for it at the time
column34: he told NBC News on Friday.\xa0
column35: \u201cI just think the time has come
column36: \u201d Baucus said. \u201cBack in \u201909
column37: we were not ready to address it. It would never have passed. Here we are nine years later
column38: I think it\u2019s time to hopefully have a very serious good faith look at it.\u201d
column39: Sen. Jon Tester\xa0(D-Mont.)
column40: a moderate who represented Montana alongside Baucus from 2007 to 2014
column41: also expressed openness to single-payer this week.
column42: \u201cMaybe it\u2019s something we should
column43: quite frankly
column44: take a solid look at
column45: \u201d Tester said Wednesday.
column46: Tester does not support single-payer legislation
column47: however. When Sen. Steve Daines (R-Mont.)
column48: aiming to put Democrats in an awkward political position
column49: introduced a trick amendment creating a single-payer system to the Obamacare repeal bill
column50: most Democratic senators voted \u201cpresent\u201d on the motion
column51: but Tester was one of four Democratic senators to vote \u201cno\u201d\xa0on it.
column52: Former Sen. Kent Conrad (D-N.D.) \u2015 a moderate who vehemently opposed creating a public health insurance option during the passage of Obamacare \u2015 told HuffPost that unlike Baucus
column53: he believes it is \u201cunlikely we will get a single-payer system in the foreseeable future.\u201d
column54: Single-payer is improbable
column55: Conrad argued
column56: because funding a federal health insurance program would cost taxpayers so much and because medical providers are so opposed to radically transforming the system.\xa0
column57: Instead
column58: he said
column59: the \u201cbest system combines universal coverage with private not-for-profit insurance with the government assisting those who cannot afford insurance.\u201d
column60: He also favors empowering Medicare to negotiate bulk discounts on prescription drugs
column61: just as the Veterans Affairs health care system does.
column62: In addition to Sanders\u2019 presidential run
column63: the collapse of Republican efforts to repeal Obamacare has increased grassroots energy behind single-payer as activists seek to go on the offensive. Progressive pressure groups like Credo have launched efforts to make support for the policy a litmus test for 2020\u2032s Democratic presidential candidates.
column64: Single-payer now has more support in Congress than at any other time in recent history. Single-payer legislation introduced by Rep. John Conyers (D-Mich.) has more co-sponsors than ever
column65: with the support of a majority of the House Democratic Caucus.
column66: Sanders plans to unveil a much-anticipated version of single-payer legislation next Wednesday. Sens. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.)
column67: a rumored 2020 presidential contender
column68: and Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) have already announced plans to co-sponsor the bill.
column69: Polling suggests that the idea of single-payer is popular with the public
column70: especially among Democrats. In a May 2016 Gallup poll
column71: 58 percent of Americans and 73 percent of Democrats said they supported replacing \u201cthe ACA with a federally funded healthcare program providing insurance for all Americans.\u201d\xa0
column72: Even elected Democrats who remain wary of single-payer have begun trying to capitalize on the ambitious proposal\u2019s popularity. The Congressional Hispanic Caucus\u2019 political action committee
column73: Bold PAC
column74: has repeatedly alluded to the \u201cMedicare for all\u201d fight in fundraising e-mails \u2015 even though half of the 30 CHC members have yet to actually endorse single-payer
column75: and the PAC does not make support for the policy a condition for its financial support.
column76: Of course
column77: \xa0it is much easier to talk about single-payer than to actually implement it. Replacing the current system with one large federal program would require a massive tax increase in exchange for what advocates believe would result in net cost reductions thanks to the government\u2019s considerable bargaining power.
column78: It would also force the nearly half of Americans who get insurance from their jobs to enroll in a new government program. Given the outcry that Obamacare elicited for canceling the plans of a fraction of that number of people
column79: enacting single-payer would likely prove an extraordinary political challenge.
column80: In the meantime
column82: the excitement around single-payer has already widened the spectrum of acceptable debate about health care.\xa0Expansions of coverage that once seemed radical now seem downright moderate by comparison. In August
column83: Sen. Brian Schatz (D-Hawaii) announced plans to introduce legislation allowing Americans of all ages and incomes to buy into Medicaid. And earlier this week
column84: Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) revealed his intention to introduce a bill creating a comparable universal buy-in option for Medicare
column85: which he said\xa0\u201cmay be the fastest way to a single-payer system.\u201d
column86: This article has been updated with comments from Tester and Conrad
column87:
as well as additional comments from Baucus.

column34: someone only needs to be \u201cdomiciled\u201d there

Miami Mayor To Donald Trump: It's Time To Talk About Climate Change

|[

Miami\u2019s Republican mayor says this year\u2019s record-breaking hurricanes are likely a result of climate change
column2: and is calling on President Donald Trump \u2015 who once dismissed global warming as a hoax created \u201cby and for the Chinese\u201d \u2015 to acknowledge the connection.
column3: \u201cIf this isn\u2019t climate change
column4: I don\u2019t know what is
column5: \u201d Mayor Tom\xe1s Regalado told reporters Friday after declaring a State of Local Emergency\xa0in his city.
column6: Thousands of Miami residents are among more than 6.3 million Floridians who have been ordered to evacuate as Hurricane Irma charges toward the state \u2015 potentially the largest evacuation in U.S. history.
column7: Irma decimated the Caribbean island of Barbuda as an extremely powerful Category 5 storm on Wednesday before hitting\xa0Cuba\u2019s Camaguey Archipelago\xa0on Friday. It was downgraded to a Category 3 storm as it moved north on Saturday morning
column8: but is expected to strengthen back to a Category 4 before reaching the Florida Keys on Sunday morning.
column9: Meanwhile
column10: Hurricane Katia is wreaking havoc in Mexico while Hurricane Jos\xe9
column11: a Category 4 storm
column12: threatens Barbuda
column13: St.\xa0Martin and St. Barts \u2015 islands that Irma already devastated. And a little more than a week ago
column14: Hurricane Harvey ravaged much of Houston and its surrounding area
column15: causing unprecedented damage that will take years to repair.\xa0
column16: \u201cThis is the time to talk about climate change. This is the time that the president and the [Environmental Protection Agency] and whoever makes decisions needs to talk about climate change
column17: \u201d Regalado told the Miami Herald. \u201cThis is a truly
column18: truly poster child for what is to come.\u201d
column19: \u201cI don\u2019t want to be political
column20: but the fact of the matter is that this is a lesson that we need protection from nature
column21: \u201d he added. \u201cSo
column22: I think this is a lesson for the people to say you know what? We have to be prepared.\u201d
column23: Although climate change causes the oceans to warm
column24: which in turn increases the frequency of extreme weather events
column25: scientists are still hesitant to link this year\u2019s historic hurricanes with the phenomenon.\xa0
column26: Florida Gov. Rick Scott (R)
column27: who on Saturday warned Floridians in evacuation zones that they \u201cwill not survive\u201d the storm surge \u2015 now expected to reach as high as 15 feet \u2015 has long expressed skepticism about the causes of climate change. Scott was even accused\xa0in 2015 of banning administrators in the Department of Environmental Protection from using the term \u201cclimate change\u201d in official communications.
column28: When asked if he believes the mountain of scientific evidence proving the connection between climate change and human activity
column29:
the governor has replied: \u201cI\u2019m not a scientist.\u201d

]

column1:
http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/mar-a-lago-has-a-flood-insurance-policy-through-the-federal-government_us_59b3cd79e4b0dfaafcf82e52?utm_campaign=hp_fb_pages&utm_source=politics_fb&utm_medium=facebook&ncid=fcbklnkushpmg00000013§ion=politics|

Mar-A-Lago Has A Flood Insurance Policy Through The Federal Government

|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 Federally insured property in Florida is in the crosshairs of potentially catastrophic Hurricane Irma \u2015 including President Donald Trump\u2019s Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach.
column2: The property has a flood insurance policy through the National Flood Insurance Program
column3: a Federal Emergency Management Agency spokesperson\xa0told HuffPost. The program\xa0provides affordable insurance in flood-prone zones where private insurers have traditionally refused to insure properties because they\u2019re so vulnerable.
column4: The Mar-a-Lago club\u2019s policy
column5: which is insured to the Trump Organization and Donald J. Trump Revocable Trust
column6: is not subsidized and is classified at a full-risk rate for the applicable flood zone
column7: the FEMA spokesperson said.\xa0
column8: A property covered at the \u201cfull-risk\u201d rate means that its owner is paying a rate that reflects\xa0the full risk of flooding\xa0up to a certain coverage amount. Older properties can be \u201csubsidized
column9: \u201d meaning their rates do not necessarily reflect the full risk for those properties. The 1968-era National Flood Insurance Program
column10: or NFIP
column11: offers a mix of rates.\xa0
column12: The insurance program\u2019s\xa0authorization was set to expire at the end of this month
column13: but Trump\xa0signed legislation on Friday that temporarily extends it.
column14: NFIP as a whole has been criticized for not charging enough to cover the\xa0expected costs of liabilities. It also\xa0consistently does not bring in enough money to pay out the properties it insures
column15: and owes around $25 billion to the U.S. Treasury. Based on policies that went into effect on Aug.\xa031
column17: the program is projected to have a one-year shortfall of $1.4 billion
column18: according to a Congressional Budget Office report published this month.
column19: Some critics say the program\xa0benefits affluent people who live on beachfront property
column20: essentially allowing them to live in places that are at a high risk of being damaged.
column21: \u201cIf [NFIP] was a regular insurance company
column22: they would have been in receivership
column23: \u201d Burl Daniel
column24: an insurance expert witness from Texas
column25: told HuffPost. \u201cBut it\u2019s a political football because of the people who live on the coast.\u201d
column26: \u201cThe program was already in trouble\u201d before Hurricanes Harvey and Irma began approaching the U.S.
column27: said Karen O\u2019Neill
column28: an associate professor at Rutgers University who studies how policies about land and water affect government power.
column29: \u201cIt became super in trouble after Katrina
column30: and Sandy was another blow
column31: \u201d O\u2019Neill said.\xa0
column32: Mar-a-Lago
column33: Trump International Golf Club in Palm Beach and Trump National Golf Club in Jupiter are all closed in advance of Irma
column34: a Trump Organization spokesperson said. (She did not respond to the question about insurance.) Irma
column35: one of the largest storms ever recorded
column36: is expected to hit Florida this weekend.
column37: Mar-a-Lago has weathered hurricanes before. According to an\xa0Associated Press investigation
column38: \xa0Trump claimed that he received a $17 million insurance payout for the estate in 2005 due to damage from a series of storms
column39: but said he pocketed some of the money instead of using it to rebuild. Trump once boasted in a deposition that he had a \u201cvery good insurance policy
column40: \u201d apparently in reference to private insurance. (The FEMA spokesperson declined to comment on whether Mar-a-Lago was also insured by NFIP at the time
column41: as that is \u201cnot publicly available information.\u201d)
column42: Mar-a-Lago
column43: which Trump bought for $10 million in 1985
column44: could see its main buildings damaged by an 8-foot storm surge
column45: according to the AP. Thirty years from now
column46: the property could be under at least a foot of water for most of the year
column47: according to a risk analysis prepared for the Guardian.
column48: A group of Democratic lawmakers introduced a bill in June\xa0that specifically aimed to block Trump properties from receiving any federal subsidy for flood insurance coverage. The name of the bill \u2015 the\xa0Prohibiting Aid for Recipients Ignoring Science
column49: or Paris
column50: Act \u2015\xa0riffs off the Paris climate accord
column51: an agreement from which Trump withdrew that same month.
column52: As FEMA noted
column53: \xa0the NFIP policy for Mar-a-Lago isn\u2019t explicitly subsidized. (HuffPost did not ask the agency about policy details for other Trump-owned properties in Florida.) But Democrats say the Paris Act
column54: which is not expected to pass anytime soon
column55: is about the larger principle.
column56: \u201cIt would be outrageous for somebody who is denying the reality of climate
column57: who is undercutting our ability to minimize the effects
column58: to then turn around and be a recipient of federal largess
column59: \u201d said Rep. Earl Blumenauer (D-Ore.)
column60: who introduced the House bill.
column61: \u201cWe need to stop building in places where nature shows repeatedly that they\u2019re not wanted
column62: \u201d he added. \u201cWe need to stop making it worse
column63:
and we need to put in place programs to try and minimize damage.\u201d

]

Equifax Clarifies Policy After Outcry Over Consumers' Legal Rights Following Hack

|[

Equifax issued a statement Friday saying that victims of a recent massive security breach won\u2019t have to waive their right to file a class action lawsuit against the company
column2: \xa0after people noticed language buried in Equifax\u2019s terms of service that barred customers from doing so.
column3: \u201cWe have made it clear that the arbitration clause and class action waiver included in the Equifax and TrustedID Premier terms of use does not apply to this cybersecurity incident
column4: \u201d the company said in an update to its website.
column5: Equifax announced Thursday that it had discovered in July it was the victim of a massive hack that exposed the personal information of an estimated 143 million Americans.\xa0Social Security numbers and credit card numbers were among the information exposed.
column6: The company offered those affected by the hack a free one-year subscription to its credit-monitoring service TrustedID Premier.\xa0Those who opt to use Equifax\u2019s free service will be charged after a year if they do not actively cancel their subscriptions.
column7: Shortly after the announcement
column8: people on social media pointed out the arbitration clause buried in the product\u2019s terms of use
column9: which bars customers from participating in any class action lawsuits against the company.
column10: DO NOT SIGN UP FOR EQUIFAX'S CREDIT MONITORING "SOLUTION" TO ITS BREACH. YOU WAIVE THE RIGHT TO ENJOIN A CLASS ACTION LAWSUIT.
column11: You know you can\u2019t be part of the Equifax class action lawsuit if you use their credit monitoring service
column12: because you read the ToS
column13: right?
column14: Don't sign up for the credit monitoring from Equifax. If you do you are agreeing to NOT join a class action lawsuit! Spread the word. pic.twitter.com/H4KJJw4h8Z
column15: Equifax clarified its terms of use after New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman on Friday called the language in question \u201cunacceptable and unenforceable.\u201d
column16: Later Friday
column17: Schneiderman said he was launching a formal investigation into Equifax\u2019s security breach and encouraged all of Equifax\u2019s customers to reach out to the company to see if they were affected.
column18: I am launching a formal investigation into the #Equifax breach. Today
column19: I sent a letter to @Equifax seeking additional information. pic.twitter.com/qlZIs8OKnO
column20: So far
column21: two class action lawsuits against Equifax have been proposed
column22:
alleging that the credit monitoring company was negligent in protecting its customers\u2019 private information and should have spent more money protecting the data against cyberattacks.\xa0

]

North Korea Holds Huge Celebration For Its Nuclear Scientists

|[

SEOUL
column2: Sept 10 (Reuters) - North Korean leader Kim Jong Un hosted a massive celebration to congratulate his nuclear scientists and technicians who steered the country\u2019s sixth and largest nuclear test a week ago
column3: its official news agency said on Sunday.
column4: The United States and its allies had been bracing for another long-range missile launch in time for the 69th anniversary of North Korea\u2019s founding on Saturday
column5: but no fresh provocations were spotted while the North held numerous events to mark the holiday.
column6: Throughout last week
column7: South Korean officials had warned the North could launch another intercontinental ballistic missile in defiance of U.N. sanctions and amid an escalating standoff with the United States.
column8: Washington told the U.N. Security Council on Friday to call a meeting on Monday to vote on a draft resolution establishing additional sanctions on North Korea for its missile and nuclear program.
column9: Japanese Defence Minister Itsunori Onodera said it was vital to put pressure on North Korea through additional sactions
column10: including blocking or slowing its fuel supplies.
column11: \u201cIf we put firm pressure on North Korea such that it realizes it cannot develop missiles
column12: it will accept dialog and we can progress with diplomatic efforts
column13: \u201d Onodera told public broadcaster NHK on Sunday. \u201cUnless we firmly apply pressure
column14: North Korea will not change its direction.\u201d
column15: KCNA said Kim threw a banquet to laud the nuclear scientists and other top military and party officials who contributed to the nuclear bomb test last Sunday
column16: topped with an art performance and a photo session with the leader himself.
column17: KCNA did not specify when the banquet had been held
column18: but analysts said it had likely been on Saturday.
column19: Photos released on Sunday by KCNA showed the young leader breaking into a broad smile at the People\u2019s Theatre with two prominent scientists: Ri Hong Sop
column20: head of North Korea\u2019s Nuclear Weapons Institute
column21: and Hong Sung Mu
column22: deputy director of the ruling Workers\u2019 Party of Korea\u2019s munitions industry department.
column23: Ri and Hong have played vital roles in the North\u2019s nuclear program
column24: appearing at close distance to Kim during field inspections and weapons tests
column25: including the latest nuclear test. Ri is a former director of Yongbyon Nuclear Research Centre
column26: North Korea\u2019s main nuclear facility north of Pyongyang
column27: where Hong also worked as a chief engineer.
column28: North Korea had said the latest test was an advanced hydrogen bomb. There was no independent confirmation but some Western experts said there was enough strong evidence to suggest the reclusive state has either developed a hydrogen bomb or was getting very close.
column29: KCNA said on Sunday the scientists and technicians \u201cbrought the great auspicious event of the national history
column30: an extra-large event through the perfect success in the test of H-bomb.\u201d
column31: Kim praised the developers in his own remarks as \u201ctaking the lead\u201d in attaining the \u201cfinal goal of completing the state nuclear force\u201d in line with his parallel pursuit of nuclear and economic development.
column32: \u201cThe recent test of the H-bomb is the great victory won by the Korean people at the cost of their blood while tightening their belts in the arduous period
column33: \u201d Kim was quoted as saying.
column34: Ri and Hong\u2019s roles have also been noted overseas
column35: prompting the United Nations
column36: the United States or South Korea to blacklist them.
column37: Aside from the elite
column38: rank-and-file North Koreans also commemorated the anniversary on Saturday by visiting the Kumsusan Palace of the Sun
column39: which houses the embalmed bodies of founding father Kim Il Sung and his son and successor Kim Jong Il.
column40: KCNA said service personnel and civilians
column41: including children
column42: laid floral baskets and bouquets at the statues of the deceased leaders across the country
column43:
while enjoying art performances and dancing parties. (Reporting by Hyonhee Shin and Christine Kim; Editing by Kim Coghill and Raju Gopalakrishnan)

]

Sikh Canadian Politician Brilliantly Foils Racist Woman During Event

|[

Canadian politician Jagmeet Singh was meeting with his constituents on Wednesday in Brampton
column2: Ontario
column3: when a woman stormed up to him and began to harass him.
column4: Singh
column5: a member of provincial Parliament and\xa0New Democratic Party leadership candidate\xa0who is Sikh
column6: was just starting his \u201cJagMeet & Greet\u201d event when the unidentified woman rushed up and interrupted him. She began to yell at Singh about sharia law and the Muslim Brotherhood.\xa0
column7: \u201cWe know you\u2019re in bed with Sharia. We know you\u2019re in bed with the Muslim Brotherhood. We know by your votes
column8: \u201d she said.
column9: Although Sikhism is the world\u2019s fifth-largest religion
column10: followers are often mistaken for Muslims and subjected to Islamophobia. Part of that is due to the traditional turban head coverings that Sikh men
column11: including Singh
column12: wear as part of their faith.
column13: During the encounter
column14: the woman kept repeating herself as people in the audience began to get upset. When someone tried to speak to her
column15: she yelled at the crowd not to touch her
column16: saying she would call the police.\xa0
column17: Singh remained calm
column18: however
column19: and spoke directly to the crowd.
column20: \u201cWe don\u2019t want to be intimidated by hate. We don\u2019t want hatred to ruin a positive event
column21: \u201d he said. \u201cLet\u2019s show people how we would treat someone with love.\u201d
column22: And he began to chant his campaign slogan
column23: \u201cLove and courage.\u201d\xa0
column24: The woman
column25: who said Singh had refused to answer her calls to his office
column26: continued to ask when he would stop supporting sharia law. As she realized she was only going to be ignored
column27: she got frustrated and ultimately decided to leave.\xa0
column28: Watch the full encounter below.
column29: Singh on Saturday night tweeted a statement regarding the incident
column30: including an explanation of why he felt it important not to clarify to the woman that he is Sikh not Muslim.
column31: With #LoveAndCourage pic.twitter.com/eRbuvOWNJX
column32: America does not do a good job of tracking incidents of hate and bias. We need your help to create a database of such incidents across the country
column33:
so we all know what\u2019s going on.\xa0Tell us your story.

]

Here's How To Help The Victims Of Hurricane Irma

|[

Hurricane Irma\xa0made landfall in Florida on Sunday
column2: \xa0hitting the state with rain and record winds.\xa0
column3: Thousands have already been displaced and at least 26 people have been killed\xa0since the storm ripped through Antigua and Barbuda
column4: \xa0Saint Martin and Saint Barth\xe9lemy
column5: \xa0Anguilla
column6: the U.S. and British Virgin Islands
column7: \xa0Puerto Rico
column8: the Turks and Caicos Islands
column9: the Bahamas and Cuba\u2019s Camaguey Archipelago over the course of this week.
column10: Ahead of what will likely be a lengthy cleanup operation in the U.S. and across the Caribbean
column11: here\u2019s what you can do to help those affected:
column12: Multiple organizations are appealing for donations so they can send volunteers and supplies to the disaster areas.
column13: They include the\xa0American Red Cross
column14: the Salvation Army
column15: Catholic Charities USA
column16: UNICEF
column17: Oxfam America
column18: Americares
column19: Habitat for Humanity\xa0and\xa0Save the Children.
column20: Crowdfunding site\xa0GlobalGiving\u2019s\xa0\u201cHurricane Irma Relief Fund\u201d aims to provide food
column21: water and medicine to survivors. It also plans to offer longer-term recovery assistance in helping people rebuild their communities.
column22: GoFundMe is\xa0hosting dozens of crowdfunding campaigns\xa0that have been launched by individuals hit by the storm
column23: or by those who want to help.
column24: With Irma expected to displace thousands of pets
column25: the ASPCA Field Investigation and Response Fund
column26: \xa0Best Friends Animal Society\xa0and The Humane Society of the United States\xa0are seeking donations to boost animal rescue efforts.\xa0
column27: Feeding Florida is working with the state\u2019s food banks to make sure people in need are kept fed and hydrated.
column28: Donors Choose\xa0has launched a recovery fund to help teachers in Florida and other parts of the southeastern U.S. rebuild their classrooms and replace supplies.
column29: Blood centers in Florida anticipate a shortage in supply
column30: as their counterparts did in Texas following Hurricane Harvey.
column31: Search online for blood drives local to you via the Red Cross website\xa0to book an appointment
column32: or visit the LifeSouth website if you are in Florida.
column33: Airbnb is seeking homeowners in Florida and northern Georgia who are willing to open their homes for free to people who have been displaced by the hurricane and for relief workers who are deployed to help.

column1: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/fires-in-the-west-hurricanes-down-south_us_59b2db6fe4b0dfaafcf7dccc?ncid=fcbklnkushpmg00000013&utm_campaign=hp_fb_pages&utm_source=politics_fb&utm_medium=facebook&section=politics|<h1 class="headline__title">While Hurricanes Batter The South
column2:
The West Is On Fire|[

While the South drowns amid a succession of unprecedented and record-shattering hurricanes
column3: the West is burning.\xa0
column4: Some 172 fires are burning across the region
column5: 78 of which the National Interagency Fire Center considers \u201clarge\u201d incidents of greater than 100 forested acres or 300 grassland acres.
column6: So far this year
column7: more than 8 million acres have burned
column8: scarring and scorching western Montana and the Pacific Northwest
column9: and smothering cities as far away as Denver\xa0in thick smoke.
column10: That\u2019s nearly twice the 10-year average of 5.5 million acres
column11: and it\u2019s taking its toll everywhere
column12: including on state budgets.\xa0
column13: Nine firefighters have died since the beginning of 2017 (two of them in training) and another 35 were injured
column14: reports the Associated Press. Upwards of 26
column15: 000 are currently deployed across the West fighting the blazes.
column16: \u201cIt has been a long and challenging fire season in Montana
column17: \u201d the state\u2019s Gov. Steve Bullock told the Helena Independent Record Thursday. \u201cWe\u2019ve had losses to homes
column18: livestock
column19: forage and infrastructure
column20: and we\u2019ve tragically lost the lives of two wildland firefighters.\u201d
column21: Montana has already spent $53.7 million fighting the wildfires
column22: far exceeding the $32.5 million it had set aside\xa0this year for the purpose. Lower than expected state revenues forced the state to cut its fire fund in half in April.
column23: Oregon
column24: too
column25: has been hit especially bad. More than a dozen large fires are ravaging the state
column26: including the Eagle Creek Fire
column27: which has ignited tens of thousands of acres of Oregon\u2019s iconic Columbia River Gorge:
column28: Despite a handful of devastating fires in the state of Washington
column29: some adventurous golfers in North Bonneville still made their tee time earlier this week
column30: resulting in a viral image of stark contrasts.
column31: And in California
column32: home to at least a dozen more blazes
column33: firefighters have finally got a handle on the more than 7
column34: 000-acre La Tuna fire
column35: the largest in the history of Los Angeles:
column36: Couldn't sleep and decided to leave my house to document this fire. Let this be a lesson not to mess with Mother Nature. #LaTunaFire pic.twitter.com/ibCqwPn5Cp
column37: On Thursday
column38: a bipartisan coalition of U.S. senators representing nine Western states sent a letter to Senate leaders Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) and Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.)
column39: urging them to include a wildfire funding fix in any disaster aid packages for hurricanes Harvey and Irma.
column40: At present
column41: underfunded federal agencies have to take funds from fire prevention measures to actively fight fires
column42: the senators noted. So far this year
column43: the U.S. Forest Service has already spent more than $1.7 billion to that end.
column44: \u201cWe stand ready to work with our colleagues in a bipartisan way in Congress to do everything we can to ensure the victims of Hurricane Harvey get the assistance they need
column45: \u201d\xa0the senators wrote.\xa0\u201cAs we work to assist Texas and Louisiana on the road to recovery
column46:
please do not forget about wildfires \u2013 the natural disaster currently raging through the West.\u201d

]

U.S. Military Begins Evacuations From St. Martin After Irma Destruction

Americans were desperate to leave the island of St. Martin in the wake of the devastation caused by Hurricane Irma.

column4: a spokesperson told HuffPost on Saturday. But nearly 5

column13: \u201d\xa0Tiffany Bunker told CBS New York.

\u201d Woolfall tweeted to HuffPost. \u201cBut people of St Maarten desperately need help. It\u2019s like a war zone.\u201d\xa0

column1: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/across-florida-schools-transform-into-shelters-to-save-those-in-hurricane-irmas-crosshairs_us_59b44276e4b0354e441237ff?ncid=fcbklnkushpmg00000013&utm_campaign=hp_fb_pages&utm_source=politics_fb&utm_medium=facebook&section=politics|<h1 class="headline__title">Across Florida
column2:
Schools Transform Into Shelters To Save Those In Hurricane Irma’s Crosshairs|[

MIRAMAR
column3: Fla. \u2015 A makeshift sign hanging from a fence outside of New Renaissance Middle School warned residents seeking last minute shelter from Hurricane Irma that the school\u2019s gym had reached its capacity and couldn\u2019t accept any more people.
column4: Outside

column7: Hurricane Irma
column8: one of the most powerful storms to ever form in the Atlantic Ocean
column9: is expected to make landfall somewhere in southern Florida early Sunday morning. And in the hours and days before it does

column12: \u201cYesterday we had a busy day getting everyone in
column13: but we got everyone in safe and secure
column14: \u201d said Mark Norville
column15: the school\u2019s head of facility services. \u201cOrganizing
column16: putting them into place
column17: getting everybody into a comfortable spot. We wanted to make sure everyone who got in was comfortable
column18: and we were able to reach that goal.\u201d
column19: New Renaissance is one of 21 schools in Broward County
column20: which sits just north of Miami and includes coastal towns like Fort Lauderdale
column21: that is now serving as a shelter. To the south
column22: Miami-Dade County\xa0opened 42 schools to shelter vulnerable residents who couldn\u2019t evacuate before the storm.

column27: Not everything has gone according to plan. In certain locations in Miami-Dade County on Friday

column29: and others that had been announced as open weren\u2019t quite ready yet.
column30: But at New Renaissance
column31: the process has been smooth so far

column33: \u201cEverybody is compliant
column34: to say the least
column35: \u201d Scott said as she stood outside the shelter. \u201cThey\u2019re not happy
column36: but they are following the rules.\u201d
column37: Florida Gov. Rick Scott (R) and local officials have ordered more than 6 million Florida residents \u2015 including at least 650
column38: 000 who live in Miami-Dade County \u2015 to evacuate their homes ahead of Irma
column39: which could smash the state with winds in excess of 130 miles per hour. Storm surges could send 2- to 4-foot walls of seawater into coastal towns
column40: and Broward County officials said they expect 10 to 20 inches of rain.
column41: That threat has made the schools-turned shelters a vital resource for many Floridians who couldn\u2019t afford to evacuate the state or didn\u2019t get out in time
column42: and they are a sign of how well state and local authorities have prepared for the storm
column43: Pauletta Scott said.
column44: As a Red Cross volunteer
column45: Pauletta Scott has worked through Hurricane Katrina in New Orleans and Hurricane Sandy in New York. Compared to those storms
column46: Scott said
column47: Florida is an \u201cA1 prototype\u201d for how to prepare for a potentially catastrophic storm.
column48: Still
column49: it\u2019s been a trying few days for volunteers and those seeking shelter alike. Since doors across the state opened Thursday
column50: thousands of people seeking refuge have swarmed shelters seeking help. Broward County had served 16
column51: 000 people as of Friday night

column53: 000 residents.

column57: but Red Cross volunteers have tried to direct those in need to other areas that still have room.\xa0

column59: we do it lovingly
column60: we do it with empathy
column61: \u201d Scott said. \u201cWe don\u2019t turn them away until we have to.\u201d

column64: \u201cIf I could take you in

dumping rain onto the shelter below. It was time to go back inside.

Hurricane Irma is so powerful that it has temporarily sucked the ocean away from beaches in Florida and the Bahamas in recent days.\xa0

column3: one of multiple people to share videos of the strange scene

column6: Bahamas.

column13: Florida

column17: Angela Fritz
column18: deputy weather editor of The Washington Post
column19: confirmed this phenomenon is real and may occur during extremely powerful hurricanes such as Irma. The storm is so powerful that it can essentially change the shape of the ocean\xa0for a time
column20: Fritz wrote.
column21: \u201cBasically
column22: Hurricane Irma is so strong and its pressure is so low
column23: it\u2019s sucking water from its surroundings into the core of the storm
column24: \u201d Fritz wrote.
column25: \u201cIn the center of the storm
column26: where there is extreme low pressure
column27: water is drawn upward. Low pressure is basically a sucking mechanism \u2014 it sucks the air into it
column28: and when it\u2019s really low
column29: it can change the shape of the surface of the ocean. As the storm draws water toward the center
column30: it gets pulled away from the surroundings.\u201d

column32: a forecaster with the Bahamas\u2019 Department of Meteorology
column33: warned residents of Long Island and Exuma
column34: where water had also reportedly receded from the beaches

column36: \u201cCare must be taken in this case because the water often returns with even greater fury

column38: People who had seen the water recede in the Bahamas on Friday said the water returned the next day.

column1: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/hurricane-irma-records-broken_us_59b48a93e4b0dfaafcf84e6a?ncid=fcbklnkushpmg00000013&utm_campaign=hp_fb_pages&utm_source=politics_fb&utm_medium=facebook&section=politics|<h1 class="headline__title">Here Are All The Records Irma Has Broken So Far
column2:
According To A Meteorologist|[

After a week of destruction in the Caribbean
column3: it was clear that Hurricane Irma was one for the books.
column4: Phil Klotzbach
column5: a meteorologist for Colorado State University
column6: has been tracking the relentless storm over the past week
column7: taking note of all the records it has broken so far.
column8: \u201cIt\u2019s definitely an impressive storm
column9: \u201d Klotzbach told HuffPost. \u201cIt\u2019s one of the heavy hitters in at least in the last 50 years or so.\u201d
column10: The Atlantic has already generated enough Accumulated Cyclone Energy to meet the NOAA ACE definition of an above-average season. #Irma #Jose pic.twitter.com/ZmRRZspUCh
column11: Klotzbach on Saturday evening predicted that Irma would go down as the second strongest storm in recorded history in terms of accumulated cyclone energy
column12: falling short of 2004\u2032s Hurricane Ivan
column13: which battered the Gulf Coast and left 20 dead.
column14: Below are the records Hurricane Irma has already broken as of Sunday morning
column15: as recorded by Klotzbach:
column16: It\u2019s the \u201clongest any cyclone around the globe has mantained that intensity on record
column17: \u201d Klotzbach writes. \u201cThe previous record was [Typhoon] Haiyan in the [Northwest]\xa0Pacific at 24 hours.\u201d
column18: #Irma had winds of 185 mph for 37 hr
column19: the longest a TC was that strong anywhere around globe in satellite era (since 1966). Irma now 175 mph pic.twitter.com/VkLaakwmhN
column20: Hurricane Irma has had a maximum wind speed of 185 miles per hour in its lifetime
column21: making this the first time for a storm like this to exist in the Atlantic. The warmer waters in the Caribbean Sea and the Gulf of Mexico make those areas more prone to cyclones.
column22: An infamously powerful and unnamed hurricane hit Cuba in 1932
column23: forcing 1 million people to evacuate from low-lying areas in central Cuban provinces. Irma tied with this hurricane for longest time spent in Category 5 strength.
column24: To determine the strength of a storm
column25: scientists measure the storm\u2019s barometric pressure using millibars. The lower the pressure the storm has
column26: the stronger the storm tends to be. Hurricane Irma had 915 millibars
column27: making it the lowest pressure of an Atlantic hurricane outside of the western Caribbean and Gulf of Mexico in recorded history.
column28: Table of all U.S. landfalling hurricanes on record with pressure <933 mb - #Irma's current pressure. All these storms were devastating. pic.twitter.com/zBwp8UhDpG
column29: On Saturday
column30: Hurricanes Irma and Jose swirled through the Atlantic at the same time with winds of 150 miles per hour
column31: according to Klotzbach.\xa0
column32: 2 Atlantic hurricanes currently have winds of 150 mph (#Irma and #Jose) - 1st time on record Atlantic has had 2 150+ mph storms at same time pic.twitter.com/SZm1VMTCOs
column33: As of early Sunday
column34: Hurricane Irma has clocked in 10.75 hurricane days
column35: making it the most hurricane days of a tropical cyclone since 2008\u2032s Hurricane Ike
column36: which accrued 10 days.
column37: Accumulated Cyclone Energy (ACE) is another way that scientists measure a hurricane season using the combined wind energy a storm produces during a set time period. According to Wunderground
column38: ACE is \u201cused to express the activity and destructive potential of individual tropical cyclones and entire tropical cyclone seasons.\u201d
column39: This breaks the old record set by Hurricane Allen in 1980.
column40: #Irma has just set the Atlantic record for Accumulated Cyclone Energy generated in a 24-hr period
column41: breaking old record set by Allen (1980). pic.twitter.com/E8wForI0o1
column42: Klotzbach noted that
column43: at Category 5 strength
column44: Hurricane Irma was the strongest storm on record to impact the Leeward Islands with maximum sustained winds of up to 185 miles per hour. Before Irma
column45: the Okeechobee Hurricane (in 1928) and Hurricane David (1979) were the strongest to hit the area with winds of 160 miles per hour.
column46: Irma was the closest a Category 5 hurricane ever came to the Turks and Caicos islands.

column24: bobcats
column25: goats
column26: \xa0birds

column38: however

WASHINGTON \u2015 Federally insured property in Florida is in the crosshairs of potentially catastrophic Hurricane Irma \u2015 including President Donald Trump\u2019s Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach.
column2: The property has a flood insurance policy through the National Flood Insurance Program
column3: a Federal Emergency Management Agency spokesperson\xa0told HuffPost. The program\xa0provides affordable insurance in flood-prone zones where private insurers have traditionally refused to insure properties because they\u2019re so vulnerable.
column4: The Mar-a-Lago club\u2019s policy
column5: which is insured to the Trump Organization and Donald J. Trump Revocable Trust
column6: is not subsidized and is classified at a full-risk rate for the applicable flood zone
column7: the FEMA spokesperson said.\xa0
column8: A property covered at the \u201cfull-risk\u201d rate means that its owner is paying a rate that reflects\xa0the full risk of flooding\xa0up to a certain coverage amount. Older properties can be \u201csubsidized
column9: \u201d meaning their rates do not necessarily reflect the full risk for those properties. The 1968-era National Flood Insurance Program
column10: or NFIP
column11: offers a mix of rates.\xa0
column12: The insurance program\u2019s\xa0authorization was set to expire at the end of this month
column13: but Trump\xa0signed legislation on Friday that temporarily extends it.
column14: NFIP as a whole has been criticized for not charging enough to cover the\xa0expected costs of liabilities. It also\xa0consistently does not bring in enough money to pay out the properties it insures
column15: and owes around $25 billion to the U.S. Treasury. Based on policies that went into effect on Aug.\xa031
column17: the program is projected to have a one-year shortfall of $1.4 billion
column18: according to a Congressional Budget Office report published this month.
column19: Some critics say the program\xa0benefits affluent people who live on beachfront property

column22: they would have been in receivership
column23: \u201d Burl Daniel
column24: an insurance expert witness from Texas
column25: told HuffPost. \u201cBut it\u2019s a political football because of the people who live on the coast.\u201d
column26: \u201cThe program was already in trouble\u201d before Hurricanes Harvey and Irma began approaching the U.S.
column27: said Karen O\u2019Neill
column28: an associate professor at Rutgers University who studies how policies about land and water affect government power.
column29: \u201cIt became super in trouble after Katrina
column30: and Sandy was another blow
column31: \u201d O\u2019Neill said.\xa0
column32: Mar-a-Lago
column33: Trump International Golf Club in Palm Beach and Trump National Golf Club in Jupiter are all closed in advance of Irma
column34: a Trump Organization spokesperson said. (She did not respond to the question about insurance.) Irma
column35: one of the largest storms ever recorded

column39: but said he pocketed some of the money instead of using it to rebuild. Trump once boasted in a deposition that he had a \u201cvery good insurance policy

column44: could see its main buildings damaged by an 8-foot storm surge
column45: according to the AP. Thirty years from now
column46: the property could be under at least a foot of water for most of the year
column47: according to a risk analysis prepared for the Guardian.
column48: A group of Democratic lawmakers introduced a bill in June\xa0that specifically aimed to block Trump properties from receiving any federal subsidy for flood insurance coverage. The name of the bill \u2015 the\xa0Prohibiting Aid for Recipients Ignoring Science
column49: or Paris
column50: Act \u2015\xa0riffs off the Paris climate accord
column51: an agreement from which Trump withdrew that same month.
column52: As FEMA noted
column53: \xa0the NFIP policy for Mar-a-Lago isn\u2019t explicitly subsidized. (HuffPost did not ask the agency about policy details for other Trump-owned properties in Florida.) But Democrats say the Paris Act
column54: which is not expected to pass anytime soon
column55: is about the larger principle.

column57: who is undercutting our ability to minimize the effects

column60: who introduced the House bill.

and we need to put in place programs to try and minimize damage.\u201d

Key Obamacare Architect Who Shunned Single-Payer Now Backs It

|[

Former Sen. Max Baucus (D-Mont.)
column2: a fiscal moderate who
column3: as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee
column4: presided over the passage of the Affordable Care Act
column5: expressed his support on Thursday for the creation of a single-payer health care system.
column6: \u201cMy personal view is we\u2019ve got to start looking at single-payer
column7: \u201d Baucus said in remarks at Montana State University
column8: according to the\xa0Bozeman Daily Chronicle. \u201cI think we should have hearings... We\u2019re getting there. It\u2019s going to happen.\u201d
column9: Single-payer health care
column10: in which the federal government insures all citizens through one large program
column11: is a model for universal coverage in many developed countries
column12: including Canada
column13: France and Australia. But it has long been viewed as a pipe dream in the United States
column14: where a <a href="http://www.kff.org/other/state-indicator/total-population/?currentTimeframe=0&sortModel=%7B%22colId%22:%22Location%22
column15: %22sort%22:%22asc%22%7D" target="_blank">plurality of people receive coverage from their employers.
column16: Baucus\u2019 endorsement of the idea speaks to just how dramatically the health policy debate has shifted within the Democratic Party in recent years \u2015 particularly since the 2016 presidential run of Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.)
column17: who made what he called \u201cMedicare for all\u201d a central issue of his campaign.
column18: Baucus was the subject of progressive frustration for his stewardship of the ACA
column19: also known as Obamacare. Critics argued that he held the bill in committee far too long in hopes of winning the support of moderate Republicans who did not end up voting for the final bill. The lengthy negotiation period he initiated gave Republicans much-needed time to mobilize opposition to reform
column20: according to Baucus\u2019 detractors.
column21: Obamacare itself relies on a hybrid model
column22: once favored by conservative policy experts
column23: that combines the creation of a new private
column24: individual insurance marketplace and an expansion of Medicaid.
column25: Given Baucus\u2019 history as a fiscal moderate active in the ACA\u2019s passage
column26: his positive remarks about single-payer could provide a boost to progressive activists agitating for its implementation.
column27: As Senate Finance Committee chairman
column28: Baucus ruled out consideration of single-payer from the beginning
column29: and declined to invite the testimony of single-payer advocates at hearings. The latter decision prompted disruptive protests from activists
column30: and Baucus later said that\xa0he regretted not engaging more with the policy\u2019s proponents.
column31: In September 2009
column32: Baucus also voted against two amendments that would have created a public health insurance option on the Obamacare individual insurance exchanges.
column33: Baucus kept single-payer off the table during the development of Obamacare because he believed the country was not ready for it at the time
column34: he told NBC News on Friday.\xa0
column35: \u201cI just think the time has come
column36: \u201d Baucus said. \u201cBack in \u201909
column37: we were not ready to address it. It would never have passed. Here we are nine years later
column38: I think it\u2019s time to hopefully have a very serious good faith look at it.\u201d
column39: Sen. Jon Tester\xa0(D-Mont.)
column40: a moderate who represented Montana alongside Baucus from 2007 to 2014
column41: also expressed openness to single-payer this week.
column42: \u201cMaybe it\u2019s something we should
column43: quite frankly
column44: take a solid look at
column45: \u201d Tester said Wednesday.
column46: Tester does not support single-payer legislation
column47: however. When Sen. Steve Daines (R-Mont.)
column48: aiming to put Democrats in an awkward political position
column49: introduced a trick amendment creating a single-payer system to the Obamacare repeal bill
column50: most Democratic senators voted \u201cpresent\u201d on the motion
column51: but Tester was one of four Democratic senators to vote \u201cno\u201d\xa0on it.
column52: Former Sen. Kent Conrad (D-N.D.) \u2015 a moderate who vehemently opposed creating a public health insurance option during the passage of Obamacare \u2015 told HuffPost that unlike Baucus
column53: he believes it is \u201cunlikely we will get a single-payer system in the foreseeable future.\u201d
column54: Single-payer is improbable
column55: Conrad argued
column56: because funding a federal health insurance program would cost taxpayers so much and because medical providers are so opposed to radically transforming the system.\xa0
column57: Instead
column58: he said
column59: the \u201cbest system combines universal coverage with private not-for-profit insurance with the government assisting those who cannot afford insurance.\u201d
column60: He also favors empowering Medicare to negotiate bulk discounts on prescription drugs
column61: just as the Veterans Affairs health care system does.
column62: In addition to Sanders\u2019 presidential run
column63: the collapse of Republican efforts to repeal Obamacare has increased grassroots energy behind single-payer as activists seek to go on the offensive. Progressive pressure groups like Credo have launched efforts to make support for the policy a litmus test for 2020\u2032s Democratic presidential candidates.
column64: Single-payer now has more support in Congress than at any other time in recent history. Single-payer legislation introduced by Rep. John Conyers (D-Mich.) has more co-sponsors than ever
column65: with the support of a majority of the House Democratic Caucus.
column66: Sanders plans to unveil a much-anticipated version of single-payer legislation next Wednesday. Sens. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.)
column67: a rumored 2020 presidential contender
column68: and Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) have already announced plans to co-sponsor the bill.
column69: Polling suggests that the idea of single-payer is popular with the public
column70: especially among Democrats. In a May 2016 Gallup poll
column71: 58 percent of Americans and 73 percent of Democrats said they supported replacing \u201cthe ACA with a federally funded healthcare program providing insurance for all Americans.\u201d\xa0
column72: Even elected Democrats who remain wary of single-payer have begun trying to capitalize on the ambitious proposal\u2019s popularity. The Congressional Hispanic Caucus\u2019 political action committee
column73: Bold PAC
column74: has repeatedly alluded to the \u201cMedicare for all\u201d fight in fundraising e-mails \u2015 even though half of the 30 CHC members have yet to actually endorse single-payer
column75: and the PAC does not make support for the policy a condition for its financial support.
column76: Of course
column77: \xa0it is much easier to talk about single-payer than to actually implement it. Replacing the current system with one large federal program would require a massive tax increase in exchange for what advocates believe would result in net cost reductions thanks to the government\u2019s considerable bargaining power.
column78: It would also force the nearly half of Americans who get insurance from their jobs to enroll in a new government program. Given the outcry that Obamacare elicited for canceling the plans of a fraction of that number of people
column79: enacting single-payer would likely prove an extraordinary political challenge.
column80: In the meantime
column82: the excitement around single-payer has already widened the spectrum of acceptable debate about health care.\xa0Expansions of coverage that once seemed radical now seem downright moderate by comparison. In August
column83: Sen. Brian Schatz (D-Hawaii) announced plans to introduce legislation allowing Americans of all ages and incomes to buy into Medicaid. And earlier this week
column84: Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) revealed his intention to introduce a bill creating a comparable universal buy-in option for Medicare
column85: which he said\xa0\u201cmay be the fastest way to a single-payer system.\u201d
column86: This article has been updated with comments from Tester and Conrad
column87:
as well as additional comments from Baucus.

]
