Mar-A-Lago Has A Flood Insurance Policy Through The Federal Government

|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 Federally insured property in Florida is in the crosshairs of potentially catastrophic Hurricane Irma \u2015 including President Donald Trump\u2019s Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach.
column2: The property has a flood insurance policy through the National Flood Insurance Program
column3: a Federal Emergency Management Agency spokesperson\xa0told HuffPost. The program\xa0provides affordable insurance in flood-prone zones where private insurers have traditionally refused to insure properties because they\u2019re so vulnerable.
column4: The Mar-a-Lago club\u2019s policy
column5: which is insured to the Trump Organization and Donald J. Trump Revocable Trust
column6: is not subsidized and is classified at a full-risk rate for the applicable flood zone
column7: the FEMA spokesperson said.\xa0
column8: A property covered at the \u201cfull-risk\u201d rate means that its owner is paying a rate that reflects\xa0the full risk of flooding\xa0up to a certain coverage amount. Older properties can be \u201csubsidized
column9: \u201d meaning their rates do not necessarily reflect the full risk for those properties. The 1968-era National Flood Insurance Program
column10: or NFIP
column11: offers a mix of rates.\xa0
column12: The insurance program\u2019s\xa0authorization was set to expire at the end of this month
column13: but Trump\xa0signed legislation on Friday that temporarily extends it.
column14: NFIP as a whole has been criticized for not charging enough to cover the\xa0expected costs of liabilities. It also\xa0consistently does not bring in enough money to pay out the properties it insures
column15: and owes around $25 billion to the U.S. Treasury. Based on policies that went into effect on Aug.\xa031
column17: the program is projected to have a one-year shortfall of $1.4 billion
column18: according to a Congressional Budget Office report published this month.
column19: Some critics say the program\xa0benefits affluent people who live on beachfront property
column20: essentially allowing them to live in places that are at a high risk of being damaged.
column21: \u201cIf [NFIP] was a regular insurance company
column22: they would have been in receivership
column23: \u201d Burl Daniel
column24: an insurance expert witness from Texas
column25: told HuffPost. \u201cBut it\u2019s a political football because of the people who live on the coast.\u201d
column26: \u201cThe program was already in trouble\u201d before Hurricanes Harvey and Irma began approaching the U.S.
column27: said Karen O\u2019Neill
column28: an associate professor at Rutgers University who studies how policies about land and water affect government power.
column29: \u201cIt became super in trouble after Katrina
column30: and Sandy was another blow
column31: \u201d O\u2019Neill said.\xa0
column32: Mar-a-Lago
column33: Trump International Golf Club in Palm Beach and Trump National Golf Club in Jupiter are all closed in advance of Irma
column34: a Trump Organization spokesperson said. (She did not respond to the question about insurance.) Irma
column35: one of the largest storms ever recorded
column36: is expected to hit Florida this weekend.
column37: Mar-a-Lago has weathered hurricanes before. According to an\xa0Associated Press investigation
column38: \xa0Trump claimed that he received a $17 million insurance payout for the estate in 2005 due to damage from a series of storms
column39: but said he pocketed some of the money instead of using it to rebuild. Trump once boasted in a deposition that he had a \u201cvery good insurance policy
column40: \u201d apparently in reference to private insurance. (The FEMA spokesperson declined to comment on whether Mar-a-Lago was also insured by NFIP at the time
column41: as that is \u201cnot publicly available information.\u201d)
column42: Mar-a-Lago
column43: which Trump bought for $10 million in 1985
column44: could see its main buildings damaged by an 8-foot storm surge
column45: according to the AP. Thirty years from now
column46: the property could be under at least a foot of water for most of the year
column47: according to a risk analysis prepared for the Guardian.
column48: A group of Democratic lawmakers introduced a bill in June\xa0that specifically aimed to block Trump properties from receiving any federal subsidy for flood insurance coverage. The name of the bill \u2015 the\xa0Prohibiting Aid for Recipients Ignoring Science
column49: or Paris
column50: Act \u2015\xa0riffs off the Paris climate accord
column51: an agreement from which Trump withdrew that same month.
column52: As FEMA noted
column53: \xa0the NFIP policy for Mar-a-Lago isn\u2019t explicitly subsidized. (HuffPost did not ask the agency about policy details for other Trump-owned properties in Florida.) But Democrats say the Paris Act
column54: which is not expected to pass anytime soon
column55: is about the larger principle.
column56: \u201cIt would be outrageous for somebody who is denying the reality of climate
column57: who is undercutting our ability to minimize the effects
column58: to then turn around and be a recipient of federal largess
column59: \u201d said Rep. Earl Blumenauer (D-Ore.)
column60: who introduced the House bill.
column61: \u201cWe need to stop building in places where nature shows repeatedly that they\u2019re not wanted
column62: \u201d he added. \u201cWe need to stop making it worse
column63:
and we need to put in place programs to try and minimize damage.\u201d

]

column6: The company offered those affected by the hack a free one-year subscription to its credit-monitoring service TrustedID Premier.\xa0Those who opt to use Equifax\u2019s free service will be charged after a year if they do not actively cancel their subscriptions.

column12: because you read the ToS

North Korea Holds Huge Celebration For Its Nuclear Scientists

|[

SEOUL
column2: Sept 10 (Reuters) - North Korean leader Kim Jong Un hosted a massive celebration to congratulate his nuclear scientists and technicians who steered the country\u2019s sixth and largest nuclear test a week ago
column3: its official news agency said on Sunday.
column4: The United States and its allies had been bracing for another long-range missile launch in time for the 69th anniversary of North Korea\u2019s founding on Saturday
column5: but no fresh provocations were spotted while the North held numerous events to mark the holiday.
column6: Throughout last week
column7: South Korean officials had warned the North could launch another intercontinental ballistic missile in defiance of U.N. sanctions and amid an escalating standoff with the United States.
column8: Washington told the U.N. Security Council on Friday to call a meeting on Monday to vote on a draft resolution establishing additional sanctions on North Korea for its missile and nuclear program.
column9: Japanese Defence Minister Itsunori Onodera said it was vital to put pressure on North Korea through additional sactions
column10: including blocking or slowing its fuel supplies.
column11: \u201cIf we put firm pressure on North Korea such that it realizes it cannot develop missiles
column12: it will accept dialog and we can progress with diplomatic efforts
column13: \u201d Onodera told public broadcaster NHK on Sunday. \u201cUnless we firmly apply pressure
column14: North Korea will not change its direction.\u201d
column15: KCNA said Kim threw a banquet to laud the nuclear scientists and other top military and party officials who contributed to the nuclear bomb test last Sunday
column16: topped with an art performance and a photo session with the leader himself.
column17: KCNA did not specify when the banquet had been held
column18: but analysts said it had likely been on Saturday.
column19: Photos released on Sunday by KCNA showed the young leader breaking into a broad smile at the People\u2019s Theatre with two prominent scientists: Ri Hong Sop
column20: head of North Korea\u2019s Nuclear Weapons Institute
column21: and Hong Sung Mu
column22: deputy director of the ruling Workers\u2019 Party of Korea\u2019s munitions industry department.
column23: Ri and Hong have played vital roles in the North\u2019s nuclear program
column24: appearing at close distance to Kim during field inspections and weapons tests
column25: including the latest nuclear test. Ri is a former director of Yongbyon Nuclear Research Centre
column26: North Korea\u2019s main nuclear facility north of Pyongyang
column27: where Hong also worked as a chief engineer.
column28: North Korea had said the latest test was an advanced hydrogen bomb. There was no independent confirmation but some Western experts said there was enough strong evidence to suggest the reclusive state has either developed a hydrogen bomb or was getting very close.
column29: KCNA said on Sunday the scientists and technicians \u201cbrought the great auspicious event of the national history
column30: an extra-large event through the perfect success in the test of H-bomb.\u201d
column31: Kim praised the developers in his own remarks as \u201ctaking the lead\u201d in attaining the \u201cfinal goal of completing the state nuclear force\u201d in line with his parallel pursuit of nuclear and economic development.
column32: \u201cThe recent test of the H-bomb is the great victory won by the Korean people at the cost of their blood while tightening their belts in the arduous period
column33: \u201d Kim was quoted as saying.
column34: Ri and Hong\u2019s roles have also been noted overseas
column35: prompting the United Nations
column36: the United States or South Korea to blacklist them.
column37: Aside from the elite
column38: rank-and-file North Koreans also commemorated the anniversary on Saturday by visiting the Kumsusan Palace of the Sun
column39: which houses the embalmed bodies of founding father Kim Il Sung and his son and successor Kim Jong Il.
column40: KCNA said service personnel and civilians
column41: including children
column42: laid floral baskets and bouquets at the statues of the deceased leaders across the country
column43:
while enjoying art performances and dancing parties. (Reporting by Hyonhee Shin and Christine Kim; Editing by Kim Coghill and Raju Gopalakrishnan)

so we all know what\u2019s going on.\xa0Tell us your story.

The West Is On Fire|[

While the South drowns amid a succession of unprecedented and record-shattering hurricanes

column4: Some 172 fires are burning across the region
column5: 78 of which the National Interagency Fire Center considers \u201clarge\u201d incidents of greater than 100 forested acres or 300 grassland acres.
column6: So far this year
column7: more than 8 million acres have burned
column8: scarring and scorching western Montana and the Pacific Northwest
column9: and smothering cities as far away as Denver\xa0in thick smoke.

column12: including on state budgets.\xa0
column13: Nine firefighters have died since the beginning of 2017 (two of them in training) and another 35 were injured
column14: reports the Associated Press. Upwards of 26
column15: 000 are currently deployed across the West fighting the blazes.
column16: \u201cIt has been a long and challenging fire season in Montana
column17: \u201d the state\u2019s Gov. Steve Bullock told the Helena Independent Record Thursday. \u201cWe\u2019ve had losses to homes
column18: livestock
column19: forage and infrastructure

column22: far exceeding the $32.5 million it had set aside\xa0this year for the purpose. Lower than expected state revenues forced the state to cut its fire fund in half in April.
column23: Oregon
column24: too
column25: has been hit especially bad. More than a dozen large fires are ravaging the state
column26: including the Eagle Creek Fire
column27: which has ignited tens of thousands of acres of Oregon\u2019s iconic Columbia River Gorge:
column28: Despite a handful of devastating fires in the state of Washington

column30: resulting in a viral image of stark contrasts.
column31: And in California
column32: home to at least a dozen more blazes
column33: firefighters have finally got a handle on the more than 7
column34: 000-acre La Tuna fire
column35: the largest in the history of Los Angeles:
column36: Couldn't sleep and decided to leave my house to document this fire. Let this be a lesson not to mess with Mother Nature. #LaTunaFire pic.twitter.com/ibCqwPn5Cp
column37: On Thursday
column38: a bipartisan coalition of U.S. senators representing nine Western states sent a letter to Senate leaders Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) and Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.)
column39: urging them to include a wildfire funding fix in any disaster aid packages for hurricanes Harvey and Irma.

column45: \u201d\xa0the senators wrote.\xa0\u201cAs we work to assist Texas and Louisiana on the road to recovery

please do not forget about wildfires \u2013 the natural disaster currently raging through the West.\u201d

Hurricane Irma is so powerful that it has temporarily sucked the ocean away from beaches in Florida and the Bahamas in recent days.\xa0
column2: Twitter user @Piznack
column3: one of multiple people to share videos of the strange scene
column4: tweeted on Saturday: \u201cY\u2019all my family in the Bahamas said Irma sucked up all the water. There\u2019s literally no water. The beach and ocean are gone.\u201d
column5: He sent out a follow-up video that showed how the water had retreated at a beach in Long Island
column6: Bahamas.
column7: Y'all my family in the Bahamas said Irma sucked up all the water. There's literally no water. The beach and ocean are gone\U0001f633
column8: Long Island
column9: Bahamas: Where's the ocean? pic.twitter.com/YCmWzUVBKI
column10: On Sunday
column11: the National Weather Service confirmed the phenomenon was also occurring in Naples
column12: Florida. A public information coordinator for Clearwater
column13: Florida
column14: shared videos of the \u201cnegative surge\u201d in Tampa Bay.\xa0
column15: 12:00 PM: Negative surge ~3.5 FT at #Naples to become 10-15 FT above ground as #Irma moves in. Life-threatening rapid water rise imminent! pic.twitter.com/pbh76VXlqn
column16: Creepy site - water in Tampa Bay is already being sucked out. This is view from downtown St. Pete waterfront. #HurricaneIrma pic.twitter.com/4hqRDSrDsh
column17: Angela Fritz
column18: deputy weather editor of The Washington Post
column19: confirmed this phenomenon is real and may occur during extremely powerful hurricanes such as Irma. The storm is so powerful that it can essentially change the shape of the ocean\xa0for a time
column20: Fritz wrote.
column21: \u201cBasically
column22: Hurricane Irma is so strong and its pressure is so low
column23: it\u2019s sucking water from its surroundings into the core of the storm
column24: \u201d Fritz wrote.
column25: \u201cIn the center of the storm
column26: where there is extreme low pressure
column27: water is drawn upward. Low pressure is basically a sucking mechanism \u2014 it sucks the air into it
column28: and when it\u2019s really low
column29: it can change the shape of the surface of the ocean. As the storm draws water toward the center
column30: it gets pulled away from the surroundings.\u201d
column31: Wayne Neely
column32: a forecaster with the Bahamas\u2019 Department of Meteorology
column33: warned residents of Long Island and Exuma
column34: where water had also reportedly receded from the beaches
column35: to be careful as the ocean surged back to high levels.
column36: \u201cCare must be taken in this case because the water often returns with even greater fury
column37: \u201d Neely said in a Facebook post explaining the phenomenon.
column38: People who had seen the water recede in the Bahamas on Friday said the water returned the next day.
column39: Irma ripped through the Caribbean Sea and parts of the Atlantic Ocean earlier this week\xa0and made landfall in Florida on Sunday morning. So far

column1: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/hurricane-irma-records-broken_us_59b48a93e4b0dfaafcf84e6a?ncid=fcbklnkushpmg00000013&utm_campaign=hp_fb_pages&utm_source=politics_fb&utm_medium=facebook&section=politics|<h1 class="headline__title">Here Are All The Records Irma Has Broken So Far
column2:
According To A Meteorologist|[

After a week of destruction in the Caribbean
column3: it was clear that Hurricane Irma was one for the books.
column4: Phil Klotzbach
column5: a meteorologist for Colorado State University
column6: has been tracking the relentless storm over the past week
column7: taking note of all the records it has broken so far.
column8: \u201cIt\u2019s definitely an impressive storm
column9: \u201d Klotzbach told HuffPost. \u201cIt\u2019s one of the heavy hitters in at least in the last 50 years or so.\u201d
column10: The Atlantic has already generated enough Accumulated Cyclone Energy to meet the NOAA ACE definition of an above-average season. #Irma #Jose pic.twitter.com/ZmRRZspUCh
column11: Klotzbach on Saturday evening predicted that Irma would go down as the second strongest storm in recorded history in terms of accumulated cyclone energy
column12: falling short of 2004\u2032s Hurricane Ivan
column13: which battered the Gulf Coast and left 20 dead.
column14: Below are the records Hurricane Irma has already broken as of Sunday morning
column15: as recorded by Klotzbach:
column16: It\u2019s the \u201clongest any cyclone around the globe has mantained that intensity on record
column17: \u201d Klotzbach writes. \u201cThe previous record was [Typhoon] Haiyan in the [Northwest]\xa0Pacific at 24 hours.\u201d
column18: #Irma had winds of 185 mph for 37 hr
column19: the longest a TC was that strong anywhere around globe in satellite era (since 1966). Irma now 175 mph pic.twitter.com/VkLaakwmhN
column20: Hurricane Irma has had a maximum wind speed of 185 miles per hour in its lifetime
column21: making this the first time for a storm like this to exist in the Atlantic. The warmer waters in the Caribbean Sea and the Gulf of Mexico make those areas more prone to cyclones.
column22: An infamously powerful and unnamed hurricane hit Cuba in 1932
column23: forcing 1 million people to evacuate from low-lying areas in central Cuban provinces. Irma tied with this hurricane for longest time spent in Category 5 strength.
column24: To determine the strength of a storm
column25: scientists measure the storm\u2019s barometric pressure using millibars. The lower the pressure the storm has
column26: the stronger the storm tends to be. Hurricane Irma had 915 millibars
column27: making it the lowest pressure of an Atlantic hurricane outside of the western Caribbean and Gulf of Mexico in recorded history.
column28: Table of all U.S. landfalling hurricanes on record with pressure <933 mb - #Irma's current pressure. All these storms were devastating. pic.twitter.com/zBwp8UhDpG
column29: On Saturday
column30: Hurricanes Irma and Jose swirled through the Atlantic at the same time with winds of 150 miles per hour
column31: according to Klotzbach.\xa0
column32: 2 Atlantic hurricanes currently have winds of 150 mph (#Irma and #Jose) - 1st time on record Atlantic has had 2 150+ mph storms at same time pic.twitter.com/SZm1VMTCOs
column33: As of early Sunday
column34: Hurricane Irma has clocked in 10.75 hurricane days
column35: making it the most hurricane days of a tropical cyclone since 2008\u2032s Hurricane Ike
column36: which accrued 10 days.
column37: Accumulated Cyclone Energy (ACE) is another way that scientists measure a hurricane season using the combined wind energy a storm produces during a set time period. According to Wunderground
column38: ACE is \u201cused to express the activity and destructive potential of individual tropical cyclones and entire tropical cyclone seasons.\u201d
column39: This breaks the old record set by Hurricane Allen in 1980.
column40: #Irma has just set the Atlantic record for Accumulated Cyclone Energy generated in a 24-hr period
column41: breaking old record set by Allen (1980). pic.twitter.com/E8wForI0o1
column42: Klotzbach noted that
column43: at Category 5 strength
column44: Hurricane Irma was the strongest storm on record to impact the Leeward Islands with maximum sustained winds of up to 185 miles per hour. Before Irma
column45: the Okeechobee Hurricane (in 1928) and Hurricane David (1979) were the strongest to hit the area with winds of 160 miles per hour.
column46: Irma was the closest a Category 5 hurricane ever came to the Turks and Caicos islands.

column42: \u201cMy granddaughter calls and she\u2019s panicked

column38: however

it ain\u2019t ours. Don\u2019t call us. Call the Florida Fish and Wildlife Department.\u201d

Mar-A-Lago Has A Flood Insurance Policy Through The Federal Government

|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 Federally insured property in Florida is in the crosshairs of potentially catastrophic Hurricane Irma \u2015 including President Donald Trump\u2019s Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach.
column2: The property has a flood insurance policy through the National Flood Insurance Program
column3: a Federal Emergency Management Agency spokesperson\xa0told HuffPost. The program\xa0provides affordable insurance in flood-prone zones where private insurers have traditionally refused to insure properties because they\u2019re so vulnerable.
column4: The Mar-a-Lago club\u2019s policy
column5: which is insured to the Trump Organization and Donald J. Trump Revocable Trust
column6: is not subsidized and is classified at a full-risk rate for the applicable flood zone
column7: the FEMA spokesperson said.\xa0
column8: A property covered at the \u201cfull-risk\u201d rate means that its owner is paying a rate that reflects\xa0the full risk of flooding\xa0up to a certain coverage amount. Older properties can be \u201csubsidized
column9: \u201d meaning their rates do not necessarily reflect the full risk for those properties. The 1968-era National Flood Insurance Program
column10: or NFIP
column11: offers a mix of rates.\xa0
column12: The insurance program\u2019s\xa0authorization was set to expire at the end of this month
column13: but Trump\xa0signed legislation on Friday that temporarily extends it.
column14: NFIP as a whole has been criticized for not charging enough to cover the\xa0expected costs of liabilities. It also\xa0consistently does not bring in enough money to pay out the properties it insures
column15: and owes around $25 billion to the U.S. Treasury. Based on policies that went into effect on Aug.\xa031
column17: the program is projected to have a one-year shortfall of $1.4 billion
column18: according to a Congressional Budget Office report published this month.
column19: Some critics say the program\xa0benefits affluent people who live on beachfront property
column20: essentially allowing them to live in places that are at a high risk of being damaged.
column21: \u201cIf [NFIP] was a regular insurance company
column22: they would have been in receivership
column23: \u201d Burl Daniel
column24: an insurance expert witness from Texas
column25: told HuffPost. \u201cBut it\u2019s a political football because of the people who live on the coast.\u201d
column26: \u201cThe program was already in trouble\u201d before Hurricanes Harvey and Irma began approaching the U.S.
column27: said Karen O\u2019Neill
column28: an associate professor at Rutgers University who studies how policies about land and water affect government power.
column29: \u201cIt became super in trouble after Katrina
column30: and Sandy was another blow
column31: \u201d O\u2019Neill said.\xa0
column32: Mar-a-Lago
column33: Trump International Golf Club in Palm Beach and Trump National Golf Club in Jupiter are all closed in advance of Irma
column34: a Trump Organization spokesperson said. (She did not respond to the question about insurance.) Irma
column35: one of the largest storms ever recorded
column36: is expected to hit Florida this weekend.
column37: Mar-a-Lago has weathered hurricanes before. According to an\xa0Associated Press investigation
column38: \xa0Trump claimed that he received a $17 million insurance payout for the estate in 2005 due to damage from a series of storms
column39: but said he pocketed some of the money instead of using it to rebuild. Trump once boasted in a deposition that he had a \u201cvery good insurance policy
column40: \u201d apparently in reference to private insurance. (The FEMA spokesperson declined to comment on whether Mar-a-Lago was also insured by NFIP at the time
column41: as that is \u201cnot publicly available information.\u201d)
column42: Mar-a-Lago
column43: which Trump bought for $10 million in 1985
column44: could see its main buildings damaged by an 8-foot storm surge
column45: according to the AP. Thirty years from now
column46: the property could be under at least a foot of water for most of the year
column47: according to a risk analysis prepared for the Guardian.
column48: A group of Democratic lawmakers introduced a bill in June\xa0that specifically aimed to block Trump properties from receiving any federal subsidy for flood insurance coverage. The name of the bill \u2015 the\xa0Prohibiting Aid for Recipients Ignoring Science
column49: or Paris
column50: Act \u2015\xa0riffs off the Paris climate accord
column51: an agreement from which Trump withdrew that same month.
column52: As FEMA noted
column53: \xa0the NFIP policy for Mar-a-Lago isn\u2019t explicitly subsidized. (HuffPost did not ask the agency about policy details for other Trump-owned properties in Florida.) But Democrats say the Paris Act
column54: which is not expected to pass anytime soon
column55: is about the larger principle.
column56: \u201cIt would be outrageous for somebody who is denying the reality of climate
column57: who is undercutting our ability to minimize the effects
column58: to then turn around and be a recipient of federal largess
column59: \u201d said Rep. Earl Blumenauer (D-Ore.)
column60: who introduced the House bill.
column61: \u201cWe need to stop building in places where nature shows repeatedly that they\u2019re not wanted
column62: \u201d he added. \u201cWe need to stop making it worse
column63:
and we need to put in place programs to try and minimize damage.\u201d

]

Democrats Target One Of Their Own For Remaining On Trump Voter Fraud Panel

|[

New Hampshire Secretary of State Bill Gardner (D) faced calls from fellow Democrats this week to step down from the Presidential Advisory Commission on Election Integrity after Kansas Secretary of State Kris Kobach (R) wrote an extremely misleading op-ed\xa0on Thursday claiming to have evidence of widespread voter fraud in New Hampshire.
column2: Both of the state\u2019s Democratic senators
column3: Maggie Hassan and Jeanne Shaheen
column4: urged Gardner to resign from the commission.
column5: \u201cSecretary Gardner\u2019s association with this partisan commission risks tarnishing his long legacy of fighting for the New Hampshire Primary and promoting voter participation
column6: and it would be in keeping with his distinguished record to immediately relinquish any role with this commission
column7: \u201d the senators wrote in a statement\xa0on Thursday.
column8: New Hampshire\u2019s two House members
column9: Democratic Reps.\xa0Carol Shea-Porter and Annie Kuster
column10: advised Gardner to step down on Friday.
column11: The Breitbart commentary by Kobach
column12: who serves as vice chair of the electoral commission
column13: \xa0has put Gardner in an awkward position. Kobach wrote to claim there was proof of voter fraud in New Hampshire. He cited data showing that some 5
column14: 000 people who had registered to vote on Election Day and identified themselves with out-of-state licenses had still failed to obtain New Hampshire driver\u2019s licenses by the end of August of this year.
column15: The problem with that argument is that New Hampshire allows people to vote in the state who plan to live there only for a relatively brief period\xa0\u2015 like college students
column16: doctors completing their residencies
column17: members of the military temporarily stationed there.\xa0Those same short-termers do not meet the requirements to get a New Hampshire driver\u2019s license
column18: which is available to people who intend to live in the state indefinitely.
column19: Gardner
column20: who has been New Hampshire\u2019s secretary of state since 1976 and is elected by state lawmakers
column21: has refused to support Kobach\u2019s claims about fraud. But he also declines to resign from the commission.
column22: \u201cNo
column23: I\u2019m not going to step down
column24: and it\u2019s hypocritical to ask me to step down as a member of a federal commission
column25: \u201d Gardner told WMUR. \u201cHave they ever stepped down from a Senate committee or a committee that they serve on because they disagreed with someone on the committee?\u201d
column26: Gardner is set to host the commission\u2019s second public meeting in Manchester
column27: New Hampshire
column28: this coming Tuesday.
column29: All five Democrats serving on the commission have faced criticism. Voting rights advocates argue their presence legitimizes an effort to stir up false fears about voter fraud
column30: which multiple studies and investigations have shown it is not a widespread problem in the U.S.
column31: Former Vermont Gov. Howard Dean
column32: who once served as chair of the Democratic National Committee
column33: tweeted that New Hampshire should be stripped of its first-in-the-nation primary unless Gardner steps down.
column34: Under no circumstances should NH be first in the nation primary if Gardiner remains on the Voter Suppression committee @TomPerez https://t.co/M418PInCF0
column35: A spokesman for the Democratic National Committee did not immediately return a request for comment.
column36: Aside from his work on the commission
column37: Gardner has also faced criticism for supporting a Republican-backed state bill to tighten the proof of identity\xa0that voters have to present when they register in New Hampshire. The bill was passed after President Donald Trump claimed without evidence that thousands were bused into New Hampshire to vote illegally in November.\xa0Gardner has said he has no evidence that was true or that widespread voter fraud occurred
column38:
but the legislation was necessary to shore up confidence in New Hampshire\u2019s elections.

Key Obamacare Architect Who Shunned Single-Payer Now Backs It

|[

Former Sen. Max Baucus (D-Mont.)
column2: a fiscal moderate who
column3: as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee
column4: presided over the passage of the Affordable Care Act
column5: expressed his support on Thursday for the creation of a single-payer health care system.
column6: \u201cMy personal view is we\u2019ve got to start looking at single-payer
column7: \u201d Baucus said in remarks at Montana State University
column8: according to the\xa0Bozeman Daily Chronicle. \u201cI think we should have hearings... We\u2019re getting there. It\u2019s going to happen.\u201d
column9: Single-payer health care
column10: in which the federal government insures all citizens through one large program
column11: is a model for universal coverage in many developed countries
column12: including Canada
column13: France and Australia. But it has long been viewed as a pipe dream in the United States
column14: where a <a href="http://www.kff.org/other/state-indicator/total-population/?currentTimeframe=0&sortModel=%7B%22colId%22:%22Location%22
column15: %22sort%22:%22asc%22%7D" target="_blank">plurality of people receive coverage from their employers.
column16: Baucus\u2019 endorsement of the idea speaks to just how dramatically the health policy debate has shifted within the Democratic Party in recent years \u2015 particularly since the 2016 presidential run of Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.)
column17: who made what he called \u201cMedicare for all\u201d a central issue of his campaign.
column18: Baucus was the subject of progressive frustration for his stewardship of the ACA
column19: also known as Obamacare. Critics argued that he held the bill in committee far too long in hopes of winning the support of moderate Republicans who did not end up voting for the final bill. The lengthy negotiation period he initiated gave Republicans much-needed time to mobilize opposition to reform
column20: according to Baucus\u2019 detractors.
column21: Obamacare itself relies on a hybrid model
column22: once favored by conservative policy experts
column23: that combines the creation of a new private
column24: individual insurance marketplace and an expansion of Medicaid.
column25: Given Baucus\u2019 history as a fiscal moderate active in the ACA\u2019s passage
column26: his positive remarks about single-payer could provide a boost to progressive activists agitating for its implementation.
column27: As Senate Finance Committee chairman
column28: Baucus ruled out consideration of single-payer from the beginning
column29: and declined to invite the testimony of single-payer advocates at hearings. The latter decision prompted disruptive protests from activists
column30: and Baucus later said that\xa0he regretted not engaging more with the policy\u2019s proponents.
column31: In September 2009
column32: Baucus also voted against two amendments that would have created a public health insurance option on the Obamacare individual insurance exchanges.
column33: Baucus kept single-payer off the table during the development of Obamacare because he believed the country was not ready for it at the time
column34: he told NBC News on Friday.\xa0
column35: \u201cI just think the time has come
column36: \u201d Baucus said. \u201cBack in \u201909
column37: we were not ready to address it. It would never have passed. Here we are nine years later
column38: I think it\u2019s time to hopefully have a very serious good faith look at it.\u201d
column39: Sen. Jon Tester\xa0(D-Mont.)
column40: a moderate who represented Montana alongside Baucus from 2007 to 2014
column41: also expressed openness to single-payer this week.
column42: \u201cMaybe it\u2019s something we should
column43: quite frankly
column44: take a solid look at
column45: \u201d Tester said Wednesday.
column46: Tester does not support single-payer legislation
column47: however. When Sen. Steve Daines (R-Mont.)
column48: aiming to put Democrats in an awkward political position
column49: introduced a trick amendment creating a single-payer system to the Obamacare repeal bill
column50: most Democratic senators voted \u201cpresent\u201d on the motion
column51: but Tester was one of four Democratic senators to vote \u201cno\u201d\xa0on it.
column52: Former Sen. Kent Conrad (D-N.D.) \u2015 a moderate who vehemently opposed creating a public health insurance option during the passage of Obamacare \u2015 told HuffPost that unlike Baucus
column53: he believes it is \u201cunlikely we will get a single-payer system in the foreseeable future.\u201d
column54: Single-payer is improbable
column55: Conrad argued
column56: because funding a federal health insurance program would cost taxpayers so much and because medical providers are so opposed to radically transforming the system.\xa0
column57: Instead
column58: he said
column59: the \u201cbest system combines universal coverage with private not-for-profit insurance with the government assisting those who cannot afford insurance.\u201d
column60: He also favors empowering Medicare to negotiate bulk discounts on prescription drugs
column61: just as the Veterans Affairs health care system does.
column62: In addition to Sanders\u2019 presidential run
column63: the collapse of Republican efforts to repeal Obamacare has increased grassroots energy behind single-payer as activists seek to go on the offensive. Progressive pressure groups like Credo have launched efforts to make support for the policy a litmus test for 2020\u2032s Democratic presidential candidates.
column64: Single-payer now has more support in Congress than at any other time in recent history. Single-payer legislation introduced by Rep. John Conyers (D-Mich.) has more co-sponsors than ever
column65: with the support of a majority of the House Democratic Caucus.
column66: Sanders plans to unveil a much-anticipated version of single-payer legislation next Wednesday. Sens. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.)
column67: a rumored 2020 presidential contender
column68: and Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) have already announced plans to co-sponsor the bill.
column69: Polling suggests that the idea of single-payer is popular with the public
column70: especially among Democrats. In a May 2016 Gallup poll
column71: 58 percent of Americans and 73 percent of Democrats said they supported replacing \u201cthe ACA with a federally funded healthcare program providing insurance for all Americans.\u201d\xa0
column72: Even elected Democrats who remain wary of single-payer have begun trying to capitalize on the ambitious proposal\u2019s popularity. The Congressional Hispanic Caucus\u2019 political action committee
column73: Bold PAC
column74: has repeatedly alluded to the \u201cMedicare for all\u201d fight in fundraising e-mails \u2015 even though half of the 30 CHC members have yet to actually endorse single-payer
column75: and the PAC does not make support for the policy a condition for its financial support.
column76: Of course
column77: \xa0it is much easier to talk about single-payer than to actually implement it. Replacing the current system with one large federal program would require a massive tax increase in exchange for what advocates believe would result in net cost reductions thanks to the government\u2019s considerable bargaining power.
column78: It would also force the nearly half of Americans who get insurance from their jobs to enroll in a new government program. Given the outcry that Obamacare elicited for canceling the plans of a fraction of that number of people
column79: enacting single-payer would likely prove an extraordinary political challenge.
column80: In the meantime
column82: the excitement around single-payer has already widened the spectrum of acceptable debate about health care.\xa0Expansions of coverage that once seemed radical now seem downright moderate by comparison. In August
column83: Sen. Brian Schatz (D-Hawaii) announced plans to introduce legislation allowing Americans of all ages and incomes to buy into Medicaid. And earlier this week
column84: Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) revealed his intention to introduce a bill creating a comparable universal buy-in option for Medicare
column85: which he said\xa0\u201cmay be the fastest way to a single-payer system.\u201d
column86: This article has been updated with comments from Tester and Conrad
column87:
as well as additional comments from Baucus.

]

column1: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/trump-conservatives-paul-ryan-fault_us_59b1c937e4b0354e4410bd4a?utm_campaign=hp_fb_pages&utm_source=politics_fb&utm_medium=facebook&ncid=fcbklnkushpmg00000013&section=politics|<h1 class="headline__title">Who Do Conservatives Blame For Donald Trump's Bad Deal? Paul Ryan
column2:
Of Course!|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 President Donald Trump made a bad deal for Republicans on the debt limit and government funding
column3: and
column4: according to House conservatives
column5: that\u2019s Speaker Paul Ryan\u2019s fault.
column6: What?
column7: A day after Trump surprised his own party by taking the first offer from congressional Democrats to raise the debt ceiling and continue government spending for three months
column8: many House conservatives have decided that House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wisc.) is ultimately to blame for Trump\u2019s impulsive deal.
column9: \u201cLack of preparation leads to poor choices
column10: and the fact that we weren\u2019t here \u2015 and you heard me say this the other night \u2015 we weren\u2019t here for six weeks
column11: the longest non-election-year break we\u2019ve had in a decade
column12: \u201d former Freedom Caucus Chairman Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) said Thursday
column13: \u201cthat\u2019s a problem.\u201d
column14: Asked if Trump had effectively stepped in front of a bullet for Ryan by taking the blame for a bad deal that the speaker would have largely taken the responsibility for if the president had just stayed out of negotiations
column15: Jordan said he wasn\u2019t here to blame anybody. \u201cWhat I\u2019m saying is we should have done what we had said back in July
column16: \u201d Jordan answered. \u201cWe should have stayed here and put together a debt ceiling plan.\u201d
column17: Obviously
column18: Ryan has a lot of blame for a congressional recess
column19: though the majority leader also has a say in the congressional schedule. But Jordan added that when lawmakers fail to prepare for deadlines
column20: they don\u2019t have the best options come decision time.
column21: That\u2019s not an unfair argument
column22: but it ignores an obvious reality: This deal that Trump struck with Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) was a deal that Trump struck
column23: not Ryan.
column24: But time and again Thursday
column25: conservatives ignored Trump\u2019s role in the agreement and found a way to blame the speaker.
column26: \u201cI think he saw the same-old
column27: same-old kind of crap coming from leadership
column28: and that wasn\u2019t good enough
column29: \u201d Rep. Paul Gosar (R-Ariz.) said of Trump
column30: theorizing that the president was effectively preserving the debt limit issue until December.
column31: As much as Gosar defended the president
column32: he couldn\u2019t find an adequate reason to vote for the bill \u2015 he said he plans to oppose the package when it comes before the House \u2015 but Gosar noted he could see how this deal works to Trump\u2019s favor if the president plays his hand right.
column33: That part seems unlikely. Lawmakers have repeatedly noted in the last two days that Trump just set a precedent that will be tough for him to break: He supported raising the debt ceiling without concessions
column34: and he has agreed to fund the government without demanding money for his border wall.
column35: Even Gosar acknowledged that Trump has made his negotiating position more difficult. \u201cHe may have lost that credibility
column36: \u201d Gosar said. \u201cBut time will tell.\u201d
column37: Still
column38: conservatives generally refused to blame Trump for a deal that most of them believe to be bad for Republicans. Many said they couldn\u2019t answer questions until actually seeing the text of the deal. Many outright refused to answer questions.
column39: \u201cI\u2019m not going to talk about whether Donald Trump or Paul Ryan did a good or bad job
column40: \u201d said Rep. Mo Brooks of Alabama.
column41: And many others made tenuous connections between the deal and Paul Ryan.
column42: \u201cI just see that the leadership team signed off on it and the rest of us find out about it
column43: \u201d said Rep. Steve King (R-Iowa). King noted that Ryan and other GOP leaders didn\u2019t ever offer a conservative alternative to a clean increase in the debt ceiling \u2015 again
column44: an argument that isn\u2019t wrong but somehow ignores the fact that Trump jumped at the chance for a clean debt limit.
column45: Rep. Louie Gohmert (R-Texas) conveyed that he was disappointed in the deal. But even after he was presented with the argument that Ryan had called the Democratic offer \u201cridiculous\u201d Wednesday morning shortly before Trump took the offer
column46: Gohmert said Ryan may actually have been a proponent of the deal. \u201cWe don\u2019t know if he was or not
column47: \u201d the congressman said.
column48: Moderates generally welcomed Trump\u2019s deal
column49: noting that the president had effectively cut out the Freedom Caucus from negotiations. \u201cTo me
column50: the main positive of this deal is we\u2019re not gonna have one group of 30 or 40 have veto power
column51: \u201d Rep. Peter King (R-N.Y.) said. \u201cWe can\u2019t allow a group of 30 or 40 to be setting policy for the House of Representatives.\u201d
column52: But as much as moderates were celebrating the compromised position of conservatives
column53: conservatives were muted in their criticism \u2015 at least of Trump
column54: who many believe is the key to overthrowing Ryan.
column55: Conservatives have quietly been laying the groundwork for a coup against Ryan
column56: pointing out with increasing frequency that the speaker had no plan to extract GOP concessions on the debt ceiling or a continuing resolution. But it\u2019s difficult to argue that this legislation is really Ryan\u2019s fault when Trump got out in front of it.
column57: Republicans have spun Trump\u2019s decision as one recognizing that Democrats were going to win this negotiation
column58: so better to just \u201cclear the decks\u201d and perhaps allow Congress to focus on tax reform. But even that explanation is fraught. The short-term nature of the deal ensures that lawmakers will be focused on negotiating a broader deal in December
column59: not just cutting taxes.
column60: Ryan\u2019s own defense of the agreement is that Trump saw a nation recovering from one hurricane and preparing for another
column61: and he wanted a bipartisan moment rather than a protracted disagreement. That argument may work for some
column62: but Trump has put Republicans in a bind for future negotiations
column63: and he did so with little to no consultation from congressional leaders or his legislative affairs staff
column64: according to one senior GOP aide familiar with discussions.
column65: And if Trump himself wanted to preserve his conservative credentials and damage Paul Ryan
column66: he just went ahead and did the exact opposite. The question is whether that will matter to the far-right lawmakers who already seem to be plotting Ryan\u2019s fall.
column67: When Gosar was asked Thursday if he still supports Ryan as speaker
column68: he repeatedly answered that he hadn\u2019t said \u201cone way or another.\u201d
column69: Asked if he would welcome Ryan campaigning for him
column70: Gosar answered that he didn\u2019t have a challenger. Asked whether he would let Ryan even fundraise for him
column71: Gosar said he didn\u2019t know about that
column72:
noting that Ryan was \u201cvery unpopular\u201d in his district.

]

Hurricane Harvey Is Just The Latest In Facebook’s Fake News Problem

|[

As the rain started falling in Houston
column2: the anonymous authors went to work.
column3: Writing under pseudonyms and hiding behind the pretense of satire
column4: they churned out lies
column5: dressed them up as news
column6: and then let Facebook\u2019s platform do their dirty work
column7: spreading their deliberate falsehoods far and wide.
column8: As a result
column9: millions of people were exposed to \u2015 and believed \u2015 false stories like this one
column10: headlined: \u201cBlack Lives Matter Thugs Blocking Emergency Crews From Reaching Hurricane Victims.\u201d (The opposite was actually true: BLM Houston has been actively collecting and distributing aid and helping recovery efforts.)
column11: One website alone
column12: \xa0\u201cFlash American News
column13: \u201d spread that narrative to more than 1 million people via Facebook. Numerous other similar websites also shared their own versions via the social media network
column14: selling the lie by using photos taken from other totally unrelated stories.
column15: While some might readily recognize the story as fake
column16: plenty who encountered it on Facebook sure didn\u2019t.
column17: \u201cThese hoodlums need to go away for a long time!\u201d One commenter wrote after the story was shared on the \u201cfanclubtrump\u201d\xa0Facebook page. \u201cMake them regret what they are doing keeping hurt
column18: innocent people from getting help is dispicable!\u201d [sic]
column19: \u201cThis is absolutely despicable!!!!\u201d another user added. \u201cTell me please how does this help anything or anybody! All it does is show the world that these people are heartless
column20: uncaring
column21: sorry excuses of what a human being should be!!!\u201d
column22: Though the story is fake
column23: its impact in the real world is not.
column24: Similar disinformation campaigns singled out other groups frequently targeted by conservative media and the so-called \u201calt-right
column25: \u201d shaping real-world opinions with fake stories spread unchecked on Facebook.\xa0
column26: Muslims were also accused in several fake stories of refusing to let Harvey victims seek shelter in mosques. (Again
column27: the opposite is true: Houston-area mosques opened their doors to thousands
column28: even as Joel Osteen\u2019s 16
column29: 800-seat megachurch drew criticism for remaining closed.) \xa0
column30: The imam pictured in the fake story above lives in Canada and says he\u2019s never even been to Texas.
column31: Nevertheless
column32: a version distributed via DailyPostFeed.com (other sites also shared other variants) was shared to 795
column33: 680 people via Facebook.\xa0
column34: Another highly-circulated fake story claimed that flooding during Hurricane Harvey somehow \u201cuncovered\u201d a huge cache of weapons and ammo apparently hidden there by the Obama administration
column35: for the purposes of staging a coup to return to power.
column36: While the above website\xa0claims to be satire
column37: it does little to announce that to visitors. Per CrowdTangle
column38: the above story was shared to 769
column39: 377 people on Facebook.
column40: The Clinton Foundation was also (falsely) accused of sending water to Houston and charging\xa0$7 per bottle for it.
column41: Misinformation on the internet is hardly a new or even rare occurrence. But one common thread here is Facebook.
column42: The social media network has enabled the rapid spread of deliberate
column43: harmful falsehoods.
column44: As of now
column45: the company is apparently unwilling to do much to stop the spread of deliberate misinformation.
column46: In response to outcry over similar disinformation campaigns during the 2016 election
column47: \xa0Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg\xa0dismissed as \u201cpretty crazy\u201d the idea that fake news on his site could have influenced the election\u2019s outcome. The company\u2019s COO Sheryl Sandberg agreed.
column48: Nevertheless
column49: Facebook calmed some critics by rolling out a system months later to flag questionable sources of information\xa0as \u201cdisputed\u201d and reconfiguring its \u201ctrending topics\u201d module. Judging by the rampant spread of the above stories
column50: however
column51: deeper problems remain.
column52: On Wednesday
column53: Facebook representatives acknowledged to congressional investigators that <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/facebook-says-likely-russian-based-operation-spent-money-on-political-ads_us_59b07007e4b0354e440f2778">the company sold around $100
column54: 000 worth of ads\xa0during the 2016 election to a Russian content farm known for producing pro-Kremlin messages

Obama Official Who Created DACA Sues Trump To Protect It

|[

ANAHEIM
column2: Calif. \u2015 Former Department of Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano sued the Trump administration on Friday to block it from taking work authorization and deportation protections away from hundreds of thousands of undocumented immigrants.
column3: The lawsuit
column4: which she filed in her capacity as president of the University of California system along with the regents
column5: \xa0is in part personal to Napolitano \u2015 she created the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program
column6: which Trump is now phasing out
column7: in 2012. But she said on Friday that her bigger interest \u201clies with the young people whose futures are now being put in doubt and doing all we can to support and protect those young people.\u201d
column8: There are roughly 4
column9: 000 undocumented immigrants who attend schools in the University of California system
column10: and Napolitano said on a call with reporters that a large proportion of them have DACA protections \u2015 so-called Dreamers. The state\u2019s university system also employs undocumented teachers
column11: healthcare workers and other staff.
column12: The lawsuit alleges that Trump\u2019s decision to rescind the program violates the Administrative Procedure Act and constitutional due process
column13: including that of students at University of California schools and the system itself.
column14: \u201cThe administration\u2019s approach in rescinding DACA was the opposite of reasoned decision-making and thus is unlawful
column15: \u201d Napolitano said. \u201cIt did not assess the costs of rescinding DACA to the hundreds of thousands of Dreamers or to the schools and communities in which they live
column16: study and work.\u201d
column17: The lawsuit comes on the heels of a complaint by 15 states and the District of Columbia and a challenge by a former recipient of the program. All are aiming to prevent Trump from ending DACA protections.
column18: Napolitano\u2019s lawsuit alleges that the Trump administration illegally neglected to follow rules outlined in the Administrative Procedure Act
column19: which would have required more notice and a public comment period before making such a far-reaching change. Napolitano said that the situation was distinct from the creation of DACA
column20: which did not go through a public comment period
column21: because the program involved case-by-case determinations about prosecutorial discretion
column22: while Trump\u2019s decision will hit recipients en masse.
column23: \u2033[Rescinding DACA] doesn\u2019t involve discretion at all
column24: \u201d Napolitano said. \u201cIt says that for this whole category of cases the administration will not exercise discretion and will not defer deportations. So it deals with this population and a whole category
column25: not individuals.\u201d
column26: She said that DACA is also distinct from the Deferred Action for Parents of Americans and Lawful Permanent Residents program
column27: or DAPA
column28: which was blocked in the courts because of a lawsuit that alleged
column29: in part
column30: that the Obama administration violated the Administrative Procedure Act in creating it.
column31: Friday\u2019s lawsuit also argues that the Trump administration violated the due process rights of DACA recipients
column32: which are protected by the Fifth Amendment
column33: by \u201cexecutive fiat.\u201d
column34: Those arguments also form part of the two other legal challenges to the termination of DACA filed in New York shortly after the Trump administration announced it would phase out the signature immigration reform of the Obama years.
column35: One of those cases was originally filed in Brooklyn last year by DACA recipient Mart\xedn Jonathan Batalla Vidal. He had challenged the revocation of his three-year work authorization after the program\u2019s expansion was blocked by a federal judge in Texas
column36: along with a farther-reaching program to shield undocumented parents of U.S. citizens from deportation. Lawyers in the Batalla Vidal case requested to amend their lawsuit to challenge the termination of DACA within hours of the Trump administration\u2019s announcement on Tuesday. \xa0
column37: A coalition of 15 states and the District of Columbia
column38: led by New York
column39: filed a second lawsuit\xa0on Wednesday aimed at keeping DACA alive.
column40: Both of the New York lawsuits allege that Trump\u2019s decision to end DACA was motivated by an intent to discriminate against Mexicans
column41: citing the vitriolic statements aimed at Mexican immigrants that he made repeatedly on the campaign trail. Napolitano\u2019s lawsuit does not include that claim.
column42: Democratic California Attorney General Xavier Becerra plans to file a fourth lawsuit in federal court in his home state disputing the decision to end DACA. \xa0
column43: The president has broad authority to undue the executive actions of previous administrations. But similar legal challenges largely blocked Trump\u2019s efforts to restrict virtually all visits from several Muslim-majority countries earlier this year.
column44: Whether or not the lawsuits are ultimately successful
column45: they open the possibility that one or more federal judges could issue an injunction that would halt the termination of DACA while the cases wind their way through the legal system.
column46: Trump has said he wants to work with Congress on a legislative solution for Dreamers in the six month window before many begin to lose their work permits and protections. Napolitano said she plans to continue to press members of Congress to solve the bill through law
column47: even as she fights to maintain DACA in court.
column48: \u201cI believe that in this case the court should act
column49: \u201d Napolitano said
column50:
\u201cor in the alternative Congress should act and settle this matter for once and for all.\u201d

Did Climate Change Spawn All These Hurricanes? Here’s Why It’s Hard To Say.

|[

PARIS \u2015 There\u2019s a bit of an apocalyptic vibe in the air. Even though it\u2019s tropical storm season
column2: it has been alarming to watch\xa0hurricanes Harvey and Irma strike land in rapid succession. Now Jos\xe9
column3: a Category 4 storm
column4: and\xa0Katia
column5: a Category 3 storm
column6: \xa0are not far behind.
column7: Harvey created unprecedented flooding in Texas
column8: \xa0and Irma is the most powerful tropical cyclone ever to take shape in the Atlantic Ocean. The French island of St. Martin has been 95 percent destroyed
column9: according to local officials
column10: and at least four people have died.\xa0The devastation has led many to wonder what role climate change\xa0may be playing in these powerful storms.
column11: Some political leaders are drawing a clear link between the two
column12: such as Paris Mayor\xa0Anne Hidalgo
column13: who declared on Thursday that Irma is a \u201cconcrete manifestation\u201d of global warming. A few hours later
column14: French President\xa0Emmanuel Macron\xa0said it was necessary to look at the \u201cdeep causes behind these types of events.\u201d\xa0
column15: But the connection between climate change and hurricanes is complicated
column16: with several separate questions to consider. Is climate change causing more hurricanes (also called typhoons and cyclones
column17: depending on where they originate)? Are the storms more powerful? Are they more destructive? And what does this portend for the future?
column18: To see what science has to say
column19: HuffPost France\xa0interviewed Robert Vautard
column20: a climatologist with France\u2019s National Center for Scientific Research who specializes in the relationship between extreme events and climate change.
column21: Researchers create mathematical models to test the ways that greenhouse gas emissions could evolve and to simulate the warming that could take place in the oceans and atmosphere. The models allow them to extrapolate how different weather phenomena
column22: such as hurricanes
column23: may develop in the future under varying temperature scenarios.\xa0
column24: But so far
column25: it\u2019s hard for the models to predict how rising temperatures will specifically affect storms. \u201cThe results lean toward a lessening in terms of the number of tropical storms and an increase in terms of wind force
column26: \u201d Vautard said. \u201cBut there are a lot of uncertainties.\u201d
column27: To be clear
column28: the models are able to predict global climate scenarios with a high degree of accuracy. But predicting the evolution of storms requires even more precision
column29: since they are only tiny events compared to the overall scale of the planet.\xa0Although there seem to be some consistencies in the storm models
column30: their predictions can\u2019t be relied upon at this point.
column31: Vautard and other scientists largely agree on one effect of climate change
column32: however. \u201cThe impact tropical storms have is going to increase
column33: because the atmosphere is going to warm up and will therefore contain more water
column34: \u201d he said. \u201cWhich means more rain.\u201d
column35: And more rain means more flooding
column36: which can be just as damaging as a hurricane\u2019s strong winds
column37: as Harvey demonstrated.
column38: Another certainty is that climate change is causing sea levels to rise
column39: which means greater storm surges and higher waves when a storm hits the coast.
column40: \u201cKnowing these two things
column41: it\u2019s safe to say that hurricanes affecting low-elevation islands will therefore cause greater damage
column42: even if they have the same features as today\u2019s do
column43: \u201d said Vautard.
column44: In short
column45: even if scientists aren\u2019t sure about the number and potency of future tropical storms
column46: they are fairly certain these storms will cause more damage if nothing is done to keep climate change in check.
column47: Harvey caused historic flooding in Texas. Is this proof that global warming is already making hurricanes worse? The United Nations\u2019\xa0World Meteorological Organization and some American climatologists\xa0say it is
column48: absolutely.\xa0But Vautard doesn\u2019t want to be that assertive.
column49: \u201cIt\u2019s too early to say. Worldwide
column50: you could say that global warming has definitely caused an increase in rainfall
column51: but in terms of Hurricane Harvey in particular
column52: we\u2019ll have to wait on the studies being done right now
column53: \u201d he said.
column54: Climate science is much more about examining what happens on a global multiyear average scale \u2015 not about specific events. Researchers will be studying Harvey and looking at how it fits into broader trends
column55: \xa0Vautard said.
column56: As far as tropical storms are concerned
column57: \xa0it\u2019s also difficult to know what the historic trends have been. \u201cSince they mostly happen at sea
column58: you need satellite data to get statistics about hurricanes
column59: \u201d said Vautard. But that type of data has only been around for about 40 years
column60: which is not long enough to establish reliable scientific models.
column61: Going forward
column62: researchers will continue to improve the precision of their models
column63: which will allow them to better understand how and why hurricanes form
column64: and how climate factors contribute to that.\xa0\u201cWe aren\u2019t far off
column65: \u201d Vautard said.
column66:
This story was first published by HuffPost France.

]

the governor has replied: \u201cI\u2019m not a scientist.\u201d

A Democratic member of President\xa0Donald Trump\u2019s commission to investigate voter fraud issued some of the strongest criticism yet from within the panel on efforts to make it more difficult to vote.
column2: In a lengthy statement to the commission
column3: Alan King
column4: a Democratic probate judge in Alabama
column5: criticized overzealous efforts to purge people from the voter rolls. In his statement
column6: King wrote that while there may be some people who voted twice
column7: there were thousands more who were removed from the rolls for no reason or had their vote suppressed. King won\u2019t be attending the panel\u2019s Tuesday meeting in Manchester
column8: New Hampshire
column9: because of a scheduling conflict
column10: he told commission organizers.
column11: \u201cThe reality is that the less affluent in our society are more prone to move and more prone to have a diminished economic position in life
column12: just to survive. But that does not mean that officials in government should \u2018game the system\u2019 to deprive the less affluent from voting

column14: \u201d he wrote.

column18: two other Republican commission members
column19: also support more aggressive voter purging.
column20: King expanded on his statement in an interview with HuffPost

column22: \u201cThis is about protecting the affluent. It doesn\u2019t take a rocket scientist to realize that those that are affluent have a more stable type of residential situation and home life. And this is about disenfranchising
column23: in my opinion
column24: those perhaps who live in apartment complexes
column25: who are maybe less educated
column26: who maybe for whatever reason in life
column27: they\u2019re not at a level that some people are. That\u2019s what this is about
column28: \u201d he said. \u201cThis is just me. But I do have almost 17 years of nuts and bolts experience in elections...It\u2019s clear to me that there is an agenda to deprive people of the right to vote and that is wrong.\u201d
column29: King declined to clarify whether he was speaking specifically about Trump\u2019s commission
column30: which critics fear will lead to widespread voter purging. That alarm was heightened when the Department of Justice sent out an unusual letter in June to\xa044 states asking for compliance\xa0with voter purge policies. The letter went out the same day Kobach sent a letter to election officials across the country requesting voter information
column31: but the Department of Justice says the two requests are unrelated.
column32: Democrats serving on the commission\xa0face calls to resign\xa0and accusations that they are enabling an effort to weaken confidence in the American electoral system. Several have resisted those calls

then I truly believe this nation will fall.\u201d

Liberal Groups Push Democrats To Slow Down Judge Confirmation Process

|[

A coalition of major progressive organizations has launched a campaign aimed at pressuring members of the Senate Judiciary Committee to slow down the confirmation process for federal judges
column2: thereby limiting how many President Donald Trump\xa0can seat.
column3: \u201cTell the Senate Judiciary Committee: No lifetime judicial appointments for a white supremacist in chief with no respect for the Constitution or the rule of law
column4: \u201d Credo
column5: one of the groups leading the charge
column6: told activists.\xa0
column7: The coalition \u2015 which also includes Democracy for America
column8: Color of Change and UltraViolet \u2015 plans to deliver petition signatures to Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) and ranking member Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) sometime next week. The groups started their campaign on Wednesday
column9: and expect to collect hundreds of thousands of signatures.
column10: The groups are mainly targeting Democrats
column11: but they also hope some Republicans who have been critical of the president
column12: such as Sens. Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.) and Ben Sasse (R-Neb.)
column13: will consider the appeal as well.\xa0They acknowledge that Democrats are limited in their ability to actually prevent the Senate from confirming conservative judges if Republican committee members remain united behind Trump\u2019s nominees.\xa0
column14: Senate rules have forbidden the minority party from filibustering presidential nominees to the federal bench since 2013
column15: when then-Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.)\xa0ended the practice. Reid and other Democrats had grown frustrated with Republican efforts to obstruct then-President\xa0Barack Obama\u2019s judicial nominees.\xa0
column16: Instead
column17: the progressive organizations plan to convince Democrats to throw up more procedural hurdles to judges\u2019 confirmation
column18: \xa0according to Heidi Hess
column19: Credo\u2019s senior campaign manager. This would limit the total number of judges that can be seated in a given year.\xa0
column20: \u201cWe want them to slow it down as much as they can
column21: \u201d Hess told HuffPost. \u201cThey should at least be speaking out about this
column22: making it clear what\u2019s happening so it\u2019s not just the case that this is happening under the radar.\u201d
column23: For example
column24: Credo and its allies are\xa0asking Democrats to more consistently withhold so-called \u201cblue slips.\u201d The Judiciary Committee does not usually begin confirmation hearings until the senators from the home state of a federal judiciary nominee turn over blue slips of paper signaling their consent that the process proceed.
column25: Some Senate Democrats are already showing greater willingness to challenge Trump\u2019s judicial nominees by withholding these pieces of paper.
column26: Democratic Sens. Ron Wyden and Jeff Merkley of Oregon announced Thursday in a letter to the White House\xa0that they would not return blue slips for Ryan Bounds
column27: an assistant U.S. attorney in their state whom Trump has nominated to a vacant seat on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 9th Circuit.
column28: Wyden and Merkley objected to the Trump White House allegedly not consulting with them before selecting the nominee. That represents a departure from \u201cOregon\u2019s long bipartisan tradition of working together to identify the most qualified candidates for judicial vacancies
column29: \u201d they said.\xa0\xa0
column30: Sen. Al Franken (D-Minn.)
column31: himself a member of the Judiciary Committee
column32: also announced Tuesday that he would not return a blue slip for David Stras
column33: a Trump nominee for the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 8th Circuit.

Did Climate Change Spawn All These Hurricanes? Here’s Why It’s Hard To Say.

|[

PARIS \u2015 There\u2019s a bit of an apocalyptic vibe in the air. Even though it\u2019s tropical storm season
column2: it has been alarming to watch\xa0hurricanes Harvey and Irma strike land in rapid succession. Now Jos\xe9
column3: a Category 4 storm
column4: and\xa0Katia
column5: a Category 3 storm
column6: \xa0are not far behind.
column7: Harvey created unprecedented flooding in Texas
column8: \xa0and Irma is the most powerful tropical cyclone ever to take shape in the Atlantic Ocean. The French island of St. Martin has been 95 percent destroyed
column9: according to local officials
column10: and at least four people have died.\xa0The devastation has led many to wonder what role climate change\xa0may be playing in these powerful storms.
column11: Some political leaders are drawing a clear link between the two
column12: such as Paris Mayor\xa0Anne Hidalgo
column13: who declared on Thursday that Irma is a \u201cconcrete manifestation\u201d of global warming. A few hours later
column14: French President\xa0Emmanuel Macron\xa0said it was necessary to look at the \u201cdeep causes behind these types of events.\u201d\xa0
column15: But the connection between climate change and hurricanes is complicated
column16: with several separate questions to consider. Is climate change causing more hurricanes (also called typhoons and cyclones
column17: depending on where they originate)? Are the storms more powerful? Are they more destructive? And what does this portend for the future?
column18: To see what science has to say
column19: HuffPost France\xa0interviewed Robert Vautard
column20: a climatologist with France\u2019s National Center for Scientific Research who specializes in the relationship between extreme events and climate change.
column21: Researchers create mathematical models to test the ways that greenhouse gas emissions could evolve and to simulate the warming that could take place in the oceans and atmosphere. The models allow them to extrapolate how different weather phenomena
column22: such as hurricanes
column23: may develop in the future under varying temperature scenarios.\xa0
column24: But so far
column25: it\u2019s hard for the models to predict how rising temperatures will specifically affect storms. \u201cThe results lean toward a lessening in terms of the number of tropical storms and an increase in terms of wind force
column26: \u201d Vautard said. \u201cBut there are a lot of uncertainties.\u201d
column27: To be clear
column28: the models are able to predict global climate scenarios with a high degree of accuracy. But predicting the evolution of storms requires even more precision
column29: since they are only tiny events compared to the overall scale of the planet.\xa0Although there seem to be some consistencies in the storm models
column30: their predictions can\u2019t be relied upon at this point.
column31: Vautard and other scientists largely agree on one effect of climate change
column32: however. \u201cThe impact tropical storms have is going to increase
column33: because the atmosphere is going to warm up and will therefore contain more water
column34: \u201d he said. \u201cWhich means more rain.\u201d
column35: And more rain means more flooding
column36: which can be just as damaging as a hurricane\u2019s strong winds
column37: as Harvey demonstrated.
column38: Another certainty is that climate change is causing sea levels to rise
column39: which means greater storm surges and higher waves when a storm hits the coast.
column40: \u201cKnowing these two things
column41: it\u2019s safe to say that hurricanes affecting low-elevation islands will therefore cause greater damage
column42: even if they have the same features as today\u2019s do
column43: \u201d said Vautard.
column44: In short
column45: even if scientists aren\u2019t sure about the number and potency of future tropical storms
column46: they are fairly certain these storms will cause more damage if nothing is done to keep climate change in check.
column47: Harvey caused historic flooding in Texas. Is this proof that global warming is already making hurricanes worse? The United Nations\u2019\xa0World Meteorological Organization and some American climatologists\xa0say it is
column48: absolutely.\xa0But Vautard doesn\u2019t want to be that assertive.
column49: \u201cIt\u2019s too early to say. Worldwide
column50: you could say that global warming has definitely caused an increase in rainfall
column51: but in terms of Hurricane Harvey in particular
column52: we\u2019ll have to wait on the studies being done right now
column53: \u201d he said.
column54: Climate science is much more about examining what happens on a global multiyear average scale \u2015 not about specific events. Researchers will be studying Harvey and looking at how it fits into broader trends
column55: \xa0Vautard said.
column56: As far as tropical storms are concerned
column57: \xa0it\u2019s also difficult to know what the historic trends have been. \u201cSince they mostly happen at sea
column58: you need satellite data to get statistics about hurricanes
column59: \u201d said Vautard. But that type of data has only been around for about 40 years
column60: which is not long enough to establish reliable scientific models.
column61: Going forward
column62: researchers will continue to improve the precision of their models
column63: which will allow them to better understand how and why hurricanes form
column64: and how climate factors contribute to that.\xa0\u201cWe aren\u2019t far off
column65: \u201d Vautard said.
