Did Climate Change Spawn All These Hurricanes? Here’s Why It’s Hard To Say.

|[

PARIS \u2015 There\u2019s a bit of an apocalyptic vibe in the air. Even though it\u2019s tropical storm season
column2: it has been alarming to watch\xa0hurricanes Harvey and Irma strike land in rapid succession. Now Jos\xe9
column3: a Category 4 storm
column4: and\xa0Katia
column5: a Category 3 storm
column6: \xa0are not far behind.
column7: Harvey created unprecedented flooding in Texas
column8: \xa0and Irma is the most powerful tropical cyclone ever to take shape in the Atlantic Ocean. The French island of St. Martin has been 95 percent destroyed
column9: according to local officials
column10: and at least four people have died.\xa0The devastation has led many to wonder what role climate change\xa0may be playing in these powerful storms.
column11: Some political leaders are drawing a clear link between the two
column12: such as Paris Mayor\xa0Anne Hidalgo
column13: who declared on Thursday that Irma is a \u201cconcrete manifestation\u201d of global warming. A few hours later
column14: French President\xa0Emmanuel Macron\xa0said it was necessary to look at the \u201cdeep causes behind these types of events.\u201d\xa0
column15: But the connection between climate change and hurricanes is complicated
column16: with several separate questions to consider. Is climate change causing more hurricanes (also called typhoons and cyclones
column17: depending on where they originate)? Are the storms more powerful? Are they more destructive? And what does this portend for the future?
column18: To see what science has to say
column19: HuffPost France\xa0interviewed Robert Vautard
column20: a climatologist with France\u2019s National Center for Scientific Research who specializes in the relationship between extreme events and climate change.
column21: Researchers create mathematical models to test the ways that greenhouse gas emissions could evolve and to simulate the warming that could take place in the oceans and atmosphere. The models allow them to extrapolate how different weather phenomena
column22: such as hurricanes
column23: may develop in the future under varying temperature scenarios.\xa0
column24: But so far
column25: it\u2019s hard for the models to predict how rising temperatures will specifically affect storms. \u201cThe results lean toward a lessening in terms of the number of tropical storms and an increase in terms of wind force
column26: \u201d Vautard said. \u201cBut there are a lot of uncertainties.\u201d
column27: To be clear
column28: the models are able to predict global climate scenarios with a high degree of accuracy. But predicting the evolution of storms requires even more precision
column29: since they are only tiny events compared to the overall scale of the planet.\xa0Although there seem to be some consistencies in the storm models
column30: their predictions can\u2019t be relied upon at this point.
column31: Vautard and other scientists largely agree on one effect of climate change
column32: however. \u201cThe impact tropical storms have is going to increase
column33: because the atmosphere is going to warm up and will therefore contain more water
column34: \u201d he said. \u201cWhich means more rain.\u201d
column35: And more rain means more flooding
column36: which can be just as damaging as a hurricane\u2019s strong winds
column37: as Harvey demonstrated.
column38: Another certainty is that climate change is causing sea levels to rise
column39: which means greater storm surges and higher waves when a storm hits the coast.
column40: \u201cKnowing these two things
column41: it\u2019s safe to say that hurricanes affecting low-elevation islands will therefore cause greater damage
column42: even if they have the same features as today\u2019s do
column43: \u201d said Vautard.
column44: In short
column45: even if scientists aren\u2019t sure about the number and potency of future tropical storms
column46: they are fairly certain these storms will cause more damage if nothing is done to keep climate change in check.
column47: Harvey caused historic flooding in Texas. Is this proof that global warming is already making hurricanes worse? The United Nations\u2019\xa0World Meteorological Organization and some American climatologists\xa0say it is
column48: absolutely.\xa0But Vautard doesn\u2019t want to be that assertive.
column49: \u201cIt\u2019s too early to say. Worldwide
column50: you could say that global warming has definitely caused an increase in rainfall
column51: but in terms of Hurricane Harvey in particular
column52: we\u2019ll have to wait on the studies being done right now
column53: \u201d he said.
column54: Climate science is much more about examining what happens on a global multiyear average scale \u2015 not about specific events. Researchers will be studying Harvey and looking at how it fits into broader trends
column55: \xa0Vautard said.
column56: As far as tropical storms are concerned
column57: \xa0it\u2019s also difficult to know what the historic trends have been. \u201cSince they mostly happen at sea
column58: you need satellite data to get statistics about hurricanes
column59: \u201d said Vautard. But that type of data has only been around for about 40 years
column60: which is not long enough to establish reliable scientific models.
column61: Going forward
column62: researchers will continue to improve the precision of their models
column63: which will allow them to better understand how and why hurricanes form
column64: and how climate factors contribute to that.\xa0\u201cWe aren\u2019t far off
column65: \u201d Vautard said.
column66:
This story was first published by HuffPost France.

Key Obamacare Architect Who Shunned Single-Payer Now Backs It

|[

Former Sen. Max Baucus (D-Mont.)
column2: a fiscal moderate who
column3: as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee
column4: presided over the passage of the Affordable Care Act
column5: expressed his support on Thursday for the creation of a single-payer health care system.
column6: \u201cMy personal view is we\u2019ve got to start looking at single-payer
column7: \u201d Baucus said in remarks at Montana State University
column8: according to the\xa0Bozeman Daily Chronicle. \u201cI think we should have hearings... We\u2019re getting there. It\u2019s going to happen.\u201d
column9: Single-payer health care
column10: in which the federal government insures all citizens through one large program
column11: is a model for universal coverage in many developed countries
column12: including Canada
column13: France and Australia. But it has long been viewed as a pipe dream in the United States
column14: where a <a href="http://www.kff.org/other/state-indicator/total-population/?currentTimeframe=0&sortModel=%7B%22colId%22:%22Location%22
column15: %22sort%22:%22asc%22%7D" target="_blank">plurality of people receive coverage from their employers.
column16: Baucus\u2019 endorsement of the idea speaks to just how dramatically the health policy debate has shifted within the Democratic Party in recent years \u2015 particularly since the 2016 presidential run of Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.)
column17: who made what he called \u201cMedicare for all\u201d a central issue of his campaign.
column18: Baucus was the subject of progressive frustration for his stewardship of the ACA
column19: also known as Obamacare. Critics argued that he held the bill in committee far too long in hopes of winning the support of moderate Republicans who did not end up voting for the final bill. The lengthy negotiation period he initiated gave Republicans much-needed time to mobilize opposition to reform
column20: according to Baucus\u2019 detractors.
column21: Obamacare itself relies on a hybrid model
column22: once favored by conservative policy experts
column23: that combines the creation of a new private
column24: individual insurance marketplace and an expansion of Medicaid.
column25: Given Baucus\u2019 history as a fiscal moderate active in the ACA\u2019s passage
column26: his positive remarks about single-payer could provide a boost to progressive activists agitating for its implementation.
column27: As Senate Finance Committee chairman
column28: Baucus ruled out consideration of single-payer from the beginning
column29: and declined to invite the testimony of single-payer advocates at hearings. The latter decision prompted disruptive protests from activists
column30: and Baucus later said that\xa0he regretted not engaging more with the policy\u2019s proponents.
column31: In September 2009
column32: Baucus also voted against two amendments that would have created a public health insurance option on the Obamacare individual insurance exchanges.
column33: Baucus kept single-payer off the table during the development of Obamacare because he believed the country was not ready for it at the time
column34: he told NBC News on Friday.\xa0
column35: \u201cI just think the time has come
column36: \u201d Baucus said. \u201cBack in \u201909
column37: we were not ready to address it. It would never have passed. Here we are nine years later
column38: I think it\u2019s time to hopefully have a very serious good faith look at it.\u201d
column39: Sen. Jon Tester\xa0(D-Mont.)
column40: a moderate who represented Montana alongside Baucus from 2007 to 2014
column41: also expressed openness to single-payer this week.
column42: \u201cMaybe it\u2019s something we should
column43: quite frankly
column44: take a solid look at
column45: \u201d Tester said Wednesday.
column46: Tester does not support single-payer legislation
column47: however. When Sen. Steve Daines (R-Mont.)
column48: aiming to put Democrats in an awkward political position
column49: introduced a trick amendment creating a single-payer system to the Obamacare repeal bill
column50: most Democratic senators voted \u201cpresent\u201d on the motion
column51: but Tester was one of four Democratic senators to vote \u201cno\u201d\xa0on it.
column52: Former Sen. Kent Conrad (D-N.D.) \u2015 a moderate who vehemently opposed creating a public health insurance option during the passage of Obamacare \u2015 told HuffPost that unlike Baucus
column53: he believes it is \u201cunlikely we will get a single-payer system in the foreseeable future.\u201d
column54: Single-payer is improbable
column55: Conrad argued
column56: because funding a federal health insurance program would cost taxpayers so much and because medical providers are so opposed to radically transforming the system.\xa0
column57: Instead
column58: he said
column59: the \u201cbest system combines universal coverage with private not-for-profit insurance with the government assisting those who cannot afford insurance.\u201d
column60: He also favors empowering Medicare to negotiate bulk discounts on prescription drugs
column61: just as the Veterans Affairs health care system does.
column62: In addition to Sanders\u2019 presidential run
column63: the collapse of Republican efforts to repeal Obamacare has increased grassroots energy behind single-payer as activists seek to go on the offensive. Progressive pressure groups like Credo have launched efforts to make support for the policy a litmus test for 2020\u2032s Democratic presidential candidates.
column64: Single-payer now has more support in Congress than at any other time in recent history. Single-payer legislation introduced by Rep. John Conyers (D-Mich.) has more co-sponsors than ever
column65: with the support of a majority of the House Democratic Caucus.
column66: Sanders plans to unveil a much-anticipated version of single-payer legislation next Wednesday. Sens. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.)
column67: a rumored 2020 presidential contender
column68: and Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) have already announced plans to co-sponsor the bill.
column69: Polling suggests that the idea of single-payer is popular with the public
column70: especially among Democrats. In a May 2016 Gallup poll
column71: 58 percent of Americans and 73 percent of Democrats said they supported replacing \u201cthe ACA with a federally funded healthcare program providing insurance for all Americans.\u201d\xa0
column72: Even elected Democrats who remain wary of single-payer have begun trying to capitalize on the ambitious proposal\u2019s popularity. The Congressional Hispanic Caucus\u2019 political action committee
column73: Bold PAC
column74: has repeatedly alluded to the \u201cMedicare for all\u201d fight in fundraising e-mails \u2015 even though half of the 30 CHC members have yet to actually endorse single-payer
column75: and the PAC does not make support for the policy a condition for its financial support.
column76: Of course
column77: \xa0it is much easier to talk about single-payer than to actually implement it. Replacing the current system with one large federal program would require a massive tax increase in exchange for what advocates believe would result in net cost reductions thanks to the government\u2019s considerable bargaining power.
column78: It would also force the nearly half of Americans who get insurance from their jobs to enroll in a new government program. Given the outcry that Obamacare elicited for canceling the plans of a fraction of that number of people
column79: enacting single-payer would likely prove an extraordinary political challenge.
column80: In the meantime
column82: the excitement around single-payer has already widened the spectrum of acceptable debate about health care.\xa0Expansions of coverage that once seemed radical now seem downright moderate by comparison. In August
column83: Sen. Brian Schatz (D-Hawaii) announced plans to introduce legislation allowing Americans of all ages and incomes to buy into Medicaid. And earlier this week
column84: Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) revealed his intention to introduce a bill creating a comparable universal buy-in option for Medicare
column85: which he said\xa0\u201cmay be the fastest way to a single-payer system.\u201d
column86: This article has been updated with comments from Tester and Conrad
column87:
as well as additional comments from Baucus.

'DACAmented' Teacher Explains Why America Needs Undocumented Educators

|[

Rio Djiwandana stared into the empty classroom during his prep period as he processed the morning\u2019s news.\xa0
column2: He felt frustrated and a little numb but also worried \u2015 not just for himself but for his students too.
column3: Djiwandana
column4: who\u2019s Indonesian-American
column5: is a Teach For America educator in New York who is enrolled under the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program. The Tuesday\xa0announcement\xa0that Trump would terminate DACA made the threat of deportation real for him and almost 800
column6: 000 other Dreamers who call the U.S. their home. For many
column7: it\u2019s the only home they\u2019ve ever known.\xa0
column8: But today
column9: the 22-year-old mulls over what would happen to his students if he were deported. The school year has just begun and he already has a lot on his mind.\xa0
column10: \u201cIt\u2019d be a very traumatic experience for the kids
column11: \u201d a concerned Djiwandana
column12: who teaches 8th grade math and special education classes in the Bronx
column13: \xa0told HuffPost.\xa0\u201cIt\u2019s one thing to have a teacher quit for personal reasons or for a teacher to get fired. But it\u2019s another thing for a teacher to be physically taken from the classroom or the school community.\u201d
column14: Djiwandana represents a significant number of DACA recipients
column15: or \u201cDACAmented\u201d people
column16: \xa0who have gone into the education field. More than a fifth of recipients are employed in educational and health services
column17: a survey showed.\xa0In fact
column18: Teach For America alone has employed nearly 200 Dreamers who have <a href="https://www.teachforamerica.org/top-stories/daca-dream-act-how-you-can-stand-tfa-dreamer-teachers-and-undocumented-students" target="_blank">served more than 10
column19: 000 students.\xa0
column20: Djiwandana\u2019s parents brought him to Los Angeles when he was 4 months old
column21: and like many immigrant parents
column22: they hoped their son would receive a good education and a stable future in America. Growing up
column23: the teacher didn\u2019t question his own status or background much. He didn\u2019t stick out as a person of color or an immigrant as his neighborhood was predominantly Asian and Latino. While his parents dropped hints about his status
column24: like dodging questions about going back to visit Indonesia
column25: he only discovered he was undocumented when applying for college financial aid.\xa0
column26: \u201cWhen I asked my parents for a lot of the forms
column27: which included a copy of a green card or an American passport
column28: they told me that we didn\u2019t have them
column29: \u201d Djiwandana
column30: a Georgetown University graduate
column31: explained. \u201cThat\u2019s when I figured out I was undocumented.\u201d
column32: Luckily
column33: his status wasn\u2019t a hindrance to his admission to the school or to receiving an appropriate financial aid package
column34: since the university provides services to undocumented students. He enrolled in DACA his freshman year and though it hadn\u2019t occurred to him at the time
column35: the program would end up being a lifeline for him as he prepared to enter the workforce.\xa0While there are still limitations on the jobs he is eligible to apply for
column36: \xa0the program has opened him up to several options and thankfully
column37: teaching in New York was one of them.\xa0
column38: \u201cI would honestly probably be chilling at home
column39: trying to get a job under the table
column40: \u201d he says.\xa0
column41: Djiwandana currently teaches in a public school that serves mostly low-income families of color. And in many schools in urban
column42: communities of color
column43: the teacher turnover rate is high.\xa0Across the country
column44: high-poverty
column45: high-minority urban schools are suffering with a turnover rate of almost 20 percent annually. And according to the National School Boards Association
column46: up to half of new teachers leave the profession within their first five years. Teacher turnover isn\u2019t cheap either.\xa0It could cost the nation\u2019s public schools more than $7.3 billion a year
column47: the National Commission On Teaching And America\u2019s Future indicated.\xa0
column48: DACAmented teachers
column49: particularly the ones in the TFA program
column50: often teach at these very urban institutions. And many of them want to be there. Djiwandana says that so many of the teachers can relate to their students\u2019 backgrounds. They\u2019ve lived it. He explained that many of his own pupils come from immigrant families like he does and often don\u2019t have college-educated parents. As a first-generation college student himself
column51: he\u2019s familiar with the added obstacles kids face when their families aren\u2019t proficient in the U.S. education system.\xa0
column52: In the classroom
column53: Djiwandana tries to explain the college application process to the students
column54: relaying how difficult the pathway can be when they don\u2019t personally know anyone who\u2019s gone through it. Other times
column55: he\u2019ll remind the pupils about how crucial it is to get homework help \u2015 whether it\u2019s from a teacher or someone in the community \u2015 if their parents are unable to assist them. He says that oftentimes these students simply lack access to pertinent information.
column56: He\u2019s there to help fill in the gaps.\xa0
column57: \u201cIt\u2019s similar things that I can relate to
column58: being a first-generation American or student from a low-income working class background
column59: \u201d he says
column60: \xa0explaining that his own parents weren\u2019t able to help him with algebra or other subjects growing up \u2015 not because they didn\u2019t want to but because they just didn\u2019t know how.\xa0
column61: Djiwandana adds that his background also helps him empathize with the pupils\u2019 emotional challenges\xa0\u2015 particularly during a time when he feels immigrants are under attack. Following the string of attempted crackdowns on\xa0legal and illegal immigration
column62: Djiwandana says his students have a pessimistic view of the administration. The students may not understand the specifics of their policies
column63: he says
column64: but they
column65: too
column66: feel the fear in their immigrant communities.\xa0
column67: The 22-year-old
column68: who renewed his DACA permit a few months ago
column69: told HuffPost it expires in 2019. While Trump allegedly told House Minority Leader\xa0Nancy Pelosi\xa0(D-Calif.) that he\u2019d support and sign the Dream Act
column70: which would give legal status to young undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children
column71: Djiwandana feels uncertain of what the future holds. However
column72: he believes it\u2019s important to be present for his students.\xa0
column73: \u201cI see a lot of myself in my students and partially because of that I think it\u2019s important for me to stay strong. But it\u2019s also important for me to be vulnerable and human so my students can also see themselves in me
column74: \u201d he says of the situation.\xa0
column75: But one thing Djiwandana knows for sure. Immigrants aren\u2019t so easily broken.\xa0
column76: \u201cThe immigrant community is super resilient. If there\u2019s one thing I\u2019m optimistic about
column77: it\u2019s that
column78:
\u201d he said. \u201cI have no doubt that documented and undocumented immigrants will find ways to fight back and hold leaders accountable.\u201d\xa0\xa0

]

'Going Back To Mexico Would Be Like Returning To Nothing': Dreamers Process DACA's End

|[

Yadira Alem\xe1n had gathered with her parents in front of the television in their home in Las Vegas on Tuesday when U.S. Attorney General Jeff Sessions made an announcement about the\xa0Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals\xa0program
column2: known as DACA.
column3: Surrounded by her family
column4: the 22-year-old business administration major learned the Trump administration was rescinding the Obama-era policy that provides two-year work visas and reprieve from deportation to so-called Dreamers \u2015 nearly 800
column5: 000 young undocumented immigrants like herself who had come to the U.S. as children.\xa0
column6: \u201cI have mixed feelings
column7: \u201d Alem\xe1n told HuffPost Mexico by phone after the announcement. \u201cBut I feel more anger
column8: because despite what we\u2019ve done
column9: they don\u2019t understand us. I think about DACA
column10: about the benefits it gave me to be able to continue my studies
column11: to be employed by a home loan business
column12: thanks to which I could buy a home for my parents who left Mexico City. And now what? We are in this limbo over what will happen to us.\u201d
column13: Isaac Montiel
column14: a 27-year-old student born in Puebla
column15: Mexico
column16: followed Sessions\u2019 announcement via social media while protesting outside the White House.
column17: Montiel co-chairs the\xa0CUNY Dreamers\xa0group and is one of 28 Dreamers on a four-day hunger strike. \u201cI am angry
column18: frustrated
column19: but I also want to continue fighting for a permanent solution from Congress
column20: \u201d he said.\xa0
column21: Individuals who currently have DACA protections will begin to lose their work permits in six months
column22: putting hundreds of thousands of young U.S. residents at risk of being sent away from the country they\u2019ve lived in since they were children \u2015 unless members of the U.S. House and Senate can agree on legislation to protect them.\xa0
column23: Mexico City-born Jos\xe9 Eduardo Morales
column24: who now lives in Utah
column25: wasn\u2019t surprised by the decision.\xa0\u201cI already knew what was going to happen
column26: but it was difficult to process
column27: \u201d Morales said. \u201cI felt a little disoriented
column28: defenseless
column29: uncertain. My permit is still valid for a year
column30: and right now I am completing a graduate degree in education.\u201d
column31: Morales said that while he can\u2019t travel to Washington D.C. to take part in protests
column32: he\u2019s using the tools at his disposal to support them. He says the\xa0U.S.-Mexico Foundation\xa0has advised Dreamers to stay on top of the news
column33: and that they\u2019re also staying connected through WhatsApp.\xa0
column34: \u201cThis is causing us emotional and physical stress
column35: \u201d he said
column36: \u201cbut I have two more years left to complete my studies and if I can complete them
column37: I will use my graduate degree here to help my community in many ways.\u201d
column38: Rebecca Vargas
column39: who co-chairs the\xa0U.S.-Mexico Foundation
column40: said dialogue and educating members of Congress will be crucial in the weeks and months ahead. \u201cThe only benefit of this announcement is that if we achieve something in Congress
column41: it should be permanent
column42: not temporary
column43: as DACA was
column44: \u201d she explained.\xa0
column45: Amid the insecurity about what lies ahead
column46: Dreamers have expressed a wide range of fears
column47: including whether they\u2019d be at risk of deportation and whether the U.S. government will make use of the data they provided when they applied for the program
column48: including their place of residence
column49: work or school.\xa0\xa0
column50: Eunice Rend\xf3n
column51: director of Agenda Migrante
column52: said that an additional worry is the Mexican government\u2019s lack of sufficient preparation for the possible return of these young people.
column53: \u201cMexico is not completely ready to receive [so many] of these young people. There are efforts and political willingness
column54: but I do not see a comprehensive return policy
column55: \u201d she explained. \u201cThat\u2019s why we have to be clear on the fact that U.S. legislators \u2015 who ultimately will be the ones to resolve these young people\u2019s current situation \u2015 can also be pressured via the media and social justice groups.\u201d
column56: Rend\xf3n also noted Dreamers\u2019 contributions to the U.S. economy \u2015 according to the Center for American Progress
column57: \xa0deporting Dreamers will result in a $460 billion loss to the U.S. GDP over the next 10 years.
column58: \u201cMore than 98 percent of them are bilingual
column59: 91 percent are formally employed
column60: and 70 percent have completed higher education
column61: Rend\xf3n said. They are the ideal citizen for any country! Trump may have a majority in Congress
column62: but we have not forgotten that there are many Republicans who have voted against his decisions.\u201d \xa0
column63: That\u2019s why Montiel did not await Session\u2019s announcement in New York
column64: where he lives
column65: but in Washington
column66: D.C.
column67: where he traveled to lend his voice to the chorus of protesters. \u201cWe are not giving up! Hopefully the Mexican government will announce their support for us. Thinking about returning [to Mexico] would be one of my last alternatives
column68: \u201d he said.\xa0
column69: Alem\xe1n echoed his sentiment. \u201cFor my family
column70: it would be very difficult to return to our country
column71: \u201d she acknowledged
column72: \u201cbut most of all for me
column73: who grew up in this country. Going back to Mexico would be like returning to nothing.\u201d
column74:
This story was first published by HuffPost Mexico. It has been translated into English and adapted for a U.S. audience.

column1: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/asian-queer-immigrant-daca_us_59b19e84e4b0b5e53104c574?utm_campaign=hp_fb_pages&utm_source=politics_fb&utm_medium=facebook&ncid=fcbklnkushpmg00000013&section=politics|<h1 class="headline__title">When You're Queer And Undocumented
column2:
The DACA Stakes Are Higher|[

When Tony Choi was in high school
column3: his friends would ask him why he didn\u2019t drive. He would evade the question with what he thought was the only plausible defense: He cared deeply about global warming
column4: he told them. Twelve years later
column5: he laughs at his attempt at that moral argument
column6: which was simply a cover-up for the fact that he\u2019s an undocumented immigrant and had no way of getting an ID.
column7: \u201cI learned to really hide myself
column8: \u201d Choi
column9: who\u2019s from Seoul
column10: South Korea
column11: and lives in New York
column12: \xa0told HuffPost. \u201cIt definitely didn\u2019t feel good. It made me scared. My sister would say
column13: \u2018If you stand out too much
column14: they\u2019ll take you away.\u2019\u201d
column15: These memories came back to Choi
column16: now 28
column17: on Tuesday
column18: when Attorney General Jeff Sessions announced President Donald Trump was nixing the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program
column19: ending protections for some 800
column20: 000 undocumented immigrants who came to the country as minors. The program
column21: originally enacted under former President Barack Obama and now in Congress\u2019 hands
column22: shielded young people from deportation and allowed them to work in the country legally.\xa0
column23: Besides being undocumented
column24: Choi is also gay. He points out there is more at stake for people who could be forced to go back to a country that isn\u2019t big on LGBTQ rights. He notes that\xa0military service is compulsory in South Korea\xa0for men \u2015 and the military penal code prohibits consensual same-sex acts. \xa0\xa0
column25: \u201cFor a lot of us
column26: going back to our home countries isn\u2019t an option because of our queerness
column27: \u201d he said. \u201cIf I were to go to Korea
column28: I would have to do the two-year mandatory service in the military
column29: and the law prohibits sodomy.\u201d
column30: Choi came to the U.S. from Seoul when he was 8 years old. His parents\u2019 lumber business had folded due to the global financial crisis
column31: he said. They lived in Hawaii for a year and eventually moved to Bergen County
column32: New Jersey. His father worked construction jobs and his mother worked as a restaurant server and in a nail salon.
column33: He remembers specific anecdotes that highlighted the fact he was undocumented
column34: though he said he didn\u2019t understand it at the time. He couldn\u2019t cross the border to the Canadian side of Niagara Falls during a family trip in fifth grade. And when it was time to take the PSAT and he asked his mother for his Social Security number
column35: she simply told him he didn\u2019t have one.
column36: As Choi got older
column37: his parents divorced and his mother suffered arthritis from her nail technician work. She\u2019s also a breast cancer survivor
column38: which meant she couldn\u2019t work for a sustained period of their family\u2019s life in the U.S.
column39: Before DACA
column40: Choi could only work cash-under-the-table jobs
column41: and he earned $5 an hour at a sushi takeout restaurant after college. He contributed what he could to his mom
column42: who was reliant on her children\u2019s salaries.\xa0
column43: \u201cEven if I don\u2019t get deported
column44: I\u2019m worried I\u2019ll be relegated to living that kind of life again
column45: \u201d Choi said.\xa0
column46: Currently
column47: his mother hasn\u2019t quite accepted the potential consequences of Tuesday\u2019s decision.
column48: \u201cMy mom says
column49: \u2018They wouldn\u2019t do this to you.\u2019 She cited examples of Trump saying he was sympathetic to our plight
column50: \u201d Choi told HuffPost. \u201cI say Trump didn\u2019t even have the courage to say he was rescinding DACA.\xa0He sent a surrogate \u2015 he sent Jefferson Beauregard Sessions III. Trump\u2019s not with us.\u201d\xa0
column51: Choi entered college in 2008 at a small school in Kentucky called Berea College. He received full tuition coverage as part of a pilot program for undocumented students.\xa0\xa0
column52: He said he felt grateful and enjoyed his time but felt like he was living a really singular experience without a community of other Asians
column53: and it was extremely isolating.\xa0Fear took a toll on his mental health.\xa0
column54: \u201cI heard about immigration raids. It started giving me nightmares
column55: \u201d he said. \u201cI grew up in Korea. Now I\u2019m in Kentucky
column56: where there weren\u2019t other Asians like me. I would have panic attacks and nightmares about ICE raiding my door.\u201d
column57: He said he finally started opening up to school leaders and friends
column58: asking for help and also spreading awareness about what he was facing.\xa0
column59: \u201cWhat I didn\u2019t realize I was doing was organizing
column60: \u201d he said. \u201cI was essentially the first immigrant rights organizer at my school.\u201d
column61: He said he connected with other immigrant groups in Kentucky after that and really \u201ccame out\u201d as undocumented in 2011 at a conference in Memphis.\xa0
column62: Choi now works as a social media manager for 18 Million Rising
column63: an Asian-American/Pacific Islander\xa0activism community. Prior to that
column64: he was an organizer with the Women\u2019s March. He points out that issues related to immigration
column65: queer
column66: women and minority rights are all related
column67: \xa0and that more people should be aware of that.\xa0
column68: \u201cA lot of times when people think about immigration
column69: there\u2019s a stereotypical immigrant in their minds
column70: \u201d he said. \u201cThere are undocumented folks from all corners of the planet living in the U.S. We don\u2019t follow the exact same story. We\u2019re not here for all the same reasons. But we\u2019re fighting the common fight. We\u2019re struggling all together.\u201d
column71: While the pool of DACA applications is made mostly of youth from Latin American countries
column72: Asian-Americans account for about 11 percent of those eligible for the immigration program. Within that group
column73: fewer than 30 percent of eligible Asian applicants apply.
column74: Those able to apply before Tuesday\u2019s decision included undocumented minors who were brought to the U.S. before their 16th birthday and met another set of guidelines related to education and criminal background
column75: among other requirements. In 2016
column76: Asian countries \u2015 namely South Korea
column77: China
column78: India and the Philippines \u2015 were among the top 10 countries of origin for DACA-eligible populations.\xa0
column79: Yet Asians don\u2019t speak out much about it.\xa0As an activist
column80: Choi is attuned to the many reasons why. He pointed out there\u2019s a litany of factors.
column81: \u201cAsian nonprofits might not be as good at outreach
column82: even though there are organizations doing wonderful work
column83: \u201d he said. \u201cResources are often not being pooled into Asian groups. We\u2019re isolated. We haven\u2019t come to terms with the fact that immigration is our issue. There\u2019s also always been a sense of shame.\u201d
column84: Undocumented Asian immigrants are now outpacing Mexicans in many areas of the country
column85: with Chinese
column86: South Koreans and Indians among the fastest growing segments.\xa0
column87: Jo-Ann Yoo
column88: executive director of the Asian American Federation
column89: told HuffPost that there is little infrastructure in terms of resources
column90: nonprofits and politicians in place to help Asians navigate the process. She cited nonprofit National Korean American Service & Education Consortium<em>
column91: which made DACA one of its primary issues and educated the Korean community on applying
column92: as a type of organization that other Asian ethnicities would benefit from but might not have access to.\xa0
column93: \u201cThis was their constant push
column94: \u201d she said. \u201cThere was a lot of education and making sure people were not afraid. They engaged people for a sustained period.\u201d
column95: For DACA recipients
column96: ending the program would mean they are now at risk of not being able to work in the U.S. and could face deportation
column97: but LGBTQ DACA recipients also face the prospect of going to countries that may not be as tolerant.
column98: Sharita Gruberg
column99: an associate director of the LGBT Research and Communications Project at the Center for American Progress
column100: told HuffPost it\u2019s not only deportation that presents a threat \u2015\xa0immigrants also face dangers while being detained.\xa0LGBTQ individuals are more than\xa0two times\xa0as likely than the general population to be sexually assaulted in confinement
column101: \xa0according to the Bureau of Justice Statistics.
column102: \u201cWe\u2019ve been\xa0documenting\xa0the horrific abuse LGBTQ people face in immigration detention since 2013 and conditions have only\xa0worsened\xa0under Trump
column103: \u201d\xa0Gruberg said.
column104: Choi said that because of these threats
column105: new leadership has arisen out of necessity\xa0\u2015 and that the LGBTQ community has really stepped up. \u201cWe\u2019re all pretty devastated
column106: \u201d he said. \u201cAt the same time you see more queer people taking up leadership positions. We face marginalization in multiple corners \u2015 there\u2019s only so many times before you speak out.\u201d
column107: Choi ultimately remains undeterred and he knows he has to continue to help leading a movement.\xa0
column108: \u201cIt\u2019s always a factor looming in the back of my mind. If I were to go back to Korea
column109:
\xa0what would I do? How would I fit in?\u201d he said. \u201cBut I am determined to stay because this is my home. \u201d\xa0\xa0

Drug Overdoses Are Killing A Lot More People Than HIV Or Guns At Their Worst

|[

More than 64
column2: 000 Americans died of drug overdoses\xa0last year
column3: according to the first government report to include all recorded drug deaths from 2016. That\u2019s up 22 percent from the roughly 52
column4: 000 overdose deaths in 2015.
column5: The current 64
column6: 070 count may even turn out to be a bit low.\xa0The numbers for last year are still provisional
column7: since the cause of death in some cases remains under investigation. The report
column8: which was issued earlier this month by the National Center for Health Statistics in conjunction with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column9: will be updated
column10: with final figures released in December.
column12: drug overdose deaths had already far outstripped firearm homicides and HIV deaths during their peak deadliest years. As of 2016
column13: overdoses also overtook the worst death toll from car accidents.\xa0
column14: Fentanyl
column15: a synthetic opioid that\u2019s 50 times more potent than heroin and 100 times stronger than morphine
column16: plays a notable role in the deadly surge.\xa0Deaths from fentanyl and other synthetic opioids more than doubled between 2015 and 2016
column17: from about 10
column18: 000 to <a href="https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/health_policy/monthly-drug-overdose-death-estimates.pdf" target="_blank">more than 20
column20: Anecdotal reports
column21: including of\xa0overstuffed morgues\xa0in St. Louis and more organ donations from people who died of overdoses\xa0in New England
column22: suggest that the epidemic isn\u2019t subsiding this year.\xa0
column23: \u201cDeath rates from opioid overdose will continue to rise until we implement a comprehensive strategy to reduce harms and expand treatment for opioid use disorder using effective medications
column24: \u201d Dr. Peter Friedmann
column25: associate dean for research at the University of Massachusetts Medical School and chief research officer at the nonprofit Baystate Health
column26: told HuffPost in August.
column27: Also last month
column28: President Donald Trump\u2019s opioid commission
column29: headed by New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie (R)
column30: urged the Trump administration to take a series of actions to address the growing crisis
column31: including improving access to medication-assisted treatment for addiction and making the overdose reversal drug naloxone more widely available.\xa0
column32:
So far the administration hasn\u2019t taken any significant steps to make those recommendations a reality.\xa0

column1: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/trump-conservatives-paul-ryan-fault_us_59b1c937e4b0354e4410bd4a?utm_campaign=hp_fb_pages&utm_source=politics_fb&utm_medium=facebook&ncid=fcbklnkushpmg00000013&section=politics|<h1 class="headline__title">Who Do Conservatives Blame For Donald Trump's Bad Deal? Paul Ryan
column2:
Of Course!|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 President Donald Trump made a bad deal for Republicans on the debt limit and government funding
column3: and
column4: according to House conservatives
column5: that\u2019s Speaker Paul Ryan\u2019s fault.
column6: What?
column7: A day after Trump surprised his own party by taking the first offer from congressional Democrats to raise the debt ceiling and continue government spending for three months
column8: many House conservatives have decided that House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wisc.) is ultimately to blame for Trump\u2019s impulsive deal.
column9: \u201cLack of preparation leads to poor choices
column10: and the fact that we weren\u2019t here \u2015 and you heard me say this the other night \u2015 we weren\u2019t here for six weeks
column11: the longest non-election-year break we\u2019ve had in a decade
column12: \u201d former Freedom Caucus Chairman Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) said Thursday
column13: \u201cthat\u2019s a problem.\u201d
column14: Asked if Trump had effectively stepped in front of a bullet for Ryan by taking the blame for a bad deal that the speaker would have largely taken the responsibility for if the president had just stayed out of negotiations
column15: Jordan said he wasn\u2019t here to blame anybody. \u201cWhat I\u2019m saying is we should have done what we had said back in July
column16: \u201d Jordan answered. \u201cWe should have stayed here and put together a debt ceiling plan.\u201d
column17: Obviously
column18: Ryan has a lot of blame for a congressional recess
column19: though the majority leader also has a say in the congressional schedule. But Jordan added that when lawmakers fail to prepare for deadlines
column20: they don\u2019t have the best options come decision time.
column21: That\u2019s not an unfair argument
column22: but it ignores an obvious reality: This deal that Trump struck with Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) was a deal that Trump struck
column23: not Ryan.
column24: But time and again Thursday
column25: conservatives ignored Trump\u2019s role in the agreement and found a way to blame the speaker.
column26: \u201cI think he saw the same-old
column27: same-old kind of crap coming from leadership
column28: and that wasn\u2019t good enough
column29: \u201d Rep. Paul Gosar (R-Ariz.) said of Trump
column30: theorizing that the president was effectively preserving the debt limit issue until December.
column31: As much as Gosar defended the president
column32: he couldn\u2019t find an adequate reason to vote for the bill \u2015 he said he plans to oppose the package when it comes before the House \u2015 but Gosar noted he could see how this deal works to Trump\u2019s favor if the president plays his hand right.
column33: That part seems unlikely. Lawmakers have repeatedly noted in the last two days that Trump just set a precedent that will be tough for him to break: He supported raising the debt ceiling without concessions
column34: and he has agreed to fund the government without demanding money for his border wall.
column35: Even Gosar acknowledged that Trump has made his negotiating position more difficult. \u201cHe may have lost that credibility
column36: \u201d Gosar said. \u201cBut time will tell.\u201d
column37: Still
column38: conservatives generally refused to blame Trump for a deal that most of them believe to be bad for Republicans. Many said they couldn\u2019t answer questions until actually seeing the text of the deal. Many outright refused to answer questions.
column39: \u201cI\u2019m not going to talk about whether Donald Trump or Paul Ryan did a good or bad job
column40: \u201d said Rep. Mo Brooks of Alabama.
column41: And many others made tenuous connections between the deal and Paul Ryan.
column42: \u201cI just see that the leadership team signed off on it and the rest of us find out about it
column43: \u201d said Rep. Steve King (R-Iowa). King noted that Ryan and other GOP leaders didn\u2019t ever offer a conservative alternative to a clean increase in the debt ceiling \u2015 again
column44: an argument that isn\u2019t wrong but somehow ignores the fact that Trump jumped at the chance for a clean debt limit.
column45: Rep. Louie Gohmert (R-Texas) conveyed that he was disappointed in the deal. But even after he was presented with the argument that Ryan had called the Democratic offer \u201cridiculous\u201d Wednesday morning shortly before Trump took the offer
column46: Gohmert said Ryan may actually have been a proponent of the deal. \u201cWe don\u2019t know if he was or not
column47: \u201d the congressman said.
column48: Moderates generally welcomed Trump\u2019s deal
column49: noting that the president had effectively cut out the Freedom Caucus from negotiations. \u201cTo me
column50: the main positive of this deal is we\u2019re not gonna have one group of 30 or 40 have veto power
column51: \u201d Rep. Peter King (R-N.Y.) said. \u201cWe can\u2019t allow a group of 30 or 40 to be setting policy for the House of Representatives.\u201d
column52: But as much as moderates were celebrating the compromised position of conservatives
column53: conservatives were muted in their criticism \u2015 at least of Trump
column54: who many believe is the key to overthrowing Ryan.
column55: Conservatives have quietly been laying the groundwork for a coup against Ryan
column56: pointing out with increasing frequency that the speaker had no plan to extract GOP concessions on the debt ceiling or a continuing resolution. But it\u2019s difficult to argue that this legislation is really Ryan\u2019s fault when Trump got out in front of it.
column57: Republicans have spun Trump\u2019s decision as one recognizing that Democrats were going to win this negotiation
column58: so better to just \u201cclear the decks\u201d and perhaps allow Congress to focus on tax reform. But even that explanation is fraught. The short-term nature of the deal ensures that lawmakers will be focused on negotiating a broader deal in December
column59: not just cutting taxes.
column60: Ryan\u2019s own defense of the agreement is that Trump saw a nation recovering from one hurricane and preparing for another
column61: and he wanted a bipartisan moment rather than a protracted disagreement. That argument may work for some
column62: but Trump has put Republicans in a bind for future negotiations
column63: and he did so with little to no consultation from congressional leaders or his legislative affairs staff
column64: according to one senior GOP aide familiar with discussions.
column65: And if Trump himself wanted to preserve his conservative credentials and damage Paul Ryan
column66: he just went ahead and did the exact opposite. The question is whether that will matter to the far-right lawmakers who already seem to be plotting Ryan\u2019s fall.
column67: When Gosar was asked Thursday if he still supports Ryan as speaker
column68: he repeatedly answered that he hadn\u2019t said \u201cone way or another.\u201d
column69: Asked if he would welcome Ryan campaigning for him
column70: Gosar answered that he didn\u2019t have a challenger. Asked whether he would let Ryan even fundraise for him
column71: Gosar said he didn\u2019t know about that
column72:
noting that Ryan was \u201cvery unpopular\u201d in his district.

Hurricane Harvey Is Just The Latest In Facebook’s Fake News Problem

|[

As the rain started falling in Houston
column2: the anonymous authors went to work.
column3: Writing under pseudonyms and hiding behind the pretense of satire
column4: they churned out lies
column5: dressed them up as news
column6: and then let Facebook\u2019s platform do their dirty work
column7: spreading their deliberate falsehoods far and wide.
column8: As a result
column9: millions of people were exposed to \u2015 and believed \u2015 false stories like this one
column10: headlined: \u201cBlack Lives Matter Thugs Blocking Emergency Crews From Reaching Hurricane Victims.\u201d (The opposite was actually true: BLM Houston has been actively collecting and distributing aid and helping recovery efforts.)
column11: One website alone
column12: \xa0\u201cFlash American News
column13: \u201d spread that narrative to more than 1 million people via Facebook. Numerous other similar websites also shared their own versions via the social media network
column14: selling the lie by using photos taken from other totally unrelated stories.
column15: While some might readily recognize the story as fake
column16: plenty who encountered it on Facebook sure didn\u2019t.
column17: \u201cThese hoodlums need to go away for a long time!\u201d One commenter wrote after the story was shared on the \u201cfanclubtrump\u201d\xa0Facebook page. \u201cMake them regret what they are doing keeping hurt
column18: innocent people from getting help is dispicable!\u201d [sic]
column19: \u201cThis is absolutely despicable!!!!\u201d another user added. \u201cTell me please how does this help anything or anybody! All it does is show the world that these people are heartless
column20: uncaring
column21: sorry excuses of what a human being should be!!!\u201d
column22: Though the story is fake
column23: its impact in the real world is not.
column24: Similar disinformation campaigns singled out other groups frequently targeted by conservative media and the so-called \u201calt-right
column25: \u201d shaping real-world opinions with fake stories spread unchecked on Facebook.\xa0
column26: Muslims were also accused in several fake stories of refusing to let Harvey victims seek shelter in mosques. (Again
column27: the opposite is true: Houston-area mosques opened their doors to thousands
column28: even as Joel Osteen\u2019s 16
column29: 800-seat megachurch drew criticism for remaining closed.) \xa0
column30: The imam pictured in the fake story above lives in Canada and says he\u2019s never even been to Texas.
column31: Nevertheless
column32: a version distributed via DailyPostFeed.com (other sites also shared other variants) was shared to 795
column33: 680 people via Facebook.\xa0
column34: Another highly-circulated fake story claimed that flooding during Hurricane Harvey somehow \u201cuncovered\u201d a huge cache of weapons and ammo apparently hidden there by the Obama administration
column35: for the purposes of staging a coup to return to power.
column36: While the above website\xa0claims to be satire
column37: it does little to announce that to visitors. Per CrowdTangle
column38: the above story was shared to 769
column39: 377 people on Facebook.
column40: The Clinton Foundation was also (falsely) accused of sending water to Houston and charging\xa0$7 per bottle for it.
column41: Misinformation on the internet is hardly a new or even rare occurrence. But one common thread here is Facebook.
column42: The social media network has enabled the rapid spread of deliberate
column43: harmful falsehoods.
column44: As of now
column45: the company is apparently unwilling to do much to stop the spread of deliberate misinformation.
column46: In response to outcry over similar disinformation campaigns during the 2016 election
column47: \xa0Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg\xa0dismissed as \u201cpretty crazy\u201d the idea that fake news on his site could have influenced the election\u2019s outcome. The company\u2019s COO Sheryl Sandberg agreed.
column48: Nevertheless
column49: Facebook calmed some critics by rolling out a system months later to flag questionable sources of information\xa0as \u201cdisputed\u201d and reconfiguring its \u201ctrending topics\u201d module. Judging by the rampant spread of the above stories
column50: however
column51: deeper problems remain.
column52: On Wednesday
column53: Facebook representatives acknowledged to congressional investigators that <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/facebook-says-likely-russian-based-operation-spent-money-on-political-ads_us_59b07007e4b0354e440f2778">the company sold around $100
column54: 000 worth of ads\xa0during the 2016 election to a Russian content farm known for producing pro-Kremlin messages
column55: along with what Facebook itself described as \u201cdivisive social and political messages.\u201d
column56:
CORRECTION: Several different photographs accompanied fake news articles about mosques in Texas. An earlier version of this article used a photo of an imam who is not the one who lives in Canada. The photo has been replaced.

These Floridians Survived Hurricane Andrew. Now They Must Prepare For Irma's Fury.

|[

MIAMI \u2014 Ralph Henderson felt the foundation of his house shifting under his feet. It was the last week of August 1992
column2: and Hurricane Andrew was pummeling South Florida with 165 mile per hour winds.
column3: As Andrew\u2019s winds and rains repeatedly slammed into his house
column4: Henderson watched as his roof began to peel off.
column5: Then suddenly the wind died. The eye of the hurricane was passing over Henderson\u2019s home. When he went outside to survey the devastation
column6: he had a hard time accepting what he saw. Across the road
column7: a 24-foot moving truck was perched perfectly on the roof of what had been a U-Haul store.
column8: \u201cIt was up there for months because no one could get it down
column9: \u201d Henderson
column11: told HuffPost.
column12: Now Hurricane Irma
column13: which has battered Caribbean islands with winds even stronger than Andrew\u2019s
column14: appears to be coming to crush the Florida coast. Henderson knows exactly what to expect.
column15: \u201cWe know that pretty much everything is going to be destroyed
column16: \u201d Henderson said. \u201cThe trees are going to be gone
column17: that fence is going to be gone. My boat might be gone. Anything left outside is going to be gone.\u201d
column18: Andrew killed 44 Floridians and caused an estimated $25 billion in damage across the state
column19: where it flattened more than 25
column20: 000 homes and damaged at least 100
column21: 000 more. Few communities suffered worse than Country Walk
column22: where the storm destroyed up to 90 percent of its 1
column23: 700 homes.
column24: Today
column25: the quaint town that sits about 25 miles southwest of Miami is home to 18
column26: 000 people \u2015 more than twice the number who lived there when Andrew hit. Concrete and stucco single-family homes with rust-colored clay tile roofs line the Country Walk area\u2019s leafy streets.
column27: Florida\u2019s \u201cinadequate building codes\u201d were responsible for the depth of Andrew\u2019s damage to areas like Country Walk
column28: a Dade County grand jury report stated in the months after the storm. For Natalie Geisman
column3: the hardest part about dealing with the hurricane about to hit her city is waiting for it to be over.
column4: She and her husband live in Deerfield Beach
column5: Florida
column6: about four miles from the ocean on the southeastern coastline. The storm\u2019s trajectory is unpredictable
column7: but they\u2019ve done everything they can to prepare: shopped for extra food
column8: stocked up on medicines
column9: and checked to make sure their independent living facility is equipped with a generator and hurricane-proof doors and windows.
column10: But still
column11: there\u2019s a lingering sense of vulnerability.
column12: \u201cThis one\u2019s scaring the hell out of me
column13: \u201d Geisman said in a telephone interview on Friday. She dreads waiting out the next several days
column14: and she\u2019s worried that if the electricity does fail
column15: she\u2019ll have to navigate four floors of stairs with her walker. But Geisman
column16: like many of the elderly residents who live in her building
column17: feels like she doesn\u2019t have much of a choice.
column18: \u201cWe\u2019re all senior citizens
column19: we have walkers
column20: electric scooters
column21: you know
column22: we were all told to stay in our apartments. We have no place to go
column23: \u201d Geisman said.
column24: With 5.2 million residents over the age of 60
column25: Florida\u2019s percentage of senior citizens ranks among the highest in the country. And many of Florida\u2019s elderly residents are concentrated near the southern coast
column26: where Hurricane Irma is expected to make landfall over the weekend.
column27: With winds forecasted to reach 150 miles per hour by the time it hits Florida
column28: Hurricane Irma has already killed at least 20 people
column29: destroying power lines and buildings as it rages through the Caribbean. It is expected to cause unprecedented levels of damage in Florida
column30: a state that has already been hit by major hurricanes.
column31: Preparing for a natural disaster of this scale presents a challenge for anyone \u2015 but senior citizens can face additional obstacles. They\u2019re more likely to deal with physical impairments that limit mobility
column32: to require medical devices that require electricity
column33: and to suffer from dementia
column34: making it difficult to plan ahead or respond to a rapidly escalating situation.
column35: A 2012 study found that nursing home residents with dementia who were evacuated during a hurricane faced increased rates of hospitalization
column36: morbidity and mortality in the months that followed. Even in non-disaster situations
column37: traveling can disrupt an individual\u2019s sleeping and eating patterns \u2015 \u201call these changes are amplified when you have a highly chaotic situation
column38: \u201d Lisa Brown
column39: the study\u2019s lead author
column40: explained in an interview.
column41: Florida\u2019s care for its elderly community during natural disasters is the \u201cgold standard
column42: \u201d Brown said. \u201cIf you\u2019re going to be struck with something like this
column43: I think Florida nursing homes are really ahead of the curve.\u201d
column44: Nursing centers in Florida are required to have an emergency preparedness plan that is approved by local government officials responsible for emergency planning. The Florida Health Care Association
column45: an advocacy group that represents 82 percent of the state\u2019s nursing centers
column46: has been holding daily phone calls to brief facilities on the hurricane. The state has a reporting system that allows nursing facilities to share the number of beds they have available for evacuees.
column47: Guillermo Someillan
column48: the owner My New Oasis
column49: an assisted living facility in Miami
column50: said he has two other facilities within driving distance that he and staff members can evacuate residents to if necessary. \u201cWe might have to get out and push tree limbs aside
column51: \u201d to travel across the roads
column52: he acknowledged.
column53: Someillan\u2019s main facility is just outside of the mandatory evacuation zone
column54: so for now
column55: he is focused on keeping his residents
column56: some of whom have mild dementia
column57: happy. He recently turned off the news and switched the televisions to show comedies instead. \u201cI don\u2019t want them to dwell on the worst-case scenario
column58: \u201d he said.
column59: Senior citizens who live on their own can be even more vulnerable during natural disasters than those in nursing homes or assisted living communities. People who want to evacuate but require assistance can register in advance with the Florida Special Needs Registry \u2015 but they aren\u2019t guaranteed a spot
column60: and not everyone who needs assistance knows how to access it.
column61: Florida\u2019s Department of Elder Affairs has a list of people enrolled in state
column62: local
column63: or community programs for senior citizens. As of Thursday
column64: staff members had finished calling everyone on the list
column65: making sure they have what they need to get through the hurricane.
column66: But several of the resource centers that provide transportation
column67: food and medical services to the elderly have already closed
column68: leaving senior citizens largely on their own for the next several days. For those who live in buildings without generators
column69: electricity cuts would mean stifling heat and no elevator to get them downstairs.
column70: Edith Lederberg
column71: the executive director of the Aging and Disability Resource Center of Broward County
column72: has spent the past several days arranging for seniors in the community to receive extra food deliveries from Meals on Wheels in preparation for the storm.
column73: Lederberg has worked at ADRC for more than 40 years
column74: so she knows better than most the needs and concerns of the community. \u201cIt\u2019s a vulnerable population. People get very lonely and frightened
column75:
\u201d she said.

Obama Official Who Created DACA Sues Trump To Protect It

|[

ANAHEIM
column2: Calif. \u2015 Former Department of Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano sued the Trump administration on Friday to block it from taking work authorization and deportation protections away from hundreds of thousands of undocumented immigrants.
column3: The lawsuit
column4: which she filed in her capacity as president of the University of California system along with the regents
column5: \xa0is in part personal to Napolitano \u2015 she created the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program
column6: which Trump is now phasing out
column7: in 2012. But she said on Friday that her bigger interest \u201clies with the young people whose futures are now being put in doubt and doing all we can to support and protect those young people.\u201d
column8: There are roughly 4
column9: 000 undocumented immigrants who attend schools in the University of California system
column10: and Napolitano said on a call with reporters that a large proportion of them have DACA protections \u2015 so-called Dreamers. The state\u2019s university system also employs undocumented teachers
column11: healthcare workers and other staff.
column12: The lawsuit alleges that Trump\u2019s decision to rescind the program violates the Administrative Procedure Act and constitutional due process
column13: including that of students at University of California schools and the system itself.
column14: \u201cThe administration\u2019s approach in rescinding DACA was the opposite of reasoned decision-making and thus is unlawful
column15: \u201d Napolitano said. \u201cIt did not assess the costs of rescinding DACA to the hundreds of thousands of Dreamers or to the schools and communities in which they live
column16: study and work.\u201d
column17: The lawsuit comes on the heels of a complaint by 15 states and the District of Columbia and a challenge by a former recipient of the program. All are aiming to prevent Trump from ending DACA protections.
column18: Napolitano\u2019s lawsuit alleges that the Trump administration illegally neglected to follow rules outlined in the Administrative Procedure Act
column19: which would have required more notice and a public comment period before making such a far-reaching change. Napolitano said that the situation was distinct from the creation of DACA
column20: which did not go through a public comment period
column21: because the program involved case-by-case determinations about prosecutorial discretion
column22: while Trump\u2019s decision will hit recipients en masse.
column23: \u2033[Rescinding DACA] doesn\u2019t involve discretion at all
column24: \u201d Napolitano said. \u201cIt says that for this whole category of cases the administration will not exercise discretion and will not defer deportations. So it deals with this population and a whole category
column25: not individuals.\u201d
column26: She said that DACA is also distinct from the Deferred Action for Parents of Americans and Lawful Permanent Residents program
column27: or DAPA
column28: which was blocked in the courts because of a lawsuit that alleged
column29: in part
column30: that the Obama administration violated the Administrative Procedure Act in creating it.
column31: Friday\u2019s lawsuit also argues that the Trump administration violated the due process rights of DACA recipients
column32: which are protected by the Fifth Amendment
column33: by \u201cexecutive fiat.\u201d
column34: Those arguments also form part of the two other legal challenges to the termination of DACA filed in New York shortly after the Trump administration announced it would phase out the signature immigration reform of the Obama years.
column35: One of those cases was originally filed in Brooklyn last year by DACA recipient Mart\xedn Jonathan Batalla Vidal. He had challenged the revocation of his three-year work authorization after the program\u2019s expansion was blocked by a federal judge in Texas
column36: along with a farther-reaching program to shield undocumented parents of U.S. citizens from deportation. Lawyers in the Batalla Vidal case requested to amend their lawsuit to challenge the termination of DACA within hours of the Trump administration\u2019s announcement on Tuesday. \xa0
column37: A coalition of 15 states and the District of Columbia
column38: led by New York
column39: filed a second lawsuit\xa0on Wednesday aimed at keeping DACA alive.
column40: Both of the New York lawsuits allege that Trump\u2019s decision to end DACA was motivated by an intent to discriminate against Mexicans
column41: citing the vitriolic statements aimed at Mexican immigrants that he made repeatedly on the campaign trail. Napolitano\u2019s lawsuit does not include that claim.
column42: Democratic California Attorney General Xavier Becerra plans to file a fourth lawsuit in federal court in his home state disputing the decision to end DACA. \xa0
column43: The president has broad authority to undue the executive actions of previous administrations. But similar legal challenges largely blocked Trump\u2019s efforts to restrict virtually all visits from several Muslim-majority countries earlier this year.
column44: Whether or not the lawsuits are ultimately successful
column45: they open the possibility that one or more federal judges could issue an injunction that would halt the termination of DACA while the cases wind their way through the legal system.
column46: Trump has said he wants to work with Congress on a legislative solution for Dreamers in the six month window before many begin to lose their work permits and protections. Napolitano said she plans to continue to press members of Congress to solve the bill through law
column47: even as she fights to maintain DACA in court.
column48: \u201cI believe that in this case the court should act
column49: \u201d Napolitano said
column50:
\u201cor in the alternative Congress should act and settle this matter for once and for all.\u201d

column16: will vote with Trump even when it goes against years of GOP rhetoric on fiscal responsibility.
column17: The deal
column18: at first glance
column19: isn\u2019t a big one. Government funding is extended for three months
column20: and the debt ceiling is raised until December
column21: at which point Treasury could once again use \u201cextraordinary measures\u201d to keep making payments without raising the debt limit.
column22: But the agreement sets up a spending showdown in early December
column23: when lawmakers will once again have to act to avert a shutdown. Bigger than what the agreement worked out between Trump
column24: Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) actually does
column25: however
column26: is the precedent it sets. Trump and Republicans are willing to fund the government without a border wall
column27: and they will raise the debt ceiling without any sort of spending reforms.
column28: That is a big victory for Democrats in Washington
column29: and that is why Republican opposition to this Harvey aid bill ballooned after the Senate amended the legislation to include a continuing resolution and a debt ceiling increase. (Earlier this week
column30: the House approved a roughly $8 billion package for Harvey victims by a vote of 419-3
column31: with the three \u201cno\u201d votes coming from Republicans who wanted to see spending offsets for the aid
column32: and then the Senate passed the amended bill 80-17 on Thursday
column33: attaching the CR and debt ceiling provisions at the behest of Trump and adding another $7 billion in community redevelopment funds.)
column34: Ultimately
column35: even with the new provisions
column36: 133 Republicans joined 183 Democrats to approve the bill.
column37: Even as raw of a deal as it was for Republicans who wanted to see some reforms on spending
column38: there was some political peril in opposing the revised legislation.
column39: The Harvey aid provisions are popular with voters
column40: and Democratic strategists believe a number of Republicans who could have tough races in 2018 \u2015 like Kevin Yoder (R-Kan.)
column41: Peter Roskam (R-Ill.) and Duncan Hunter (R-Calif.) \u2015 made a mistake by opposing the bill.
column42: \u201cVulnerable House Republicans voting against relief for American families still reeling from Hurricane Harvey would be reckless and cruel on its own
column43: but the fact that it was also a vote for a government shutdown and defaulting on America\u2019s debt gives new meaning to the word irresponsible
column44: \u201d Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee spokesman Tyler Law told HuffPost. \u201cIf you want to understand why Americans are disgusted by Republicans in Congress
column45: look no further than this vote.\u201d
column46: One constituency that did get behind the bill was Texas Republicans.
column47: After 23 out of 24 Texas Republicans voted against aid for Hurricane Sandy
column48: citing unrelated spending provisions they didn\u2019t like
column49: only four Texas Republicans voted against aid for Harvey: Joe Barton
column50: Jeb Hensarling
column51: Sam Johnson and Mac Thornberry.
column52: You can take a look at every member who voted for and against the bill here.
column53:
The bill now goes to the president\u2019s desk for his signature.
