Meet The Woman Who Could Be Texas' First Latina In Congress

|[

EL PASO \u2015\xa0Ask a Texan about El Paso
column2: the colorful desert town on the southwest tip of the state that shares a border with Ju\xe1rez
column3: Mexico
column4: and you might hear one of several unearned nicknames: \u201cEl Pass-through.\u201d \u201cEl Pisshole.\u201d \u201cThe anus of Texas.\u201d
column5: People who live in El Paso cannot fathom why the rest of Texas so loathes their friendly city
column6: which regularly<a href="https://www.texastribune.org/2013/02/05/el-paso-again-ranked-countrys-safest-city/" target="_blank">\xa0tops lists of the safest in America
column7: \xa0despite feeling like the last true vestige of the \u201cWild West.\u201d\xa0Locals speculate that it\u2019s because the city has a Hispanic name
column8: but so does San Antonio. El Paso is also a blue island in a blood red state \u2015 nearly 70 percent of the city voted for Hillary Clinton \u2015 but the same is true for Austin
column9: the beloved state capitol.
column10: It seems more likely that El Paso\u2019s public image problem has to do with its role as a junction
column11: one that joins the U.S. to Mexico. At a time when President Donald Trump is campaigning to build a wall between the two nations
column12: El Paso is a bridge.
column13: Veronica Escobar wants to be the woman to change people\u2019s perceptions of El Paso
column14: and the border more broadly.\xa0The gregarious
column15: irreverent 47-year-old Mexican-American announced in late August that she is running in the Democratic primary to replace U.S. Rep. Beto O\u2019Rourke\u2019s (D-Texas) as he vacates the seat to challenge Republican Ted Cruz for Senate. If successful
column16: she would be the first Latina Texas has ever elected to Congress \u2015 a surprising milestone
column17: given that the state is 40 percent Latino. \xa0\xa0
column18: But Escobar is more interested in being a voice for El Paso and immigrant rights than breaking a glass ceiling.
column19: \u201cEl Paso is in my blood; it\u2019s in my DNA
column20: \u201d she told HuffPost. \u201cI love our geography in the middle of the desert
column21: that we\u2019re isolated from other areas and having to make do. I love our position on the U.S.-Mexico border. I love that we\u2019ve always been the underdog. I just love this community so much that even without Donald Trump
column22: I\u2019m inspired by El Paso.\u201d
column23: The Friday night before announcing her run for Congress
column24: Escobar gathered with a half-dozen of her campaign volunteers in the empty lobby of an artful terra-cotta low-rise building in downtown El Paso
column25: Texas. She\u2019d brought together a diverse cadre of supporters
column26: including a young gay couple whose wedding she officiated and the 27-year-old high school civics teacher who taught her her son and daughter.
column27: Escobar\u2019s campaign manager was trying to give the team a rehearsal for the event the next day
column28: but the candidate was too excited to take the moment seriously. She joked that the plan was to slowly lower her into the crowd from the building\u2019s skylight atrium in a puff of confetti
column29: and then dramatically unfurl a banner from the second-story balcony with her name on it. \u201cThe technical term is big ass banner
column30: \u201d she said. \u201cWe\u2019ll all do some tequila shots before.\u201d
column31: Escobar wanted to\xa0announce her campaign in a central building downtown because she has worked hard to revitalize the neighborhood since being elected El Paso county judge in 2010 \u2015 an administrative leadership position that oversees that county\u2019s budget. The once-bustling border town was largely deserted in the mid-1990s as unemployment soared after the enactment of the North American Free Trade Agreement. But the town has since witnessed a rebirth as officials trained workers to take advantage of their location as a trade hub and move into higher-wage jobs
column32: where they have been\xa0adapting and transforming the city\u2019s economy.
column33: Under Escobar\u2019s leadership for the past eight years
column34: downtown El Paso has flourished and now boasts green parks with fountains and sculptures
column35: bustling bars
column36: theaters
column37: hipster music venues and a famous pawn shop that claims to have Mexican revolutionary Pancho Villa\u2019s trigger finger on sale for $9
column39: \u201cIt was really important to me that we launch downtown
column40: \u201d she told her volunteers the night before the launch. \u201cWe\u2019ve seen such an evolution downtown \u2015 a decline
column41: and a renaissance now
column42: and this is the center of it.\u201d
column43: After meeting with her team
column44: Escobar brought them to the patio of her favorite bar downtown
column45: overlooking the Franklin mountains
column46: for cocktails and nachos. Her whole family joined
column47: including her 20-year-old son
column48: a sophomore at Harvard; her 18-year-old daughter
column49: a rising freshman at Simmons College; her husband
column50: a federal immigration judge (confirmed
column51: ironically
column52: by Trump); and her brother
column53: a foreign service officer who flew into town from Washington
column54: D.C.
column55: for her announcement the next day. Nearly everyone who walked into or out of the bar squealed and waved when they spotted her at a table. \u201cTomorrow!\u201d Escobar shouted back to each one. \u201cBe there or be square!\u201d
column56: Escobar is blissfully happy in El Paso. Having inherited a passion for Mexican cooking from her mother
column57: her favorite thing to do after coming home from work is to pick apples from the tree in her front yard and make calabacitas
column58: enchiladas
column59: \xa0and apple pies for her daughter and son
column60: whom she addresses as \u201cmi amor.\u201d \xa0\u201cIf my kids were smaller
column61: I wouldn\u2019t have even considered this
column62: \u201d she says.
column63: The idea of commuting to Washington
column64: D.C.
column65: every week from her remote town does not appeal to Escobar at all. But Donald Trump and his rhetoric about immigrants and the border have terrified her and inspired her to run.
column66: \u201cHe really frightens me and in a way that I haven\u2019t been frightened before
column67: \u201d she says. \u201cI worry about the planet. I worry about immigrants. I worry about women. I worry about the LGBT community. I worry about the El Paso and the border. And I feel this very intense sense of dread.\u201d
column68: Across the table
column69: a campaign volunteer interrupts Escobar to read her a news alert from his smartphone: Trump has just pardoned ex-sheriff Joe Arpaio
column70: who was convicted in July of violating a federal court order to stop racially profiling Latinos in Arizona. \xa0
column71: \u201cUn-fucking-believable
column72: \u201d Escobar seethes
column73: before remembering that she is sitting next to a reporter. \u201cI\u2019m sorry
column74: but do you know what message that sends to Hispanics? \u2018You don\u2019t belong here.\u2019\u201d
column75: Despite being a public servant for more than a decade
column76: Escobar said she never pictured herself running for Congress before Trump became president. Her friends describe her as the \u201csalt-of-the-earth.\u201d She grew up working on a dairy farm in El Paso
column77: washing milk and manure out of her four brothers\u2019 jeans. She left to obtain a Master\u2019s Degree in English Literature at New York University
column78: and then returned in 1993 to teach Chicano literature at the University of Texas at El Paso.
column79: Upon returning home
column80: she noticed some \u201cdisturbing\u201d xenophobia and anti-immigrant sentiment in her largely Mexican-American community that has close ties to Ju\xe1rez \u2015 there was talk
column82: of a wall being built on the border. She decided to join advocacy efforts for the Border Rights Coalition (now the Border Network for Human Rights) in addition to her job at the school. \u201cI just remember thinking
column83: \u2018I have to get involved
column84: this not who we are. We\u2019re this great bi-national community. What happened?\u2019\u201d\xa0
column85: Escobar eventually became co-chair of the coalition
column86: and her passion for public service grew from there. During her time as county judge
column87: \xa0she and the four other members of the commissioners court fought to build El Paso\u2019s first children\u2019s hospital
column88: extended health care benefits to the domestic partners of LGBT city and county employees
column89: and passed a resolution denouncing Texas\u2019 \u201cbathroom bill
column90: \u201d which would prevent transgender students from using the bathroom of their choice. One year short of her full term
column91: Escobar resigned from her position in August to run for Congress.
column92: She is far from an elite politician. The night before her campaign event
column93: one of her volunteers asked her what took her so long to jump into the Democratic primary race
column94: since her opponent
column95: Republican-turned-Democrat Dori Fenenbock
column96: has been fundraising for months. Escobar replied that she and her husband
column97: federal immigration judge Michael Pleters
column98: needed to get their finances in order before she went jobless for a year. \u201cI had to buy a lot of tortillas and beans and freeze them
column99: \u201d she said.
column100: Because El Paso is a solidly blue district
column101: Escobar won\u2019t face any significant challenge from a Republican. Her main challenge is that she is behind on fundraising in the primary \u2015 Fenenbock
column102: former president of the El Paso Independent School District board
column103: had already raised hundreds of thousands of dollars before Escobar entered the race. But nearly half of that money came from Republicans
column104: which might not play well in the progressive district. And El Paso\u2019s popular former congressman
column105: O\u2019Rourke
column107: which gives her a major advantage in the race.
column108: Escobar\u2019s candidacy has been highly anticipated by the Latino community. A long list of Latino celebrities and politicians
column109: including U.S. Rep. Joaquin Castro (D-Tx.) and actresses Eva Longoria and Grace Parra
column110: have been urging Escobar to run through the Latino Victory Fund\u2019s \u201cRun Veronica Run\u201d campaign. Escobar is \u201cfloored\u201d by the attention
column111: but mostly thrilled that the race is putting El Paso on the map.
column112: \u201cThe fact that there\u2019s so much interest in our community and so many eyes on us right now
column115: it was an opportunity for El Paso to be in the limelight.\u201d
column116: Escobar could have a bright future in the Democratic party. Beyond border issues
column117: she considers herself a Bernie Sanders-style progressive
column118: favoring single-payer health care and free college tuition for those who want a degree. She strongly supports abortion rights
column119: despite the issue\u2019s controversy in the deeply Catholic Latino community. And she believes that Trump was elected in part because the Democratic Party focused too much on identity politics and not enough on the fact that the American middle class is \u201cshrinking and calling out for help.\u201d
column120: \u201cIt\u2019s really not necessarily just about minorities being left out
column121: it\u2019s more about an entire class of Americans being left out
column122: many of whom are white and who feel like they don\u2019t have access to great jobs and great education
column123: and the jobs they could do and were comfortable doing are gone
column124: \u201d she said. \u201cMany of them feel like Democrats are only about pushing minority rights. Here I am
column125: the person who could break a barrier for Texas \u2015 and I believe diversity is critical
column126: and I am very proud that I have the opportunity to blaze that trail for other Latinas behind me \u2015 but as a party
column127: we have to recognize that there are white Americans in the middle class that have been left out. And I think Bernie did that.\u201d
column128: Escobar channeled Sanders\u2019 spirit and brio as she announced her candidacy on a sunny Saturday afternoon in downtown El Paso. Roughly 300 El Pasoans packed into the lobby of the 7-story
column129: mixed-use building to see her speak. Noting the presence of her 72-year-old immigrant mother in the crowd
column130: Escobar delivered a passionate 20-minute speech about her pride for El Paso
column131: her support for universal health care and education
column132: her plans to be a voice for the U.S.-Mexico border
column135: But her biggest cheers came when she condemned Trump\u2019s treatment of Hispanics.
column136: \u201cWhen you have a president who pardons someone who believes racial profiling should be the M.O. in an entire state
column138: \u201d she said. \u201cTrump is sending Latino communities a very clear message with that pardon
column139: and that message is that we don\u2019t matter and that our civil rights and our constitutional rights don\u2019t matter. You know what? They matter to us.
column140: Some Latinos in the crowd were visibly emotional as Escobar spoke. Christina Sanchez
column142: burst into tears when asked whether it was important to her that Escobar break that barrier for Hispanic women.\xa0
column144: especially now with what you near from the national level
column145: \u201d she said. \u201cTo really be that first Latina from Texas\u2026 it\u2019s important for me
column147: and it\u2019s important for my daughter to see a person who\u2019s like her in that role.\u201d
column148: Escobar ended her speech to the Beatles\u2019 song \u201cRevolution.\u201d
column151: \u201d she said after the event. \u201cI want people to feel like they have a stake in creating change
column152: and we\u2019re arming ourselves with good vibes and a lot of love to head into battle.\u201d

Harvey Damaged At Least 200 Houston Schools

Hurricane Harvey wreaked havoc on the Houston Independent School District \u2014 the largest public school system in Texas and the seventh-largest in the United States \u2014 forcing school closures and disrupting the lives of hundreds of thousands of students and teachers.
column2: As of last Friday
column3: district officials reported that each of the 200 school-related facilities they\u2019d inspected had sustained damage from the hurricane
column4: which was later downgraded to a tropical storm. An additional 100 facilities likely face similar problems
column5: but have been inaccessible because of flooding or other circumstances
column6: Richard Carranza
column7: the district\u2019s superintendent
column8: told HuffPost.
column9: Schools in other Houston-area districts have also suffered damage. But if Hurricane Katrina
column10: which struck the Gulf Coast in 2005
column11: is any indication
column12: the worst of Harvey\u2019s effects on education are still ahead. Katrina
column13: which displaced more than 370
column14: 000 students in Mississippi and Louisiana
column15: created a lost generation of students who were forced from their homes and schools. As a result
column16: their academic achievement was lower
column17: their dropout rates were higher
column18: and they struggled with joblessness even a decade after the storm.
column19: School officials in Houston
column20: which took in more Katrina evacuees than any other city
column21: are leaning on the research
column22: experiences and improved technology that came out of Katrina to implement plans to reduce Harvey\u2019s worst possible consequences for children \u2014 and to prevent the storm from negatively impacting students for generations to come.
column23: Houston schools will provide three free meals a day to every student during the upcoming school year
column24: an expansion of an existing program. The district has also organized food and clothing drives with neighboring districts. When students and teachers return to school next week
column25: crisis counselors will be waiting for them. Houston\u2019s district will also use technology to identify and track displaced and homeless students
column26: Carranza said
column27: a crucial step in implementing the lessons learned from Katrina.
column28: But Houston can\u2019t successfully mitigate Harvey\u2019s worst educational impacts on its own. The school district has already faced crunched budgets and potential funding shortfalls. Experts who studied the aftermath of Katrina say an influx of money is necessary to hire staff and implement full recovery programs for displaced students who will need years of academic and emotional support.
column29: And although the House of Representatives will take up its first Harvey-related legislation this week \u2014 a $7.85 billion relief package that will help the Federal Emergency Management Agency continue its efforts in Houston and other affected areas \u2014 Congress\u2019 crowded docket and looming spending fights could imperil future relief funding
column30: included the sort of targeted education funding school districts need.
column31: For the vast majority of students
column32: merely returning to the normalcy of school and receiving early counseling will be enough to recover
column33: or come close to it. A year after Hurricane Andrew hit Florida in 1992
column34: nearly 80 percent of students had recovered from the psychological trauma they experienced because of the storm
column35: according to researchers. Even after Katrina
column36: 71 percent of students had similarly recovered within two years of the storm making landfall
column37: similar research found.
column38: But for some students
column39: recovery will take longer \u2014 and that\u2019s where Houston and other affected districts need to avoid the biggest post-Katrina mistakes.
column40: A year after Katrina made landfall
column41: students the storm displaced missed more days of school and had lower rates of achievement than they did before the hurricane
column42: according to Dr. Michael Ward
column43: who
column44: as an education professor at the University of Southern Mississippi
column45: studied Katrina\u2019s effects on students who moved schools.
column46: But their rates of suspension and discipline for misconduct also fell
column47: suggesting that teachers and administrators were more understanding and lenient than they typically had been \u2014 that they \u201creally worked hard and really went out of their way to make sure that kids who had been displaced and suffered worst got the support and the help they needed from teachers
column48: \u201d Ward said.
column49: Five years after Katrina
column50: however
column51: rates of suspension for displaced students had skyrocketed beyond their pre-storm levels
column52: and Mississippi\u2019s Katrina kids were twice as likely to drop out of school than students the storm hadn\u2019t displaced
column53: Ward found. (The numbers were likely similar in Louisiana
column54: he said.)
column55: \u201cSo the lesson there appears to be that
column56: if you\u2019re not thoughtful \u2014 if the adults in the process are not thoughtful \u2015 what will happen is that the needs of kids will outlast the patience of adults
column57: \u201d Ward said. \u201cUnless there\u2019s a system for keeping track of kids who were displaced
column58: the next school year they may end up with a teacher who doesn\u2019t know they experienced that sort of trauma. Two years out
column59: five years out
column60: it\u2019s kind of old history \u2014 except for the kids.\u201d
column61: Houston and other districts
column62: Ward said
column63: will \u201cneed to maintain support systems around these kids for multiple years.\u201d
column64: The most vulnerable children \u2015 kids from poorer families and students of color\xa0\u2015 are particularly likely to suffer from the hurricane. Harvey has already had a disproportionate impact on those communities
column65: and the demographics of Houston\u2019s public schools \u2014 in 2016
column66: 62 percent of its students were Hispanic or Latino
column67: while another 24 percent were African-American \u2014 suggests the educational outcome could be similarly unequal.
column68: Texas doesn\u2019t have any near-term plans to provide extra money to help Houston and other school districts deal with the educational effects of Harvey. DeEtta Culbertson
column69: a spokeswoman for the Texas Education Agency
column70: said she was not yet aware of any plans for the state to step in to provide such funding
column71: and last week
column72: Gov. Greg Abbott (R) said he would not call a special legislative session to seek Harvey relief funding.
column73: That leaves the feds. After Katrina
column74: Congress approved $880 million in federal funding to assist school districts that took in displaced students
column75: intended to help them hire staff and provide support to students in need.
column76: As part of the package
column77: Congress granted each district $1
column78: 500 per displaced student
column79: allowing districts to provide basic education services
column80: reopen schools
column81: and operate temporary facilities. But many districts said that funding fell short of what they needed
column82: according to a 2011 assessment from the Government Accountability Office
column83: and only three of the 13 districts the GAO observed reported using the funds to hire new staff.
column84: Hiring new counseling staff may be especially important in Texas. The state employs one school counselor for every 465 students
column85: said Jill Cook
column86: the assistant director of the American School Counselors Association
column87: which recommends a ratio of one counselor for every 250 students.
column88: School districts also reported that the verification process for the aid program proved challenging
column89: according to the GAO. And district leaders told the agency that they were overly cautious in how they spent the money because they were unsure what costs it covered and feared they would have to return misused funds to the federal government.
column90: Much of the federal aid
column91: meanwhile
column92: provided assistance only for the school year immediately following Katrina
column93: even though children and their schools continued to deal with the storm years after it devastated the Gulf Coast. A federal package that helps avoid the failures of Katrina\u2019s recovery may need to be more ambitious than Congress\u2019 package a decade ago.
column94: Members of Congress have held committee-level discussions about education relief funding
column95: though no dollar figure has been floated yet
column96: one House Republican said. Carranza
column97: the Houston superintendent
column98: said that he has heard \u201cgood rumblings\u201d from lawmakers about \u201cfederal support for all of the students who have been displaced and students who will be actually homeless.\u201d
column99: The good news
column100: Ward said
column101: is that Katrina led to loads of new information about what does \u2014 and doesn\u2019t \u2014 help schools recover after a storm. The challenge now is to apply those lessons.
column102: \u201cIt\u2019s a worst-case scenario
column103: \u201d Ward explained. \u201cKatrina was a 500-year flooding event
column104: and you hope that we\u2019d have been spared something that catastrophic. But here we are again
column105: and I\u2019d like to hope that the research and the dissemination of that research after Katrina is helping Texas school districts now.\u201d

Congress Eyes Brief Extension For Flood Insurance Program

|[

WASHINGTON \u2014 Lawmakers in Washington largely agree that the National Flood Insurance Program \u2014 now nearing $25 billion in debt \u2014 is in need of a fix. Where they differ
column2: of course
column3: is on how to reform it.
column4: But with Hurricane Harvey having just pummeled the Gulf Coast
column5: Hurricane Irma now barreling toward the Florida peninsula
column6: a jam-packed September to-do list in Congress and the insurance program set to expire Sept. 30
column7: there is little time for constructive negotiations. And it appears lawmakers will opt to buy themselves more time.
column8: A short-term\xa0extension of the program was tucked into\xa0an agreement struck Wednesday by President Donald Trump and senate Democrats to provide billions in disaster aid for Hurricane Harvey
column9: raise the debt ceiling and keep the government from shutting down. The Senate passed the package Thursday by an 80-17 vote
column10: doubling the amount of disaster aid to $15.3 billion
column11: the Washington Post reported. The House is expected to vote as soon as Friday.
column12: If passed
column13: the package would extend the reauthorization deadline to Dec. 8.
column14: The NFIP was established by Congress in 1968 to provide low-cost insurance to people living in flood-prone areas.\xa0In exchange
column15: communities are required to adopt flood management plans and work to reduce the risk of infrastructure being damaged in a flood.\xa0But many properties are being destroyed and rebuilt several times in the same high-risk location
column16: with construction being subsidized each time by taxpayer dollars.\xa0
column17: Today

We\u2019ve got a realization that actually our failed policies regarding flood mitigation and recovery actually contribute to future problems. I think it\u2019s possible to put these pieces together.\u201d\xa0

Hurricane Harvey Is Just The Latest In Facebook’s Fake News Problem

|[

As the rain started falling in Houston
column2: the anonymous authors went to work.
column3: Writing under pseudonyms and hiding behind the pretense of satire
column4: they churned out lies
column5: dressed them up as news
column6: and then let Facebook\u2019s platform do their dirty work
column7: spreading their deliberate falsehoods far and wide.
column8: As a result
column9: millions of people were exposed to \u2015 and believed \u2015 false stories like this one
column10: headlined: \u201cBlack Lives Matter Thugs Blocking Emergency Crews From Reaching Hurricane Victims.\u201d (The opposite was actually true: BLM Houston has been actively collecting and distributing aid and helping recovery efforts.)
column11: One website alone
column12: \xa0\u201cFlash American News
column13: \u201d spread that narrative to more than 1 million people via Facebook. Numerous other similar websites also shared their own versions via the social media network
column14: selling the lie by using photos taken from other totally unrelated stories.
column15: While some might readily recognize the story as fake
column16: plenty who encountered it on Facebook sure didn\u2019t.
column17: \u201cThese hoodlums need to go away for a long time!\u201d One commenter wrote after the story was shared on the \u201cfanclubtrump\u201d\xa0Facebook page. \u201cMake them regret what they are doing keeping hurt
column18: innocent people from getting help is dispicable!\u201d [sic]
column19: \u201cThis is absolutely despicable!!!!\u201d another user added. \u201cTell me please how does this help anything or anybody! All it does is show the world that these people are heartless
column20: uncaring
column21: sorry excuses of what a human being should be!!!\u201d
column22: Though the story is fake
column23: its impact in the real world is not.
column24: Similar disinformation campaigns singled out other groups frequently targeted by conservative media and the so-called \u201calt-right
column25: \u201d shaping real-world opinions with fake stories spread unchecked on Facebook.\xa0
column26: Muslims were also accused in several fake stories of refusing to let Harvey victims seek shelter in mosques. (Again
column27: the opposite is true: Houston-area mosques opened their doors to thousands
column28: even as Joel Osteen\u2019s 16
column29: 800-seat megachurch drew criticism for remaining closed.) \xa0
column30: The imam pictured in the fake story above lives in Canada and says he\u2019s never even been to Texas.
column31: Nevertheless
column32: a version distributed via DailyPostFeed.com (other sites also shared other variants) was shared to 795
column33: 680 people via Facebook.\xa0
column34: Another highly-circulated fake story claimed that flooding during Hurricane Harvey somehow \u201cuncovered\u201d a huge cache of weapons and ammo apparently hidden there by the Obama administration
column35: for the purposes of staging a coup to return to power.
column36: While the above website\xa0claims to be satire
column37: it does little to announce that to visitors. Per CrowdTangle
column38: the above story was shared to 769
column39: 377 people on Facebook.
column40: The Clinton Foundation was also (falsely) accused of sending water to Houston and charging\xa0$7 per bottle for it.
column41: Misinformation on the internet is hardly a new or even rare occurrence. But one common thread here is Facebook.
column42: The social media network has enabled the rapid spread of deliberate
column43: harmful falsehoods.
column44: As of now
column45: the company is apparently unwilling to do much to stop the spread of deliberate misinformation.
column46: In response to outcry over similar disinformation campaigns during the 2016 election
column47: \xa0Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg\xa0dismissed as \u201cpretty crazy\u201d the idea that fake news on his site could have influenced the election\u2019s outcome. The company\u2019s COO Sheryl Sandberg agreed.
column48: Nevertheless
column49: Facebook calmed some critics by rolling out a system months later to flag questionable sources of information\xa0as \u201cdisputed\u201d and reconfiguring its \u201ctrending topics\u201d module. Judging by the rampant spread of the above stories
column50: however
column51: deeper problems remain.
column52: On Wednesday
column53: Facebook representatives acknowledged to congressional investigators that <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/facebook-says-likely-russian-based-operation-spent-money-on-political-ads_us_59b07007e4b0354e440f2778">the company sold around $100
column54: 000 worth of ads\xa0during the 2016 election to a Russian content farm known for producing pro-Kremlin messages
column55: along with what Facebook itself described as \u201cdivisive social and political messages.\u201d
column56:
CORRECTION: Several different photographs accompanied fake news articles about mosques in Texas. An earlier version of this article used a photo of an imam who is not the one who lives in Canada. The photo has been replaced.

Paul Ryan
column2:
Of Course!|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 President Donald Trump made a bad deal for Republicans on the debt limit and government funding
column3: and
column4: according to House conservatives
column5: that\u2019s Speaker Paul Ryan\u2019s fault.
column6: What?
column7: A day after Trump surprised his own party by taking the first offer from congressional Democrats to raise the debt ceiling and continue government spending for three months
column8: many House conservatives have decided that House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wisc.) is ultimately to blame for Trump\u2019s impulsive deal.
column9: \u201cLack of preparation leads to poor choices
column10: and the fact that we weren\u2019t here \u2015 and you heard me say this the other night \u2015 we weren\u2019t here for six weeks
column11: the longest non-election-year break we\u2019ve had in a decade
column12: \u201d former Freedom Caucus Chairman Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) said Thursday
column13: \u201cthat\u2019s a problem.\u201d
column14: Asked if Trump had effectively stepped in front of a bullet for Ryan by taking the blame for a bad deal that the speaker would have largely taken the responsibility for if the president had just stayed out of negotiations
column15: Jordan said he wasn\u2019t here to blame anybody. \u201cWhat I\u2019m saying is we should have done what we had said back in July
column16: \u201d Jordan answered. \u201cWe should have stayed here and put together a debt ceiling plan.\u201d
column17: Obviously
column18: Ryan has a lot of blame for a congressional recess
column19: though the majority leader also has a say in the congressional schedule. But Jordan added that when lawmakers fail to prepare for deadlines
column20: they don\u2019t have the best options come decision time.
column21: That\u2019s not an unfair argument
column22: but it ignores an obvious reality: This deal that Trump struck with Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) was a deal that Trump struck
column23: not Ryan.
column24: But time and again Thursday
column25: conservatives ignored Trump\u2019s role in the agreement and found a way to blame the speaker.
column26: \u201cI think he saw the same-old
column27: same-old kind of crap coming from leadership
column28: and that wasn\u2019t good enough
column29: \u201d Rep. Paul Gosar (R-Ariz.) said of Trump
column30: theorizing that the president was effectively preserving the debt limit issue until December.
column31: As much as Gosar defended the president
column32: he couldn\u2019t find an adequate reason to vote for the bill \u2015 he said he plans to oppose the package when it comes before the House \u2015 but Gosar noted he could see how this deal works to Trump\u2019s favor if the president plays his hand right.
column33: That part seems unlikely. Lawmakers have repeatedly noted in the last two days that Trump just set a precedent that will be tough for him to break: He supported raising the debt ceiling without concessions
column34: and he has agreed to fund the government without demanding money for his border wall.
column35: Even Gosar acknowledged that Trump has made his negotiating position more difficult. \u201cHe may have lost that credibility
column36: \u201d Gosar said. \u201cBut time will tell.\u201d
column37: Still
column38: conservatives generally refused to blame Trump for a deal that most of them believe to be bad for Republicans. Many said they couldn\u2019t answer questions until actually seeing the text of the deal. Many outright refused to answer questions.
column39: \u201cI\u2019m not going to talk about whether Donald Trump or Paul Ryan did a good or bad job
column40: \u201d said Rep. Mo Brooks of Alabama.
column41: And many others made tenuous connections between the deal and Paul Ryan.
column42: \u201cI just see that the leadership team signed off on it and the rest of us find out about it
column43: \u201d said Rep. Steve King (R-Iowa). King noted that Ryan and other GOP leaders didn\u2019t ever offer a conservative alternative to a clean increase in the debt ceiling \u2015 again
column44: an argument that isn\u2019t wrong but somehow ignores the fact that Trump jumped at the chance for a clean debt limit.
column45: Rep. Louie Gohmert (R-Texas) conveyed that he was disappointed in the deal. But even after he was presented with the argument that Ryan had called the Democratic offer \u201cridiculous\u201d Wednesday morning shortly before Trump took the offer
column46: Gohmert said Ryan may actually have been a proponent of the deal. \u201cWe don\u2019t know if he was or not
column47: \u201d the congressman said.
column48: Moderates generally welcomed Trump\u2019s deal
column49: noting that the president had effectively cut out the Freedom Caucus from negotiations. \u201cTo me
column50: the main positive of this deal is we\u2019re not gonna have one group of 30 or 40 have veto power
column51: \u201d Rep. Peter King (R-N.Y.) said. \u201cWe can\u2019t allow a group of 30 or 40 to be setting policy for the House of Representatives.\u201d
column52: But as much as moderates were celebrating the compromised position of conservatives
column53: conservatives were muted in their criticism \u2015 at least of Trump
column54: who many believe is the key to overthrowing Ryan.
column55: Conservatives have quietly been laying the groundwork for a coup against Ryan
column56: pointing out with increasing frequency that the speaker had no plan to extract GOP concessions on the debt ceiling or a continuing resolution. But it\u2019s difficult to argue that this legislation is really Ryan\u2019s fault when Trump got out in front of it.
column57: Republicans have spun Trump\u2019s decision as one recognizing that Democrats were going to win this negotiation
column58: so better to just \u201cclear the decks\u201d and perhaps allow Congress to focus on tax reform. But even that explanation is fraught. The short-term nature of the deal ensures that lawmakers will be focused on negotiating a broader deal in December
column59: not just cutting taxes.
column60: Ryan\u2019s own defense of the agreement is that Trump saw a nation recovering from one hurricane and preparing for another
column61: and he wanted a bipartisan moment rather than a protracted disagreement. That argument may work for some
column62: but Trump has put Republicans in a bind for future negotiations
column63: and he did so with little to no consultation from congressional leaders or his legislative affairs staff
column64: according to one senior GOP aide familiar with discussions.
column65: And if Trump himself wanted to preserve his conservative credentials and damage Paul Ryan
column66: he just went ahead and did the exact opposite. The question is whether that will matter to the far-right lawmakers who already seem to be plotting Ryan\u2019s fall.
column67: When Gosar was asked Thursday if he still supports Ryan as speaker
column68: he repeatedly answered that he hadn\u2019t said \u201cone way or another.\u201d
column69: Asked if he would welcome Ryan campaigning for him
column70: Gosar answered that he didn\u2019t have a challenger. Asked whether he would let Ryan even fundraise for him
column71: Gosar said he didn\u2019t know about that
column72:
noting that Ryan was \u201cvery unpopular\u201d in his district.

Betsy DeVos Says The Title IX System Has 'Failed' Both Survivors And The Accused

|[

During a planned press conference on Thursday
column2: Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos announced that\xa0\u201cthe era of rule by letter is over\u201d with regards to campus sexual assault.\xa0
column3: DeVos delivered a speech on Title IX to a crowd at George Mason University\u2019s Law School campus in Arlington
column4: VA on Thursday early afternoon. During her 20-minute speech
column5: DeVos called the current campus reporting process a \u201cfailed system\u201d that is \u201cincreasingly elaborate and confusing.\u201d\xa0
column6: She did not announce any large policy changes to Title IX other than implying that the\xa02011 Dear Colleague Letter\xa0would be rescinded when she told the crowd\xa0\u201cthe era of rule by letter\u201d has ended.\xa0
column7: The Obama-era\xa0Dear Colleague Letter
column8: which was created by then-Vice President Joe Biden in 2011
column9: is a comprehensive set of guidelines that essentially serve as a reminder to universities and Title IX administrators that schools need to follow the Title IX law. \xa0
column10: DeVos also announced two new approaches to the campus sexual violence reporting process that the Department of Education is exploring. The first is that the Department \u201cwill launch a transparent notice and comment process to incorporate the insights of all parties
column11: \u201d including feedback from the public and educational institutions.\xa0
column12: \u201cNo one benefits from a system that does not have the public\u2019s trust
column13: \u201d DeVos said
column14: referring to the current Title IX system.\xa0
column15: The second approach DeVos announced on Thursday is that the department will implement a regional reporting center model. The model would allow universities and colleges to opt in to local reporting centers that would partner with state attorneys general and law enforcement to ensure the reporting process runs fairly. \xa0
column16: The Secretary of Education repeatedly discussed the rights of not only survivors of sexual assault
column17: but also those who have been \u201cwrongly accused\u201d of sexual misconduct.
column18: She allotted most of her speech to anecdotes about how the current Title IX system has failed survivors and those wrongly accused.
column19: \u201cOne rape is one too many
column20: one assault is one too many
column21: one aggressive act of harassment is one too many
column22: one person denied due process is one too many
column23: \u201d DeVos told the crowd at George Mason. \u201cThis conversation may be uncomfortable
column24: but we must have it. It is our moral obligation to get it right.\u201d
column25: Although just between\xa02 and 10 percent of reported rapes turn out to be false claims
column26: DeVos devoted equal time to the stories of sexual assault survivors and those wrongly accused as if the group is the same size as survivors of sexual violence.
column27: \u201cThis campus official
column28: who may or may not have any training in adjudicating sexual misconduct
column29: is expected to render a judgment
column30: \u201d DeVos said
column31: walking the crowd through the Title IX process. \u201cA judgment that changes the direction of\xa0both\xa0students\u2019 lives. The right to appeal may or may not be available to either party and no one is permitted to talk about what went on behind closed doors.\xa0It\u2019s no wonder so many call these proceedings kangaroo courts.\u201d\xa0
column32: Notably
column33: the groups that most often refer to Title IX proceedings as\xa0\u201ckangaroo courts\u201d are Men\u2019s Rights Activists\xa0and others who believe that the Title IX process is built to favor accusers over the accused.\xa0
column34: While\xa0Title IX is best known as a broad tool for enforcing\xa0equal treatment of female and male student athletes
column35: it also offers\xa0other important protections\xa0in areas including sexual harassment
column36: sexual assault
column37: and protections for trans and parenting students.\xa0In the past six months DeVos\xa0rescinded protections for transgender students\xa0and made the investigation process for college sexual assault\xa0less transparent
column38: while also\xa0threatening to cut resources and funding.
column39: DeVos\u2019 announcement doesn\u2019t come as a surprise to many advocacy groups who have had concerns about the Secretary of Education\u2019s\xa0views on Title IX\xa0since she was\xa0confirmed in February.\xa0
column40: Before the announcement
column41: survivor advocacy groups including End Rape on Campus and Know Your IX
column42: NARAL and the Feminist Majority Foundation\xa0rallied outside of the law school\xa0as a sign of protest. Many protestors tweeted their support of the advocacy groups using the\xa0hashtag #StopBetsy.\xa0
column43: \u201cThere are no two sides when it comes to rape. Period
column44: \u201d NitaChaudhary
column45: co-founder of feminist organization UltraViolet
column46: said in a press statement after DeVos\u2019 announcement. \u201cWith sexual assaults routinely going unreported
column47: un-investigated and unpunished
column48: the scales are already heavily tipped in the favor of rapists. The idea that we need to focus more on the rights of the accused would be laughable if it weren\u2019t so terrifying and outright dangerous.\u201d\xa0
column49: Anti-sexual violence organization KnowYourIX\xa0put out a similar statement after DeVos\u2019 announcement:
column50: Today
column51: Secretary DeVos sent the message to student and survivors across the country that the Department of Education doesn\u2019t have their back. Before the Education Department took action to protect survivors
column52: and hold schools accountable
column53: too many young people were forced to drop classes they shared with their rapists
column54: take long leaves of absence
column55: or even leave school entirely. The Department\u2019s guidance
column56: which outlined survivors\u2019 rights under longstanding federal law
column57: was a response to this urgent reality. Today\u2019s announcement risks taking us back to to the days when sexual violence routinely compromised survivors\u2019 access to education and schools swept sexual assault under the rug.
column58: Alexandra Brodsky
column59: a civil rights attorney and co-founder of\xa0KnowYourIX
column60: told HuffPost earlier this week that rescinding the 2011 Dear Colleague Letter does not actually change the law.\xa0
column61: \u201cThe [Title IX] law hasn\u2019t changed at all

column16: which analyzed drug mortality rates from death certificates in an effort to more accurately assess opioid and heroin drug fatalities.\xa0It found mortality rates that were 24 percent higher for opioid overdoses and 22 percent higher for heroin overdoses than the numbers that had previously been reported.\xa0
column17: As it stands
column18: more than 50
column19: 000 Americans died of drug overdoses in 2015
column20: surpassing annual HIV and firearm deaths during the peak years of those epidemics. \xa0
column21: \u201cDeath rates from opioid overdose will continue to rise until we implement a comprehensive strategy to reduce harms and expand treatment for opioid use disorder using effective medications
column22: \u201d Dr. Peter Friedmann

column24:
told HuffPost.

'Going Back To Mexico Would Be Like Returning To Nothing': Dreamers Process DACA's End

|[

Yadira Alem\xe1n had gathered with her parents in front of the television in their home in Las Vegas on Tuesday when U.S. Attorney General Jeff Sessions made an announcement about the\xa0Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals\xa0program
column2: known as DACA.
column3: Surrounded by her family
column4: the 22-year-old business administration major learned the Trump administration was rescinding the Obama-era policy that provides two-year work visas and reprieve from deportation to so-called Dreamers \u2015 nearly 800
column5: 000 young undocumented immigrants like herself who had come to the U.S. as children.\xa0
column6: \u201cI have mixed feelings
column7: \u201d Alem\xe1n told HuffPost Mexico by phone after the announcement. \u201cBut I feel more anger
column8: because despite what we\u2019ve done
column9: they don\u2019t understand us. I think about DACA
column10: about the benefits it gave me to be able to continue my studies
column11: to be employed by a home loan business
column12: thanks to which I could buy a home for my parents who left Mexico City. And now what? We are in this limbo over what will happen to us.\u201d
column13: Isaac Montiel
column14: a 27-year-old student born in Puebla
column15: Mexico
column16: followed Sessions\u2019 announcement via social media while protesting outside the White House.
column17: Montiel co-chairs the\xa0CUNY Dreamers\xa0group and is one of 28 Dreamers on a four-day hunger strike. \u201cI am angry
column18: frustrated
column19: but I also want to continue fighting for a permanent solution from Congress
column20: \u201d he said.\xa0
column21: Individuals who currently have DACA protections will begin to lose their work permits in six months
column22: putting hundreds of thousands of young U.S. residents at risk of being sent away from the country they\u2019ve lived in since they were children \u2015 unless members of the U.S. House and Senate can agree on legislation to protect them.\xa0
column23: Mexico City-born Jos\xe9 Eduardo Morales
column24: who now lives in Utah
column25: wasn\u2019t surprised by the decision.\xa0\u201cI already knew what was going to happen
column26: but it was difficult to process
column27: \u201d Morales said. \u201cI felt a little disoriented
column28: defenseless
column29: uncertain. My permit is still valid for a year
column30: and right now I am completing a graduate degree in education.\u201d
column31: Morales said that while he can\u2019t travel to Washington D.C. to take part in protests
column32: he\u2019s using the tools at his disposal to support them. He says the\xa0U.S.-Mexico Foundation\xa0has advised Dreamers to stay on top of the news
column33: and that they\u2019re also staying connected through WhatsApp.\xa0
column34: \u201cThis is causing us emotional and physical stress
column35: \u201d he said
column36: \u201cbut I have two more years left to complete my studies and if I can complete them
column37: I will use my graduate degree here to help my community in many ways.\u201d
column38: Rebecca Vargas
column39: who co-chairs the\xa0U.S.-Mexico Foundation
column40: said dialogue and educating members of Congress will be crucial in the weeks and months ahead. \u201cThe only benefit of this announcement is that if we achieve something in Congress
column41: it should be permanent
column42: not temporary
column43: as DACA was
column44: \u201d she explained.\xa0
column45: Amid the insecurity about what lies ahead
column46: Dreamers have expressed a wide range of fears
column47: including whether they\u2019d be at risk of deportation and whether the U.S. government will make use of the data they provided when they applied for the program
column48: including their place of residence
column49: work or school.\xa0\xa0
column50: Eunice Rend\xf3n
column51: director of Agenda Migrante
column52: said that an additional worry is the Mexican government\u2019s lack of sufficient preparation for the possible return of these young people.
column53: \u201cMexico is not completely ready to receive [so many] of these young people. There are efforts and political willingness
column54: but I do not see a comprehensive return policy
column55: \u201d she explained. \u201cThat\u2019s why we have to be clear on the fact that U.S. legislators \u2015 who ultimately will be the ones to resolve these young people\u2019s current situation \u2015 can also be pressured via the media and social justice groups.\u201d
column56: Rend\xf3n also noted Dreamers\u2019 contributions to the U.S. economy \u2015 according to the Center for American Progress
column57: \xa0deporting Dreamers will result in a $460 billion loss to the U.S. GDP over the next 10 years.
column58: \u201cMore than 98 percent of them are bilingual
column59: 91 percent are formally employed
column60: and 70 percent have completed higher education
column61: Rend\xf3n said. They are the ideal citizen for any country! Trump may have a majority in Congress
column62: but we have not forgotten that there are many Republicans who have voted against his decisions.\u201d \xa0
column63: That\u2019s why Montiel did not await Session\u2019s announcement in New York
column64: where he lives
column65: but in Washington
column66: D.C.
column67: where he traveled to lend his voice to the chorus of protesters. \u201cWe are not giving up! Hopefully the Mexican government will announce their support for us. Thinking about returning [to Mexico] would be one of my last alternatives
column68: \u201d he said.\xa0
column69: Alem\xe1n echoed his sentiment. \u201cFor my family
column70: it would be very difficult to return to our country
column71: \u201d she acknowledged
column72: \u201cbut most of all for me
column73: who grew up in this country. Going back to Mexico would be like returning to nothing.\u201d

Poll: Most Americans Want Congress To Save Dreamers

|[

Most Americans disagree with President Donald Trump\u2019s decision to end the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program and want Congress to do something about it
column2: a new HuffPost/YouGov survey finds.
column3: A majority
column4: 55 percent
column5: say Trump made the wrong decision when he announced Tuesday he was ending the program protecting undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children
column6: a group sometimes known as \u201cDreamers.\u201d Fifty-one percent of those polled say they\u2019d like to see their congressional representatives create a new program to allow Dreamers to stay in the country
column7: with just 26 percent opposed.
column8: Past surveys
column9: taken before Trump\u2019s decision
column10: have shown broad support for the program
column11: although the exact level of backing has varied between polls.
column12: A Politico/Morning Consult survey
column13: for instance
column14: found that 76 percent of voters believed Dreamers should be able to stay in the country and become either legal residents or citizens
column15: with just 15 percent favoring their deportation; an NBC/SurveyMonkey poll
column16: meanwhile
column17: found that 64 percent of Americans favored DACA
column18: with 30 percent opposed. The most recent YouGov/Economist tracking poll found slightly lower backing
column19: with 55 percent favoring DACA and 48 percent saying Trump should keep the program.
column20: The HuffPost/YouGov poll tested two differently-worded questions about DACA
column21: finding relatively similar levels of support in both cases.
column22: Among the half of those polled who were asked for their feelings about \u201callowing undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children to stay in the country
column23: \u201d a 53 percent majority favored the idea
column24: with just 29 percent in opposition.
column25: Among the other half
column26: who were asked to choose what should happen to \u201cundocumented immigrants who were brought to the U.S. as children
column27: \u201d 47 percent said they should be allowed to stay in the country and 30 percent that they should be required to leave.
column28: While there are clear partisan divides on the issue
column29: the left is far more unified in support for DACA than the right is in opposition.
column30: Voters who supported Hillary Clinton in last year\u2019s election
column31: for instance
column32: say by a 74 percentage-point margin that Congress should work to protect Dreamers
column33: while Trump voters say by only a 14-point margin that it should not. Democrats support congressional action by a 63-point margin
column34: while Republicans disapprove by an 11-point margin.
column35: Some Democrats are hoping that the ongoing debate over DACA could rally voters in their favor during the 2018 midterms
column36: especially in some California districts where Republican representatives are serving large minority populations.
column37: Nationwide
column38: the Democratic Party has a 7-point edge in trust over the GOP to handle immigration issues
column39: according to the HuffPost/YouGov survey
column40: although that falls to just 3 points among the registered voters polled.
column41: And there are mixed signals about how much importance both foes and supporters of DACA place on the issue. Eighty-nine percent of Americans who want to see Congress create a new program say that it\u2019s at least somewhat important that legislators do so
column42: higher than the three-quarters of opponents who say it\u2019s at least somewhat important that they do not.
column43: But just 18 percent of those who support the creation of a new program to allow Dreamers to stay in the country say that immigration is among the two issues they consider most important to them
column44: while 35 percent of those who oppose it say the same.

column47: The HuffPost/YouGov poll consisted of 1
column48: 000 completed interviews conducted Sept. 5-6 among U.S. adults

Trump’s Deal With Democrats Gives Proof To Fans And Critics Alike

|[

WASHINGTON \u2013 Supporters and critics of President Donald Trump finally have something they can agree on: His alliance with Democrats for a short-term fix on crucial debt ceiling legislation proves his bona fides as a dealmaker once and for all.
column2: \u201cThis is brilliant
column3: \u201d said Michael Caputo
column4: a former campaign aide who previously worked with Trump for several years on other issues
column5: adding that the strategy reminded him of Trump\u2019s 1987 bestseller. \u201cIt\u2019s straight out of The Art of the Deal.\u201d
column6: Speaking on the condition of anonymity
column7: one of Trump\u2019s informal advisers said taking up Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi on their offer of a three-month extension to the nation\u2019s borrowing authority meant clearing the deck for his top priority. \u201cWhat he wanted to do was spend the next three months doing tax reform
column8: \u201d the adviser said. \u201cThis lets him do that.\u201d
column9: But the notion that the president\u2019s move was somehow good for Republicans as a whole or even Trump personally brought open laughter from Trump\u2019s GOP critics
column10: who said it actually proves that his \u201cdealmaking\u201d prowess has always been a scam.
column11: \u201cHe\u2019s as reliable as a rattlesnake
column12: \u201d said Florida Republican consultant Rick Wilson
column13: who added that Trump has now empowered Democrats to win their positions on any number of issues
column14: from tax policy to health care. \u201cYou gave the Democrats a gun to your head. These guys are now hostage to Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi.\u201d
column15: House Speaker Paul Ryan
column16: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and even Trump\u2019s treasury secretary
column17: Steven Mnuchin
column18: had wanted an 18-month extension of the debt ceiling
column19: pushing its expiration to beyond the 2018 congressional elections. Increasing the statutory debt limit does not increase debt
column20: but merely authorizes the government to pay debts already incurred. Nevertheless
column21: in recent decades
column22: lawmakers \u2015 especially Republicans \u2015 have conflated the two in their campaigns for office
column23: and prefer to minimize the number of times they must cast debt-ceiling votes. Thanks to Trump
column24: they will now have two such votes in a matter of three months heading into primary election season.
column25: One of those wrapped up Friday
column26: with the House overwhelmingly passing a package that included $15 billion for Hurricane Harvey relief
column27: a three-month government funding bill
column28: and the Schumer-Pelosi three-month debt ceiling extension. The Senate had already passed it on Thursday.
column29: \u201cHe insists on loyalty
column30: never gives any back
column31: \u201d said John Weaver
column32: who worked on Ohio Gov. John Kasich\u2019s bid for the GOP presidential nomination last year.
column33: Other Republicans
column34: who supported Trump once he had secured the nomination and defended him because they believed he would approve GOP legislative priorities
column35: saw this latest move as a threat to their agenda. \u201cHe thinks he\u2019s going to play the Democrats off the Republicans
column36: \u201d said one longtime Republican National Committee member who spoke on the condition of anonymity. \u201cRyan and McConnell better plan for more.\u201d
column37: Many of the same Republicans surprised and dismayed by Trump\u2019s move had openly embraced him a year ago. They pushed on voters the idea that he was a smart
column38: wealthy business executive \u2013 that despite a record that included scores of lawsuits
column39: four bankruptcies and a relatively low net worth given that he began four decades ago with a business worth $1 billion in today\u2019s dollars.
column40: That actual history
column41: Wilson said
column42: should have guided congressional leaders as they dealt with his White House. \u201cHe\u2019s never kept a vow
column43: contract or agreement. Ever. Sane people know he\u2019s a lying liar who lies at all times
column44: \u201d he said
column45: attributing Trump\u2019s successful image to his hit television show
column46: \u201cThe Apprentice.\u201d \u201cHe\u2019s not really a business guy. He\u2019s a guy who played a business guy on TV.\u201d
column47: Trump\u2019s defenders say that if Republicans are angry about Trump choosing to work with Democrats
column48: they have only themselves to blame for failing to give Trump legislative successes during his first seven months in office. \u201cThey\u2019ve been openly hostile to him for months. This is the price they pay
column49: \u201d Caputo said. \u201cHe taught the Republicans a lesson they sorely needed.\u201d
column50: Weaver disputed that congressional Republicans have been holding Trump back
column51: arguing that Trump\u2019s failure to achieve any significant legislation on his priorities this year was due entirely to the president\u2019s lack of serious interest in any issue. \u201cWhich is what?\u201d Weaver said about Trump\u2019s supposed priorities. \u201cOther than blocking the Russia investigation
column52: I\u2019m not sure what he wanted.\u201d
column53: He warned his fellow Republicans that the worst was likely yet to come
column54: with Trump continuing to abandon GOP legislative goals in favor of whatever he happens to seize upon at that moment \u2013 and taking his strongest supporters with him
column55: endangering Republicans in next fall\u2019s elections.
column56: \u201cHis hardcore 20 percent?\u201d Weaver said. \u201cThey don\u2019t really care about Paul Ryan\u2019s Ayn Rand agenda or Mitch McConnell\u2019s apparatchik agenda.
column57:

Trump DOJ To Supreme Court: Making Gay Wedding Cake Would Violate Baker's Rights

|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 The Department of Justice told the Supreme Court on Thursday that a baker who is religiously opposed to gay marriage should not be forced to make wedding cakes for same-sex couples.
column2: DOJ said that requiring Jack Phillips
column3: the owner of Masterpiece Cakeshop in Colorado
column4: to create a wedding cake for a gay couple under public accommodations laws would violate his constitutional rights.
column5: \u201cForcing Phillips to create expression for and participate in a ceremony that violates his sincerely held religious beliefs invades his First Amendment rights
column6: \u201d the Justice Department wrote in an amicus brief filed ahead of oral argument in the case. \u201cIn the view of the United States
column7: a ... First Amendment intrusion occurs where a public accommodations law compels someone to create expression for a particular person or entity and to participate
column8: literally or figuratively
column9: in a ceremony or other expressive event.\u201d
column10: Businesses and other places that are considered \u201cpublic accommodations\u201d are barred by law from discriminating against people on the basis of factors like race and religion.\xa0The DOJ brief suggests that such laws should not be able to compel artists to create\xa0\u201cinherently communicative\u201d goods
column11: like wedding cakes.
column12: DOJ\u2019s filing raises the possibility that if the Masterpiece Cakeshop can\u2019t refuse to bake a cake for the marriage of a same-sex couple
column13: then a freelance graphic designer who designs flyers for Jewish affinity groups might also be forced to do so \u201cfor a neo-Nazi group or the Westboro Baptist Church.\u201d
column14: \u201cA custom wedding cake can be sufficiently artistic to qualify as pure speech
column15: akin to a sculptural centerpiece
column16: \u201d the Justice Department wrote. \u201cIn short
column17: a custom wedding cake is not an ordinary baked good; its function is more communicative and artistic than utilitarian.\u201d
column18: If forced to create such a cake for a gay couple
column19: the DOJ brief argues
column20: Phillips would be required to essentially \u201cparticipate in a wedding celebration that conflicts with his sincerely held religious beliefs.\u201d
column21: The Justice Department also noted that
column22: at the time Phillips refused to make the cake for David Mullins and Charlie Craig in July 2012
column23: the state of Colorado did not recognize same-sex marriages.
column24: \u201cIn other words
column25: the State itself did not acknowledge the validity of the union it sought to compel petitioners to celebrate
column26: \u201d DOJ wrote. \u201cEspecially given that background
column27: the State has not advanced a sufficient state interest to override petitioners\u2019 weighty First Amendment interest in declining to create the expression at issue here.\u201d
column28: In a statement
column29: a Justice Department spokeswoman said the amicus brief was filed to protect the free expression of all Americans.
column30: \u201cAlthough public-accommodations laws serve important purposes
column31: they \u2015 like other laws \u2015 must yield to the individual freedoms that the First Amendment guarantees
column32: \u201d said spokeswoman Lauren Ehrsam. \u201cThat includes the freedom not to create expression for ceremonies that violate one\u2019s religious beliefs.\u201d\xa0
column33: Louise Melling
column34: deputy legal director for the American Civil Liberties Union
column35: said the brief \u201cwas shocking
column36: even for this administration.\u201d She said the Trump administration \u201cis advocating for nothing short of a constitutional right to discriminate.\u201d
column37:

This Is What It's Like To Lose Your Job Because Of A Hurricane

|[

Kelsey Averill used to work at the Cypresswood Golf Club in Spring
column2: Texas
column3: as a cart girl and server. She loved her gig
column4: which she said paid $7.25 an hour plus tips
column5: and was saving up to move out of her parent\u2019s house. Then
column6: Hurricane Harvey hit.
column7: The flood engulfed the golf clubhouse and ruined\xa0equipment. At first
column8: Averill thought she\u2019d be able to return to work
column9: eventually. But days later
column10: after the storm had settled
column11: her managers sent the staff information about signing up for unemployment benefits
column12: the 18-year-old college student said. Managers at the business could not be reached for comment
column13: though their website notes that the club is closed \u201cuntil further notice\u201d because of Harvey.
column14: \u201cThey\u2019re definitely trying to help and do everything that they can
column15: \u201d she said. But in the meantime
column16: she has bills to pay
column17: including insurance and gas. It\u2019s \u201chard trying to get back into the job world
column18: \u201d she said
column19: adding she\u2019s worried there are a lot of people applying for jobs.
column20: During any major hurricane
column21: victims are left to deal with devastating flooding
column22: ruined homes
column23: lost possessions
column24: and unusable cars. But a disaster on the scale of Harvey\u2014and potentially
column25: Hurricane Irma\u2014can also wipe out livelihoods. A number of Texans are finding that the storm has destroyed their workplaces
column26: and many don\u2019t know when they will reopen. One person
column27: who spoke to HuffPost on the condition of anonymity because he didn\u2019t want to jeopardize his job
column28: forwarded an email his Texas-based employer sent out.\xa0He said the company was docking staff salaries as a result of Harvey-related losses.
column29: Still more Texans may have been fired simply because they couldn\u2019t get to work during the storm. Amanda Bosley
column30: a legal fellow at Lone Star Legal Aid in Houston
column31: which had its headquarters damaged by Harvey
column32: told HuffPost she had spoken to one such person so far
column33: but suspected \u201cthere are many more.\u201d \xa0
column34: In 49 states
column35: including Texas
column36: people are employed \u201cat-will
column37: \u201d which means you can be \u201cfired for good
column38: bad
column39: or no reason at all
column40: \u201d said Paul Secunda
column41: a law professor at Marquette University in Milwaukee
column42: Wisconsin
column43: who assisted victims during Hurricane Katrina. \u201cThere is no job security.\u201d
column44: There is federal funding available to people who have faced job repercussions as a direct result of a major disaster \u2015 a state administered program known as Disaster Unemployment Assistance. As of Tuesday
column45: the Texas Workforce Commission had taken about 75
column46: 300 disaster-related unemployment insurance claims
column47: agency spokeswoman Lisa Givens told HuffPost via email. She added that the agency is still in the process of determining who is eligible.
column48: In some cases
column49: \xa0an employer and employee may disagree about why the person was fired. But when it comes to benefits
column50: \u201cwe make decisions about eligibility based on the individual situations
column51: \u201d Givens said. \u201cIn general
column52: a person must have lost their job through no fault of their own.\u201d
column53: The aid extends to people who were scheduled to start a new job\xa0that no longer exists due to the storm. It also applies to people who have suffered a disaster-related injury. More than half a million people lost their jobs after hurricanes Katrina and Rita
column54: and there was an increase in applicants for both regular unemployment insurance and DUA benefits
column55: according to a 2007 Government Accountability Office report. (With DUA
column56: people already on unemployment cannot get additional disaster-related benefits.)\xa0
column57: Mark Levi Betancourt
column59: was a full-time employee of Woody\u2019s Sports Center
column60: which charters boat trips
column61: in Port Aransas
column62: Texas. Harvey forced him to evacuate
column63: and his family is now fundraising to replace his damaged trailer home. He says he\u2019s been busy helping older people in the trailer park since the storm
column64: cleaning out houses and putting garbage on the curb. But even if he could make it to his job
column65: there\u2019s no work to go back to.
column66: The Sports Center docks are unusable
column67: and power and water lines are wiped out. Glenn Martin
column68: the president of the business
column69: estimates they\u2019re not going to reopen for at least two months. Employees can help out with some reconstruction
column70: but Martin doesn\u2019t expect there to be a full-time job available for a while.
column71: Betancourt said the storm is \u201churting a lot of people emotionally.\u201d But he felt like he was already struggling financially and living paycheck to paycheck.\xa0\u201cI\u2019ve been living on the bottom forever
column72: it\u2019s not like I had far to fall.\u201d Despite that
column73: he said he is conflicted about applying for disaster unemployment: \u201cI\u2019ve never taken a free dollar in my life.\u201d
column74: As in past disasters
column75: the federal government has given extra food stamp benefits to people enrolled in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program who live in counties affected by the storm. The Federal Emergency Management Agency also hires local survivors for 120-day terms to help with disaster assistance.
column76: Averill
column77: from the golf club
column78: said she applied for benefits
column79: and is already sending her application in for other jobs
column80: at restaurants like Panera Bread. But
column82: \u201cno calls yet.\u201d
column83:
Arthur Delaney contributed reporting.

]

U.S. Appeals Court Rules Against Trump's Effort To Broadly Enforce Travel Ban

|[

By Mica Rosenberg and Jonathan Stempel
column2: NEW YORK (Reuters) - A U.S.\xa0appeals court on Thursday rejected the Trump administration\u2019s effort to temporarily bar most refugees from entering the country
column3: ruling that those who have relationships with a resettlement agency should be exempt from an executive order banning refugees.
column4: A three-judge 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals panel also ruled that grandparents
column5: aunts
column6: uncles and cousins of legal U.S. residents should be exempted from President Donald Trump\u2019s order
column7: which banned travelers from six Muslim-majority countries.
column8: The ruling is the latest legal blow to the President\u2019s sweeping executive order barring travelers from Iran
column9: Syria
column10: Libya
column11: Somalia
column12: Sudan and Yemen for 90 days
column13: which the Republican president said was necessary for national security.
column14: The Justices said that the government did not persuasively explain why the travel ban should be enforced against close relatives of people from the six countries or refugees with guarantees from resettlement agencies. The 3-0 ruling takes effect in five days.
column15: The U.S. Supreme Court ruled in June that Trump\u2019s ban could be implemented on a limited basis
column16: but should not be applied to people with \u201cbona fide\u201d relationships to people or entities in the United States.
column17: The government took a narrow view of that interpretation
column18: which the state of Hawaii challenged in court. A lower court judge sided with Hawaii
column19: and the 9th Circuit judges upheld that view.
column20: \u201cIt is hard to see how a grandparent
column21: grandchild
column22: aunt
column23: uncle
column24: niece
column25: nephew
column26: sibling-in-law
column27: or cousin can be considered to have no bona fide relationship with their relative in the United States
column28: \u201d the court said.
column29: The court also rejected the administration\u2019s argument that the written assurances provided by resettlement agencies obligating them to provide services for specific refugees is not a bona fide relationship.
column30: The agencies\u2019 advance preparation and expenditure of resources for each refugee \u201csupports the district court\u2019s determination that a bona fide relationship with the refugee exists
column31: \u201d the decision said.
column32: Trump\u2019s first version of the executive order
column33: signed in January
column34: sparked protests and chaos at airports around the country and the world before it was blocked by courts. The administration replaced that version of the ban with a new order in March in response to the legal challenges.
column35: A Department of Justice spokeswoman said: \u201cThe Supreme Court has stepped in to correct these lower courts before
column36: and we will now return to the Supreme Court to vindicate the Executive Branch\u2019s duty to protect the Nation.\u201d
column37: Hawaii\u2019s Attorney General Douglas Chin said the ruling \u201ckeeps families together. It gives vetted refugees a second chance. The Trump administration keeps taking actions with no legal basis. We will keep fighting back.\u201d
column38: Refugee organizations cheered Thursday\u2019s decision
column39: saying it will give relief to people fleeing violence who were caught in limbo after the ban.
column40: The broader question of whether the revised travel ban discriminates against Muslims in violation of the U.S. Constitution will be considered by the U.S. Supreme Court in October.
column42:
(Reporting by Mica Rosenberg and Jonathan Stempel in New York; Additional reporting by Andrew Chung and Lawrence Hurley in Washington; editing by Sue Horton and Grant McCool)

]
