How Food Stamps Help Disaster Victims

|[

When Crystal Estrada returned to Victoria
column2: Texas
column3: after Hurricane Harvey
column4: she found her home ripped apart with shreds of fiberglass insulation strewn among her family\u2019s belongings.
column5: \u201cThere\u2019s no roof
column6: \u201d she said. \u201cThere\u2019s no walls
column7: there\u2019s no doors
column8: there\u2019s nothing.\u201d
column9: Estrada
column11: and her family evacuated the day before the storm arrived. Now they\u2019re living in a San Antonio motel
column12: and the Federal Emergency Management Agency is paying for the room until Sept.\xa026. (State governments
column13: though
column14: can collaborate with FEMA and\xa0extend stays for up to six months.)\xa0Estrada said she has no idea what she and her family will do once that ends.
column15: \u201cAfter the 26th
column16: we will be in the streets
column17: \u201d she said.
column18: One thing that has made the ordeal a little more bearable: extra food stamp benefits. To make up for all the food lost in powerless refrigerators and ruined kitchens
column19: the Texas Department of Health and Human Services on Friday\xa0reissued the benefit allotment for the month of August to more than 700
column20: 000 people who had been receiving Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program benefits in 58 Harvey-afflicted counties.
column21: \u201cWe were really hungry
column22: and when we got them food stamps
column23: we were so happy
column24: \u201d Estrada said.
column25: The state also distributed September benefits on the first of the month
column26: rather than following the usual practice of staggering delivery over several days. Estrada would normally have received her $194 benefit on Sept. 6.
column27: The U.S. Department of Agriculture
column28: which oversees food stamps
column29: approved the replacement benefits and the early September distribution last week. The USDA also agreed to waive SNAP\u2019s prohibition on using benefits for prepared meals; the program typically restricts purchases to food products for home consumption. Estrada said she\u2019s been able to use her benefits for chicken tenders and fries at Walmart.
column30: On Thursday
column31: the USDA announced a plan to distribute boxes of food directly to people\u2019s houses. Sometime soon
column32: a department spokesman said
column33: Texas will probably also be able to distribute special disaster benefits
column34: known as D-SNAP
column35: that can be used by storm victims who didn\u2019t already qualify for food stamps because of poverty. (Such disaster benefits are typically rolled out later in a storm recovery since it\u2019s necessary for retail stores to be up and running for the benefits to be redeemed.) \xa0
column36: Extra food stamp benefits have long been an important part of the federal government\u2019s response to disasters
column37: which partly reflects the program\u2019s built-in responsiveness to economic need. The USDA distributed $320 million worth of disaster and replacement food stamps last year
column38: plus emergency food supplies. After Hurricanes Katrina and Rita in 2005
column39: the department distributed more than $680 million worth of disaster SNAP assistance to nearly 1.5 million households. The money comes from the program\u2019s budget and doesn\u2019t need an additional appropriation from Congress.
column40: The nutrition program isn\u2019t a first responder
column41: said Ellen Vollinger of the Food Research & Action Center. \u201cBut within the world of government relief programs
column42: \u201d she said
column43: \u201cSNAP is considered a pretty important near-term responder.\u201d
column44: Other federal nutrition programs
column45: including the National School Lunch Program and the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program For Women
column46: Infants and Children
column47: also typically relax rules for people affected by major disasters.
column48: The city of Victoria is about an hour north from where Harvey made landfall. Estrada
column49: along with her girlfriend
column50: her girlfriend\u2019s two young children
column51: and their dog
column52: fled to San Antonio the day before the storm arrived. For a week they stayed in a shelter
column53: sleeping in a room with hundreds of other people.
column54: They got the motel room on Friday. Estrada said she is disabled and had to use all of her monthly Supplemental Security Income check to pay for necessities like gas
column55: clothes and cleaning supplies. The SNAP benefits have been a huge help.
column56: \u201cWe\u2019re spending our own money to where we don\u2019t have no more money and we\u2019re out of gas
column57: \u201d she said.
column58: People at the motel have been incredibly nice
column59: she said
column60: and someone even gave them free tickets to Six Flags
column61: which was a thrill for her girlfriend\u2019s 9-year-old and 6-year-old. After they returned
column62: the person who gave them the tickets asked the kids if they had fun and was surprised that they didn\u2019t seem more enthusiastic.
column63: \u201cThe lady was like
column64: \u2018What\u2019s wrong with them?\u2019 They\u2019re still dazed on it. I guess they don\u2019t get it. They want to go home
column65:
\u201d Estrada said. \u201cThey\u2019re missing a lot of school and we don\u2019t know what to do.\u201d

]

Why One Congressional Primary Has Democrats Excited For 2018

|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 The Democratic Party has a good problem going into the 2018 midterms: Things are starting to feel a little crowded.
column2: Consider the jam-packed Democratic primary to unseat Rep.\xa0Barbara Comstock (R-Va.)
column3: a longtime Democratic target who party officials believe can finally be toppled thanks to President Donald Trump\u2019s unpopularity in the district.\xa0At last count
column4: no fewer than eight Democratic candidates have declared for that race.
column5: State Sen. Jennifer Wexton (D-Leesburg)
column6: initially considered the favorite to win the nomination
column7: is facing an unexpectedly stiff challenge. After the first two fundraising quarters of 2018
column8: Wexton has been heavily outraised by three opponents: former State Department official and anti-human trafficking advocate Alison Kiehl Friedman; Army veteran and business strategist Dan Helmer; and Obama administration alumnus and communications consultant Lindsey Davis Stover.
column9: Friedman
column10: already leading the pack in fundraising thanks to an early endorsement from the feminist activist and writer Gloria Steinem
column11: is set to announce several high-profile endorsements in the days and weeks to come \u2015 including one this week from Khizr Khan
column12: an outspoken critic of Trump whose son
column13: Army Capt. Humayun Khan
column14: was killed while deployed in Iraq in 2004. In an endorsement letter provided to HuffPost
column15: Khan
column16: writing as \u201ca proud Virginian patriot
column17: \u201d praises Friedman\u2019s work \u201cserving people who are often ignored or left out.\u201d Friedman
column18: whose mother
column19: Kristina Kiehl
column20: co-founded the reproductive rights group Voters for Choice with Steinem
column21: has benefited from deep ties to a nationwide network of progressive activists.
column22: Friedman isn\u2019t the only rookie candidate lining up high-profile endorsements. Davis Stover is set to appear alongside reproductive rights activist and former Texas state Sen. Wendy Davis
column23: and recently held an event with Sen. Tammy Duckworth (D-Ill.)
column24: who worked with Davis Stover at the Department of Veterans Affairs in the Obama administration.
column25: \u201cWe bring a lot of depth of federal experience to this race
column26: \u201d Davis Stover told HuffPost. \u201cI\u2019ve lived many of the challenges people are facing right now.\u201d
column27: Helmer
column28: meanwhile
column29: has received a number of endorsements from the national security establishment \u2015 which is heavily represented in Comstock\u2019s district
column30: thanks to its proximity to Washington\xa0\u2015 including former Obama administration official Michele Flournoy and the progressive veterans organization VoteVets.
column31: That many of the most competitive candidates weren\u2019t even on the district\u2019s political radar a year ago is striking evidence of how the surge in political engagement on the left
column32: prompted by Trump\u2019s contentious administration
column33: is reshuffling just who makes up the party \u201cestablishment.\u201d This
column34: in turn
column35: is forcing Democratic Party officials to take a more passive approach to elections
column36: as grassroots activists and members of the party\u2019s myriad factions jockey for position.
column37: The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee
column38: House Democrats\u2019 campaign arm
column39: had recruited Wexton and publicly heralded her entrance into the race earlier this year
column40: but was forced to sit back as more candidates threw their hats in the ring. Now
column41: instead of focusing its efforts solely on Wexton
column42: the DCCC is providing assistance to a number of candidates and is coordinating anti-Comstock messaging where it can.
column43: Wexton still sports the deepest endorsement bench
column44: including Reps. Gerry Connolly and Donald McEachin
column45: both Virginia Democrats
column46: as well as a slew of state legislators
column47: county supervisors

A Few Simple Ideas From State Officials To Shore Up Obamacare Markets

|[

The weirdest thing happened on Wednesday: A calm
column2: sensible and bipartisan\xa0conversation about health care broke out on Capitol Hill.
column3: The discussion took place in the Senate\u2019s health
column4: education
column5: labor and pensions committee
column6: which held the first of four planned hearings on \u201cstabilizing\u201d the Affordable Care Act\u2019s private insurance markets. And the very existence of the hearing represents a milestone of sorts
column7: although the prospects of that conversation leading to meaningful legislation this year remain slim.\xa0
column8: For the last eight months
column9: ever since Donald Trump became president
column10: the focus of official debate on Capitol Hill has been on whether and how to repeal Obamacare. The premise of repeal
column11: a cause that has defined GOP politics for years
column12: is that the 2010 health care law has been an utter failure \u2015 sticking people with unaffordable
column13: lousy coverage while causing private insurance markets to break down completely.
column14: Wednesday\u2019s hearing
column15: which featured testimony from five state insurance regulators
column16: produced a more nuanced picture \u2015 of a law that has done a lot of good while running into some severe difficulties in parts of the country. Conversation between the senators and the witnesses kept returning to a series of relatively modest policy initiatives that could shore up shaky markets where they exist. And most of the senators seemed genuinely interested in thinking about
column17: or at least talking about
column18: the merits of each.
column19: This is the way governing is supposed to work
column20: and it\u2019s precisely the sort of hearing that the committee\u2019s Republican chairman
column21: Lamar Alexander of Tennessee
column22: had promised. \u201cThis hearing is about taking one small step
column23: \u201d Alexander said in his opening statement.
column24: And it shouldn\u2019t be a hard step to take
column25: at least in theory. The Affordable Care Act has brought the number of Americans without insurance to historic lows
column26: in part by making comprehensive insurance coverage available to people who couldn\u2019t get it before
column27: either because they had pre-existing conditions or couldn\u2019t afford it without the law\u2019s federal tax credits.
column28: But in many states
column29: insurers have struggled to attract enough healthy people
column30: whose premium dollars end up subsidizing the bills of those with serious medical problems. In response
column31: carriers have raised premiums or abandoned markets altogether. Although millions get tax credits that insulate them from higher premiums
column32: millions do not. A large number of counties are down to just one insurer for next year and
column33: as of Wednesday afternoon
column34: a number of counties in Virginia have none \u2015 although
column35: if recent history is indicative
column36: an insurer will swoop in to take the business.
column37: Heading into 2017
column38: as President Barack Obama was leaving office
column39: there were signs that the overall situation was finally\xa0improving
column40: with insurers finding their way to better margins and some companies expanding operations
column41: even as others were withdrawing. One reason for this was careful nurturing from the Obama administration and those state officials
column42: such as California\u2019s
column43: who were committed to making the program work well.
column44: But now
column45: instead of a president trying to make the program succeed
column46: there\u2019s a president doing what he can to make it fail. Trump has threatened repeatedly to stop special payments to insurers
column47: promised by the law but never appropriated
column48: that are designed to underwrite the cost of extra financial protection for low-income consumers. Insurers have responded by seeking even higher premiums for 2018. The higher premiums might not affect consumers
column49: depending on how insurers and regulators set the increases
column50: but the federal government would end up spending more
column51: and it\u2019s one more sign of how antsy the carriers have become.
column52: As if that were not enough
column53: last week the Department of Health and Human Services announced a massive cut to advertising and outreach. Many experts fear that
column54: without the outreach
column55: enrollment will drop
column56: particularly among the healthy people insurers want to attract. In other words
column57: the cut to enrollment spending could make the system\u2019s actuarial problems worse
column58: driving premiums even higher.\xa0
column59: The potential damage of those moves and the importance of counteracting them were common refrains from the witnesses and their interlocutors at Wednesday\u2019s hearing. Julie McPeak
column60: Tennessee\u2019s insurance commissioner
column61: called restoration of the insurance funding \u201cthe single most critical issue that you can address to help stabilize insurance markets for 2018 and potentially bring down costs.\u201d\xa0
column62: The other big idea to get attention Wednesday was a proposal to create a federal \u201creinsurance\u201d program
column63: similar to one that the Affordable Care Act had in place for its first three years. Reinsurance essentially reimburses insurers for their most expensive customers \u2015 say
column64: anybody with claims that exceed $1 million in a year. It\u2019s a way of spreading those costs across a broad population
column65: which is what insurance is designed to do
column66: and such an initiative would almost certainly allow insurers to reduce premiums across the board.
column67: States can take that action on their own by taking advantage of special waivers the Affordable Care Act already allows
column68: and the commissioner from one of those states
column69: Alaska\u2019s Lori Wing-Heier
column70: told the panel how successful it\u2019s been. But she and other state officials want the federal government to streamline the waiver application process
column71: and many would like Congress to put some new federal money into the program as well.
column72: That last part is probably more than Congress is willing to do right now. Even though creating a new federal reinsurance program is a sensible idea with a history of bipartisan support
column73: it would require appropriating money that
column74: at least in the short term
column75: this Republican Congress is not about to spend. Alexander made that clear
column76: endorsing the idea in theory but repeatedly asking why the federal government
column77: rather than the states
column78: should devote new money to it.
column79: Of course
column80: passing even a narrower measure could be difficult. Alexander and the committee\u2019s ranking Democratic
column82: have sketched out what such a bill would entail: making those insurer payments
column83: at least for a little while
column84: in exchange for giving states some new flexibility over how the law works in their states. Although it looks like Murray wants a longer duration of payments than Alexander is willing to guarantee and Alexander wants more flexibility than Murray wants to give
column85: it\u2019s easy to imagine the two of them finding a compromise.
column86: What\u2019s not so easy to imagine is getting agreement from the rest of the Senate
column87: to say nothing of the House and then the president
column88: given lingering GOP interest in repeal. As if to underscore the difficulty
column89: Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.)
column90: whose no vote helped kill a GOP repeal effort in July
column91: told reporters Wednesday that he would support a health care bill his best friend in Congress
column92: Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.)
column93: has sponsored. That bill is another effort at full repeal and would almost surely leave millions without coverage.
column94: McCain later walked back his statement

getting their support for a narrow repair bill will be that much harder.

Nancy Pelosi Says Trump Promised Her He'd Sign The Dream Act

|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) said Thursday that President Donald Trump told her on two occasions that he supports and would sign a bill to give legal status to young undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children.
column2: \u201cWe made it very clear in the course of the conversation that the priority was to pass the Dream Act
column3: \u201d Pelosi said at a press briefing. \u201cObviously it has to be bipartisan. The president supports that
column4: he would sign it. But we have to get it passed.\u201d
column5: Democrats are pushing for the bill
column6: called the Dream Act
column7: after Trump rescinded the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program earlier this week. So-called Dreamers who received two-year work permits and deportation protections will begin to lose them in six months unless Congress steps in to act.
column8: Trump has said he wants to work with Congress
column9: including Democrats
column10: to pass a bill that addresses DACA recipients before that time. He called Pelosi earlier Thursday and made the comment about the Dream Act then
column11: as well as in a meeting on Wednesday
column12: according to Pelosi.\xa0
column13: After their phone conversation
column14: Trump tweeted to say Dreamers should not worry about being detained\xa0over the next six months
column15: which a Democratic aide said Pelosi requested he say publicly.
column16: The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment on the conversations.
column17: Democrats in the House and Senate called for a vote on the Dream Act in September and said they are prepared to attach the legislation to other bills until it passes. Earlier this week
column18: lawmakers opened up an informal restriction on co-sponsorship of the bill \u2015 they were allowing members to sign on only in Democrat-Republican pairs \u2015 and expect the number of backers to go up significantly in the House.
column19: Pelosi predicted it would pass in the House if it was allowed to go for a vote. That would depend
column20: however
column21: on whether House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) allowed it to go for a vote. He said Wednesday that he wanted to pair Dreamer legislation with border security.
column22: The same goes for the Senate
column23: where Senate Majority Leader Mitchell McConnell (R-Ky.) has previously opposed the Dream Act and other immigration bills that would grant legal status to undocumented immigrants.
column24: Pelosi said she believes Trump will demand border security measures as part of a Dream Act package
column25: but not a wall.
column26: Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) said Thursday morning on the Senate floor that Trump called him earlier in the day and \u201csaid he wanted to help in the Dream Act.\u201d Schumer said that he asked Trump to push other Republicans to support the bill and Ryan and McConnell to hold a vote \u201cASAP.\u201d
column27: \u201cWe now have four Republican cosponsors. We need more
column28: \u201d Schumer said. \u201cThere are many on the floor
column29: in the Senate
column30: who seem to be sympathetic to the Dream Act. Maybe the president can help them get to cosponsor.\u201d
column31: The Dream Act
column32: first introduced in 2001
column33: would allow certain young undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. under the age of 18 to gain legal status and eventually become eligible for citizenship.\xa0
column34: Republicans are also gathering support for the Recognizing America\u2019s Children
column35: or RAC Act
column36: a standalone bill that would allow certain young undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children to gain legal status. That bill would apply to a narrower population of Dreamers: only those who entered before the age of 16 would be eligible.\xa0
column37: The RAC Act is picking up steam in the House. It gained nine co-sponsors on Tuesday and Wednesday
column38: and is now up to 28 backers in total
column39:
all of them Republicans. Sen. Thom Tillis (R-N.C.) is expected to introduce the RAC Act in the Senate in coming days.

For Hurricane Irma|[

FORT LAUDERDALE
column4: Fla. \u2015 Hamilton de Toledo had finally made it to the checkout counter at Home Depot when a frantic employee approached the cashier with bad news: There\u2019s no more plywood.
column5: Just outside the store\u2019s front door
column6: the line that had formed for the sheets of plywood that would
column7: hopefully
column8: protect windows
column9: doors and homes from the winds of the fast-approaching Hurricane Irma had finally drained Home Depot\u2019s supply. Wednesday alone
column10: this location had gone through three truckloads of plywood \u2015 with each truck carrying 20 bundles of 60 sheets apiece
column11: one store employee said \u2015 as the city and its residents scrambled to prepare for the arrival of Irma
column12: the storm that has already devastated Caribbean islands and is expected to turn north toward Florida.
column13: De Toledo\u2019s house has impact-resistant windows
column14: so the wood wasn\u2019t for his home. Instead
column15: he needed it for his niece
column16: who lives a few blocks away. Irma

column20: with the cashier in the process of swiping his card

column23: after a nervous few minutes of waiting in line
column24: he snagged the final five sheets of plywood Home Depot had
column25: plus two broken pieces the store gave him for the price of one.
column26: \u201cI\u2019ve never been this concerned
column27: \u201d de Toledo said as he wheeled the sheets to his pickup truck. \u201cI\u2019m trying not to be
column28: but it\u2019s hard.\u201d
column29: Florida Gov. Rick Scott (R) has warned that Hurricane Irma is \u201cbigger
column30: faster and stronger\u201d than even Hurricane Andrew
column31: the devastating storm that barreled into the Miami coast in 1992
column32: causing 44 deaths and $25 billion worth of damage a quarter century ago last week. As of late Wednesday
column33: Irma had had sustained winds of 185 miles per hour for more than 24 hours
column34: and it remained a Category 5 storm capable of causing massive destruction across the Caribbean and into Florida.
column35: Miami-Dade County Mayor Carlos Gim\xe9nez began ordering evacuations Wednesday. The Florida Keys were under mandatory evacuation orders
column36: and Miami Beach Mayor Philip Levine pushed residents of the barrier island to head toward the mainland.
column37: It was an odd paradox
column38: though
column39: that their urgency also fostered a sense of calm as residents of Florida\u2019s Atlantic Coast communities prepared for Irma\u2019s wrath.
column40: Home Depot wasn\u2019t the only store short on supplies. At a local Walmart
column41: shelves that would normally hold pallets of bottled water
column42: non-perishable food items and necessities such as gas cans and batteries were bare before noon Wednesday. Lines of cars stretched from gas station pumps into the streets
column43: with wait times for the chance to fuel up lasting an hour or longer. Some stations have run out of gas.
column44: But for the most part
column45: there was little outward indication of fear or frenzy. Those in line behind de Toledo left Home Depot without fuss
column46: vowing to return Thursday. Lines of patient Walmart shoppers waited with barely a word as employees fetched extra packages of water bottles from storage.
column47: The dire warnings of Irma\u2019s strength
column48: it seems
column49: have succeeded in persuading Floridians to prepare for disaster well in advance of its prospective arrival
column50: which in turn has succeeded in keeping everyone as tranquil as can be expected. If stores run out of water or gas today
column51: it is early enough for new shipments to come in tomorrow
column52: with at least some time to spare. It\u2019s as if everyone understands that freaking out will only make everyone\u2019s lives worse.
column53: \u201cPeople are getting ready [early]
column54: \u201d de Toledo said. \u201cSo the gas stations
column55: the stores
column56: they have time to replenish for people to continue getting ready.\u201d
column57: At times Wednesday
column58: that sense of serenity and normality felt almost eerie.
column59: On Fort Lauderdale Beach
column60: tourists and locals alike still enjoyed a day of sun as lifeguard stands flew green flags to indicate that the ocean was calm
column61: no matter what sort of storm loomed beyond the horizon.
column62: Jim Green
column63: who has lived here for four years
column64: spent the early afternoon on the beach. Green rents a fourth-floor condo nearby and has a place on the Gulf Coast
column65: too. There\u2019s still a chance Irma might swing out east into the Atlantic or turn westward toward the Gulf of Mexico. Green is waiting for Thursday\u2019s forecast to see which direction the storm might go. Only then will he decide which way he heads in response. His biggest worry is how his two cats will fare. Either way
column66: they\u2019re going with him.
column67: Kristal and Corey Davis sat a short walk down the beach
column68: gazing out at an ocean dotted with a dozen yachts and catamarans sprinting across the water as if it were any other day. The couple vacations in Fort Lauderdale every year. They\u2019ll head home to Maryland on Saturday morning
column69: a day earlier than planned.
column70: The emptier-than-usual beaches and restaurants are \u201ca little bit more relaxing
column71: \u201d Kristal Davis said. \u201cBut it\u2019s still tense
column72: because you know a hurricane is coming and people are going to be impacted. \u2026 For it to impact a place that we call a second home
column73: it is concerning to us.\u201d
column74: Across the beachfront boardwalk behind them
column75: Freddy Bousquet opened The Drunken Taco for lunch
column76: as he has most every day for the last three years. The lunchtime crowd was small
column77: aside from a few barflies and a table of men and women in Army fatigues. But September is always the slowest time here. Bousquet
column78: the restaurant\u2019s general manager
column79: lost a few employees for the weekend as they evacuated or went home to prepare for Irma\u2019s arrival
column80: and he\u2019s still trying to determine what course he and the restaurant will take.\xa0
column81: \u201cThursday will be the right time to know where the storm will end up going
column82: \u201d Bousquet said. \u201cWe\u2019ll have a better idea where we\u2019re going to be and what we\u2019ll need to do at that point. If Thursday they say it\u2019s coming here
column83: we\u2019ll have to start shutting down the place.\u201d
column84: But Wednesday night
column85: the situation began to feel more desperate.\xa0The National Hurricane Center updated its projections to show that Irma could slam directly into South Florida as a Category 4 hurricane
column86: with tropical storm-force winds that could spread across the entire state. The NHC is expected to issue a hurricane watch for Florida on Thursday
column87: and more evacuation orders could be coming for Fort Lauderdale and beyond.
column88: Many local residents seem resolved to stay and ride out the storm. As if to hammer that point home
column89: a bar just off the beach announced a Wednesday night hurricane party with a sign that read
column90: bluntly
column91: \u201cFuck you
column92: Irma. We\u2019re Floridians.\u201d
column93: Scott
column94: however
column95: urged them not to.
column96: \u201cThis storm has the potential to devastate our state
column97: \u201d the governor said at a Wednesday evening news conference. \u201cWe have to take this seriously. ... Please do not think you can ride this storm out. Again

column101: Many residents who spoke to HuffPost suggested that they would likely leave if ordered to
column102: even if they weren\u2019t sure where they might go. Some pondered visits to far-off family. Others considered leaving almost everything behind. A waitress working overnight in a cafe near the ocean said she was considering a one-way flight out of town as soon as her shift ended.\xa0
column103: At least for now
column104:
South Florida seemed as prepared as it could be for a storm that no one could quite predict \u2015 and that no one could truly prepare for.

column49: she answered call after call from families who were stranded and frantically trying to find a way in for treatment. Their children were overdue for dialysis
column50: and starting to experience symptoms from missing it
column51: such as headaches and trouble breathing.
column52: \u201cThey missed Monday
column53: \u201d Besandre said. \u201cThey could not miss Tuesday as well.\u201d
column54: For five nights
column55: she slept on a recliner at the hospital
column56: where she stole a few hours rest between tornado drills. As the patients began arriving
column57: she was able to relax some.
column58: \u201cWe were so happy
column59: \u201d she said.
column60: For the Coast Guard members
column61: the feeling was mutual.
column62: \u201cTo hear the panic in that parent or guardian\u2019s voice
column63: you just feel for them
column64: \u201d Cook told HuffPost. \u201cSo when we got the email from [Gardner] saying that all the kids were accounted for and that they had made it to the hospital
column65:
it was such an amazing feeling.\u201d

column2:
Are Americans Still Reading Books?|[

In the Trump era
column3: it feels like book publishing is under siege. But is it really?
column4: Since the November election
column5: the majority of the publishing world \u2015 a mostly white
column6: mostly liberal crowd \u2015 has been reeling
column7: and not just because the Donald Trump presidency goes against the vaunted egalitarian principles of intellectual tastemakers. In The New Republic recently
column8: Morgan Jerkins reported that many authors
column9: editors and booksellers have noticed a significant slump in the market
column10: which many blame on the current administration.
column11: \u201cThe disastrous and almost comically incompetent Trump presidency has both frightened the reading market away from popular books and functioned as a kind of mass entertainment with which it is difficult to compete
column12: \u201d she wrote.\xa0
column13: But what are readers actually experiencing? Are they reading less and spending more time on activism? According to a new HuffPost/YouGov poll
column14: the answer to that is complicated
column15: but it suggests that Trump\u2019s rise has done little to substantially shift the habits of readers.
column16: Though 21 percent of respondents said they spent less time reading books in 2016 and 2017 than in past years
column17: 18 percent said they\u2019d spent more time reading books \u2015 and 41 percent spent about the same time as in previous years. (Notably
column18: black respondents were the most likely demographic group to report having read less in the past two years \u2015 32 percent
column19: compared to 20 percent of white and Hispanic respondents
column20: 21 percent of men and 24 percent of women.)\xa0
column21: Those who read less were significantly more likely to attribute it to having less free time or to stress rather than prioritizing political activism; only 9 percent said political engagement was a factor in reducing their reading time.
column22: Sales data from 2016 adds to this picture of a fairly stable publishing industry. According to Publishers Weekly
column23: print sales edged up last year
column24: and while adult fiction sales took a 1 percent dip
column25: juvenile fiction surged by 3.8 percent. That 3.8 percent boost was driven by a Y.A. book certainly purchased in bulk by adult readers: the script of J.K. Rowling\u2019s \u201cHarry Potter and the Cursed Child: Parts 1 and 2.\u201d PW also noted that adult nonfiction rocketed up by 6.9 percent
column26: specifically thanks to \u201ccrafts and hobbies
column27: where the adult coloring book boom \u2015 though slowing down from 2015\u2019s blitz \u2015 continues to have a large impact
column28: \u201d along with religious and self-help texts.
column29: Miriam Sontz
column30: CEO of Powell\u2019s Books
column31: a popular independent bookstore chain in and around Portland
column32: Oregon
column33: told HuffPost that the store did notice a lull in the immediate time frame of the election
column34: from the beginning of September to mid-November. \u201cThe news
column35: whether you thought it was good or bad
column36: dominated the landscape and didn\u2019t lead people to our shelves
column37: \u201d she said. But the idea of an ongoing slump didn\u2019t ring true to her. \u201cSince then
column38: \u201d she told HuffPost
column39: \u201csales have returned to reasonable levels and even increased in some areas.\u201d
column40: Notably
column41: several industry professionals reported to The New Republic a shift in readers\u2019 tastes
column42: if not the volume of reading. Booksellers and publishers have noticed a burst in popularity for classic dystopias
column43: and a renewed interest in political nonfiction or books by authors from marginalized groups \u2015 titles relevant
column44: in other words
column45: to the current political situation \u2015 and so have critics. This makes a lot of sense; one literary agent pointed out that authors keep getting bumped from morning TV shows to make space for political firestorms
column46: and authors have complained
column47: understandably
column48: that it feels gauche or unwelcome to promote their work in such a climate. Books like 1984\xa0or Ta-Nehisi Coates\u2019 Between the World and Me
column49: on the other hand
column50: have been eagerly pushed by tastemakers (and publications like HuffPost) looking to prove how literature can aid in our understanding of a challenging political era.\xa0
column51: Sontz agreed with the proposition that demands have shifted between genres \u2015 though not always in the expected areas. Poetry
column52: she said
column53: has seen a marked sales increase at Powells
column54: as have self-help books. Overall
column55: she told HuffPost
column56: \u201cPeople read what brings them comfort... and if that is a science fiction series
column57: or a political biography
column58: or a memoir
column59: they are reaching for the familiar and comfortable.\u201d
column60: As a whole
column61: it\u2019s unclear whether politics have shifted how most Americans are really choosing their books. The YouGov poll offered little support for the claim that readers are choosing politically-geared nonfiction over more frivolous options
column62: for example. While 12 percent of respondents said they\u2019d read more political essays or political science
column63: 13 percent said they\u2019d read less. And though publicist Kima Jones pointed out
column64: in The New Republic
column65: that writers of color have been particularly visible and successful in this market
column66: 46 percent of respondents reported never reading books by authors from marginalized groups
column67: including communities of color
column68: and just 6 percent reported increasing such reading since 2016 began. Nine percent reported reading fewer books by authors of color and other marginalized groups.
column69: Digging past the top line of results
column70: significant racial
column71: gender and political differences appeared in responses to the latter question. Fifty-two percent of men
column72: 50 percent of white respondents and 68 percent of Republicans reported never reading books by authors from traditionally marginalized groups
column73: compared to 41 percent of women
column74: 37 percent of black respondents
column75: 32 percent of Hispanic respondents and 38 percent of Democrats. While breakout authors of color have enjoyed critical and sales success in the past few years
column76: as Jones noted
column77: the readership of such books appears to come predominantly from more traditionally progressive demographics \u2015 most likely readers who are already sympathetic to the experiences and ideas of the authors.
column78: To be sure
column79: a sea change may have begun building in 2016
column80: but only grown to full strength by 2017. And self-reported behavior can be dicey; readers may fail to recognize shifts in their own behavior
column81: while those who work with large communities of readers easily pick up on the trends. Of respondents who read less in the past two years
column82: 19 percent cited not having \u201cseen as many books that I find interesting\u201d as a factor; if authors are getting bumped from publicity appearances and book review column inches
column83: that may be affecting how likely readers are to hear about new books they\u2019d find interesting.
column84: On the other hand
column85: it\u2019s also tempting for people within the industry to attribute the underperformance of specific books to the distracted cultural climate
column86: when some books have always underperformed the initial expectations.\xa0Alana Massey
column87: whose book came out in February
column88: said to Jerkins that she \u201cwas told that it just came out at a really bad time... I was sort of jokingly told that any books that weren\u2019t political
column89: dystopian
column90: or both
column91: weren\u2019t really selling.\u201d Maybe so \u2015 but it also might be easy for publishers to offer that explanation up to soften disappointment.
column92: Authors
column93: publishers and booksellers are constantly reading the tea leaves to decipher how much the reading public feels like reading
column94: and whether they\u2019re currently jonesing for a dystopia or a memoir or a romance. Promoting major books involves getting them into a news cycle that is currently consumed with Trump
column95: and so industry professionals are unquestionably forced to ask how to make their products seem relevant. This means a book like J.D. Vance\u2019s Hillbilly Elegy
column96: as Jerkins pointed out in TNR
column97: can garner a big publicity bump
column98: while a less timely book might wither.\xa0
column99: But this doesn\u2019t mean publishing as a whole will implode
column100: or even that certain genres will disappear. There\u2019s a strong possibility that
column101: overall
column102: readers who love romance will continue to read romance
column103: and that thriller lovers will continue to read thrillers
column104: regardless of what\u2019s on the news. \u201cI don\u2019t believe any president has this kind of impact on book buying
column105: \u201d Sontz told HuffPost. \u201cNow Oprah... that\u2019s a different story.\u201d
column107: 000 completed interviews conducted Aug. 14-15 among U.S. adults
column108: using a sample selected from YouGov\u2019s opt-in online panel to match the demographics and other characteristics of the adult U.S. population.

column111: but not all
column112: potential survey errors. YouGov\u2019s reports include a model-based margin of error
column113: which rests on a specific set of statistical assumptions about the selected sample rather than the standard methodology for random probability sampling. If these assumptions are wrong

the model-based margin of error may also be inaccurate. Click here for a more detailed explanation of the model-based margin of error.

This 6-Year-Old Spent A Year Of Her Life Fighting To Use Her School's Bathroom

|[

\u201cYou\u2019re going to have to hold it
column2: \u201d the teacher said.
column3: But 6-year-old Emma Smith couldn\u2019t.
column4: It was the second time that Emma was forced to urinate on herself while attending Glen Arden Elementary
column5: a small public school tucked away in the rural mountains of Western North Carolina.\xa0
column6: When the teacher realized what happened
column7: she walked Emma from the cafeteria to her classroom at the opposite end of Glen Arden to change \u2015 a trek the length of the school\u2019s campus \u2015 while Emma\u2019s urine trickled from her soiled clothing
column8: down her legs and filled her shoes.
column9: When she came home that day with a bag of urine-soaked clothes in tow
column10: it wasn\u2019t difficult for her parents to piece together what happened.
column11: Emma is a transgender child living in a part of America that has become a battleground for transgender rights\xa0\u2015 including the right to use the bathroom that corresponds with an individual\u2019s gender identity. First with 2016\u2032s\xa0House Bill 2 and now House Bill 142
column12: North Carolina helped galvanize a wave of proposed legislation that has swept the American South
column13: targeting transgender individuals and challenging their right to exist in public spaces.
column14: For Emma and her family
column15: this fight has become tangible and all-consuming over the past year.
column16: Amy and Kevin Smith live in a modest home in a small community outside of historically liberal Asheville
column17: North Carolina with their three children and a menagerie of pets. In 2014
column18: Emma
column19: their youngest child
column20: who was assigned male at birth
column21: began gravitating towards toys and clothing traditionally understood for girls.
column22: \u201cShe always had girl tendencies
column23: \u201d Kevin told HuffPost. \u201cShe\u2019s always been petite
column24: she\u2019s aways been sweet like a little girl. Before we ever realized
column25: she was always wanting pink and girls\u2019 toys
column26: dolls. We didn\u2019t really know what was going on with it
column27: we just thought
column28: \u2018Pink
column29: blue
column30: what makes a difference? We don\u2019t care.\u2019\u201d
column31: For a few years
column32: the parents thought Emma\u2019s preference for girls\u2019 toys and clothing might just be a phase. But as time passed and Emma began trying to articulate her understanding of the world around her
column33: it became clear that something was different about Emma from her two older brothers.\xa0
column34: \u201cShe began calling me \u2018he
column35: \u2019\u201d Amy said. \u201cWe thought she was just really confused and we needed to explain to her the difference in gender. I said
column36: \u2018Let\u2019s explain this: Boys\u2019 pronouns are he and him. Girls\u2019 are she and her.\u2019 But Emma kept saying
column38: And then one day she said
column39: \u201cWell
column40: if I\u2019m a boy
column41: you\u2019re a boy.\u201d
column42: In other words: if that is what I am
column43: then you must be it
column44: too.
column45: What followed was an intense period of self-education by Kevin and Amy \u2015 nights spent researching and purchasing books on Amazon
column46: hours spent scouring Facebook for support groups to join. \u201cI think that we just got online to make sure that we weren\u2019t going to damage her and that we were doing things right
column47: \u201d Amy said. \u201cThat\u2019s when we started seeing that she could be transgender.\u201d
column48: The Smiths learned that being trans at Emma\u2019s age doesn\u2019t involve taking hormones or medical intervention
column49: but coming to understand herself and her relationship with the world around her
column50: the way every child does.
column51: The family grew alongside Emma
column52: allowing her burgeoning sense of self to shape how they related to her. It was important to the Smiths to avoid inscribing upon Emma their own thoughts and feelings about her gender.
column53: \u201cWe were confused [at first] \u2015 but she\u2019s never been confused
column54: \u201d Amy said. \u201cIt was gradual
column55: it wasn\u2019t all of a sudden. We kept letting her express herself the way she wanted to express herself.\u201d
column56: And life seemed to be ideal \u2015 almost perfect \u2015 until Emma and her brother
column57: Miller
column58: who is one year older
column59: began kindergarten at their local public elementary school
column60: Glen Arden.
column61: Emma entered her first day of kindergarten at Glen Arden Elementary in August 2016 wearing a white dress with flower embroidery that she picked out herself.
column62: Amy and Kevin thought that if they simply told Glen Arden educators about Emma\u2019s personal journey with gender and identity
column63: they\u2019d be met with support and understanding. But
column64: according to the couple
column65: Emma faced immediate resistance.
column66: \u201cIt just turned into a mess
column67: \u201d Kevin said. \u201cThey wouldn\u2019t [call her Emma]
column68: they refused to do it
column69: the teachers wouldn\u2019t do it. So we had to get a meeting with the principal and formally tell them
column70: \u2018Her name is going to be Emma.\u2019 But the teacher she was with from day one disagreed with it
column71: and expressed her feelings to Emma daily. Emma would say she had girl hair and the teacher would tell her
column73: you\u2019ve got boy hair. You\u2019re a boy.\u2019\u201d
column74: Kevin and Amy sat down with the Glen Arden principal to explain that their child was mid-transition
column75: currently considered gender-nonconforming and unsure of pronouns
column76: and that their family was still in the process of coming to understand her identity.
column77: The pair say that what they found was a school under-equipped to deal with issues of gender
column78: projected through the lens of cultural prejudice and framed by the political climate of North Carolina.
column79: HuffPost reached out to Glen Arden Elementary and the Buncombe County School System and asked them to comment on these allegations. Stacia Harris
column80: Director of Communications for Buncombe County Schools
column82: Federal law prevents us from publicly discussing the specifics of any student matter. We can say that the Buncombe County School system works to ensure that all students
column83: employees
column84: and visitors feel safe
column85: welcomed
column86: and respected in all of our facilities. Our teachers
column87: administrators
column88: and parents work diligently to address sensitive student issues that are brought to our attention on a case-by-case basis
column89: including issues that are related to transgender students. Individual needs and privacy concerns vary from student to student and we work to accommodate those needs so our students can focus on learning.\xa0
column90: But according to the Smiths
column91: from the very first meeting with the principal
column92: it was evident that things were not going to be easy for their family.
column93: \u201cThe principal said
column94: \u2018Exactly who buys his clothes?\u2019 I said
column95: \u2018Of course we do. We\u2019re his parents
column96: we\u2019re going to buy his clothes. We buy all of our kids clothes
column97: \u2019\u201d Amy
column98: who at the time was using male and female pronouns interchangeably to describe Emma
column99: told HuffPost. \u201d[The principal responded with]
column100: \u2018You know that you can tell your child to not wear these kind of clothes? He could wear boy clothes
column101: \u2019 and just going on and on.\u201d
column102: The conversation eventually turned to bathrooms \u2015 and the principal brought up House Bill 2.
column103: \u2033\u2018We have to follow HB 2
column104: \u2018\u201d the principal allegedly stated
column105: according to Amy and Kevin. \u201cAnd that states... she has to use the boys\u2019 bathroom. And that\u2019s all we can offer.\u2019\u201d\xa0\xa0
column106: The North Carolina General Assembly passed House Bill 2 in 2016 during a special session and Former Governor Pat McCroy signed it into law.\xa0In addition to blocking cites and counties from passing LGBTQ anti-discrimination policies
column107: the bill forced trans people to use public restrooms that correspond with the gender they were assigned at birth.
column108: The Tar Heel state faced enormous cultural backlash for HB 2
column109: resulting in massive financial loss for the state and McCroy losing his governorship. Current Democratic Governor Roy Cooper\xa0ran on a platform of repealing HB 2
column110: but instead ushered in \u201ccompromise\u201d HB 142
column111: legislation that essentially\xa0allows anti-trans discrimination enabled by HB 2 to flourish.
column112: \u201cNothing has changed whatsoever so it\u2019s really hard when it\u2019s been touted on such a public level that it\u2019s a repeal
column114: director and founder of Western North Carolina transgender advocacy organization Tranzmission
column115: told HuffPost. \u201cIt just leaves people\u2019s civil rights flapping in the wind. To have delayed passing on discrimination ordinances to December of 2020 \u2015 this is civil rights! How can you delay it? It\u2019s just morally repugnant. It\u2019s wrong.\u201d
column116: Discrimination against transgender students in the North Carolina public school system is just one effect of HB 2 \u2015 but it\u2019s an insidious function that provided a framework for similar \u201cbathroom bills\u201d in other states like Mississippi and Texas.
column117: Activists say both HB 2 and HB 142 prevent students from feeling safe at school and receiving an education because the legislation creates a climate of harassment
column118: bullying and humiliation by both students and teachers. The Smiths say Emma experienced this firsthand during her year in kindergarten at Glen Arden Elementary.\xa0
column119: \u201cSeveral times she came home crying over the teacher telling her about being a boy
column120: \u201d Kevin told HuffPost. \u201cAnd they actually punished her for telling them that she was a girl.\u201d
column121: Students in Emma\u2019s kindergarten class were assigned clips on a chart to indicate how they\u2019re behaving while at school
column122: sort of like a sticker system.\xa0Good behavior was rewarded with the clip moving up the chart\xa0\u2015 bad with it moving down.
column123: \u201cShe would come home devastated that her clip was moved down
column125: \u2018Why did your clip get moved down? What happened?\u2019 [and she responded] \u2018I said that I was a girl...\xa0and [the teacher] said that I was a boy and that if I say I\u2019m a girl again
column126: she\u2019s going to move my clip down.\u2019... We felt like we were in a movie \u2015 like we\u2019re watching one of those Lifetime films. This can\u2019t be real. This can\u2019t be happening.\u201d
column127: The Smiths talked about other moments when they felt Emma was being unfairly punished. They claim their daughter was told she had to be a pilgrim boy in the Thanksgiving play
column128: when all other students were given a choice about which character they would play.
column129: There was the \u201cnew rule\u201d that Emma was no longer allowed to hug any of her friends at Glen Arden \u2015 a rule the Smiths maintain only applied to Emma. \u201cThe only thing I can think of is a concerned parent called the school thinking that transgender [identity] was contagious or some such bullshit
column131: Amy and Kevin say Emma\u2019s \u201cAll About Me Day\u201d was also particularly traumatic. Each student gets their own day where the teacher draws an image of the student in front of the class and their classmates follow suit.
column132: Emma was ecstatic for her \u201cAll About Me Day\u201d and picked out a pink shirt with a glitter heart and a pair of little pastel shorts for the occasion.
column133: She came home that afternoon bawling. Not only had the teacher written her \u201cboy name\u201d on the \u201cAbout Me\u201d image \u2015 she had erased all aspects of femininity from Emma\u2019s appearance
column134: with all of her classmates then following the teacher\u2019s lead.
column136: \u201cAll About Me Day\u201d was the last straw \u2015 and they had Emma moved to a different classroom in November 2016
column138: \u201cThere\u2019s no way that that [\u201cAbout Me\u201d image] was her
column139: \u201d Amy said. \u201cIf you would\u2019ve seen her and what she was wearing
column140: it was \u2015 I don\u2019t know who that is. Completely different child... It was just this non-stop
column142: every day. What\u2019s going to happen today?\u201d
column143: Emma\u2019s new teacher respected her chosen name and pronouns. But the Smiths\u2019 nightmare was far from over. The issues Emma faced then became magnified through the lens of HB 2 when she found herself in situations where she was unable to reach the school\u2019s assigned single-stall bathrooms.
column144: Emma urinated on herself on two different occasions during the remainder of the school year.
column145: Whenever she needed to use the bathroom during her year at Glen Arden
column146: Emma had three options: use a single-stall facility if one was in close proximity
column148: or hold it. She was not allowed to use the girls\u2019 room.
column149: The first time Emma urinated on herself was during gym class. According to Amy and Kevin
column150: she came home with a bag of soaking wet clothes and said the gym teacher told her that with no single-stall bathroom nearby
column151: she had to either use the boys\u2019 bathroom or \u201chold it.\u201d
column154: \u201d Amy recalled. \u201cWhere do you have to be in your mind to be forced to urinate on yourself or go in the boy\u2019s bathroom? What kind of choice is that for a child?\u201d
column155: The second time took place during lunch.\xa0Emma was in the cafeteria and had to use the bathroom. There were single-stall restrooms located in the cafeteria.
column157: Emma told her parents that she was not allowed to leave the cafeteria and a teacher told her to \u201chold it.\u201d Sitting in the middle of a crowded lunchroom with a locked single-stall bathroom only twenty feet away
column159: When Amy visited the school a week later to have lunch with her daughter
column160: the single-stall bathrooms in the cafeteria were still locked.
column162: Tranzmission became intimately involved in Emma\u2019s fight with the Buncombe County School System. Amy put a plea for help on a local Facebook page and eventually was connected with the organization and Christopoulos. He reassured her that the school was in the wrong and promised to help however they could.
column163: \u201cThe school locked\xa0[the bathrooms] so Emma couldn\u2019t use them
column168: that as a kid I did pee on myself in school because I didn\u2019t want to go to the bathroom because I didn\u2019t want to be seen going into the girls\u2019 room. Emma\u2019s having that forced on her. She\u2019s been in the girls\u2019 room. She\u2019s used it. She feels comfortable with that. She doesn\u2019t want to go in the boys\u2019 room and she\u2019s being forced to.\u201d
column169: Other organizers and activists involved with Tranzmission also view Emma\u2019s fight as highly personal. Allison Scott
column171: told HuffPost that she sees much of herself as a child in Emma \u2015 and that the Smith\u2019s story sounds just like countless others as families with trans and gender-nonconforming children all over the country are fighting for their kids\u2019 rights.
column172: \u201cThis is the thing that makes Amy and Emma and Kevin and their family
column174: so wonderful and so painful at the same time
column175: \u201d Scott told HuffPost. \u201cMost families [with transgender children] have not pushed it publicly
column176: have not pushed it this far because they don\u2019t want the hate. They don\u2019t want the blowback from their community
column179: from schools... This is why so many kids are going through this silently. For every Emma out there
column180: there are ten Emmas and there are ten trans boys and there are ten gender-nonconforming kids who are not fighting. Not because they\u2019re weak
column181: not because they don\u2019t want it
column182: just because the blowback is too much for them to handle.\u201d

The New York Times Hires Michelle Goldberg As A Columnist

|[

The New York Times is adding Michelle Goldberg to its stable of columnists
column2: according to a newsroom memo obtained by HuffPost.
column3: Goldberg
column4: a progressive writer most recently with Slate
column5: began contributing regularly to the Times opinion section earlier this year. Her work quickly stood out and prompted internal speculation that she could be in line for a full-time columnist job
column6: one of the most prestigious perches in journalism.\xa0
column7: However
column8: Goldberg told HuffPost she never dreamed of landing a columnist slot. Shortly after the announcement on Wednesday
column9: Goldberg said she was still \u201cstaggered by what an honor it is to have that platform at this moment.\u201d
column10: \u201cIt\u2019s the opposite of the end of history
column11: \u201d Goldberg said. \u201cSuddenly everything has been thrown open and it\u2019s really terrifying. I don\u2019t think it\u2019s a silver lining as a writer is that it\u2019s suddenly such an ideologically fertile time. It\u2019s a terrible and harrowing time. But there is so much to explore.\u201d
column12: \u201cOne thing I hope to do is to be a voice for the majority of the people in this country who cannot believe what the fuck is going on
column13: \u201d she said.\xa0\xa0
column14: The Times has recently been incorporating new voices by adding contributing columnists. But the\xa0stable\xa0of 14 full-time columnists
column15: which boasts high-profile writers like Paul Krugman and David Brooks
column16: has lacked diversity. Goldberg is one of three women in the group
column17: joining Maureen Dowd and Gail Collins. Charles Blow is the only writer of color among the group.
column18: And the last columnist hire by Times editorial page editor James Bennet
column19: conservative writer Bret Stephens
column20: ignited controversy. Some Times readers even canceled their subscriptions in April over the selection of Stephens
column21: a self-identified \u201cclimate agnostic\u201d known for mocking environmentalists. Bennet defended the hire at the time
column22: telling HuffPost\xa0it was \u201ctotally unfair\u201d to label Stephens a \u201cclimate denialist.\u201d
column23: Goldberg
column24: who has written for The New Yorker
column25: The New Republic and The Nation
column26: \xa0focuses\xa0largely on politics
column27: gender
column28: religion and ideology and is the author of three books: Kingdom Coming: The Rise of Christian Nationalism
column29: <em>The Means of Reproduction: Sex
column30: Power
column31: and the Future of the World
column32: and <em>The Goddess Pose: The Audacious Life of Indra Devi
column33: the Woman Who Helped Bring Yoga to the West.
column34: While progressive
column35: Goldberg wouldn\u2019t likely be identified as coming from the Bernie Sanders wing of the Democratic Party. During the 2016 primary race
column36: Goldberg wrote how the Independent Vermont senator\u2019s politics were \u201cmore or less my own
column37: \u201d yet she\xa0supported Hillary Clinton.
column38: Goldberg described her politics to HuffPost as close to those of Krugman and Blow
column39: though coming from a more feminist framework. She said she understood if some people in the Sanders wing of the progressive movement \u201c<span style="font-weight: 400;">continue to feel underrepresented
column40: \u201d yet she described much of her work as being \u201din dialogue with people to my left.\u201d
column41: For instance
column42: Goldberg said she\u2019s interested in arguments found in Jacobin
column43: a socialist-leaning magazine
column44: the growth of the Democratic Socialists of America (DSA)
column45: and debates on the left over the radical
column46: anti-fascist group known as antifa.\xa0
column47: \u201cOne thing I can do is to give voice to people\u2019s incredulity as they watch their democracy crumble around them and nobody seems to be doing anything about it
column48: \u201d she said.\xa0
column49: The Times
column50: whose columnists generally veer center-left to center-right and at times share views on foreign intervention whether liberal or conservative
column51: also doesn\u2019t boast a full-time columnist representing more of the Steve Bannon-like populist
column52: nationalist viewpoints found on Breitbart News.\xa0The Times\u2019 conservative columnists \u2015 \xa0Brooks
column53: Stephens and Ross Douthat \u2015 have all been critical of President Donald Trump.\xa0
column54: In a memo
column55: Bennet and deputy editorial page editors Jim Dao and Katie Kingsbury promised \u201cfurther additions to our lineup in the coming months as we continue to broaden the range of Times debate about consequential questions.\u201d
column56: Read the full memo below:
column57: All:\xa0
column58: We\u2019re delighted to tell you that Michelle Goldberg is joining the strongest lineup of columnists in the world. Many of you know Michelle from her regular contributions here
column59: as well as from her column at Slate
column60: so you have some sense already of her intellectual depth
column61: courage and ambition. She is the author of three books that together point to her range: The first
column62: \u201cKingdom Coming
column63: \u201d investigated the rise of Christian nationalism in the United States; the second
column64: \u201cThe Means of Reproduction
column65: \u201d examined struggles worldwide for women\u2019s self-determination and its connections to economic development and national identity; and the third
column66: \u201cThe Goddess Pose
column67: \u201d told the rollicking tale of Indra Devi
column68: the extraordinary woman who fled the Russian Revolution and eventually \u2013 as the twentieth century unfolded and she passed through stints in Berlin cabaret
column69: Indian silent film
column70: and Hollywood \u2013 helped bring yoga to the United States.
column71: \xa0Michelle knows how to deliver big ideas through great stories
column72: and to do the hard reporting to support both. She knows how to write fast and forcefully off the news and how to structure a complex
column73: magazine-length argument. She is interested in pretty much everything
column74: and she sees no contradiction between having fierce convictions and keeping an open mind. She is
column75: in other words
column76: our kind of colleague.
column77: You can expect further additions to our lineup in the coming months as we continue to broaden the range of Times debate about consequential questions.
column78: Michelle\u2019s first day will be in about two weeks
column79: and we\u2019ll ask you to join us in welcoming her then.
column80: \xa0All best
column82:
Jim and Katie

]

There's A Potential Crack In Trump's Base: Supporters Who Once Voted For Obama

|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 Very few Americans outright regret their votes in last year\u2019s election. But such regrets
column2: new data reveals
column3: are highest among voters who may now make up the most tenuous part of the base that swept Donald Trump into office: those\xa0who supported Barack Obama in 2012.\xa0
column4: \u201cI\u2019m off that boat
column5: \u201d said Hildegarde Evans
column6: a registered Democrat from Sacramento
column7: California
column8: who supported Obama in 2012.\xa0She says she voted for Trump because she hoped his business experience would give him a different perspective
column9: but is now adamant that she\u2019d never support him for re-election. \u201cThere\u2019s nothing he can say or do that will impress me or cause me to vote for him again
column10: no
column11: absolutely not. That\u2019s out.\u201d
column12: After seeing Trump\u2019s\xa0record on health care and immigration
column13: his handling of foreign affairs
column14: and his continued combativeness on Twitter
column15: she says she wishes she\u2019d cast a write-in ballot last year.
column16: Evans is among the 16 percent of Obama/Trump voters who now say they regret their votes
column17: according to a newly released set of polling. Six percent of all 2016 voters say they regret the decision they made last year
column18: and 3 percent those who voted for Mitt Romney in 2012 and Hillary Clinton in 2016 say the same.\xa0
column19: Fewer than 4 in 10 of Obama/Trump voters say they\u2019re sure they\u2019ll vote GOP in the 2018 midterms.
column20: The data comes from an online YouGov poll conducted in July by the Democracy Fund Voter Study Group
column21: which describes itself as a collaboration by \u201cnearly two dozen analysts and scholars from across the political spectrum.\u201d The survey reinterviewed 5
column22: 000 Americans who\u2019d previously been polled in 2011
column24: allowing the researchers to track the shifts in their political opinions.
column25: Democrats are now faced with several questions:\xa0how many Obama/Trump voters are persuadable
column26: and to what degree pursuing the sliver who are should take precedence over drumming up midterm turnout among the Democratic base or wooing those who voted third-party or sat out 2016.
column27: Between 6.7 million and 9.2 million Americans may have backed Obama in 2012 and Trump in 2016
column28: according to an analysis Geoffrey Skelley of Sabato\u2019s Crystal Ball\xa0conducted earlier this year.\xa0He\xa0concluded such voters \u201cplayed a crucial role\u201d in Rust Belt states such as Michigan
column29: Pennsylvania and Wisconsin. According to the Voter Study Group
column30: they represent about 9 percent or 10 percent of Obama\u2019s supporters.
column31: \u201cAmong the people who supported Trump
column32: they\u2019re showing some of the highest levels of dissatisfaction
column33: \u201d said Robert Griffin
column34: the director of quantitative analysis at the progressive Center for American Progress and one of the participants in the Voter Study Group. \u201cI think there are some people who argue this is a segment of the population the Democrats can\u2019t win back
column35: but this is already a population that\u2019s already shown itself to have some flip-flopping tendencies \u2015 to vote for one party and then to vote for another. So
column36: I think the evidence would suggest that this is a group that\u2019s in play. They\u2019re by no means lost to the Democratic Party.\u201d
column37: The behavior of these voters stands out in a political environment often characterized by inflexible hyper-partisanship
column38: as they are less tethered to a partisan identity than most of the electorate.
column39: Although they are considerably right-leaning and by no means largely wayward Democrats
column40: Obama/Trump voters do appear in some ways significantly different from the rest of Trump\u2019s electorate
column41: according to additional YouGov polling conducted for the Economist in June and shared with HuffPost.
column42: They\u2019re less likely
column43: for instance
column44: to closely follow politics
column45: to consider themselves conservatives
column46: or to feel a strong kinship with the Republican Party. They\u2019re less likely than other Trump voters to consider immigration a very important issue. And although they aren\u2019t significantly likelier to express personal worries or to name the economy as a top issue
column47: they are more bearish about its prospects. Just 46 percent of Obama/Trump voters
column48: compared to 61 percent of other Trump voters
column49: say the economy is getting better. And 36 percent
column50: compared to 58 percent of other Trump voters
column51: think Trump cares a lot about people like them.
column52: Most Trump voters
column53: no matter whom they supported in previous years
column54: aren\u2019t rueing their decision. About 70 percent of Obama/Trump voters said in July that they approved of the current president\u2019s performance
column55: according to the Voter Study Group.
column56: \u201cDonald Trump
column57: in my opinion
column58: he put down his feet and started running right away
column59: as soon as he was inaugurated
column60: to move his agenda forward. I like that
column61: \u201d another Obama/Trump voter
column62: Cornell Rankin
column63: told HuffPost earlier this summer.
column64: Rankin
column65: a resident of Wilmington
column66: Delaware
column67: who originally hails from Pittsburgh
column68: Pennsylvania
column69: said he hoped that Trump would restore manufacturing jobs.
column70: \u201cI grew up with the steel mills and other manufacturing that was [flourishing] during my childhood
column71: and by the time I got old enough to get into the workforce
column72: those things were dwindling and eventually closed down
column73: \u201d he said. \u201cAnd now the manufacturing in western Pennsylvania is almost nothing. And I would like to see the return of some manufacturing because as a nation we used to be very strong at providing everything that we need.\u201d
column74: And unlike even many Republicans
column75: Rankin called Trump\u2019s pugnaciousness \u201crefreshing
column76: \u201d saying he liked having someone in office to confront the status quo.
column77: Most Obama/Trump voters
column78: however
column79: aren\u2019t wholly upbeat
column80: especially in comparison with straight-ticket Republican voters. Just 35 percent in the Voter Study Group\u2019s poll strongly approve of Trump\u2019s performance
column81: significantly below the level of Trump voters as a whole. (A 63 percent majority of Obama voters who backed third-party candidates
column82: meanwhile
column83: disapprove of Trump entirely.)
column84: \u201cI still have hope for him. I have not given up
column85: \u201d said Ella Johnson
column86: a 62-year-old from Rochester
column87: Minnesota
column88: who backed Trump in 2016 after voting for Obama in 2012. Johnson
column89: who picked Trump because she thought he\u2019d do a better job of working with Congress
column90: praised him for fighting for what he wanted
column91: even if it meant taking on other politicians or the press.
column92: But Johnson also expressed concerns about Trump\u2019s record on health care
column93: \xa0noted that the president hasn\u2019t yet accomplished much
column94: and said he often seemed to let his ego get the best of him. And although she hasn\u2019t given a great deal of thought yet to the midterm elections
column95: she\u2019s more than open to the idea of supporting a Democrat.
column96: That openness is not entirely uncommon among Obama voters who didn\u2019t support Clinton
column97: according to the study. Thirty-six percent of Obama voters who voted for a third-party candidate last year say they plan to vote Democratic in the midterms
column98: and 23 percent that they haven\u2019t made up their minds. Obama/Trump voters
column99: while less Democratic-leaning
column100: aren\u2019t solidly Republican either: 39 percent of Obama/Trump voters say they plan to back a Republican candidate in 2018
column101: according to the study
column102: with 17 percent saying they\u2019ll vote Democratic and another 41 percent still unsure.
column103: Given their loose tethers to partisanship
column104: even those who remain happy with Trump may not necessarily be a reliable vote for the GOP.
column105: \u201cSometimes it\u2019s not a bad thing to have a little opposition in the government

Debt Ceiling Hike|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 Democratic leaders found themselves in the unusual position of being on the same side as President\xa0Donald Trump\xa0on Wednesday
column3: reaching agreement on a plan to keep the government funded and raise the debt ceiling.
column4: Trump met with Senate Minority Leader\xa0Chuck Schumer\xa0(D-N.Y.) and House Minority Leader\xa0Nancy Pelosi\xa0(D-Calif.)
column5: as well as Senate Majority Leader\xa0Mitch McConnell\xa0(R-Ky.)
column6: House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) and House Speaker\xa0Paul Ryan\xa0(R-Wis.)
column7: at the White House on Wednesday.
column8: \u201cIn the meeting
column9: the President and Congressional leadership agreed to pass aid for Harvey
column10: an extension of the debt limit
column11: and a continuing resolution both to December 15
column12: all together. Both sides have every intention of avoiding default in December and look forward to working together on the many issues before us
column13: \u201d Schumer and Pelosi said in a joint statement after the meeting.
column14: Democrats had gone into the meeting hoping to get exactly this outcome.\xa0A congressional aide briefed on the meeting said Republican leaders wanted an 18-month debt ceiling hike
column15: and then suggested six months instead. Pelosi and Schumer dismissed a six-month hike
column16: and Trump eventually agreed to the Democrats\u2019 three-month proposal.
column17: Another source briefed on the meeting said Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin sided with the Republican leaders in the room in wanting a longer debt limit extension. When it was clear the congressional leaders were going to agree to disagree
column18: Trump unexpectedly agreed to the three-month extension.
column19: Republicans\xa0often need Democratic votes\xa0to raise the debt ceiling
column20: because many conservatives oppose increasing the government\u2019s borrowing limit without spending cuts to decrease the deficit. With a shorter-term debt ceiling hike coming up in December at the same time as a government funding fight
column21: Democrats will have more leverage in the budget battle.\xa0
column22: But by siding with Democrats
column23: Trump rejected the wishes of his own party \u2015 a move that reportedly\xa0left Republicans furious\xa0\u2015 and it\u2019s not clear how many GOP lawmakers will go along with this deal.\xa0
column24: McConnell said he would add the three-month funding and debt ceiling extension to\xa0legislation providing $7.85 billion in aid for Hurricane Harvey.
column25: \u201cThe president can speak for himself
column26: but his feeling was that we needed to come together to not create a picture of divisiveness at a time of genuine national crisis. And that was the rationale
column27: \u201d McConnell told reporters
column28: distancing himself from the deal.
column29: Earlier Wednesday
column30: Ryan derided Democrats\u2019 proposal to raise the debt ceiling for three months
column31: calling the idea \u201cridiculous\u201d and \u201cdisgraceful.\u201d
column32: \u201cWe\u2019ve got all this devastation in Texas. We\u2019ve got another unprecedented hurricane about to hit Florida. And they want to play politics with the debt ceiling?\u201d Ryan told reporters. \u201cThat will strand the aid that we need to bring to the victims of these storms that have occurred or are about to occur.\u201d
column33: Mnuchin has said that he and the president wanted the debt ceiling hike to be tied to aid for Hurricane Harvey \u2015 a proposal opposed by many conservatives.\xa0
column34: Congress has until Sept. 30 to reach a funding deal to avoid a government shutdown. Mnuchin said Congress needs to raise the debt ceiling by Sept. 29
column35: or else the United States risks default and throwing the economy into a tailspin.
column36: Sen. Thom Tillis (R-N.C.) admitted that Democrats walked away with a pretty good deal.\xa0
