column1: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/hispanic-caucus-raises-money-off-single-payer_us_59af24d9e4b0354e440d7c01?utm_campaign=hp_fb_pages&utm_source=politics_fb&utm_medium=facebook&ncid=fcbklnkushpmg00000013&section=politics|<h1 class="headline__title">A Democratic PAC Is Raising Money Off Of Single-Payer
column2:
But Not All Members Back Policy|[

In the wake of the November election and the collapse of efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act
column3: enacting single-payer health care \u2015 one government insurer for all Americans \u2015 has been steadily gaining steam as a priority for progressive activists.
column4: The Congressional Hispanic Caucus\u2019 political action committee
column5: Bold PAC
column6: has sought to capitalize on the energy behind the so-called \u201cMedicare for all\u201d push with at least eight fundraising emails in the past few months that suggest contributing to the PAC will help advance single-payer legislation.
column7: The emails frequently invoke Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.)
column8: who is planning to introduce single-payer legislation in the coming weeks
column9: after he mainstreamed the ambitious policy with his 2016 presidential bid.
column10: The strategy is paying off: In a non-election year
column11: the Bold PAC has already raised nearly $3.9 million \u2015 including over $820
column12: 000 in contributions under $200. In the first quarter of 2017
column13: it brought in over $2 million
column14: breaking its previous fundraising record for a three-month period.
column15: By contrast
column16: the PAC raised about $6.1 million in the entire 2015-2016 election cycle \u2015 a period when it had the benefit of national attention on a presidential race in which the Democratic nominee
column17: \xa0Hillary Clinton
column18: was highly favored to win.
column19: The trouble is
column20: just half of the 30 full voting members of the Congress Hispanic Caucus have publicly endorsed single-payer health care. (The caucus has 31 members including Northern Mariana Islands Delegate Gregorio Sablan
column21: but he does not have the authority to vote on legislation that makes it to the House floor.)
column22: Of the 28 CHC members with full voting rights in the House
column23: 15 are among the 117 co-sponsors of single-payer legislation introduced by Rep. John Conyers (D-Mich.).
column24: The 13 CHC members in the House who have not signed onto the bill include Rep. Tony Cardenas (D-Calif.)
column25: chair of Bold PAC and a member of House Democratic leadership; Rep. Ben Ray Lujan (D-N.M.)
column26: chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee; and Rep. Joaquin Castro (D-Texas)
column27: a nationally prominent former Texas state lawmaker
column28: whose twin brother Julian Castro served as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in the Barack Obama administration.
column29: Sens. Catherine Cortez Masto (D-Nev.) and Robert Menendez (D-N.J.)
column30: the two senators in the Congressional Hispanic Caucus
column31: have not revealed whether they plan to support Sanders\u2019 single-payer legislation or otherwise indicated it is a policy they support.
column32: Menendez\u2019s office pointed to his past support for a public health insurance option. Cortez Masto\u2019s office did not immediately respond to a request for confirmation of her current positions.
column33: Reps. Cardenas
column34: Pete Aguilar (D-Calif.)
column35: Lou Correa (D-Calif.)
column36: Jim Costa (D-Calif.)
column37: Salud Carbajal (D-Calif.)
column38: Raul Ruiz (D-Calif.) and Ruben Kihuen (D-Nev.)
column39: all of whom are CHC members who have not co-sponsored the Conyers bill
column40: received major contributions from Bold PAC in the 2015-2016 cycle.
column41: A number of other House Democrats who have yet to sign onto Conyers\u2019 bill were recipients of Bold PAC largesse last cycle as well
column42: including Democratic Reps. Kyrsten Sinema (Ariz.)
column43: Brad Schneider (Ill.)
column44: Sean Patrick Maloney (N.Y.)
column45: Stephanie Murphy (Fla.)
column46: Charlie Crist (Fla.)
column47: Josh Gottheimer (N.J.) and Cheri Bustos (Ill.).\xa0
column48: A spokesperson for Bold PAC said the decision to fundraise off of the \u201cMedicare for all\u201d push is not intended to reflect the positions of all CHC members
column49: or candidates it endorses.
column50: \u201cThe passage of Trumpcare would be a disaster and Medicare for All is one solution that many of our Members support
column51: \u201d the spokesperson said in a statement.
column52: \u201cMinority communities are more likely to lack access to affordable healthcare
column53: which is why CHC Bold PAC is committed to ensuring that healthcare is available for every American \u2015 not just for a privileged few
column54: \u201d the statement continued. \u201cCHC BOLD PAC will fight with the progressive community to protect the American people from Trumpcare with everything we have.\u201d
column55: The spokesperson would not say whether the PAC is even planning to urge its members or candidates it endorses to sign on to single-payer legislation.
column56: But given the strident tone of the fundraising emails
column57: rank-and-file Democrats might not be aware of the subtleties in the PAC\u2019s single-payer stance.
column58: In an Aug. 6 email with the subject line \u201cMISSING your support of Bernie\u2019s new bill! (sign right now >>)
column59: \u201d Bold PAC employed the urgency of a political candidate facing a deadline to solicit petition signatures in support of Sanders\u2019 yet-to-be-announced \u201cMedicare for all\u201d bill. Using issue-based petitions and surveys to raise money is a common digital fundraising tactic.
column60: \u201cHUGE UPDATE: Bernie Sanders is \u2018absolutely\u2019 introducing Medicare for All bill.\xa0YES!!! We need 50
column61: 000 signatures immediately \u2015 or Republicans will CRUSH our chances of passing Bernie\u2019s landmark plan
column62: \u201d the email stated alongside a photo of Sanders and a link labeled \u201csupport Medicare for all\u201d that led to a landing page with the petition.
column63: A follow-up email on Aug. 10 with the subject line \u201cMedicare for All (Your Feedback Needed \u2015 URGENT)\u201d warns against the dire consequences of not completing a survey about single-payer health care.
column64: \u201cBernie Sanders is officially introducing a Medicare for All plan to guarantee every American the right and access to affordable
column65: quality healthcare. This is groundbreaking! But Republicans are still determined to DESTROY our healthcare system
column66: no matter who suffers. So we need to find out where you stand NOW
column67: \u201d Bold PAC admonishes the recipients.
column68: Two other similar email solicitations invoke liberal economist Robert Reich and comic Jon Stewart
column69: both of whom support single-payer.
column70: If readers sign the petitions or complete the surveys
column71: they are led to other webpages that solicit donations that supposedly go toward the \u201cMedicare for all\u201d fight.
column72: Bold PAC even has a special \u201cMedicare for All fund\u201d donation webpage it has set up on the Democratic fundraising site Act Blue where supporters can \u201cchip in $5 or $10 right now to support Medicare for All.\u201d
column73: A senior aide to a progressive House Democrat
column74: \xa0speaking on condition of anonymity
column75: argued that Bold PAC\u2019s behavior was outside the norm in terms of its disregard for \u201cauthenticity.\u201d
column76: \u201cIn general
column77: representing your actual positions helps avoid the messiness associated with taking conflicting positions
column78: \u201d the aide said.
column79: To complicate matters further
column80: Bold PAC has received major funding from pharmaceutical and health insurance companies that ardently oppose modest health care reforms
column81: let alone single-payer legislation. The drug makers Amgen
column82: AstraZeneca
column83: Pfizer
column84: Johnson & Johnson and Merck each donated $10
column85: 000 to Bold PAC in the 2015-2016 cycle
column86: as did health insurers Anthem and Humana. Eli Lilly
column87: another pharmaceutical company
column88: also contributed $7
column90: \u201cThey\u2019re telling their grassroots supporters that they want to get profit out of heath care
column91: \u201d the House Democratic aide said. \u201cAt the same time
column92: they\u2019re taking corporate PAC money from the industries most opposed to Medicare for All \u2015 Pharma and the health insurance industry. It\u2019s disingenuous at best and malicious at worst.\u201d
column93: But Kenneth Pennington

Court Says Texas Can Continue To Enforce Voter ID Law For Now

|[

A panel of federal judges ruled Tuesday that Texas can keep in place voter ID requirements while the state appeals a lower court decision that last month found the rules intentionally discriminate against minority voters.
column2: The three-judge panel for the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 5th Circuit ruled 2-1 that Texas could still enforce an interim order allowing use of the voter ID requirements. The ruling comes as a legal battle continues over the ID rules that state wants for voters.
column3: Texas in 2011 passed a law
column4: SB 14
column5: requiring voters present photo identification
column6: such as a driver\u2019s license
column7: gun permit or passport
column8: when casting a ballot. Last year
column9: U.S. District Court Judge Nelva Gonzales Ramos blocked the law
column10: ruling it was passed to intentionally discriminate against blacks and Latinos.
column11: The state this year passed SB 5
column12: which was designed fix the problems Gonzales Ramos had found with SB 14. But in August
column13: \xa0she ruled that SB 5 perpetuated the initial\u2019s law discriminatory features \u2015 a decision Texas is appealing.
column14: SB 5 wasn\u2019t set to go into effect until Jan. 1
column16: but the ruling by the appeals court panel means its requirements can be used in elections this year.
column17: Texas lawyers argue SB 5 is non-discriminatory because it allows voters to cast a ballot if they lack the required IDs if they present other documents providing their identity and sign a declaration of \u201creasonable impediment
column18: \u201d swearing under penalty of perjury they could not obtain the required IDs.
column19: The majority opinion by the appeals panel wrote that it was allowing the state to enforce SB 5 for the upcoming elections in order to avoid confusion.
column20: \u201cThe state has already spent $2.5 million in 2016 to educate voters about the availability of the SB 5 reasonable-impediment procedures
column21: which were used in the November 2016 general election and local elections this year
column22: \u201d Judges Jerry Smith and Jennifer Elrod wrote. A temporary stay of the ruling by Gonzales Ramos blocking SB 5 while the court considers that decision \u201cwill minimize confusion among both voters and trained election officials
column23: \u201d the two judges wrote.
column24: Judges James Graves
column25: Jr. dissented from the court\u2019s ruling
column26:
writing the \u201ccorrect approach would be to stay both the district court\u2019s order and the new legislation.\u201d

column1: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/daca-has-ended-you-are-outraged-heres-what-you-can_us_59ae4bd7e4b0c50640cd619e?ncid=fcbklnkushpmg00000013&utm_campaign=hp_fb_pages&utm_source=politics_fb&utm_medium=facebook&section=politics|<h1 class="headline__title">If You're Outraged By Trump's DACA Decision
column2:
Here's How You Can Help Recipients Like Me|[

Now that the president has announced the end of DACA
column3: you might be wondering what happens next. The announcement presents an opportunity to mobilize and push Congress to pass immigration reform so the 800
column4: 000 DACA recipients will be protected. If you can spare one hour of your day
column5: your actions might make a difference.
column6: Leave a comment here to let the president know how much you disagree with his decision to end DACA. Here is a sample comment:
column7: Mr. President
column9: As an American citizen
column10: I am appalled by your decision to terminate protections for 800
column11: 000 DACA beneficiaries who pay taxes
column12: attend our colleges and universities
column13: and contribute to our communities as doctors
column14: lawyers
column15: teachers
column16: social workers and business owners. Your decision could reduce the U.S. GDP by more than $400 billion over the next decade. I urge you to work with Congress to pass a legislative solution that will ensure the protection of those affected by your decision to terminate DACA.
column17: After you have submitted a comment
column18: call the White House and leave a message at 202-456-1111.
column19: First
column20: find your representative and senators here. Just enter your zip code and click on their names to obtain their contact information.
column21: Second
column22: pick up the phone and call each one of them. You can ask to speak with the staffer in charge of immigration policy or just leave a message. Here is a sample script:
column23: Hello
column25: My name is ____
column26: and I am one of your constituents. I am calling to express my discontent with the White House\u2019s decision to end DACA and ask Senator/Representative ______ to support legislative action that will protect immigrants affected by the termination of DACA. Eight hundred thousand lives are affected because of the president\u2019s decision to end DACA
column27: and now it is time for Congress to pass a law that would provide a pathway to citizenship for this group of immigrants. Does Senator/Representative _____ currently support the Dream\xa0Act or Hope Act?
column28: If you are told your representative/senator supports either the Dream\xa0(in the Senate) or Hope Act (in the House of Representatives)
column29: say thank you and let them know you applaud that decision.
column30: If you are told your representative/senator does not support either the Dream or Hope Act
column31: ask the staffer to explain why. Then
column32: let the staffer know the human and economic impact that leaving 800
column33: 000 youth undocumented would have (see script for the White House above).
column34: If you are told your representative/senator has not made up his or her mind on the Dream or Hope Act
column35: let the staffer know you urge the representative/senator to support these legislative efforts.
column36: Take 15 minutes to tweet to different members of Congress and the White House
column37: letting them know you (1) disapprove the president is terminating the DACA program and (2) you expect Congress to pass legislative action to protect those affected. Make sure to Tweet at the president @realdonaldtrump and Speaker Paul Ryan @SpeakerRyan.
column38: Here are some sample messages:
column39: This tool kit has some images that target specific members of Congress on Twitter.
column40: Repetition is critical. As an ally
column41: you can block one hour every other day (or every day) to contact the White House and Congress
column42: letting them know you expect them to pass a law that would protect those affected by the president\u2019s decision to terminate DACA. Even if you feel confident your representative or senators support legislation to protect DACA beneficiaries
column43: it is important you continue to call them. Remember they are also receiving calls from those who oppose DACA
column44: so your calls are essential to keep the issue relevant.
column45: The process will probably take several weeks or even months
column46: and you might become rather frustrated with Congress\u2019s inaction or slow progress. If you do become annoyed
column47: remember some of the people affected by the president\u2019s decision to end DACA have been living in limbo for decades
column48: sometimes for 20 or 30 years.
column49:
The one hour you spend a few times a week will keep the pressure on Congress to act. Your advocacy can make a difference.

]

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/democrats-2016-campaign-hacking-annette-taddeo_us_59af02f0e4b0b5e53101acf1?utm_campaign=hp_fb_pages&utm_source=politics_fb&utm_medium=facebook&ncid=fcbklnkushpmg00000013§ion=politics|

Hillary Clinton Wasn't The Only Democrat Whose Campaign Got Hacked In 2016

|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 Every candidate running for office may be unique
column2: but
column3: when it comes to campaigning
column4: they all essentially end up worrying about the same things.
column5: Candidates fret about how best to reach voters
column6: how to raise enough cash and when to run their first attack ads. How they handle these three issues will determine whether they are successful on election night.
column7: No candidate has had to confront the hacking of their private campaign materials.\xa0That is
column8: until 2016. When Hillary Clinton\u2019s Democratic presidential campaign fell victim to a Russian-backed hacking operation
column9: down-ballot candidates across the country were targeted as well. On this week\u2019s episode of \u201cCandidate Confessional
column10: \u201d we interviewed one of those targets: Annette Taddeo
column11: a Democrat who ran for Congress in South Florida.
column12: Taddeo started her campaign worrying about her name recognition
column13: trying to win over the dominant Cuban immigrant voting bloc and having to make up a 24-point deficit against her primary opponent
column14: former U.S. Rep. Joe Garcia. Unlike her opponent
column15: who had his share of baggage
column16: Taddeo saw her clean record as her selling point.\xa0
column17: \u201cThe strength was cleanliness \u2015 the not having any kind of blemish on my record
column18: \u201d Taddeo explained. \u201cThis district in particular was very tired of the scandals.\u201d
column19: The hack of her campaign changed all that.
column20: Taddeo knew that the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee had been hacked. She said she asked party officials about it. No one raised alarms that her materials might have been stolen. She didn\u2019t find out her campaign had been hacked until it was too late: when a blogger started to publish stories using the private materials.
column21: \u201cThere was no preparation and no warning
column22: \u201d she told us.
column23: Among the materials leaked to reporters: Taddeo\u2019s opposition research on Garcia as well as the Democratic Party leaders\u2019 private concerns\xa0about Taddeo as a candidate. One memo considered her an \u201cincompetent candidate\u201d and worried that voters could look at her and see just another \u201cwealthy elitist.\u201d
column24: Taddeo
column25: who had been gaining ground on Garcia
column26: suddenly saw her campaign stall. Garcia used the materials to paint her as the\xa0real dirty candidate. \u201cI definitely felt like I was out there campaigning sort of naked
column27: \u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s the best way I can describe it because you\u2019re an open book.\u201d
column28: Taddeo lost to Garcia by 2 percentage points in the primary. Republicans were then able to successfully use the hacked materials against Garcia
column29: who lost to Carlos Curbelo in November. With a just few keystrokes
column30: hackers were able to take down two Democratic candidates in one congressional district.
column31: At the time of our interview with Taddeo
column32: she said she had not been interviewed by the FBI about the hacking.
column33: Listen to the latest episode of \u201cCandidate Confessional\u201d above.\xa0
column34: \u201cCandidate Confessional\u201d is produced by Zach Young.\xa0To listen to this podcast later
column35: download it on\xa0Apple Podcasts.\xa0While you\u2019re there
column36: please rate and review our show.\xa0To subscribe

visit the following:\xa0Apple Podcasts\xa0/\xa0Acast\xa0/\xa0RadioPublic\xa0/\xa0Google Play\xa0/\xa0Stitcher\xa0/\xa0RSS\xa0

column1: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/as-trump-ends-daca-dreamers-worry-about-family_us_59af37a7e4b0354e440d8121?utm_campaign=hp_fb_pages&utm_source=politics_fb&utm_medium=facebook&ncid=fcbklnkushpmg00000013&section=politics|<h1 class="headline__title">As Trump Nixes DACA
column2:
Dreamers Worry About Their Families|[

AUSTIN \u2015 When Karla P\xe9rez handed over a stack of paperwork including her home address
column3: photographs and her fingerprints to U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services five years ago to apply for DACA
column4: she was still living at home with her parents. To gain the ability to work legally under the new program despite being undocumented
column5: P\xe9rez had to make the tough choice to give the Department of Homeland Security not just her own address
column6: but the one for her mom and dad as well.
column7: \u201cThat always weighs heavily on my mind
column8: \u201d P\xe9rez said. \u201cMy biggest concern right now is my parents because DHS has my information\u2026 I\u2019m not so much worried for myself as for my family.\u201d
column9: After the Trump administration announced the termination of DACA on Tuesday
column10: several of the program\u2019s recipients interviewed by HuffPost described feeling a sense of both injustice and betrayal. The program
column11: whose full title is Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals
column12: shielded undocumented immigrants who came to the country as minors from deportation and allowed them to work legally in the United States.
column13: To take advantage of the program
column14: DACA recipients had to make a leap of faith that the federal government would not turn around after Barack Obama\u2019s presidency ended and use their own information against them. \xa0
column15: Many of them
column16: like P\xe9rez
column17: were living with undocumented family members when they provided their address to USCIS on their first applications. As the Trump administration eviscerates the last major immigration reform of the Obama years
column18: many DACA beneficiaries were not worried so much about themselves as their parents or other family members left out of the program and in limbo by stalled attempts to pass farther-reaching reforms through Congress.\xa0
column19: \u201cI\u2019m freaked out
column20: \u201d P\xe9rez said. \u201cBut at the same time
column21: there\u2019s this renewed commitment to fight for everyone in the immigrant community
column22: including my parents.\u201d\xa0
column23: Juan Belman
column25: obtained DACA while studying at the University of Texas at Austin. He\u2019s since moved on to a job at the Workers Defense Project
column26: an organization dedicated to recouping the unpaid money owed to low-wage workers. The address Belman submitted with his DACA application was his family home
column27: where his undocumented parents live.
column28: \u201cThat\u2019s a concern
column29: \u201d Belman told HuffPost. \u201cI\u2019m not always home. That\u2019s something I worry about. We\u2019ve given them all our information.\u201d \xa0
column30: Another DACA recipient
column31: who asked to be identified only as Luis in order to protect his family
column32: remembered feeling ecstatic back in 2012 when the Obama administration rolled out DACA. Having fled years ago as an unaccompanied minor from gang violence and an abusive father in Central America
column33: Luis had no way to apply to normalize his status before DACA.
column34: \u201cMany of us ran from persecution
column35: from violence
column36: from absolute levels of poverty
column37: \u201d Luis said. \u201cAll of the sudden
column38: a Dreamer is told that there is going to be a line. Of course you\u2019re going to jump on line!\u201d
column39: \u201cOf course I trusted it
column40: \u201d he continued. \u201cBecause I believe in this nation and I want to serve this nation
column41: regardless of its politics and its different administrations.\u201d
column42: Now enrolled in graduate school
column43: he worries about what the Trump administration\u2019s decision to kill the program will mean for his ability to work here
column44: or the impact it will have on more mundane but life-changing opportunities the program granted him
column45: like the ability to obtain a driver\u2019s license. (A spokeswoman for the Texas Department of Public Security wrote in an email that DACA recipients\u2019 licenses would expire along with their participation in the program.)
column46: But more than that
column47: he\u2019s concerned about the impact the decision will have on his mother.
column48: \u201cI wonder what my mom is thinking
column49: \u201d Luis said. \u201cI talk to her and she\u2019s crying\u2026 I am in college and so is my mom every single day I\u2019m in class because I have her in my heart. My family trusted. And now the entire nation has been betrayed.\u201d \xa0
column50: Homeland Security officials insist that they will not use the information provided by DACA recipients against them to pursue deportation orders. Those who participated in the program gave their information to U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services
column51: the agency that processes applications to obtain legal residency or to obtain American citizenship. That agency is separate from Immigration and Customs Enforcement
column52: which carries out deportation policy.
column53: But both agencies belong to DHS
column54: leading to unease among the program\u2019s recipients that their trust of federal authorities may backfire on them.
column55: Ahead of Tuesday\u2019s announcement that the Trump administration would end DACA
column56: Homeland Security officials told reporters that USCIS will not share information with ICE
column57: unless they had a compelling reason. \u201cIn instances of criminality or law enforcement
column58: we will use all of our law enforcement databases
column59: \u201d one of the department\u2019s senior officials said.
column60: A statement posted on the DHS website noted that the information-sharing policy between the department\u2019s agencies could change without warning. \xa0
column61: \u201cThis policy
column62: which may be modified
column63: superseded
column64: or rescinded at any time without notice
column65: is not intended to
column66: does not
column67: and may not be relied upon to create any right or benefit
column68: substantive or procedural
column69: enforceable by law by any party in any administrative
column70: civil
column71: or criminal matter
column72: \u201d the statement reads.
column73: The vagueness of those assertions offers little assurance to the individuals concerned about what Tuesday\u2019s changes mean for themselves or their families.
column74: At the same time
column75: concerns about information sharing through the soon-to-be-defunct DACA program is unlikely to keep many of the program\u2019s beneficiaries quiet. \xa0
column76: Even before the Obama administration implemented DACA
column77: many undocumented youths had begun openly declaring their immigration status as a political act
column78: adopting the slogan \u201cundocumented and unafraid.\u201d One of them
column79: Cesar Vargas
column80: became the first undocumented immigrant in the state of New York to obtain a license to practice law in 2015 \u2015 a state court decision based partly on the fact that he had DACA.
column82: he practices immigration law in Staten Island. Despite concerns about information sharing between USCIS and ICE
column83: Vargas emphasized that until it\u2019s phased out
column84: the program continues.
column85: \u201cI\u2019m telling clients
column86: \u2018your information should be safe
column87: \u2019\u201d he said. \u201cBut don\u2019t get in trouble. That\u2019s where we\u2019re at right now.\u201d
column88: While his hard-fought ability to practice law was plunged into doubt with the Trump administration\u2019s decision
column89: Vargas urged other Dreamers to keep publicly pushing for reform
column90: noting like most others interviewed for this story that it was their efforts that led to the creation of DACA in the first place.
column91: \u201cOne of the things we try to tell people is that this is a moment not to regress back to the shadows
column92: \u201d Vargas said. \u201cThis is a moment where we\u2019re undocumented and unafraid. Trump and [Attorney General] Jeff Sessions want us to regress back to the shadows. They tell stories that portray us as criminals and rapists. But we need to keep telling our own stories.\u201d

|[

The descendant of Confederate General Robert E. Lee
column2: Rev. Robert Lee IV
column3: has left the Bethany United Church of Christ after receiving backlash for his denouncement of white supremacy at the MTV Video Music Awards last week.
column4: On Monday
column5: an open letter by Lee describing the events that unfolded after his speech was published on a website for the Auburn Seminary. In the piece
column6: Lee wrote that some members of the church \u201cwere concerned\u201d about his speech and that the attention it brought to the church wasn\u2019t desired.
column7: \u201cMy presence at the church as a descendent of Robert E. Lee and an outspoken opponent of white supremacy had already attracted attention
column8: but with my appearance on MTV the media\u2019s focus on my church reached an all time high
column9: \u201d he wrote. \u201cA faction of church members were concerned about my speech and that I lifted up Black Lives Matter movement
column10: the Women\u2019 s March
column11: and Heather Heyer as examples of racial justice work.\u201d
column12: He went on to say that \u201cthe church\u2019s reaction was deeply hurtful\u201d to him.
column13: The 24-year-old pastor had served the North Carolina church for just six months and says he doesn\u2019t want \u201cthis episode to be a distraction from the sacred work of confronting white supremacy in all its forms.\u201d
column14: Adding: \u201cMy calling and my vocation has led me to speak out against violence and oppression in any form
column15: and I want to especially challenge white Christians in America to take seriously the deadly legacy of slavery in our country and commit ourselves to follow Jesus into a time of deep reflection
column16: repentance and reconciliation.\u201d
column17: At the VMA\u2019s
column18: the fourth-great-nephew of Robert E. Lee introduced Susan Bro \u2015 the mother of slain Charlottesville counter protester
column19: Heather Heyer \u2015 and said it was his \u201cduty to speak out against racism
column20: America\u2019s original sin
column21: \u201d and advocated for viewers to \u201cconfront racism and white supremacy head on.\u201d\xa0
column22: Since Lee cut ties with the church
column23: he\u2019s been vocal on social media
column24: expressing thanks to supporters and sharing his thoughts on speaking out:
column25: If we all used what we had to speak up
column26: no matter how large or small. I think this world would be a better place. https://t.co/ia5Rlz5Oxc
column27: Lee ended his open letter by saying he is \u201clooking forward with great hope to what God\u2019s unfolding future and what God has in store for me and ask for all of your prayers and blessings for the future of my ministry.\u201d
column28: Following white supremacist rallies in Charlottesville
column29: Va.
column30: Lee told HuffPost that he was deeply troubled by the actions taken in his family\u2019s name and that statues honoring his great-great-great-great uncle
column31: Confederate General Robert E. Lee
column32: ought to come down.\xa0
column33: \u201cIt broke my heart to see a symbol of my family being used to allow such hate
column34: \u201d Lee told HuffPost. \u201cAll in the name of what my relative stood for.\u201d
column35: \u201cThese statues have morphed into a symbol of racism
column36: a symbol of bigotry
column37: a symbol of the alt-right
column38: a symbol of white nationalist movements
column39: \u201d he said. \u201cThat is not okay and that can never be celebrated or honored in any way
column40:
whether you believe you should honor legacy or ancestors or not.\u201d

column1: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/trump-daca-decision_us_59a04060e4b05710aa5bda7b?utm_campaign=hp_fb_pages&utm_source=politics_fb&utm_medium=facebook&ncid=fcbklnkushpmg00000013&section=politics|<h1 class="headline__title">Trump To End Protections For Nearly 800
column2:
000 Dreamers If Congress Can't Pass A Deal|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 The Trump administration is officially terminating the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals in six months and punting the matter to Congress
column3: putting nearly 800
column4: 000 young undocumented immigrants at risk of deportation if the president and members of the House and Senate can\u2019t make a deal to protect them.
column5: On Tuesday
column6: President Donald Trump\xa0\u2015 who later said he has \u201ca great heart\u201d and \u201cgreat love\u201d for undocumented young people \u2015 sent out Attorney General Jeff Sessions to announce his policy decision. Sessions
column7: who\xa0supports enforcing current law through increased deportations
column8: \xa0has opposed the DACA program since its inception under President Barack Obama in 2012. As a senator
column9: he helped block legislative efforts to help so-called \u201cDreamers\u201d who came to the U.S. as children.\xa0
column10: \u201cWe are people of compassion and we are people of law
column11: \u201d Sessions said during a speech at the Department of Justice. \u201cBut there is nothing compassionate about the failure to enforce immigration laws. ...\xa0<span style="font-weight: 400;">The compassionate thing to do is to end the lawlessness
column12: enforce our laws and
column13: if Congress chooses to make changes to those laws
column14: to do so through the process set forth by our founders in a way that advances the interest of the American people.\u201d\xa0
column15: DACA protections
column16: which last for two years and allow Dreamers to work legally
column17: won\u2019t end immediately. Current DACA recipients whose permits expire between now and March 5 can apply to renew them
column18: but must submit their renewal applications by Oct. 5 or will be unable to do so. Individuals who do not currently have DACA protections cannot receive permits unless they applied to the program before Sept. 5.
column19: Dreamers whose permits expire on March 6 or later will begin to lose their protections and work permits as soon as they expire
column20: putting them at risk of deportation.
column21: Trump said in a statement that he \u201cadvised the Department of Homeland Security that DACA recipients are not enforcement priorities unless they are criminals
column22: are involved in criminal activity
column23: or are members of a gang.\u201d
column24: But losing DACA protections would nonetheless put Dreamers at risk of being sent away from the country they\u2019ve lived in since they were children.\xa0Although administration officials have said their focus is on deporting criminals
column25: they have also made clear that no undocumented immigrant is safe from being detained or forced out of the country. That includes Dreamers
column26: some of whom have already been locked up.\xa0
column27: Department of Homeland Security officials said before the announcement that there are no plans to specifically target current DACA recipients or use their information for enforcement purposes
column28: although they will continue to do so if needed for criminal or national security investigations.\xa0
column29: The official Trump administration announcement comes on the Sept. 5 deadline set by 10 state attorneys general who threatened legal action if Trump did not announce a phaseout of DACA by that date. Tennessee Attorney General Herbert Slatery III (R)\xa0backed off that threat last week
column30: but the others continued to demand an end to the program. The threat was not a court order
column31: so it was not a mandate for the Trump administration to end the program ahead of a legal challenge or ruling.
column32: Trump misstated the facts of the threat in a statement after Sessions\u2019 announcement. The president claimed that\xa0\u201cofficials from 10 States are suing over the program
column33: \u201d even though they had not taken legal action and only nine of the 10 states had maintained that threat.
column34: Trump decided to end DACA against the wishes of Democrats and some members of his own party
column35: including House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.)
column36: who said Congress should get the chance to pass a bill.
column37: The president said on Tuesday afternoon that he hoped Congress would move forward to help Dreamers
column38: although he said nothing about what he thinks they should do.\xa0
column39: \u201cI have a love for these people and hopefully now Congress will be able to help them and do it properly
column40: \u201d Trump said in the White House. \u201cAnd I can tell you
column41: speaking to members of Congress
column42: they want to be able to do something and do it right. ...\xa0I think it\u2019s going to work out very well and long-term
column43: it\u2019s going to be the right solution.\u201d\xa0
column44: Ahead of Trump\u2019s announcement
column45: a number of Republicans said they would be willing to support protections for Dreamers that Democrats have attempted to get through Congress multiple times.
column46: Most Republicans opposed those past measures
column47: including the Dream Act
column48: a bill first introduced in 2001 that would grant legal status to some undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children. The bill has a small number of Republican supporters
column49: but the White House immediately shot it down when it was re-introduced in the Senate in July.
column50: Some Republicans are pushing what they say is a more conservative version of the Dream Act
column51: called the Recognizing America\u2019s Children Act
column52: or RAC Act
column53: which would offer a path to citizenship to a smaller category of Dreamers.\xa0
column54: Sessions\u2019 speech only mentioned one piece of legislation specifically: the RAISE Act
column55: which would slash legal immigration numbers and has nothing to do with Dreamers. His remarks more broadly made the case against offering Dreamers legal status
column56: something he has opposed many times throughout his career.\xa0
column57: Sessions said that DACA \u201cdenied jobs to hundreds of thousands of Americans by allowing those same illegal aliens to take those jobs\u201d \u2015 an argument that could also be applied to legislation that allows Dreamers to stay in the country and work legally. He claimed that a surge in unaccompanied minors at the southwest U.S. border was also due to DACA
column58: although those children were ineligible for the program. Sessions also said that the U.S. \u201cmust set and enforce a limit on how many immigrants we admit each year.\u201d
column59: \u201cThis does not mean they are bad people or that our nation disrespects or demeans them in any way
column60: \u201d Sessions said. \u201cIt means we are properly enforcing our laws as Congress has passed them.\u201d
column61: Trump\u2019s statement similarly emphasized other changes to the immigration system. Like Sessions
column62: he cited the RAISE Act and said his \u201cfirst and highest priority in advancing immigration reform must be to improve jobs
column63: wages and security for American workers and their families.\u201d
column64: \u201cAs I\u2019ve said before
column65: we will resolve the DACA issue with heart and compassion \u2013 but through the lawful Democratic process \u2013 while at the same time ensuring that any immigration reform we adopt provides enduring benefits for the American citizens we were elected to serve
column66: \u201d the statement read. \u201cWe must also have heart and compassion for unemployed
column67: struggling
column68: and forgotten Americans.\u201d
column69:
This story has been updated with Donald Trump\u2019s statements.

]

column1: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/steve-harvey-my-wife-told-me-to-skip-meeting-with-trump-i-shouldve-listened_us_59aee344e4b0354e440d0925?utm_campaign=hp_fb_pages&utm_source=politics_fb&utm_medium=facebook&ncid=fcbklnkushpmg00000013&section=politics|<h1 class="headline__title">Steve Harvey: My Wife Told Me To Skip Meeting With Trump
column2:
I Should’ve Listened|[

When comedian and TV host Steve Harvey met with President Donald Trump earlier this year
column3: he didn\u2019t expect the degree of outrage he\u2019d receive.\xa0
column4: Harvey
column5: who recently\xa0opened up to The Hollywood Reporter\xa0about his career as a comedian and a TV host
column6: spoke about both personal and political experiences over the years and how his meeting with Trump made for one that brings him regrets. The meeting drew ire from fans and critics alike.\xa0
column7: \u201cI didn\u2019t see that coming. Jesus
column8: \u201d Harvey\xa0told the publication\xa0in a new piece published Tuesday. \u201cIt was so vicious that it really threw me.\u201d
column9: \u201cI was being called names that I\u2019ve never been called: Uncle Tom. A coon. A sellout
column10: \u201d he added.\xa0
column11: Harvey said he first met with Trump after he said his business partner received \u201ca call from the Obama transition team
column12: who said that the Trump transition team would like to set up a meeting.\u201d\xa0He said yes \u2015 but the meeting was also to be held around Harvey\u2019s 60th birthday celebration which was hosted on a boat. So
column13: his wife Marjorie Harvey
column14: suggested he deliberately miss the meeting.\xa0
column15: \u201cMy wife says
column16: \u2019Steve
column17: just take off [and skip the meeting]. You\u2019ll meet with him some other time
column18: \u2033\u201d he recalled. \u201cGod
column19: I should\u2019ve listened.\u201d\xa0
column20: Harvey met with the President at the Trump Towers and said he spent about 20 minutes in the January meeting talking about golf. He recalled how he told Trump about potentially working with Ben Carson
column21: who the president appointed to lead the department of Housing and Urban Development
column22: to help identify ways he could help transform closing schools into \u201cvision centers and teach STEM and computers and coding.\u201d\xa0
column23: Harvey said he has since been to HUD twice and that he\u2019s met with Carson. \u201cWe\u2019re actually trying to get it started
column24: \u201d he said. \u201cHopefully before the year goes out
column25: we\u2019ll be making the announcement about the first vision center.\u201d\xa0
column26: Harvey
column27: who was pictured with Trump immediately following their meeting
column28: drew ire from critics who called out the disrespect and shame they felt in seeing him
column29: a black man
column30: be so willing to work with a man who has consistently neglected and disrespected the black community.\xa0
column31: Harvey himself released a statement in January as the outrage began to bubble up
column32: explaining then why he met with the President and affirming that \u201che would sit with Trump anytime.\u201d \xa0
column33: My meeting with @realDonaldTrump ... pic.twitter.com/Tz2O2W3a5n
column34: A fancy birthday boat ride doesn\u2019t sound half bad
column35:
after all.\xa0

column1: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/new-york-opioid-crisis_us_59a94fb6e4b0dfaafcef8c26?utm_campaign=hp_fb_pages&utm_source=politics_fb&utm_medium=facebook&ncid=fcbklnkushpmg00000013&section=politics|<h1 class="headline__title">In New York State
column2:
A Glimmer Of Good News About The Opioid Crisis|[

After years of rising opioid mortality
column3: opioid deaths in most New York counties fell between 2015 and 2016
column4: according to new numbers from the New York State Department of Health.
column5: Excluding New York City
column6: which is counted separately and where opioid deaths rose during the same period
column7: there were 1
column8: 238 opioid deaths in New York state last year
column9: compared to 1
column10: 520 deaths the year before. Overdose deaths take time to confirm
column11: and it\u2019s possible the new report\u2019s numbers could change
column12: but the apparent improvement comes amid growing use of the overdose reversal drug naloxone \u2015 lending credence to the public health theory that increased access to naloxone helps prevent opioid deaths.
column13: \u201cThe increased use of naloxone in New York State reflects both the ongoing opioid epidemic as well as increased access to this life-saving medication
column14: \u201d Jill Montag
column15: a state health department spokeswoman
column16: told HuffPost in an email. \u201cCounty health departments \u2015 as well as treatment programs
column17: community-based organizations and public safety agencies \u2015 have taken critical roles in working with the state to expand this capacity.\u201d\xa0
column18: Montag noted that New York plans to continue expanding access to the medication
column19: via a naloxone copay assistance program that offers up to $40 in copay assistance to people with health insurance. (Those without insurance can get naloxone for free through a registered overdose prevention program.)
column20: \u201cThese findings are consistent with the increasingly definitive medical and public health evidence that expanded access to naloxone for first responders
column21: community and family members
column22: as well as those using opioids
column23: saves lives
column24: \u201d Dr. Peter Friedmann
column25: associate dean for research at the University of Massachusetts Medical School and chief research officer at the nonprofit Baystate Health
column26: told HuffPost.
column27: Indeed
column28: the new numbers track with previous research
column29: including a National Bureau of Economic Research working paper released in February
column30: which found that between 1999 and 2014
column31: adopting naloxone access laws was associated with a 9 to 11 percent reduction in opioid deaths. (The paper has not yet been peer-reviewed or published in a journal.)
column32: New York City\u2019s numbers complicate the picture
column33: however. The state report does not include the city\u2019s overdose death figures
column34: but the New York City Health Department confirmed that unintentional overdose deaths in NYC\xa0<a href="http://www1.nyc.gov/assets/doh/downloads/pdf/epi/databrief89.pdf" target="_blank">rose from 937 in 2015 to 1
column35: 374 in 2016. More than 80 percent of those deaths involved an opioid.
column36: \u201cNew York City has had high rates of opioid overdose deaths in the Bronx
column37: and particularly the South Bronx
column38: \u201d an NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene spokesperson told HuffPost. \u201cNonetheless
column39: similar to other parts of the city
column40: state and country
column41: the Bronx has seen steep increases in opioid-involved overdose deaths since 2010
column42: with sharp increases from 2015 to 2016. If the South Bronx were a state
column43: it would have the second highest overdose rate after West Virginia.\u201d
column44: This increase comes despite the city\u2019s robust naloxone program. In March
column45: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced a $38 million plan to fight opioid addiction and overdose
column46: including a commitment to distributing 100
column47: 000 naloxone kits per year. According to the new state report
column48: emergency medical services in New York City administered the overdose reversal drug 5
column49: 088 times in 2015 and 7
column50: 667 times last year.\xa0
column51: On the national level
column52: news about the opioid crisis has been bleak in recent years. In 2015
column53: more than 50
column54: 000 Americans died of drug overdoses
column55:
with overdose deaths outpacing historical epidemics like HIV and firearm deaths during their deadliest years.\xa0

Immigration Hard-Liners Also Mad At Trump’s DACA Decision – For Being Too Soft

|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 While much of America criticized as heartless President Donald Trump\u2019s decision to end protections for people brought to this country illegally as children
column2: one slice of America is angry for the opposite reason: that it took too long and leaves too much wiggle room.
column3: \u201cI have a love for these people
column4: and hopefully now Congress will be able to help them and do it properly
column5: \u201d Trump said Tuesday at a White House photo opportunity. \u201cI think it\u2019s going to work out very well. And long term it\u2019s going to be the right solution.\u201d
column6: William Gheen of Americans for Legal Immigration
column7: which advocates for restricting immigration into this country
column8: was not happy. \u201cHe\u2019s implying that Congress should pass amnesty instead of him.\u201d
column9: Unfortunately for Trump
column10: immigration hard-liners make up a disproportionate chunk of that 35 percent of the nation that still approves of his job performance.
column11: \u201cThat\u2019s not what those stadiums full of people wanted
column12: \u201d Gheen said. \u201cDonald Trump is letting a lot of Americans down today.\u201d
column13: Gheen and others who want to limit immigration point to a Phoenix rally on Aug. 31
column15: when Trump gave his word on ending the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program
column16: or DACA.
column17: \u201cWe will immediately terminate President Obama\u2019s two illegal executive amnesties in which he defied federal law and the Constitution to give amnesty to approximately 5 million illegal immigrants
column18: \u201d Trump said
column19: referring to DACA and a related program that was blocked by the courts.
column20: But almost exactly three years earlier
column21: Trump met with a handful of so-called Dreamers \u2015 named for the acronym of the failed legislation that sought to protect them \u2015 during which he reportedly told them that they had persuaded him on the issue. And since taking office
column22: Trump has on numerous occasions talked about his \u201cheart\u201d and his \u201ccompassion\u201d toward the DACA enrollees.
column23: These conflicting statements follow a pattern of Trump\u2019s personality
column24: in which appears to want to please or at least avoid a confrontation with whatever group he happens to be speaking to at the moment.
column25: When meeting with the DACA recipients
column26: he told them what they wanted to hear. Then
column27: in front of a rally crowd
column28: he told them what he thought they wanted to hear.
column29: \u201cHe doesn\u2019t like conflict
column30: \u201d said one Republican consultant close to the Trump White House
column31: who spoke on condition of anonymity in order to speak candidly about the president.
column32: So
column33: the consultant said
column34: after having promised his voting base one thing and DACA kids the opposite
column35: Trump decided to offload the issue onto Congress
column36: which should have dealt with it in the first place.
column37: \u201cThis is checkmate for him
column38: \u201d the adviser said of Trump\u2019s strategy
column39: adding that Trump has many times made clear he empathizes with the plight of the DACA recipients. \u201cHe thinks more of the Dreamers than he does of Republican leaders in Congress.\u201d
column40: That punt-to-Congress tactic was accepted Tuesday
column41: if not necessarily embraced
column42: by some of DACA\u2019s most strident critics. Ira Mehlman of the Federation for American Immigration Reform also wished Trump had acted sooner. \u201cWe can\u2019t go back and change the past. The announcement today is that it\u2019s going to be phased out.\u201d Mehlman added that he expects Trump to force Democrats to \u201ccome to the table\u201d and work to fix border security and eliminate the benefits of coming to this country illegally. \u201cAnd then we can figure out how to deal with this.\u201d
column43: But to Gheen
column44: the fact that he and his group have to deal with the issue at all with Trump in the Oval Office is maddening.
column45: \u201cWe\u2019re miffed now that we\u2019re having to fight Trump\u2019s amnesty. Those are two powerful words that we never thought we\u2019d have to put together: Trump possessive \u2018s\u2019 amnesty
column46:
\u201d Gheen said.

White House special counsel Ty Cobb asked Business Insider\u2019s Natasha Bertrand if she was on drugs during an email thread late on Saturday.\xa0
column2: Bertrand was speaking with Cobb after he took issue with an analysis piece she wrote Saturday\xa0about a letter that\xa0President Donald Trump\xa0reportedly drafted to fire former FBI director James Comey.\xa0White House counsel Don McGahn advised against sending the letter
column3: and Bertrand says it may now be used as evidence in the obstruction of justice case special counsel Robert Mueller is reportedly building against Trump. \xa0
column4: Cobb insisted that the president had wide support within the White House for choosing to fire Comey
column5: but refused to answer why the letter was never sent directly to the former FBI director.
column6: After receiving follow up questions to his statement
column7: Cobb asked Bertrand
column8: \u201cAre you on drugs?\u201d\xa0
column9: Bertrand posted the exchange to Twitter\xa0on Sunday morning.\xa0
column10: pic.twitter.com/KPjgkuV5x1
column11: Cobb\u2019s abrupt and unprofessional response came as a shock to the reporter.
column12: \u201cCobb supposedly has a great reputation and is a very respected lawyer
column13: \u201d Bertrand told HuffPost. \u201cHe was brought in to bring some discipline to the whole operation. So I wasn\u2019t expecting that response to what I thought was a pretty basic question.\u201d\xa0
column14: Bertrand then responded to Cobb
column15: assuring him that she was not on drugs and that he hadn\u2019t been forthcoming in his emails.
column16: \u201cNo I\u2019m not on drugs. But you\u2019re not giving me much to work with. I\u2019ve asked several times for an explanation of what in the story (which is an analysis piece
column17: in any case) is false.\u201d
column18: Cobb has not responded to the reporter\u2019s email message and the White House did not immediately respond to HuffPost\u2019s request for comment.\xa0
column19: Bertrand wrote about the exchange in more detail Sunday morning
column20:
which can be read here.\xa0

Trump's Mine Safety Pick Would Be Policing His Friends And Once-Fellow Coal Operators

|[

When David Zatezalo was the chief executive of Rhino Resources
column2: his coal company had its share of run-ins with regulators at the U.S. Mine Safety and Health Administration. At one point in 2010
column3: MSHA even threatened to put one of Rhino\u2019s mines on its list of egregious safety lawbreakers. \xa0
column4: Seven years later
column5: Zatezalo is now President Donald Trump\u2019s nominee to run MSHA. Zatezalo told HuffPost on Tuesday that he doesn\u2019t see any problem with a former industry executive serving as the top cop responsible for making sure miners are protected by their employers.
column6: \u201cI don\u2019t agree with that
column7: \u201d he said of concerns that he may be too cozy with coal operators. \u201cPeople can say what they\u2019re going to say. Actions speak louder than words.\u201d
column8: If he\u2019s confirmed by the Republican-controlled Senate
column9: Zatezalo would be just the latest business-friendly official installed in Trump\u2019s deregulation-happy administration. And like many of the appointees before him
column10: Zatezalo has a resume that appears better suited to an industry trade group than a watchdog government agency.
column11: Though he started out as a rank-and-file union miner
column12: Zatezalo climbed his way to the top of the industry over the decades
column13: eventually helming Lexington
column14: Kentucky-based Rhino. He also served stints as chairman of the Kentucky and Ohio coal lobbying groups.
column15: Zatezalo
column16: who retired from his Rhino post in 2014
column17: told the Wheeling Intelligencer that coal executives including Murray Energy CEO Bob Murray \u2015 a major Trump donor and longtime critic of the federal government \u2015 essentially recruited him for the MSHA job.
column18: \u201cThere aren\u2019t a lot of people in the industry I don\u2019t know
column19: and people said
column20: \u2018You\u2019d be great for that position. I\u2019m going to call [Senate Majority Leader Mitch] McConnell and tell him he needs to support you for this
column21: \u2019\u201d Zatezalo told the paper.
column22: MSHA was created in 1977 in the wake of deadly mining disasters to enforce the rights of miners and to make sure they aren\u2019t put in harm\u2019s way. The agency is responsible for inspecting all of the nation\u2019s mines (not just coal)
column23: identifying workplace hazards and fining operators when they\u2019re breaking the law. MSHA differs from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration in that it\u2019s tasked with protecting workers in a single
column24: dangerous line of work. \xa0
column25: So it worries mine safety advocates that
column26: assuming Zatezalo wins Senate confirmation
column27: the agency\u2019s reins will be handed to a former executive. Many coal operators view MSHA\u2019s inspections and citations as an annoyance that slow down production and cost them money. Zatezalo\u2019s friend Murray
column28: for instance
column29: has referred to MSHA inspections as \u201dtotal harassment.\u201d
column30: \u201cYou always want to give someone the benefit of the doubt
column31: but history tells us that people chosen from industry typically don\u2019t do a good job
column32: \u201d Tony Oppegard
column33: a Kentucky lawyer who represents miners in safety cases
column34: told HuffPost. \u201cI don\u2019t expect him to be a zealous advocate of mine safety. I don\u2019t think Trump\u2019s team would have chosen him if that was the case.\u201d
column35: When Zatezalo was running Rhino in 2011
column36: the company had to pay $44
column37: 500 in fines after a foreman was killed when a wall collapsed in a West Virginia mine. The same year
column38: MSHA accused Rhino employees at a Kentucky mine of tipping off workers underground when agency inspectors were about to make their rounds. As the Charleston Gazette-Mail reported
column39: the agency went so far as to seek a court injunction against Rhino over the practice.\xa0
column40: MSHA is required by law to inspect every workplace in its purview multiple times each year. Absent action by Congress
column41: that won\u2019t change even with an MSHA chief who wanted to scale back enforcement and be a friend to industry. But there are other ways an agency leader could soften regulations and go easy on mining companies.
column42: Celeste Monforton
column43: an occupational health expert and former MSHA employee
column44: said the MSHA chief could alter the criteria that lands a mine on the agency\u2019s \u201cpattern of violations\u201d list. That\u2019s the list that Zatezalo\u2019s company nearly wound up on in 2010.
column45: Monforton said the agency\u2019s leader could also decide not to pursue high-dollar penalties against mine operators
column46: or go easy on them in settlement talks over safety violations.
column47: \u201cWhat will his focus be \u2015 will it be on miners and mine safety
column48: or will he have a philosophy that MSHA is there to help mine operators
column49: provide a lot of compliance assistance
column50: and be wary of taking a tough stand?\u201d she asked.
column51: If he\u2019s confirmed
column52: Zatezalo will be coming to MSHA at a time when black lung cases are spiking in much of Appalachia. It\u2019s up to MSHA to make sure mine operators are taking the right precautions to limit coal dust
column53: excessive levels of which can destroy miners\u2019 lungs.
column54: Monforton said there is still much that MSHA can do to protect miners from lung illnesses
column55: including strengthening the regulations for silica dust
column56: which comes from cut rock.
column57: She said she hopes Zatezalo would remember his experience as a rank-and-file miner
column58: rather than his role as an executive
column59: in regulating mine safety.
column60: \u201cHe has seen first-hand the tragedy and the suffering that goes on with people who develop black lung and silicosis
column61:
\u201d Monforton said. \u201cIt really would be a way for him to make a positive mark.\u201d

]

column2:
But Not Without Democratic Concessions|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 Lawmakers on Capitol Hill broadly agreed on Tuesday that something should be done about young undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children and who will eventually lose deportation protections if Congress does not step in to help them.
column3: But Republicans are already placing conditions on their support that could kill the effort entirely. They are willing to vote for protecting so-called \u201cDreamers\u201d \u2015 but not without getting something in exchange for it.
column4: \u201cHopefully there will be some give and take and we can accomplish something
column5: \u201d Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.) said
column6: suggesting Democrats could support efforts to boost border security.
column7: President Donald Trump announced on Tuesday that his administration rescinded the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program
column8: with enforcement to begin in six months. That time period gives Congress time to pass its own measures to allow undocumented young people to stay in the country
column9: something that a majority of Americans support.
column10: Most Republicans in Congress have previously opposed such measures. A majority of them voted against past versions of the Dream Act
column11: a stand-alone bill that would provide legal status to young undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children. Some GOP senators voted for a comprehensive immigration reform bill that included measures for Dreamers in 2013
column12: but also would have increased border security and included other enforcement measures.
column13: Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.)
column14: one of the sponsors of the current iteration of the Dream Act
column15: argued during a press conference on Tuesday that lawmakers\xa0\u201cdon\u2019t have that luxury right now\u201d of taking the time to pass another comprehensive bill
column16: given the six-month time limit. Only four Republicans are currently co-sponsoring the Dream Act: Graham
column17: Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.)
column18: Lisa Murkowski (R-Alaska) and Cory Gardner (R-Colo.). Gardner announced his support on Tuesday evening.
column19: Another possibility for stand-alone legislation is the Recognizing America\u2019s Children Act
column20: or RAC Act
column21: that Sen. Thom Tillis (R-N.C.) plans to introduce in the Senate soon.\xa0The RAC Act in the form already introduced in the House would grant legal status to certain young undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. at age 15 or younger before 2012; the 2017 Dream Act would be open to individuals who came before the age of 18 and were in the U.S. since four years prior to the bill taking effect.\xa0
column22: Tillis indicated on Tuesday that his bill is meant to pass on its own \u2015 he told reporters that although \u201cwe need border security measures
column23: it\u2019s a different bill going through Congress.\u201d
column24: \u201cThe bottom line of it is
column25: I don\u2019t think DACA as a clean bill can get through the Congress by itself
column26: \u201d Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa)\xa0said in a call with reporters on Tuesday
column27: according to Politico. He added that this was an \u201copportunity for compromise between people that want DACA plus a lot of other things dealing with legal immigration
column28: and I suppose even some things dealing with illegal immigration
column29: that can probably be packaged together.\u201d
column30: Some Republicans want to pair protections for Dreamers with cutting legal immigration
column31: which Sen. Tom Cotton (R-Ark.) is pushing through in a bill called the RAISE Act. That legislation \u2015 which has nothing to do with Dreamers \u2015 was the only specific measure that Trump or Attorney General Jeff Sessions mentioned on Tuesday while announcing the DACA decision. The RAISE Act would face opposition not just from Democrats
column32: but some Republicans as well.
column33: Trump hasn\u2019t actually said what he specifically wants Congress to do about Dreamers
column34: although the White House previously indicated he wouldn\u2019t sign a stand-alone bill like the Dream Act.
column35: \u201cI have a love for these people and hopefully now Congress will be able to help them and do it properly
column36: \u201d the president said on Tuesday afternoon. \u201cAnd I can tell you
column37: speaking to members of Congress
column38: they want to be able to do something and do it right. And really
column39: we have no choice
column40: we have to be able to do something
column41: and I think it\u2019s going to work out very well.\u201d
column42: Even if enough Republicans ultimately come out in support of a stand-alone Dream Act
column43: it\u2019s no sure bet that all Democrats would join them.
column44: Sen. Jon Tester (D-Mont.)
column45: who helped defeat a similar measure in 2013
column46: said Tuesday he opposed the president\u2019s \u201cill-informed\u201d decision to rescind DACA. But the vulnerable red state Democrat
column47: who is facing a tough re-election fight in 2018
column48: would not say whether he would vote to provide legal status to Dreamers in the future.
column49: \u201cI don\u2019t know. It depends on what it is
column50: \u201d Tester said
column51: adding that Congress now had an \u201copportunity\u201d to tackle comprehensive immigration reform
column52: which he supports.
column53: Democrats are unlikely to compromise on funding Trump\u2019s border wall
column54: some said. But they might be willing to accept other measures. Graham
column55: when touting the Dream Act
column56: noted that his Democratic colleagues had voted for border security and enforcement measures as part of the 2013 comprehensive immigration reform bill.
column57: \u201cIn order to get 68 votes in the Senate
column58: I swallowed hard
column59: \u201d Sen. Dick Durbin (D-Ill.)
column60: the top champion of the Dream Act
column61: said at the press conference with Graham of the 2013 bill. \u201cI\u2019ve been open to border security issues
column62: I continue to be open to them. The wall
column63: though
column64:
is a wall too far.\u201d

]

Undocumented Filipino Immigrant Journalist: DACA Fight Isn’t Over

|[

Jose Antonio Vargas isn\u2019t going to stop challenging President Donald Trump\u2019s decision to end Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA).\xa0
column2: The Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist
column3: who\u2019s undocumented
column4: told HuffPost in an email that there\u2019s much more work to do even after\xa0Attorney General Jeff Sessions\xa0announced on Tuesday that the administration was terminating the program. While DACA will officially end in six months
column5: it\u2019s now up to the House and Senate to formulate a solution to protect the nearly<a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/trump-daca-decision_us_59a04060e4b05710aa5bda7b?t6"> 800
column6: 000 Dreamers.\xa0
column7: \xa0And Vargas is adamant about pushing Congress to step up and serve DACA recipients. In order for that to happen
column8: the journalist told HuffPost
column9:
awareness must be spread regarding the program\u2019s payoffs for both undocumented and documented Americans alike.

\u201cDon\u2019t give up. We\u2019re with you. The majority of the country is also outraged right now and together
column10: we are powerful
column11: \u201d Vargas
column12: who\u2019s Filipino-American
column13: told HuffPost of his message to Dreamers. \u201cWe will fight for a new \u2015 and maybe even better \u2015 solution. We\u2019ve done it before.\u201d
column14: Vargas called on local media outlets and allies to highlight the contributions DACA recipients in their own communities bring to society. And the activist said that there are many of them. In the Teach For America program alone
column15: there are almost 200 educators and alumni enrolled in the DACA program who serve more than 10
column16: 000 students.\xa0A significant portion of recipients also work in healthcare with about 21 percent working in educational and health services
column17: \xa0a\xa0survey indicated\xa0\u2015 a particularly noteworthy statistic as the U.S. faces a projected shortage of between 40
column19: 900 doctors
column20: according to the Association of American Medical Colleges.
column21: \u201cOne day
column22: that teacher won\u2019t be able to show up for her kids. That nurse
column23: who might be the only ray of sunshine in one of their patient\u2019s lives
column24: won\u2019t be able to provide them comfort
column25: \u201d Vargas
column26: who co-founded nonprofit <a href="https://defineamerican.com/about/" target="_blank">Define American
column27: said of the consequences of ending the program. \u201cWe have brilliant students who won\u2019t be able to finish out their studies and give back the fruits of their knowledge.
column28: The journalist also pointed out Dreamers are a benefit to the economy as a whole. More than 90 percent of the group is currently enrolled in school or employed
column29: according to the Center for American Progress. And DACA beneficiaries will contribute\xa0$460.3 billion\xa0to the country\u2019s GDP over the next decade. It\u2019s why Vargas stresses the importance of grassroots efforts to show the true value of Dreamers.\xa0
column30: While Trump\u2019s decision makes this a difficult time for anyone benefitting from DACA
column31: Vargas remains hopeful. And He has a few words for anyone looking to create change following Tuesday\u2019s announcement:
column32:
\u201cThere is so much information out there about what DACA actually is and the benefits it provides. We need to keep speaking up and showing up. This fight isn\u2019t over.\u201d

]

column1: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/luther-strange-alabama-moore_us_59aec4d8e4b0b5e531011d13?utm_campaign=hp_fb_pages&utm_source=politics_fb&utm_medium=facebook&ncid=fcbklnkushpmg00000013&section=politics|<h1 class="headline__title">Feeling The Heat In Alabama's Senate Race
column2:
Luther Strange Calls For Filibuster Change|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 Sen. Luther Strange (R-Ala.) is calling on the Senate to lower its threshold for ending a filibuster from 60 votes to 51 votes \u2015 a simple majority \u2015 in order for the GOP to more easily advance President Donald Trump\u2019s legislative agenda.
column3: The proposal
column4: which Trump backs but the Senate\u2019s Republican leadership opposes
column5: also appears aimed at buttressing Strange\u2019s chances of holding onto his office this year \u2015 even as it puts him at odds with his main supporter in that bid
column6: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.).
column7: Strange
column8: who since February has been temporarily filling the seat fellow Republican Jeff Sessions gave up to serve as Trump\u2019s attorney general
column9: is struggling to fend off a tough challenge from Roy Moore in a special GOP Senate primary on Sept. 26. The victor is virtually assured of winning the Dec. 12 special election in heavily Republican Alabama.
column10: Moore
column11: a staunch social conservative and former Alabama Supreme Court chief justice known nationally for his refusal to remove a monument of the Ten Commandments from the Alabama Judicial Building
column12: has cast himself as the anti-establishment candidate in the race.
column13: The controversial provocateur has portrayed Strange as beholden to \u201cWashington elitists
column14: \u201d and has attacked him for the receiving financial backing from McConnell and his allies. Moore\u2019s supporters include Steve Bannon
column15: Trump\u2019s former chief strategist in the White House who has returned to his old job of running the right-wing Breitbart News website.
column16: A survey\xa0conducted last week by Harper Polling found Strange
column18: and Moore
column20: locked in a virtual tie in the primary race.
column21: In his call for the Senate to
column22: in essence
column23: end the ability of the chamber\u2019s minority party to block legislation
column24: Strange noted that Alabamians \u201coverwhelmingly supported\u201d Trump in the 2016 presidential election.
column25: They \u201cexpect his agenda to be enacted by Congress
column26: \u201d Strange said in a letter to McConnell and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.). \u201cBut
column27: because of obstructionist tactics by Democrats and broken promises by some Republicans
column28: very little legislation is even making it to the Senate floor.\u201d
column29: \u201cWhile I had hoped that Republicans and Democrats would work together to accomplish the will of the American people
column30: it has become obvious that politics and self-preservation will continue to rule the day
column31: \u201d\xa0he said.
column32: Strange added that \u201cconversations with the president\u201d led him to change his position on the filibuster as \u201cthe only way we will be able to build the border wall
column33: rein in sanctuary cities
column34: defund Planned Parenthood
column35: and give the American people real tax relief.\u201d
column36: Trump backed Strange in the first round of the nomination race in a 10-candidate primary on Aug. 15. Moore
column37: with 39 percent of the vote
column38: and Strange
column39: with 33 percent
column40: were the two top finishers and headed into this month\u2019s runoff because neither exceeded the 50-percent mark.
column41: Strange got a \u201cTrump bump\u201d in the initial vote
column42: said Vince Gawronski
column43: a professor of political science at Birmingham-Southern College In Alabama.
column44: Trump
column45: though
column46: has not actively touted Strange since then. And reports have surfaced that some conservatives are urging him to stay silent.
column47: Strange
column48: meanwhile
column49: has benefited throughout his campaign from millions of dollars spent on his behalf by a McConnell-aligned super PAC
column50: which makes his push to revise the filibuster rule awkward for both men. McConnell and other Senate GOP leaders prefer retaining the 60-vote requirement to end a filibuster as a protection for whenever control of the chamber reverts to the Democrats.
column51: Strange\u2019s call for the rule change follows reports of a pair of key endorsements of Moore this week.
column52: Former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee (R) \u2015 whose daughter
column53: Sarah Huckabee Sanders
column54: serves as the White House press secretary
column55: announced his support for Moore on Monday.
column56: Huckabee said on his website\xa0his decision \u201chas nothing to do with specific displeasure\u201d with Strange. But
column57: Huckabee said
column58: \u201cif the \u2018power brokers\u2019 in D.C. are as desperate as they seem to be to keep Judge Moore from joining them
column59: then they must fear that he can\u2019t be counted on to \u2018join the club.\u2019\u201d
column60: The Senate Conservatives Fund
column61: which supported Rep. Mo Brooks in the first-round primary
column62: also backed Moore on Monday.
column63: The group\u2019s president
column64: Ken Cuccinelli
column65: in a statement praised Moore as \u201ca political outsider who isn\u2019t afraid to stand up to the liberals in his own party.\u201d
column66: He also said the race\u2019s outcome would \u201cimpact\u201d McConnell\u2019s \u201cfuture as the Republican leader in the Senate.\u201d
column67: \u201cNothing would destabilize McConnell more than losing the Alabama Senate race after spending\u201d millions \u201cto crush conservatives\u201d in the state
column68: Cuccinelli said.
column69: Brooks
column70: who finished third in the first-round primary with 20 percent of the vote
column71:
has so far declined to make an endorsement in the runoff.

What You Need To Know About North Korea's Nuclear Program

|[

Since the ascension of Kim Jong Un as North Korea\u2019s leader in 2011
column2: the country has posed an ongoing diplomatic challenge for the United States. Pyongyang has ramped up work on its nuclear program and claims it is capable of launching a nuclear-armed missile that would reach the continental U.S.
column3: The reclusive nation carried out its sixth and most powerful nuclear test early Sunday morning
column4: which North Korean state television swiftly described as a \u201cperfect success.\u201d
column5: The regime claims it detonated a hydrogen bomb
column6: and although analysts have expressed skepticism about that
column7: Japan\u2019s Chief Cabinet Secretary
column8: Yoshihide Suga
column9: said Tokyo could not yet dismiss\xa0the possibility that it was indeed an H-bomb\xa0\u2015 a device much more powerful than the atomic bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki during World War II.
column10: Pyongyang\xa0successfully conducted its first two intercontinental ballistic missile tests in July \u2015 a feat U.S. President\xa0Donald Trump had called an impossibility\xa0shortly before his inauguration in January.\xa0The launches triggered international alarm and condemnation
column11: and sparked a battle of escalating threats between the Trump administration and the North Korean regime.
