Whitehouse Make Bipartisan Appeal To SCOTUS Against Wisconsin Gerrymandering|[

Sens. John McCain (R-Ariz.) and Sheldon Whitehouse (D-R.I.) asked the Supreme Court\xa0on Tuesday to uphold a lower court\u2019s ruling that Wisconsin\u2019s electoral maps for the state legislature were unconstitutional.
column3: The senators made their argument in a friend of the court brief filed in Gill v. Whitford
column4: a potentially monumental case the Supreme Court is set to hear on Oct. 3. The nation\u2019s highest court has never said whether an electoral map
column5: drawn by state lawmakers every 10 years \u2015 often by the party in power \u2015 can be unconstitutional simply for favoring one party too much over the other.
column6: The Supreme Court could make such a determination in the Wisconsin case
column7: which could remake American politics by requiring states to draw maps that put lawmakers in more competitive races.
column8: In the brief
column9: McCain and Whitehouse said the case \u201cimplicates the effective functioning of American representative democracy.\u201d
column10: Redrawing electoral maps to weaken the electoral influence of a particular group
column11: often called gerrymandering
column12: can now be done with extreme sophistication
column13: using algorithms and complex software
column14: the senators wrote.
column15: \u201cThis new breed of \u2018bulk\u2019 partisan gerrymandering distorts statewide votes
column16: systematically diluting the effect of votes based on political affiliation and leading to the election of congressional and state legislative delegations that do not represent the will of the voters
column17: \u201d they wrote. \u201cThis practice violates \u2018the core principle of republican government
column18: namely
column19: that the voters should choose their representatives
column20: not the other way around.\u2019\u201d
column21: Both Republicans and Democrats have benefitted from gerrymandering
column22: the brief notes.\xa0The progressive Brennan Center for Justice estimates that gerrymandering accounts for 16 or 17 current Republican seats in the House of Representatives.\xa0
column23: In a 2004 case called Vieth v. Jubelirer
column24: the court ruled 5-4 not to strike down Pennsylvania\u2019s congressional maps as an unconstitutional gerrymander
column25: and four justices wrote the Supreme Court couldn\u2019t even hear the case.\xa0Despite voting with the majority
column26: however
column27: Justice Anthony Kennedy\xa0wrote that he believed\xa0a standard for determining whether a map was unconstitutional could in fact exist. Because of that opinion
column28: Kennedy is being closely watched in the Wisconsin case and the plaintiffs are hoping he sees a standard that he likes.
column29: The brief argues the court does not need to establish a comprehensive test in the Wisconsin case about gerrymandering. But it says that affirming the ruling of the lower court that the maps in that case were unconstitutional would send a strong signal about the Supreme Court\u2019s attitude on the issue.
column30: \u201cThe district court\u2019s test provides a workable framework for distinguishing between district maps drawn based on legitimate political considerations and those constituting unlawful partisan gerrymandering
column31: \u201d the brief says. \u201cBeyond remedying the constitutional violations present in this case
column32: affirming the district court\u2019s decision will send a clear message that partisan gerrymandering will not be tolerated.\u201d
column33: In a separate brief filed Tuesday
column34: 65 current and former state lawmakers (26 Republicans and 39 Democrats) from eight states also asked the Supreme Court to uphold the lower court\u2019s decision and say Wisconsin\u2019s map was unconstitutional.
column35: In the brief from McCain and Whitehouse
column36: the senators noted that\xa0gerrymandering weakens confidence in the electoral system.
column37: \u201cAmericans do not like gerrymandering. They see its mischief
column38: and absent a legal remedy
column39: their sense of powerlessness and discouragement has increased
column40: deepening the crisis of confidence in our democracy. We share this perspective
column41: \u201d they wrote. \u201cWe see wasted votes and silenced voices. We see hidden power. And we see a correctable problem.\u201d
column42: More than three dozen current and former Republican lawmakers have signed onto briefs urging the court to say the Wisconsin maps were unconstitutional. The Republicans ranged across the political spectrum and included House Freedom Caucus Chairman Mark Meadows (S.C.)
column43: former California Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger and Ohio Gov. John Kasich.

This article has been updated with more information about which GOP lawmakers have signed onto briefs.\xa0

column49: But others saw the Trump administration\u2019s legal excuse for ending DACA as just a cover for a political decision.
column50: \u201cLet\u2019s be clear: the action taken today isn\u2019t required legally. It\u2019s a political decision
column51: and a moral question
column52: \u201d said former President Obama.
column53: \u201cThis Administration cannot hide behind the excuse of DACA being \u2018unlawful.\u2019 It is not
column54: \u201d said Elizabeth Wydra
column55: president of the Constitutional Accountability Center
column56: in a statement. \u201cThe Obama Administration acted fully within its constitutional and statutory authority when it recognized that these young people should be able to live

column59: Thomas Saenz

argued that Trump was \u201cacting on tainted and biased \u2018legal\u2019 advice\u201d when he \u201ccaved to the overstated demands of the Texas attorney general and a dwindling number of other states.\u201d

Asian-American Activists Speak Out For DACA Recipients After Trump Ends Program

|[

Moments after Attorney General Jeff Sessions announced that the Trump administration is terminating the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program
column2: Asian-American activists spoke up against the decision
column3: in support of all Dreamers.\xa0
column4: Several Asian-American organizations expressed their opposition to DACA\u2019s termination
column5: which was announced on Tuesday. The program is scheduled to end in six months
column6: with Congress now responsible for coming up with a solution that would preserve the program\u2019s protections. The Obama-era program had protected nearly 800
column7: 000 young undocumented immigrants
column8: who would be at risk for deportation if a solution cannot be reached.\xa0
column9: The National Korean American Service and Education Consortium (NAKASEC) and its affiliates HANA Center
column10: and Korean Resource Center
column11: along with The National Asian Pacific American Women\u2019s Forum (NAPAWF) and many others have issued statements condemning the cancellation.\xa0
column12: \u201cIt is cruel and un-American to ruin the lives of young people who stepped forward in good faith to participate in a program that has proven to be successful
column13: \u201d NAKASEC\u2019s co-director
column14: \xa0Dae Joong Yoon
column15: explained in a press release. \u201cThey trusted the government. Ending DACA means the country is abandoning them and all the progress we have made together.\u201d\xa0
column16: While youth from Latin American countries make up the majority of DACA applications
column17: Asian-Americans make up a sizable chunk of those eligible for the immigration program. Those who were previously able to request program consideration included undocumented individuals under the age of 31 as of June 15
column19: who were brought the the U.S. before their 16th birthday and met another set of guidelines related to education and criminal background
column20: among other issues. In 2016
column21: <a href="http://www.migrationpolicy.org/programs/data-hub/deferred-action-childhood-arrivals-daca-profiles" target="_blank"> South Korea
column22: China
column23: India and the Philippines were among the top ten countries of origin of DACA-eligible populations. The program\u2019s termination could affect tens of thousands of members of the minority group.\xa0
column24: Some organizations accused the Trump administration of acting immorally
column25: \xa0with the Asian Americans Advancing Justice organization stating that the termination of the program
column26: which disproportionately helped immigrants and people of color
column27: is further proof that the administration\u2019s agenda \u201cis rooted in hate and inhumanity.\u201d And others
column28: including NAKASEC
column29: have challenged allies and activists alike to resist the decision and fight to protect the undocumented community whether it\u2019s through pro-bono case work
column30: providing sanctuaries undocumented Americans
column31: or calling members of Congress.\xa0
column33: But many also expressed fears regarding what the termination of DACA could mean for those who\u2019ve benefitted from the program. NAPAWF said it believes more ICE raids are looming. In July alone
column34: \xa0more than 650 people were arrested during a four-day spree. And back in February
column35: immigration officers and agents raided a string of Asian restaurants\xa0in Mississippi
column36:
\xa0causing alarm in the state\u2019s immigrant communities.\xa0

\u201cWe know what is going to happen next. ICE raids and months spent in detention centers and the mass deportation of people who have only known the United States as their home
column37: \u201d the organization wrote in a statement. \u201cWe have already seen the devastating impact of deportation on our communities
column38: especially for AAPI women and youth. The threat of deportation tears families apart and negatively impacts their economic stability
column39: employment
column40: and reproductive choices.\u201d
column41: Still
column42: many are hoping Congress will step up to provide an acceptable
column43: permanent solution for undocumented youth \u2015 something AAAJ says that the administration has failed to do.\xa0
column44: \u201cIt is incumbent upon our Senators and Representatives to enact a permanent legislative solution that would once and for all protect our DACA recipients and place them on a pathway to citizenship
column45:
\u201d the group said.\xa0

column1: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/domestic-violence-shelters-harvey_us_59ae07b2e4b0b5e531004a23?utm_campaign=hp_fb_pages&utm_source=politics_fb&utm_medium=facebook&ncid=fcbklnkushpmg00000013&section=politics|<h1 class="headline__title">For Some
column2:
Domestic Violence Shelters Are A Last Resort. Harvey Took That Too.|[

HUMBLE
column3: Texas \u2015 Mary Woods grew concerned when she took the last gallon of milk out of the fridge.
column4: It was a week after Hurricane Harvey made landfall in Texas
column5: slamming the eastern region of the state with torrential rains
column6: and food supplies were running low at The Door
column7: the only domestic violence shelter in the northern Houston area.
column8: Woods
column10: is an advocate there. She quickly jotted down a list of highest-priority needs: eggs
column11: bread
column12: diapers
column13: toilet paper
column14: lunch meat and juice boxes.
column15: The main roads surrounding The Door flooded during the storm
column16: stranding about 40 women and children who live there. No one could arrive or leave. As the water started to recede and roads began to clear
column17: many stores were still closed and the shelter was in dire need of donations.
column18: Woods shared her list with the Texas Council on Family Violence
column19: a statewide coalition on domestic violence
column20: but it had been inundated with requests. More than one-quarter of the state\u2019s domestic violence programs were in Harvey\u2019s path of destruction
column21: and virtually all of them had suffered effects of the storm.
column22: The shelter in Beaumont was completely underwater and possibly gone for good. Another shelter lost its back fence
column23: compromising security. Countless others were badly damaged. Some centers tried to evacuate before the storm
column24: but they didn\u2019t have places to send their residents. It wasn\u2019t safe to stay with family
column25: where abusers would most certainly look. Mass evacuation shelters
column26: like those run by Red Cross
column27: could also be a risk. Hotels were full
column28: and relocating to other domestic violence shelters wasn\u2019t always feasible
column29: as most were already at capacity.
column30: \u201cWe wound up having to go further and further out [to find places to send residents]
column31: \u201d said Gloria Terry
column32: the executive director of the coalition
column33: noting that some people were sent as far as six hours away to find a domestic violence shelter with free beds. Other shelters
column34: like The Door
column35: had decided not to evacuate
column36: believing their clients were safest remaining where they were.
column37: Terry received Woods\u2019 list of needs on Saturday
column38: as she was busy frantically assessing the needs of the 32 programs affected by the storm. She sent Woods\u2019\xa0list to several relief organizations
column39: but most places required her to pick up the supplies herself
column40: and she couldn\u2019t get to them. A few hours later
column41: the request ended up in the hands of Colony Soto
column42: a former professional wrestler who had set up a food bank at his company\u2019s training center\xa0in Katy
column43: Texas. \xa0
column44: Domination Zone Wrestling\xa0usually hosts men and women looking to square off WWE-style. Last week
column45: it acted as overflow storage for the food donated to a nearby Elk\u2019s Lodge \u2015 its wrestling ring itself was surrounded by dry food
column46: cleaning supplies and diapers. Soto told HuffPost that he\u2019d wanted to help as soon as the hurricane hit.
column47: He and his helpers methodically scoured the list to see what they had before racing around the room and tossing supplies into boxes. Tuna
column48: check. Peanut butter
column49: check. Bleach and latex gloves
column50: check. An hour later
column51: two HuffPost reporters transported the supplies to The Door.
column52: When the supplies arrived
column53: Woods was still busy dealing with damage from the days of rain Harvey dumped on the city. The back room of the 21-year-old shelter had flooded and part of the ceiling had fallen down over the front desk. Someone taped up a bed pan liner to stop the flow. Woods had spent much of the storm trying to keep water from seeping into the shelter by rolling up sheets and pressing them into the seam where the wall met the floor. Once a sheet was soaked
column54: she\u2019d toss it in the washer and repeat. She didn\u2019t want the dirty water to make it out to the front part of the shelter
column55: where families slept.
column56: She prided herself on making The Door feel cozy and comfortable. It was once a residential home
column57: but has been renovated to feature a maze of corridors that almost require a trail of breadcrumbs to navigate. It has a daycare and play room
column58: as well as bedrooms that each house at least four women
column59: with extra room for bassinets and baby beds. Residents are allowed to stay at least 30 days
column60: but many remained as long as three months because it was so hard to find affordable housing.\xa0In 2016 alone
column61: over 700 victims sought emergency shelter there.
column62: Woods
column63: who is also a domestic violence survivor
column64: knew how much trauma her residents were dealing even without the added stress of the storm.
column65: \u201cAs I told them
column66: you have a safe place here
column67: \u201d she said. \u201cWe may not be able to get out
column68: but you\u2019re safe.\u201d
column69: Woods worked at The Door through both Hurricane Rita
column71: and Hurricane Ike
column72: in 2008. Shelter residents had evacuated before Rita hit
column73: along with an estimated 2.5 million other Texans. Clients ended up spending more than 24 hours stuck in a massive traffic jam on the highway. During Ike
column74: they\u2019d decided to stay put
column75: but the building lost power. That meant its front gate
column76: which uses an electromagnetic lock and serves as one of the shelter\u2019s primary layers of protection
column77: was open to anyone who wanted to walk in.
column78: \u201cI ran out there with a bicycle lock and wrapped it around the gate
column79: \u201d Woods said.
column80: Food and medicine are the most immediate and easily met needs for domestic violence victims who end up in shelters like The Door after fleeing abusive relationships \u2015 often with just the clothes on their backs. They rely on the shelter to connect them to a range of services as they begin the complicated process of rebuilding their lives from scratch. Those resources will be harder to come by in the aftermath of Harvey
column82: as thousands of other Texans deal with losing their homes and belongings. (Donate here.)\xa0
column83: \u201cThere was already an inadequate amount of transitional housing
column84: but when you go from scarce to none \u2015 what do you do with that?\u201d Terry said. She noted that Lone Star Legal Aid in Houston
column85: which assists domestic violence victims with protective orders and other legal help
column86: burned down during the storm. She also worried about the victims who may have been considering seeking help but are now scattered across the state \u2015 likely alongside those who are abusing them.
column87: Judy Cox
column88: executive director of the Family Time Crisis and Counseling Center
column89: which runs The Door
column90: said that a longtime client had recently lined up a furnished apartment for her and her five children \u2015 and now it\u2019s been flooded
column91: as has her car. \xa0
column92: \u201cShe lost it all
column93: \u201d Cox said. \u201cIt\u2019s really devastating. I\u2019ve been in many
column94: many hurricanes
column95: but oh my God
column96: this is something else.\u201d
column97: Woods
column98: who was busy taking inventory of all the new food supplies
column99: said that domestic violence victims are resilient.
column100: \u201cWhen they come in
column101: they cry and cry
column102: \u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s been 12 years for me
column103: and there are still days when I cry. I think
column104: I made it
column105: but it\u2019s OK to cry
column106: it\u2019s part of the healing process. It\u2019s important for me that the women understand they can make it too.\u201d
column107:
Andy Campbell contributed reporting.

]

Obama Speaks Out On Trump Ending Dreamer Protections

|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 Former President Barack Obama said Tuesday that President Donald Trump\u2019s decision to dismantle the program protecting young undocumented immigrants was \u201ccontrary to our spirit
column2: and to common sense.\u201d \xa0
column3: Trump announced Tuesday that he will end Obama\u2019s Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program
column4: or DACA
column5: in six months. Unless Congress steps in
column6: ending the program could put nearly 800
column7: 000 undocumented young people at risk of deportation and unable to work legally when their two-year permits expire.
column8: Obama said it was a \u201cpolitical decision
column9: and a moral question\u201d \u2015 and one of basic decency.\xa0
column10: \u201cTo target these young people is wrong \u2015 because they have done nothing wrong
column11: \u201d he said in a statement. \u201cIt is self-defeating \u2015 because they want to start new businesses
column12: staff our labs
column13: serve in our military
column14: and otherwise contribute to the country we love. And it is cruel. This is about whether we are a people who kick hopeful young strivers out of America
column15: or whether we treat them the way we\u2019d want our own kids to be treated. It\u2019s about who we are as a people \u2015 and who we want to be.\u201d
column16: Obama started the program in 2012 and urged undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children to come forward to the government
column17: pay a fee and undergo a background check before receiving a two-year work permit and reprieve from deportation.
column18: He did so after legislative efforts to help Dreamers \u2015 which are being revived now because of Trump\u2019s decisions \u2015 failed multiple times
column19: as he noted in his statement.\xa0
column20: \u2033[B]ecause it made no sense to expel talented
column21: driven
column22: patriotic young people from the only country they know solely because of the actions of their parents
column23: my administration acted to lift the shadow of deportation from these young people
column24: so that they could continue to contribute to our communities and our country
column25: \u201d Obama said.
column26: To target hopeful young strivers who grew up here is wrong
column27: because they\u2019ve done nothing wrong. My statement: https://t.co/TCxZdld7L4
column28: Trump promised during his presidential campaign to immediately end DACA
column29: but Obama urged him not to
column30: \xa0both publicly\xa0and in private conversations. In his final press conference as president
column31: Obama said he would speak out if Trump targeted Dreamers \u201cwho have grown up here and for all practical purposes are American kids and send them someplace else when they love this country; they are our kids\u2019 friends and their classmates
column32: and are now entering into community colleges or
column33: in some cases
column34: serving in our military.\u201d
column35: \u201cThe notion that we would just arbitrarily
column36: or because of politics
column37: punish those kids when they didn\u2019t do anything wrong themselves I think would be something that would merit me speaking out
column38: \u201d Obama said at the time.
column39: By ending DACA
column40: Trump dismantled one of Obama\u2019s most significant immigration policy achievements. Trump already dramatically reshaped immigration enforcement from how it was under Obama
column41: who began his presidency with record deportation numbers before changing enforcement priorities to focus on certain undocumented immigrants over others.
column42: Trump immediately eliminated those priorities as president and has detained and deported people whom Obama allowed to remain in the country if they checked in with the government or met other requirements.\xa0
column43: Trump said that Congress should act on Dreamers
column44: although his statements were vague and the only legislation he mentioned specifically during his statement on DACA focused on limiting legal immigration
column45: not actually undocumented immigrants.\xa0
column46: Obama said it was time for Congress to act as well.
column47: \u201cNow that the White House has shifted its responsibility for these young people to Congress
column48: it\u2019s up to Members of Congress to protect these young people and our future
column49: \u201d Obama said. \u201cI\u2019m heartened by those who\u2019ve suggested that they should. And I join my voice with the majority of Americans who hope they step up and do it with a sense of moral urgency that matches the urgency these young people feel.\u201d
column50: Former Vice President Joe Biden
column51: who served with Obama
column52: \xa0similarly condemned Trump\u2019s decision\xa0to end DACA.\xa0
column53: \u2033[L]et\u2019s be clear: throwing [Dreamers] out is cruel
column54: \u201d Biden said in a statement. \u201cIt is inhumane. And it is not America. Congress and the American people now have an obligation to step up and show our neighbors that they\u2019re welcome here
column55:
in the only place they\u2019ve ever called home.\u201d

Republicans Make Vague Promises To Protect Dreamers Endangered By Trump Decision

|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 Members of Congress promised\xa0on Tuesday\xa0to work on legislative solutions to protect young undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children
column2: after President Donald Trump followed through on a campaign promise to put them back at risk of deportation.
column3: Attorney General Jeff Sessions announced Tuesday morning\xa0that the Trump administration is ending the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program
column4: which allowed nearly 800
column5: 000 so-called \u201cDreamers\u201d to get two-year work permits and reprieve from deportation. When their permits expire
column6: DACA recipients will now be unable to work legally and could be detained and deported under Trump\u2019s efforts to expel more undocumented immigrants.
column7: The administration\u2019s directive gives Congress six months to reach a deal to address the status of Dreamers.\xa0But so far
column8: \xa0Republicans have offered vague proposals or prior legislative options that don\u2019t have a clear shot at passing.
column9: Calling DACA a \u201cclear abuse of executive authority
column10: \u201d House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) said in a statement that \u201cit is my hope\u201d Congress\xa0\u201cwill be able to find consensus on a permanent legislative solution.\u201d
column11: \u201cThe president\u2019s announcement does not revoke permits immediately
column12: and it is important that those affected have clarity on how this interim period will be carried out. At the heart of this issue are young people who came to this country through no fault of their own
column13: and for many of them it\u2019s the only country they know
column14: \u201d Ryan said.
column15: But other than a few who have signed on to bills with Democrats that would offer legal status to Dreamers
column16: most Republicans have obstructed immigration bills for years
column17: and their vague statements of support for Dreamers don\u2019t mean they\u2019ll actually push for legislation that stands a chance of passing.
column18: And even if they do
column19: it\u2019s not clear that Trump
column20: for all his calls for Congress to act
column21: would even sign a bill to protect Dreamers without extreme conditions such as slashing legal immigration. The urgency to act is there
column22: but so are the difficult politics of immigration that have led to past failures on bills to provide legal status to Dreamers.
column23: Ahead of the announcement
column24: Trump tweeted that Congress should \u201cget ready to do your job.\u201d
column25: Congress
column26: get ready to do your job - DACA!
column27: Later Tuesday
column28: White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders placed the onus on Congress to find \u201ca permanent solution done through the legislative process
column29: \u201d providing few details on what kind of bill Trump would want to sign into law.
column30: She did
column31: however
column32: level a threat against lawmakers who can\u2019t get the job done.
column33: \u201cIf Congress doesn\u2019t want to do the job they were elected to do
column34: maybe they should get out of the way and let someone else do it
column35: \u201d she told reporters at Tuesday\u2019s White House press briefing.
column36: Trump tweeted on Tuesday evening that he would revisit the issue if Congress failed to act on DACA.
column37: Congress now has 6 months to legalize DACA (something the Obama Administration was unable to do). If they can't
column38: I will revisit this issue!
column39: Many Republicans have voted in the past to end DACA \u2015 likely an easier vote under former President Barack Obama
column40: who created the program and would not sign into law any bill to terminate the protections. Most of them also opposed previous efforts to provide reprieve to Dreamers
column41: such as the Dream Act
column42: a bill first introduced 16 years ago that would allow undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children to gain legal status and eventual citizenship.\xa0
column43: Republicans have multiple options if they want to sign on to current legislation to protect Dreamers. There is a 2017 iteration of the Dream Act in both chambers; the House bill has two Republican sponsors and the Senate bill has three Republican sponsors.
column44: Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.) said Tuesday that he plans to re-double his efforts on the Dream Act
column45: criticizing Trump\u2019s announcement as \u201cthe wrong approach to immigration policy.\u201d
column46: .@POTUS's decision on #DACA is wrong approach at a time when both sides need to compromise on #immigration reform https://t.co/kPBCUhJ2m4 pic.twitter.com/5stY5spxOC
column47: House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) on Tuesday called on Ryan to \u201cbring the Dream Act to the floor for a vote without delay.\u201d
column48: GOP members have also created what they are calling a more conservative version of the Dream Act. It would provide a path to citizenship to Dreamers with some restrictions
column49: such as eligibility for those who entered the country before they were 16 years old
column50: versus the current cutoff of 18.
column51: In the House
column52: Rep. Carlos Curbelo (R-Fla.) introduced the Recognizing America\u2019s Children
column53: or RAC
column54: Act with support from 18 fellow Republicans. Sen. Thom Tillis (R-N.C.) said Tuesday that he is planning a similar bill in the Senate.
column55: My legislation will provide a fair and rigorous path for undocumented children to earn legal status. (6/9)
column56: Republicans may try to tie legislation to help Dreamers to other measures
column57: such as funding for Trump\u2019s border wall and increasing other deportation efforts. While Democrats have supported measures coupling legal status for undocumented immigrants and enforcement in the past
column58: they have said they would not allow Dreamers to be used as a bargaining chip.
column59: On Tuesday
column60: Sanders would not say whether Trump wants funding for the wall included in a bill addressing DACA recipients. She also would not say whether he would sign a \u201cstandalone\u201d bill
column61: without any other conditions.
column62: Yet she reiterated that Congress should pursue \u201ccomprehensive\u201d legislation that is not \u201ca one-piece fix\u201d \u2014 again providing few details on what that would entail
column63: placing the ball squarely in Congress\u2019 court.
column64:
This article was updated with comments from White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders.

Tech Leaders Blast Trump Plan To Drop Dreamers Program|[

The Trump administration announced Tuesday it intends to\xa0terminate Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals
column3: an Obama-era program that protects from deportation close to 800
column4: 000 people who entered the U.S. illegally as children.
column5: The decision provoked strong condemnation from business and technology leaders
column6: many of whom are immigrants themselves.
column7: The backlash began last Thursday
column8: as a broad spectrum of CEOs and other business
column9: community and educational leaders signed a public letter by FWD.us
column10: an immigration reform group
column11: opposing any action on DACA.
column12: By Monday
column13: more than 400 business leaders had signed the letter
column14: running the gamut from industry stalwarts like General Motors CEO Mary Barra to Silicon Valley titans such as Apple\u2019s Tim Cook
column15: Amazon\u2019s Jeff Bezos
column16: Google CEO Sundar Pichai and Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella.
column17: Many also spoke out individually.
column18: Microsoft\u2019s chief legal officer Brad Smith offered a strong defense of DACA as \u201cboth an economic imperative and a humanitarian necessity.\u201d He urged Congress to reprioritize its legislative calendar to focus on legislation to protect the so-called Dreamers instead of digging into tax a reform bill.
column19: Attorney General Jeff Sessions
column20: in announcing the decision on DACA
column21: said it will end in six months
column22: giving Congress a window to figure out legislation to protect from deportation those covered by the program.\xa0
column23: Smith pledged that Microsoft will provide and pay for legal counsel for any of its employees who are Dreamers
column24: should the government attempt to deport them:
column25: As this debate moves forward
column26: we need to remember that these 800
column27: 000 individuals came to our nation as children. They grew up in this country. They attended our local schools and count millions of American citizens as friends. They obey our laws
column28: pay taxes here and have registered voluntarily with the federal government for DACA relief. They are loyal to this country and contribute their time and money to local churches
column29: schools and community groups. The Dreamers are part of our nation\u2019s fabric. They belong here.
column30: This is why we will work as needed with other companies and the broader business community to vigorously defend the legal rights of all Dreamers. For the 39 Dreamers that we know of who are our employees
column31: our commitment is clear. If Congress fails to act
column32: our company will exercise its legal rights properly to help protect our employees. If the government seeks to deport any one of them
column33: we will provide and pay for their legal counsel. We will also file an amicus brief and explore whether we can directly intervene in any such case. In short
column34: if Dreamers who are our employees are in court
column35: we will be by their side.
column36: Cook also noted the number of Dreamers who work at Apple and offered his support:
column37: 250 of my Apple coworkers are #Dreamers. I stand with them. They deserve our respect as equals and a solution rooted in American values.
column38: Mark Zuckerberg encouraged his Facebook followers to call their representatives and tell them to \u201cdo the right thing.\u201d
column39: \u201cThis is a sad day for our country
column40: \u201d he wrote. \u201cIt is particularly cruel to offer young people the American Dream
column41: encourage them to come out of the shadows and trust our government
column42: and then punish them for it.
column43: Google\u2019s Pichai also reaffirmed his support:
column44: Dreamers are our neighbors
column45: our friends and our co-workers. This is their home. Congress needs to act now to #DefendDACA. #WithDreamers
column46: Uber tweeted its support\xa0for the FWD.us letter
column47: as did Airbnb co-founder and CEO Brian Chesky. Lyft co-founders Logan Green and John Zimmer\xa0also signed the letter and individually tweeted affirmations of it Tuesday.
column48: Here\u2019s the full text of the letter
column49: which was addressed to President Donald Trump and congressional leaders from both parties:
column50: As entrepreneurs and business leaders
column51: we are concerned about new developments in immigration policy that threaten the future of young undocumented immigrants brought to America as children.
column52: The Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program
column53: which allows nearly 800
column54: 000 Dreamers the basic opportunity to work and study without the threat of deportation
column55: is in jeopardy. All DACA recipients grew up in America
column56: registered with our government
column57: submitted to extensive background checks
column58: and are diligently giving back to our communities and paying income taxes. More than 97 percent are in school or in the workforce
column59: 5 percent started their own business
column60: 65 percent have purchased a vehicle
column61: and 16 percent have purchased their first home. At least 72 percent of the top 25 Fortune 500 companies count DACA recipients among their employees.
column62: Unless we act now to preserve the DACA program
column63: all 780
column64: 000 hardworking young people will lose their ability to work legally in this country
column65: and every one of them will be at immediate risk of deportation. Our economy would lose $460.3 billion from the national GDP and $24.6 billion in Social Security and Medicare tax contributions.
column66: Dreamers are vital to the future of our companies and our economy. With them
column67: we grow and create jobs. They are part of why we will continue to have a global competitive advantage.
column68:
We call on President Trump to preserve the DACA program. We call on Congress to pass the bipartisan DREAM Act or legislation that provides these young people raised in our country the permanent solution they deserve.\xa0

]

|[

Actress Louise Linton
column2: who came in for widespread denunciation last month after flaunting her lavish lifestyle on social media and then berating a critic
column3: has expressed remorse for the post\xa0and her subsequent remarks
column4: saying she is \u201cvery sorry\u201d for the incident and that she \u201cdeserved the criticism.\u201d
column5: \u201cMy post itself and the following response were indefensible. Period. I don\u2019t have any excuses
column6: nor do I feel any self-pity for the backlash I experienced
column7: \u201d Linton said in an interview with Washington Life magazine\xa0published Tuesday. \u201cI sincerely take ownership of my mistake. It\u2019s clear that I was the one who was truly out of touch and my response was reactionary and condescending.\u201d
column8: Last month
column9: Linton
column10: the wife of Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin
column11: \xa0posted a picture on her Instagram account touting the designer brand names of her clothing
column12: such as a Hermes scarf and Tom Ford sunglasses. After a number of commenters criticized her for the out-of-touch post
column13: she admonished one of them \u2015\xa0Jennifer Miller
column14: a health care product manager and mother of three from Oregon \u2015 while doubling down on the original comments.
column15: \u201cHave you given more to the economy than me and my husband?\u201d Linton asked Miller
column16: boasting about the \u201csacrifice\u201d that she and Mnuchin
column17: a former Goldman Sachs executive
column18: have made.
column19: Linton later deleted the post and apologized in a statement
column20: calling the post \u201cinappropriate and highly insensitive.\u201d
column21: The photo was taken during a trip that has since become the focus of ethics concerns.\xa0The Treasury Department\u2019s inspector general opened an investigation\xa0after an ethics watchdog group alleged that Mnuchin and Linton may have planned the trip around viewing last month\u2019s solar eclipse
column22: thus using government resources for personal purposes.
column23: Speaking to Washington Life
column24: \xa0Linton did not address the ethics issue directly but acknowledged that as the spouse of a government official
column25: she now realizes she is subject to greater scrutiny.
column26: \u201cI was on a government trip and my husband is a government employee
column27: \u201d she said. \u201cAs his wife
column28: I am now a more public person and I am
column29: and should be
column30: held to a higher standard of ethics and care.\u201d
column31: Of her comments toward Miller
column32: in which she called the Oregon woman \u201cadorably out of touch\u201d and told her to \u201cgo chill out
column33: \u201d Linton said she typically does not respond to social media criticism.
column34: \u201cI don\u2019t know why I did this time
column35: but I really regret it
column36: \u201d she said. \u201cI wish I hadn\u2019t spoken in such a patronizing tone. It was an out of character
column37: knee-jerk reaction
column38: and I felt so awful about it that I removed it.\u201d
column39: Linton said the criticism she faced for the incident \u201chas been a life-changing event.\u201d
column40: \u201cIt was scary and surreal but it forced me to take a deep look at what I had done. I don\u2019t feel like a victim
column41: \u201d she said. \u201cI feel like the world gave me a good
column42: hard wake-up call and I\u2019m OK with that.\u201d
column43: Linton insists that the Instagram post was not representative of her true self.
column44: \u201cI was just trying to portray what I thought was a public image that isn\u2019t me
column45: \u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019m a no makeup girl. I was trying to create this public image that was elegant and stylish
column46:
but that was just so clueless because I should have focused on who I really am instead.\u201d

Lisa Murkowski Is Acting Like The Independent Many Alaskans Wanted|[

ANCHORAGE
column3: Alaska \u2015 At 74
column4: Carroll Knutson has seen Alaska go through a lot of changes. She lived here before it was even a state. She remembers when most Alaskans were Democrats. She remembers when the oil industry came in \u2015 and with it
column5: lots of money \u2015 and turned the Republican Party
column6: her party
column7: into \u201creally crazy right-wing nuts.\u201d
column8: But if there\u2019s been one constant
column9: it\u2019s that people here pride themselves on being fiercely independent. And for Knutson
column10: who lives on a homestead near the tiny town of Soldotna
column11: there\u2019s one Alaskan in particular who\u2019s been embodying that spirit lately: Lisa Murkowski.
column12: \u201cOut of 100 members in the Senate
column13: she\u2019s the only one that\u2019s really wearing the balls right now
column14: \u201d said Knutson
column15: in between bites of salmon at a 70-year-old\u2019s birthday party in Anchorage that HuffPost crashed. \u201cI don\u2019t know if you can put that in your story.\u201d
column16: Murkowski caught everyone\u2019s attention last month when she helped kill her party\u2019s effort to repeal the Affordable Care Act. She was\xa0one of three Republicans\xa0\u2015 Susan Collins of Maine and John McCain of Arizona were the others \u2015 who voted with Democrats to sink a bill that would have gutted President\xa0Barack Obama\u2019s signature health care law.
column17: Most of the buzz about that vote centered on McCain
column18: who returned to the Senate after a brain cancer diagnosis to cast a dramatic
column19: last-minute vote against the bill. But it was Murkowski who stuck her neck out more than anyone.
column20: For weeks
column21: she and Collins resisted intense lobbying by their party to vote for various repeal bills. That was a particularly risky move for Murkowski
column22: who
column23: unlike Collins
column24: represents a heavily Republican state.\xa0President Donald Trump\xa0lashed out at her on Twitter\xa0over her opposition
column25: saying she\u2019d \u201creally let the Republicans
column26: and our country
column27: down.\u201d\xa0Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke called her to warn that\xa0energy projects in her state were at risk\xa0if she didn\u2019t vote to repeal the law.\xa0For good measure
column28: two separate House Republicans\xa0criticized\xa0her
column29: \xa0too.
column30: And yet
column31: Murkowski didn\u2019t budge. She maintained that the repeal bills would be devastating for Alaskans. She was right; among other things
column32: 25 percent of people in her state rely on Medicaid
column33: a program the bills would have gutted. She also criticized the rushed
column34: closed-door process GOP leaders used to bring the bills to the Senate floor. While Obamacare isn\u2019t perfect
column35: she\u2019s argued
column36: lawmakers need to take a more thorough approach to changing the law
column37: one that includes public hearings and working with Democrats.
column38: Her votes\xa0infuriated party officials\xa0in Alaska. But she was hailed as a hero by constituents who had been urging her for weeks to vote \u201cno.\u201d People hugged her at the airport when she flew back to Anchorage. They held a rally for her that included a plane flying above with a massive \u201cThank You\u201d sign. They delivered roses to her office. In\xa0a Q&A with her summer interns\xa0that she posted on YouTube
column39: she said her vote against repeal was the biggest difference she\u2019s made in her roughly 15 years as a senator.
column40: \u201cThe constant is remembering who you work for
column41: \u201d Murkowski told the kids. \u201cI don\u2019t work for the party. I don\u2019t work for the president. I work for the people of Alaska. And sometimes that\u2019s hard.\u201d
column42: \u201cThere are pressures that would allow you to forget that
column43: that would put you in a place where it would just be easier if I just went along with what everybody else is doing
column44: \u201d she continued. \u201cBut if it doesn\u2019t fit with who you represent
column45: why are we here
column46: if not to serve the people who sent us here?\u201d
column47: This is the Lisa Murkowski many Alaskans have long wanted to see.
column48: Ever since 2010
column49: when she pulled off a stunning re-election victory
column50: the mixed-up coalition of people who helped her win that year have been hoping she\u2019d get all mavericky. That was the year she lost the Republican primary to a tea party challenger. She responded by running as an independent
column51: launching a write-in campaign featuring\xa0now-famous ads\xa0(see below) that carefully spelled out her name
column52: M-U-R-K-O-W-S-K-I. Against the odds
column53: and with no support from the Republican Party
column54: she won
column55: making her the first candidate to win in a write-in Senate campaign since South Carolina\u2019s Strom Thurmond in 1954.
column56: It doesn\u2019t get much more exciting than that
column57: and the people she won over in 2010 \u2015 a smattering of Democrats
column58: moderate Republicans and independents \u2015 hoped she\u2019d head back to D.C. emboldened to break from the GOP and go her own way. After all
column59: Alaska may be a red state
column60: but\xa0more than 50 percent of voters here\xa0are \u201cundeclared\u201d or \u201cnonpartisan.\u201d

column62: she really spoke to me

column64: 52-year-old Alyse Galvin of Anchorage. \u201cI thought
column65: here\u2019s a woman in a very difficult state to be a strong woman
column66: who seems to be willing to work in a bipartisan way. I bought in hook
column67: line and sinker. I think most of Alaska did.\u201d
column68: But back in Washington
column69: there weren\u2019t obvious signs she\u2019d changed. She continued to vote mostly in lockstep with GOP leaders. It wasn\u2019t until this year that something shifted. In February

column196: HuffPost reached out several times to Murkowski\u2019s office for an interview

column7: who\xa0supports enforcing current law through increased deportations

column18: but must submit their renewal applications by Oct. 5 or will be unable to do so. Individuals who do not currently have DACA protections cannot receive permits unless they applied to the program before Sept. 5.
column19: Dreamers whose permits expire on March 6 or later will begin to lose their protections and work permits as soon as they expire

column25: they have also made clear that no undocumented immigrant is safe from being detained or forced out of the country. That includes Dreamers
column26: some of whom have already been locked up.\xa0
column27: Department of Homeland Security officials said before the announcement that there are no plans to specifically target current DACA recipients or use their information for enforcement purposes
column28: although they will continue to do so if needed for criminal or national security investigations.\xa0
column29: The official Trump administration announcement comes on the Sept. 5 deadline set by 10 state attorneys general who threatened legal action if Trump did not announce a phaseout of DACA by that date. Tennessee Attorney General Herbert Slatery III (R)\xa0backed off that threat last week

column39: \u201cI have a love for these people and hopefully now Congress will be able to help them and do it properly
column40: \u201d Trump said in the White House. \u201cAnd I can tell you
column41: speaking to members of Congress

column43: it\u2019s going to be the right solution.\u201d\xa0
column44: Ahead of Trump\u2019s announcement
column45: a number of Republicans said they would be willing to support protections for Dreamers that Democrats have attempted to get through Congress multiple times.
column46: Most Republicans opposed those past measures
column47: including the Dream Act
column48: a bill first introduced in 2001 that would grant legal status to some undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children. The bill has a small number of Republican supporters
column49: but the White House immediately shot it down when it was re-introduced in the Senate in July.

column51: called the Recognizing America\u2019s Children Act
column52: or RAC Act
column53: which would offer a path to citizenship to a smaller category of Dreamers.\xa0
column54: Sessions\u2019 speech only mentioned one piece of legislation specifically: the RAISE Act
column55: which would slash legal immigration numbers and has nothing to do with Dreamers. His remarks more broadly made the case against offering Dreamers legal status
column56: something he has opposed many times throughout his career.\xa0
column57: Sessions said that DACA \u201cdenied jobs to hundreds of thousands of Americans by allowing those same illegal aliens to take those jobs\u201d \u2015 an argument that could also be applied to legislation that allows Dreamers to stay in the country and work legally. He claimed that a surge in unaccompanied minors at the southwest U.S. border was also due to DACA
column58: although those children were ineligible for the program. Sessions also said that the U.S. \u201cmust set and enforce a limit on how many immigrants we admit each year.\u201d
column59: \u201cThis does not mean they are bad people or that our nation disrespects or demeans them in any way
column60: \u201d Sessions said. \u201cIt means we are properly enforcing our laws as Congress has passed them.\u201d
column61: Trump\u2019s statement similarly emphasized other changes to the immigration system. Like Sessions
column62: he cited the RAISE Act and said his \u201cfirst and highest priority in advancing immigration reform must be to improve jobs
column63: wages and security for American workers and their families.\u201d
column64: \u201cAs I\u2019ve said before

column67: struggling
column68: and forgotten Americans.\u201d

Republicans Could Protect Dreamers If They Wanted To. But Will They?

|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 Republican lawmakers who have said they sympathize with young undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children will now get the chance to prove it.
column2: President Donald Trump has decided to terminate the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program
column3: or DACA
column4: with a six-month delay on enforcement
column5: Politico and Reuters reported on Sunday evening. An official announcement is expected on Tuesday with further details.
column6: Ending the program would mean nearly 800
column7: 000 so-called \u201cDreamers\u201d who have been in the U.S. since they were children would eventually lose two-year work permits and be at risk for deportation.
column8: Trump\u2019s decision puts Republicans in a bind. Many of them have said they think something should be done to help Dreamers
column9: and some pro-immigration-reform Republicans have joined Democrats to push for legislation.
column10: But most Republicans \u2015 including party leaders in the House and Senate \u2015 have repeatedly voted to block legislation that would allow young undocumented immigrants to stay in the country. House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) hasn\u2019t allowed votes on bills that would allow legal status for Dreamers
column11: and his predecessor
column12: former Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio)
column13: let a comprehensive immigration reform bill that passed the Senate in 2013 die in the House.
column14: Ryan and other GOP members now say they\u2019re ready for legislation. But the question will be whether they\u2019re willing to break from the past and work with Democrats to make it happen. Doing so could invite primary challenges from the right.
column15: Ryan said on Friday that he had urged Trump not to end DACA because he believed Congress should pass a bill to protect Dreamers.
column16: \u201cThere are people in limbo
column17: \u201d Ryan said on the radio station WCLO in Janesville
column18: Wisconsin. \u201cThese are kids that know no other country
column19: who were brought here by their parents and don\u2019t know another home
column20: and so I really do believe there needs to be a legislative solution
column21: that\u2019s one that we\u2019re working on.\u201d
column22: Others similarly urged Trump not to end the program
column23: which he is expected to announce Tuesday \u2015 the deadline set for him by 10 state attorneys general who threatened legal action if he did not terminate DACA by that date.
column24: Speaking about Dreamers
column25: Sen. Tom Cotton (R-Ark.)\xa0told The Washington Examiner\xa0Sunday\xa0evening \u201cwe ought to take care of them
column26: \u201d and it wasn\u2019t their fault they had come to the country illegally.
column27: \u201cIn any legislative fix
column28: I would like to see them receive a green card
column29: \u201d he said. \u201cWe ought to recognize that giving them legal status has two problems. First
column30: it creates a whole new class of people who will then be eligible for a green card and citizenship \u2015 namely
column31: the extended family members of those who will receive legal status who can
column32: through chain migration
column33: get legal status themselves.\u201d
column34: Cotton added such a program would also encourage more illegal immigration
column35: a problem he said could be fixed by passing an immigration bill he and Trump both back that would make it more difficult to come\xa0to the U.S. legally. That bill would face heavy opposition from Democrats and some Republicans because it would slash legal immigration numbers.\xa0He also called for expanding E-Verify
column36: a government system employers can use to verify the identity of job applicants.
column37: On Friday
column38: Tennessee Attorney General Herbert Slatery (R)
column39: announced he would not take part in the legal challenge to DACA as he\u2019d promised and\xa0called for legislation on Dreamers. Slatery encouraged senators to support the Dream Act
column40: a bill that would provide a path to legal status for undocumented young people who came to the country as children
column41: or legislation like it.
column42: The Dream Act currently has bipartisan sponsors in both the House and Senate
column43: but a majority of Republicans have opposed past efforts to get it through Congress since it was first introduced in 2001.
column44: Sen. James Lankford (R-Okla.) also urged Trump not to end DACA.
column45: \u201cIt is right for there to be consequences for those who intentionally entered this country illegally
column46: \u201d\xa0he said in a statement.\xa0\xa0\u201cHowever
column47: we as Americans do not hold children legally accountable for the actions of their parents.\u201d
column48: Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.)\xa0said in a Monday statement\xa0he supported seeking a legislative solution to the plight of Dreamers
column49: should Trump give Congress a six-month window to act.
column50: \u201cI have always believed DACA was presidential overreach. However
column51: I equally understand the plight of Dream Act kids who \u2015 for all practical purposes \u2015 know no country other than America
column52: \u201d said Graham.\xa0
column53: Some Republicans are also pushing for the Recognizing America\u2019s Children Act
column54: or RAC Act
column55: which they\u2019re calling a conservative answer to the Dream Act. It similarly would allow Dreamers to receive legal status and eventually become eligible for citizenship
column56: but would have narrower eligibility requirements. Sen. Thom Tillis (R-N.C.) plans to introduce the bill in the Senate in the coming weeks; Rep. Carlos Curbelo (R-Fla.)
column57: a moderate member
column58: has already introduced it in the House. It also has backing outside Congress:\xa0Florida Gov. Rick Scott (R) came out in support of the bill last week.\xa0
column59: There are GOP members who would likely support legislation for Dreamers as standalone bills
column60: without other conditions. But most have said they would only vote on bills that help undocumented immigrants if Congress first addresses border security or enforcement measures \u2015 if they would vote for them at all.
column61: Democrats have previously supported bills coupling border security and enforcement with legal status for undocumented immigrants. But they\u2019d likely only go so far \u2015 Democratic leaders have dismissed an idea floated by the White House to protect Dreamers in exchange for slashing legal immigration numbers
column62: funding Trump\u2019s border wall and increasing other deportation efforts.
column63: Democrats have argued Dreamers shouldn\u2019t be used as a bargaining chip
column64: and young undocumented immigrant activists agree. That means Democrats and advocates may eventually be forced into a bind of their own over whether to sell out other immigrants to protect Dreamers.
column65: Standalone bills that support Dreamers could likely get enough support to pass
column66: but that would probably require a large number of Democratic votes and a smaller proportion of Republicans. Ryan and McConnell would have to bring those bills for a vote for it to happen. Whether they want to remains to be seen.
column67: For all of the Republican opposition to DACA
column68: it has saved them for five years from having to actually do anything to support the Dreamers they say should be helped. That might be why some of them didn\u2019t want Trump to end it.

column71: that decision was made by his predecessor
column72:
John Boehner.

Trump Reportedly To End DACA With 6-Month Delay

|[

WASHINGTON \u2015\xa0President Donald Trump plans to end an Obama-era program that protects young undocumented immigrants from deportation
column2: according to multiple reports. But the decision wouldn\u2019t take effect for six months
column3: raising the prospect that Trump could change his mind or Congress could work on a legislative solution \u2015 and prolonging uncertainty for hundreds of thousands of people protected by the program.
column4: On Sunday
column5: Politico\xa0and Reuters reported that Trump plans to eventually terminate the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program
column6: which grants work permits and protections for so-called Dreamers
column7: or undocumented young people brought to the U.S. as children.
column8: There will be a six-month delay to any enforcement of the president\u2019s decision
column9: unnamed sources told\xa0Politico\xa0and\xa0Reuters
column10: which would give Trump ample time to reverse his decision or decline to follow through on it. Otherwise
column11: Congress would have to pass legislation during that gap if they want to keep protections for DACA recipients in place. Dreamers might not know for months whether or how their lives could be upended.\xa0
column12: The White House is expected to officially announce Trump\u2019s decision on Tuesday.
column13: The decision would run against the recommendation of some Republicans
column14: including House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.)
column15: who\xa0said Friday that Trump should\xa0keep DACA in place while Congress works on a legislative solution.\xa0
column16: The program
column17: often referred to as DACA
column18: allows undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. before they turned 16 to apply for two-year work authorization and reprieve from deportation. Since President Barack Obama created DACA in 2012
column19: nearly 800
column20: 000 people have been granted those protections
column21: which meant they could obtain driver\u2019s licenses
column22: work legally and live without the imminent threat of being returned to countries they hadn\u2019t seen since childhood.\xa0
column23: Trump\u2019s decision comes ahead of an informal Sept. 5 deadline set by state attorneys general who\xa0threatened legal action\xa0if the president did not suspend DACA by that time.
column24: But supporters of DACA
column25: including members of Congress and immigrant rights groups
column26: said Trump could have fought for the program in court \u2015 or even waited to see if the states actually followed through on a legal challenge. They\xa0made a last-ditch push\xa0to persuade him to maintain DACA. Instead
column27: the president\u2019s decision could put those hundreds of thousands of Dreamers in limbo.
column28: Trump said repeatedly during his presidential campaign that he would end DACA \u2015 which he argued was unconstitutional \u2015 immediately upon becoming president. But he also spoke often about Dreamers in a vague but positive way
column29: hinting that he favored action to support them. Last December
column30: Trump said he would \u201cwork something out\u201d for Dreamers. In February
column31: he said he would \u201cshow great heart\u2033 toward them. In April
column32: he said Dreamers should \u201crest easy\u201d because his focus was deporting criminals.\xa0
column33: White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders said\xa0on Thursday\xa0ahead of the announcement that Trump \u201cabsolutely\u201d stood by his commitment to treat Dreamers with heart.
column34: The president has kept DACA going for months in spite of his previous claims that it was illegal. From January through March
column35: during most of which he was president
column36: U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services approved nearly 125
column37: 000 people for DACA
column38: most of them for renewal.
column39: DACA recipients have not been entirely safe
column40: however
column41: under the Trump administration. Immigrant rights advocates said there has been an uptick in the detention of Dreamers since the president took over and began an expansion of deportation efforts.
column42: Without DACA
column43: \xa0all Dreamers would be at risk of deportation. Trump officials have said no individuals are exempt from removal
column44: and have sought to deport people who merely cross their paths even if they haven\u2019t otherwise committed a crime. Trump wants to deport more undocumented immigrants
column45: and more DACA recipients will likely be among them.
column46: There could also be major economic implications. If DACA recipients are unable to renew their work permits
column47: nearly 700
column48: 000 people who are currently employed would exit the workforce. An average of 1
column49: 400 people would lose work authorization each business day and more than 6
column50: 000 could be fired in the first week alone
column51: according to a\xa0recent report\xa0by FWD.us and the Center for American Progress
column52: both supporters of the program.
column53: Deporting Dreamers is not a popular move \u2015 even among Republicans and Trump supporters
column54: \xa0according to polling. Nearly two-thirds of all Americans support DACA
column55: \xa0according to a\xa0NBC News/SurveyMonkey poll.\xa0That means there is a chance Congress will step in and protect Dreamers
column56: although it\u2019s not clear the White House would buy in without major concessions from Democrats on a border wall
column57: immigration enforcement and cuts to legal immigration. Such a deal was reportedly being pushed by top White House officials
column58: but Democrats\xa0quickly shot it down\xa0at the time
column59: saying Dreamers should not be used as bargaining chips.
column60: The White House has not supported other bipartisan efforts to help Dreamers that don\u2019t have additional items attached
column61: such as the stopgap Bridge Act
column62: which would temporarily extend protections
column63: or the Dream Act
column64: which would put them on a path to legal status and potential citizenship.
column65: Congressional Republicans have repeatedly blocked efforts to grant legal protections to Dreamers
column66: but will be under increased pressure to do so after Trump\u2019s announcement. Ahead of the decision
column67: some Republican lawmakers said they planned to work on more legislation that focuses on Dreamers.\xa0
column68: Sen. Thom Tillis (R-N.C.) intends to introduce what some backers are touting as a conservative version of the Dream Act
column69: called the Recognizing America\u2019s Children
column70: or RAC Act
column71: which was already introduced in the House and would grant legal status to a slightly narrower category of young undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children.\xa0

that\u2019s one that we\u2019re working on.\u201d

|[

BEAUMONT
column2: Texas\xa0\u2015 Like many people at Ford Park
column3: Dr. Nick Moore isn\u2019t sure exactly how he got here. He just knows why \u2015 to save horses.
column4: Over the past few days
column5: he and other veterinarians
column6: veterinary assistants and volunteers converged at this sports and entertainment complex\xa0built to host concerts
column7: sporting events and fairs.
column8: Since Hurricane Harvey hit Texas
column9: Ford Park has become something quite different. It is currently a makeshift animal triage hospital
column10: where Moore estimates 150 to 160 horses have been treated \u2015 many ravaged by hypothermia
column11: fever
column12: respiratory infections and stress-induced colic.
column13: \u201cA lot of these horses had to paddle in water or stand in water for anywhere from multiple hours to days
column14: \u201d the Georgetown
column15: Texas
column16: vet told HuffPost on Sunday.
column17: When owners started bringing animals here \u2015 simply because Ford Park was one of the few places in the area that could accommodate them \u2015 people who cared started showing up
column18: without any formal organization.
column19: \u201cThis is all volunteers
column20: \u201d Moore said. \u201cI ended up here by accident. There were people desperate for help.\u201d
column21: \u201cAt first it was just chaos and we were short on supplies
column22: \u201d he added. \u201cAnd all of a sudden people started pouring in from everywhere. We had teenage girls that drove in from Kentucky
column23: people from Florida
column24: veterinarians from Wisconsin. ... And you can see the amount of the supplies that have been donated.\u201d\xa0
column25: It was hard to witness the shape some of the animals were in as they arrived. Many were emaciated
column26: severely dehydrated and had skin conditions
column27: after being stranded in dirty
column28: toxic water.
column29: \u201cTheir skin was literally falling off
column30: \u201d Maggie Olthaus
column31: a veterinary technician at Bella Vista Equine in Blacklick
column32: Ohio
column33: said of some of the horses she treated.
column34: Like Moore
column35: Olthaus found it hard to explain how she ended up in Ford Park.
column36: \u201cWe came to work on Wednesday with a full schedule of our normal day planned out. Around 7 a.m. we all decided we needed to come and help out. We put the post out on Facebook on our page asking for donations so that we could start packing things and getting ready to leave
column37: and the public outreach we received \u2026 it was so incredible.\u201d
column38: \u201cWe started out with two trailers filled with hay
column40: 500 of donated medical supplies and equipment donated by MWI Veterinary Supply
column41: a company we do business with
column42: \u201d Olthaus said.
column43: In the days since
column44: she said
column45: her group has raised more than $20
column46: 000. \u201cWe have multiple semis headed down here hauling hundreds of bales of hay and tons of grain
column47: \u201d along with other supplies
column48: she said. \u201cOvernight
column49: things have gotten very organized.\u201d
column50: IV bags were still hanging from many of the remaining horses on Sunday afternoon. The ones that need more care are being stabilized
column51: so they can be transferred to Texas A&M University and another large animal clinic for further treatment.
column52: \u201cBetween all the vets that showed up
column53: all the volunteers
column54: and all the supplies
column55: we basically saved 150
column56: 160 horses
column57: \u201d Moore said. \u201cWe only lost four horses
column58: which is pretty much miraculous considering the shape they were coming in.\u201d
column59: Harley
column60: a 7-year-old quarterhorse
column61: is among those heading to Texas A&M
column62: where she will be treated for a fever and possibly pneumonia.
column63: \u201cI got her at 8 months. She is my baby
column64: \u201d said Jamie Sander
column65: a 33-year-old woman who was born in Austin and now lives in Colorado.
column66: Haley was one of three horses that Jamie and her sister
column67: Cristina Coots
column68: were planning to take to Colorado.
column69: Floodwater at the facility where the horses were being held was knee-deep in one area and muddy everywhere else.
column70: \u201cThey were good until the wind got really bad
column71: and then they were anxious with each other
column72: just kicking and biting
column73: \u201d Coots said. \u201cOur 2-year-old stud has bites all over him. We know it\u2019s from her and the other horse.\u201d
column74: Coots
column75: a 43-year-old mother of five
column76: said the hurricane has given her a new perspective
column77: despite all she has seen at Ford Park and elsewhere in Texas.
column78: \u201cI feel fortunate because this is the most we lost. We didn\u2019t lose everything
column79: and we pray for the people who did. Because I\u2019ve seen a lot of the devastation and it\u2019s bad
column80:
and it\u2019s hard to explain to my kids.\u201d

House To Vote This Week On First Package Of Harvey Aid

|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 House Republican leaders announced on Monday that lawmakers would vote this week on an initial relief package for victims of Hurricane Harvey
column2: potentially removing a key carrot for winning over GOP votes on a deal later this month to raise the U.S. debt ceiling and avert a government shutdown.
column3: The $7.85 billion package includes $7.4 billion earmarked for the Federal Emergency Management Agency\u2019s disaster relief fund. The money would replenish FEMA coffers so that it can continue to respond to Harvey and meet the immediate needs of other crises that may arise. The other $450 million would go to the Small Business Administration\u2019s disaster loan program
column4: designed to help individuals and small businesses begin rebuilding their homes.
column5: While the package almost certainly won\u2019t be the last funding legislation responding to the damage caused by Harvey in southeastern Texas
column6: it could complicate other urgent matters facing Congress.
column7: Government funding runs until Sept. 30
column8: close to the time that the government\u2019s borrowing authority expires. A leading option for congressional leaders has to address both issues in a bill to extend funding until mid-December through a so-called continuing resolution and raise the debt ceiling for some yet-to-be-determined period.
column9: Although such legislation may not naturally be too popular among Republicans \u2015 especially if it doesn\u2019t fund President Donald Trump\u2019s border wall and does fund certain Obamacare payments to win over Democrats \u2015 GOP leaders had believed the inclusion of Harvey aid could be enough to get many of their party members to support the bill.
column10: A second round of disaster relief \u2015 tightly focused to the specific needs of southeastern Texas \u2015 still could be part of a continuing resolution/debt ceiling measure. But there\u2019s also the chance that acting this week of partial Harvey-related aid will remove some of the motivation for conservatives to grudgingly back a spending/debt ceiling deal.
column11: The conservatives could more reasonably argue that they showed their support for Harvey aid at the beginning of the month
column12: but that they do not back raising the debt ceiling without structural spending reforms or funding the government if Trump doesn\u2019t get money to build his wall.
column13: In August
column14: Trump told a rally in Phoenix that he was getting funding for that wall even \u201cif we have to close down our government.\u201d That sort of condition could be a real problem for GOP leaders
column15: as Democrats seem to have no intention of giving in to Trump\u2019s demands and are reasonably confident that the public would blame Republicans for a shutdown.
column16: Again
column17: GOP leaders may still intend to attach a larger Harvey aid package in the final version of a continuing resolution/debt ceiling bill. They can still argue that Harvey aid is a key win for Congress
column18: and that voting \u2018no\u2019 would come with the political backlash of ignoring a devastated community.
column19: But letting lawmakers vote on the initial Harvey aid package first
column20: tempering any immediate criticism that they\u2019re heartless
column21: could prove to be a political misstep
column22:
even as the GOP leaders try to do the right thing.
