Republicans Could Protect Dreamers If They Wanted To. But Will They?

|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 Republican lawmakers who have said they sympathize with young undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children will now get the chance to prove it.
column2: President Donald Trump has decided to terminate the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program
column3: or DACA
column4: with a six-month delay on enforcement
column5: Politico and Reuters reported on Sunday evening. An official announcement is expected on Tuesday with further details.
column6: Ending the program would mean nearly 800
column7: 000 so-called \u201cDreamers\u201d who have been in the U.S. since they were children would eventually lose two-year work permits and be at risk for deportation.
column8: Trump\u2019s decision puts Republicans in a bind. Many of them have said they think something should be done to help Dreamers
column9: and some pro-immigration-reform Republicans have joined Democrats to push for legislation.
column10: But most Republicans \u2015 including party leaders in the House and Senate \u2015 have repeatedly voted to block legislation that would allow young undocumented immigrants to stay in the country. House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) hasn\u2019t allowed votes on bills that would allow legal status for Dreamers
column11: and his predecessor
column12: former Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio)
column13: let a comprehensive immigration reform bill that passed the Senate in 2013 die in the House.
column14: Ryan and other GOP members now say they\u2019re ready for legislation. But the question will be whether they\u2019re willing to break from the past and work with Democrats to make it happen. Doing so could invite primary challenges from the right.
column15: Ryan said on Friday that he had urged Trump not to end DACA because he believed Congress should pass a bill to protect Dreamers.
column16: \u201cThere are people in limbo
column17: \u201d Ryan said on the radio station WCLO in Janesville
column18: Wisconsin. \u201cThese are kids that know no other country
column19: who were brought here by their parents and don\u2019t know another home
column20: and so I really do believe there needs to be a legislative solution
column21: that\u2019s one that we\u2019re working on.\u201d
column22: Others similarly urged Trump not to end the program
column23: which he is expected to announce Tuesday \u2015 the deadline set for him by 10 state attorneys general who threatened legal action if he did not terminate DACA by that date.
column24: Speaking about Dreamers
column25: Sen. Tom Cotton (R-Ark.)\xa0told The Washington Examiner\xa0Sunday\xa0evening \u201cwe ought to take care of them
column26: \u201d and it wasn\u2019t their fault they had come to the country illegally.
column27: \u201cIn any legislative fix
column28: I would like to see them receive a green card
column29: \u201d he said. \u201cWe ought to recognize that giving them legal status has two problems. First
column30: it creates a whole new class of people who will then be eligible for a green card and citizenship \u2015 namely
column31: the extended family members of those who will receive legal status who can
column32: through chain migration
column33: get legal status themselves.\u201d
column34: Cotton added such a program would also encourage more illegal immigration
column35: a problem he said could be fixed by passing an immigration bill he and Trump both back that would make it more difficult to come\xa0to the U.S. legally. That bill would face heavy opposition from Democrats and some Republicans because it would slash legal immigration numbers.\xa0He also called for expanding E-Verify
column36: a government system employers can use to verify the identity of job applicants.
column37: On Friday
column38: Tennessee Attorney General Herbert Slatery (R)
column39: announced he would not take part in the legal challenge to DACA as he\u2019d promised and\xa0called for legislation on Dreamers. Slatery encouraged senators to support the Dream Act
column40: a bill that would provide a path to legal status for undocumented young people who came to the country as children
column41: or legislation like it.
column42: The Dream Act currently has bipartisan sponsors in both the House and Senate
column43: but a majority of Republicans have opposed past efforts to get it through Congress since it was first introduced in 2001.
column44: Sen. James Lankford (R-Okla.) also urged Trump not to end DACA.
column45: \u201cIt is right for there to be consequences for those who intentionally entered this country illegally
column46: \u201d\xa0he said in a statement.\xa0\xa0\u201cHowever
column47: we as Americans do not hold children legally accountable for the actions of their parents.\u201d
column48: Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.)\xa0said in a Monday statement\xa0he supported seeking a legislative solution to the plight of Dreamers
column49: should Trump give Congress a six-month window to act.
column50: \u201cI have always believed DACA was presidential overreach. However
column51: I equally understand the plight of Dream Act kids who \u2015 for all practical purposes \u2015 know no country other than America
column52: \u201d said Graham.\xa0
column53: Some Republicans are also pushing for the Recognizing America\u2019s Children Act
column54: or RAC Act
column55: which they\u2019re calling a conservative answer to the Dream Act. It similarly would allow Dreamers to receive legal status and eventually become eligible for citizenship
column56: but would have narrower eligibility requirements. Sen. Thom Tillis (R-N.C.) plans to introduce the bill in the Senate in the coming weeks; Rep. Carlos Curbelo (R-Fla.)
column57: a moderate member
column58: has already introduced it in the House. It also has backing outside Congress:\xa0Florida Gov. Rick Scott (R) came out in support of the bill last week.\xa0
column59: There are GOP members who would likely support legislation for Dreamers as standalone bills
column60: without other conditions. But most have said they would only vote on bills that help undocumented immigrants if Congress first addresses border security or enforcement measures \u2015 if they would vote for them at all.
column61: Democrats have previously supported bills coupling border security and enforcement with legal status for undocumented immigrants. But they\u2019d likely only go so far \u2015 Democratic leaders have dismissed an idea floated by the White House to protect Dreamers in exchange for slashing legal immigration numbers
column62: funding Trump\u2019s border wall and increasing other deportation efforts.
column63: Democrats have argued Dreamers shouldn\u2019t be used as a bargaining chip
column64: and young undocumented immigrant activists agree. That means Democrats and advocates may eventually be forced into a bind of their own over whether to sell out other immigrants to protect Dreamers.
column65: Standalone bills that support Dreamers could likely get enough support to pass
column66: but that would probably require a large number of Democratic votes and a smaller proportion of Republicans. Ryan and McConnell would have to bring those bills for a vote for it to happen. Whether they want to remains to be seen.
column67: For all of the Republican opposition to DACA
column68: it has saved them for five years from having to actually do anything to support the Dreamers they say should be helped. That might be why some of them didn\u2019t want Trump to end it.
column69: This story has been updated to include a comment from Sen. Lindsey Graham.
column70: CORRECTION:\xa0A previous version of this story stated that House Speaker Paul Ryan did not allow a House vote on an immigration reform bill that passed the Senate in 2013. In fact
column71: that decision was made by his predecessor
column72:
John Boehner.

]

Tennessee Attorney General Backs Off Threat Over DACA Protections For Dreamers

|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 One of the 10 state attorneys general who threatened President Donald Trump with legal action over protections for young undocumented immigrants rescinded his threat on Friday and is now urging Congress to pass legislation to give so-called Dreamers a path to citizenship.
column2: Tennessee Attorney General Herbert Slatery III (R) wrote in a letter to the state\u2019s Republican senators
column3: \xa0Bob Corker and Lamar Alexander
column4: that he will no longer challenge the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program
column5: or DACA
column6: which gives two-year work permits and deportation protections to young undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children.
column7: Prompted in part by a Sept. 5 deadline set by states attorneys general \u2015 including Slatery \u2015 to either terminate DACA or face legal action
column8: \xa0Trump is currently weighing whether to end the program. He will announce his decision on Tuesday
column9: according to the White House.
column10: Slatery said that while he believes a legal challenge to DACA will prevail
column11: he won\u2019t join one.
column12: \u201cThere is a human element to this ... that is not lost on me and should not be ignored
column13: \u201d he wrote. \u201cMany of the DACA recipients
column14: some of whose records I reviewed
column15: have outstanding accomplishments and laudable ambitions
column16: which if achieved
column17: will be of great benefit and service to our country.\u201d
column18: Slatery went on to urge Corker and Alexander to give \u201cserious consideration\u201d to the Dream Act
column19: a bill that would allow young undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children to gain legal status and eventually become eligible for citizenship. Slatery specifically referenced the bill
column20: introduced by Sens. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) and Dick Durbin (D-Ill.)
column21: and said it was \u201cnot a comprehensive answer to our immigration policy challenges
column22: but ... would be a very good start.\u201d
column23: \u201cIt is my sincere hope that the important issues raised by the States will be resolved by the people\u2019s representatives in the halls of Congress
column24: not in a courtroom
column25: \u201d Slatery wrote.
column26: As Sept. 5 approaches
column27: more Republicans have said Trump should leave DACA in place and seek a legislative fix instead. House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) said Friday that the president should not end DACA and that Republicans were \u201cworking on\u201d a bill to address Dreamers.
column28: The Dream Act is only one of the legislative options available. The Recognizing America\u2019s Children
column29: or RAC
column30: Act was introduced in the House as a Dream Act alternative that would also grant Dreamers a path to citizenship
column31: but with more restrictions on eligibility. Sen. Thom Tillis (R-N.C.) is working on similar legislation. There is also a stopgap bill called the Bridge Act that would extend DACA-like protections on a temporary basis.
column32: While Slatery has backed off his threat of legal action
column33: other attorneys general have not. Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton (R)
column34: who led the effort
column35: has remained firm on the ultimatum.
column36: Attorneys general from Alabama
column37: Arkansas
column38: Idaho
column39: Kansas
column40: Louisiana
column41: Nebraska
column42: South Carolina and West Virginia
column43: as well as Idaho Gov. C.L. \u201cButch\u201d Otter
column44: joined Paxton and Slatery on the letter threatening legal action.
column45: Immigrant rights advocates plan to protest in some of those states to pressure their attorneys general to similarly back off the legal threat.\xa0
column46:
Slatery previously declined to file a suit against the government over refugee resettlement after the Tennessee state legislature voted to approve one in 2016. The legislature had to hire an outside firm to initiate the suit instead.\xa0

Virginia Republican Channels Donald Trump In New Campaign Tone

|[

In a new negative ad and revved-up rhetoric
column2: Ed Gillespie
column3: the Republican nominee for Virginia governor
column4: has begun to echo the right-wing populism of President\xa0Donald Trump\xa0in his bid to defeat Democratic Lt. Gov.\xa0Ralph Northam\xa0in the November election.
column5: Gillespie
column6: a former chairman of the Republican National Committee who is known as a mild-mannered fiscal conservative
column7: is slamming Northam in a new ad for allegedly casting the \u201cdeciding vote in favor of\u201d so-called sanctuary cities. In fundraising emails to supporters
column8: Gillespie has also taken a tougher line against the removal of Confederate monuments
column9: and he used red-meat rhetoric to malign The Washington Post. He has even hired a controversial former Trump campaign staffer. \xa0
column10: It\u2019s all part of the delicate balance Gillespie must strike as he courts swing voters along with the GOP base that turned out for Corey Stewart
column11: Gillespie\u2019s populist primary opponent who nearly pulled off an upset win in June
column12: according to Mark Rush
column13: a politics professor at Washington and Lee University in Lexington
column14: Virginia.
column15: \u201cIf the primary hadn\u2019t been so close
column16: he could have been more moderate. Now he needs to work to get the Stewart voters as well
column17: \u201d Rush said.
column18: Quentin Kidd
column19: a Virginia politics watcher at Christopher Newport University in Newport News
column20: described Gillespie\u2019s attempts to excite the Republican base while winning over moderate constituencies
column21: such as college-educated women in northern Virginia
column22: as a \u201cgeometry problem.\u201d
column23: \u201cHe needs to appeal to his base and the median voter at the same time
column24: and Gillespie\u2019s base is more demanding on him than Northam\u2019s is on him
column25: \u201d Kidd said.
column26: \u201cSanctuary cities\u201d is a broad
column27: frequently politicized term used to describe cities that limit their cooperation with federal authorities on immigration enforcement
column28: most commonly by refusing to detain someone on behalf of the federal government for possible immigration violations. They often cite the chilling effect that this type of cooperation has on undocumented immigrants\u2019 willingness to report or help solve crimes and the legal challenges inherent in holding someone without an arrest warrant.
column29: Gillespie\u2019s ad about a vote on these localities is at once his most striking use of the immigration-driven politics that elected Trump and his least-significant policy shift.
column30: Gillespie had already declared his opposition to cities restricting immigration cooperation while running against Stewart in May. And in July he proclaimed his commitment to \u201ceradicating\u201d gangs and restrictions on cooperation with federal authorities.
column31: Still
column32: the 30-second ad Gillespie released Wednesday
column33: \u201cRalph Northam\u2019s Risky Policies
column34: \u201d is notable for the tough tone it takes and its omission of key nuances about Northam\u2019s vote.
column35: \u201cRalph Northam cast the deciding vote in favor of sanctuary cities that let illegal immigrants who commit crimes back on the street
column36: \u201d the narrator says in the ad.
column37: In fact
column38: rather than voting \u201cin favor\u201d of so-called sanctuary cities
column39: Northam merely cast the tie-breaking vote against a bill in the Virginia Senate that would have forbidden Virginia localities from restricting cooperation with federal authorities on immigration matters.
column40: And Northam only had the opportunity to vote on it in February because Republican Senate Majority Leader Thomas Norment\u2019s initial vote against it\xa0created a tie that forced Northam
column41: as lieutenant governor
column42: to cast a politically fraught vote against it. In a subsequent iteration of the legislation
column43: the Senate passed the bill with Norment\u2019s support. Democratic Gov. Terry McAuliffe vetoed it.
column44: Gillespie has also sharpened his rhetoric in support of Confederate monuments. In a fundraising email to supporters this week
column45: The Washington Post reported
column46: \xa0 the Gillespie campaign invited respondents to show their support if they agreed with him that \u201cthese statues should stay right where they are and we should teach history \u2014 NOT erase it.\u201d
column47: Gillespie had previously stated that it was up to local communities to decide how to deal with Confederate monuments
column48: a stance shared by Northam
column49: a multi-generation Virginia native who has nonetheless expressed his disdain for the statues in the wake of the violence in Charlottesville in August. Northam also had promised to be a \u201cvocal advocate\u201d for their removal.
column50: And in another email blast this week
column51: Gillespie tried to raise money off of critical coverage in The Washington Post
column52: which he dubbed an \u201cout-of-state media outlet ... working overtime to elect Democrat Ralph Northam as Virginia\u2019s next governor.\u201d The email even echoed Trump\u2019s attacks against the Post\u2019s owner
column53: Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos
column54: calling him a \u201cSeattle billionaire.\u201d
column55: (Although the Post is headquartered in Washington
column56: it is a regional newspaper that closely covers Virginia politics with a bureau in the state capital
column57: Richmond.)
column58: Finally
column59: Gillespie\u2019s campaign this week hired Jack Morgan
column60: the Trump campaign\u2019s southwest Virginia field director
column61: to do similar grassroots organizing. Morgan
column62: an evangelical Christian preacher
column63: has a history of fiery right-wing rhetoric
column64: including recent remarks calling the push for the removal of Confederate monuments \u201cnothing but pure communists trying to come after America again.\u201d He supported Stewart in the primary
column65: warning that nominating the \u201clobbyist\u201d Gillespie would be a \u201cdisaster.\u201d
column66: David Abrams
column67: a spokesman for Gillespie\u2019s campaign
column68: insisted that Gillespie\u2019s ad on sanctuary cities and recent comments about Confederate monuments and The Washington Post were unremarkable reflections of his long-standing positions. Gillespie still believes that removal of the monuments is a decision best left to localities but he personally opposes removals
column69: which he has expressed in the past
column70: Abrams said.\xa0
column71: In addition
column72: Abrams highlighted previous occasions when Gillespie had criticized The Washington Post on Twitter and in a blog post. As for Morgan
column73: the campaign is \u201cthrilled to have him on the team
column74: \u201d Abrams said.
column75: \u201cEd is laser-focused on putting forward policies that will create jobs
column76: raise take-home pay
column77: help people lift themselves out of poverty
column78: improve our public schools and ease traffic congestion
column79: \u201d he said.
column80: Liz Mair
column81: a libertarian-leaning Republican strategist based in northern Virginia
column82: was untroubled by Gillespie\u2019s immigration ad and hiring of Morgan
column83: noting that alumni of successful campaigns are often hired by politicians from the same party with differing views.
column84: She suggested
column85: however
column86: that if Gillespie is too vocal about the Confederate monuments in the final months of the campaign
column87: it risks coming off as inauthentic.
column88: \u201cThat just doesn\u2019t read as Ed Gillespie
column89: \u201d she said.
column90: The Northam campaign sees in Gillespie\u2019s new tone an opportunity to tie him to Trump
column91: whose popularity in Virginia has been\xa0steadily declining.
column92: \u201cEd Gillespie is abandoning any pretense of being the moderate Republican he once portrayed himself to be because he\u2019ll say and do anything to get elected
column93: principles be damned
column94: \u201d said Northam spokeswoman Ofirah Yheskel. \u201cThe Trumpification of Ed is moving full steam ahead
column95: and he\u2019s not stopping the train for anyone.\u201d
column96: Democrats are eager to put wins on the board in Virginia\u2019s elections this November. It is one of two states \u2015 the other is New Jersey \u2015 where state-level elections give the party a chance to make a comeback after its devastating losses in 2016.
column97: Party leaders view Virginia
column98: where Hillary Clinton defeated Trump by 5 percentage points\xa0in November
column99: as an especially ripe place to consolidate gains made there in recent years.
column100: Gillespie has kept the race very close thus far
column101: however. The lieutenant governor led Gillespie
column102: 42 percent to 37 percent
column103: among likely voters
column104:
according to an August poll conducted by Virginia Commonwealth University.

Trump Reportedly To End DACA With 6-Month Delay

|[

WASHINGTON \u2015\xa0President Donald Trump plans to end an Obama-era program that protects young undocumented immigrants from deportation
column2: according to multiple reports. But the decision wouldn\u2019t take effect for six months
column3: raising the prospect that Trump could change his mind or Congress could work on a legislative solution \u2015 and prolonging uncertainty for hundreds of thousands of people protected by the program.
column4: On Sunday
column5: Politico\xa0and Reuters reported that Trump plans to eventually terminate the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program
column6: which grants work permits and protections for so-called Dreamers
column7: or undocumented young people brought to the U.S. as children.
column8: There will be a six-month delay to any enforcement of the president\u2019s decision
column9: unnamed sources told\xa0Politico\xa0and\xa0Reuters
column10: which would give Trump ample time to reverse his decision or decline to follow through on it. Otherwise
column11: Congress would have to pass legislation during that gap if they want to keep protections for DACA recipients in place. Dreamers might not know for months whether or how their lives could be upended.\xa0
column12: The White House is expected to officially announce Trump\u2019s decision on Tuesday.
column13: The decision would run against the recommendation of some Republicans
column14: including House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.)
column15: who\xa0said Friday that Trump should\xa0keep DACA in place while Congress works on a legislative solution.\xa0
column16: The program
column17: often referred to as DACA
column18: allows undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. before they turned 16 to apply for two-year work authorization and reprieve from deportation. Since President Barack Obama created DACA in 2012
column19: nearly 800
column20: 000 people have been granted those protections
column21: which meant they could obtain driver\u2019s licenses
column22: work legally and live without the imminent threat of being returned to countries they hadn\u2019t seen since childhood.\xa0
column23: Trump\u2019s decision comes ahead of an informal Sept. 5 deadline set by state attorneys general who\xa0threatened legal action\xa0if the president did not suspend DACA by that time.
column24: But supporters of DACA
column25: including members of Congress and immigrant rights groups
column26: said Trump could have fought for the program in court \u2015 or even waited to see if the states actually followed through on a legal challenge. They\xa0made a last-ditch push\xa0to persuade him to maintain DACA. Instead
column27: the president\u2019s decision could put those hundreds of thousands of Dreamers in limbo.
column28: Trump said repeatedly during his presidential campaign that he would end DACA \u2015 which he argued was unconstitutional \u2015 immediately upon becoming president. But he also spoke often about Dreamers in a vague but positive way
column29: hinting that he favored action to support them. Last December
column30: Trump said he would \u201cwork something out\u201d for Dreamers. In February
column31: he said he would \u201cshow great heart\u2033 toward them. In April
column32: he said Dreamers should \u201crest easy\u201d because his focus was deporting criminals.\xa0
column33: White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders said\xa0on Thursday\xa0ahead of the announcement that Trump \u201cabsolutely\u201d stood by his commitment to treat Dreamers with heart.
column34: The president has kept DACA going for months in spite of his previous claims that it was illegal. From January through March
column35: during most of which he was president

column41: under the Trump administration. Immigrant rights advocates said there has been an uptick in the detention of Dreamers since the president took over and began an expansion of deportation efforts.
column42: Without DACA
column43: \xa0all Dreamers would be at risk of deportation. Trump officials have said no individuals are exempt from removal
column44: and have sought to deport people who merely cross their paths even if they haven\u2019t otherwise committed a crime. Trump wants to deport more undocumented immigrants
column45: and more DACA recipients will likely be among them.
column46: There could also be major economic implications. If DACA recipients are unable to renew their work permits
column47: nearly 700
column48: 000 people who are currently employed would exit the workforce. An average of 1

column54: \xa0according to polling. Nearly two-thirds of all Americans support DACA
column55: \xa0according to a\xa0NBC News/SurveyMonkey poll.\xa0That means there is a chance Congress will step in and protect Dreamers

that\u2019s one that we\u2019re working on.\u201d

|[

The president of a Pennsylvania police union responded to Black Lives Matter activists demanding accountability for the police killing of a black man by calling the group a \u201cpack of rabid animals.\u201d\xa0\xa0
column2: Philadelphia Fraternal Order of Police President John McNesby made the statement Thursday during a rally held by and in support of police
column3: according to NBC Philadelphia. The \u201cBack the Blue\u201d rally was in response to a protest the week before by members of Black Lives Matter held outside the house of Officer Ryan Pownall
column4: who fatally shot David Jones in June.
column5: Pownall
column6: a 12-year veteran
column7: shot Jones in the back as he fled from a traffic stop. Police said Jones was armed with a gun. This marks the second time Pownall has shot a black man in the back as he was fleeing. In 2010
column8: he shot Carnell Williams-Carney who ran from cops while having an illegal gun on him.
column9: \u201cThat was the day I took my last steps on my own
column10: \u201d\xa0Williams-Carney
column11: the now 36-year-old shot by Pownall
column12: told Philly.com from his wheelchair. \u201cI\u2019ve been in a chair ever since.\u201d
column13: At Thursday\u2019s police rally
column14: McNesby called BLM protesters \u201cracist hate groups determined to instigate violence.\u201d
column15: \u201cWhen you go to work each day
column16: you shouldn\u2019t have to worry that a pack of rabid animals will suddenly show up at your home and openly threaten your family
column17: \u201d McNesby said inside FOP headquarters
column18: according to NewsWorks.\xa0\u201cThese are not activists
column19: they are racist hate groups determined to instigate violence.\u201d
column20: An activist with the city\u2019s Black Lives Matter chapter
column21: Asa Khalif
column22: told NBC Philadelphia he and other members were only exercising their First Amendment right.
column23: \u201cWe will not let words stop us
column24: \u201d Khalif told the station. \u201cThe only words we\u2019re using is justice for David Jones
column25: and we will not be sidetracked by the bullying tactics of the FOP.\u201d
column26: The Pennsylvania Attorney General\u2019s office is still investigating the fatal shooting.
column27: McNesby also came under fire last year after defending an officer that appeared to be sporting a Nazi tattoo.\xa0Last September
column28: Officer Ian Hans Lichtermann was seen on social media with what appeared to be part of\xa0the official insignia of Adolph Hitler\u2019s Nazi Party\xa0on the left forearm:\xa0an eagle with outstretched wings
column29: topped by the word \u201cFatherland.\u201d\xa0
column30: While Philadelphia Mayor Jim Kenney called the tattoo \u201cincredibly offensive
column31: \u201d McNesby had other thoughts.
column32: \u201cI\u2019ve seen [the tattoo photo]. It\u2019s an Eagle. Not a big deal
column33: \u201d he told Philly.com by text at the time. An internal affairs investigation later cleared Lichtermann of any wrongdoing
column34:
even as the mayor stood by his stance that the tattoo is \u201cdeeply offensive.\u201d\xa0

North Korea Claims To Have Built An Advanced Hydrogen Bomb

|[

SEOUL (Reuters) - North Korea said on Sunday it has developed a more advanced nuclear weapon that has \u201cgreat destructive power\u201d and leader Kim Jong Un inspected a hydrogen bomb that will be loaded on a new intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM).
column2: The report by North Korea\u2019s official KCNA news agency comes amid heightened regional tension following Pyongyang\u2019s test launch of two ICBM-class missiles in July that potentially had a range of about 10
column4: 200 miles) that could hit many parts of the mainland United States.
column5: Under its leader Kim Jong Un
column6: North Korea has pursued work on building nuclear weapons and long-range ballistic missiles that can deliver them at an unprecedented pace
column7: defying U.N. sanctions and international pressure.
column8: Experts and officials have said North Korea could conduct its sixth nuclear test at any time
column9: and that the reclusive country has maintained a readiness at its nuclear test site to conduct another detonation test at any time.
column10: The hydrogen bomb\u2019s power is adjustable to hundreds of kilotons and can be detonated at high altitudes
column11: with its indigenously produced components allowing the country to build as many nuclear weapons as it wants
column12: KCNA news agency said.
column13: Kim visited the country\u2019s Nuclear Weapons Institute and \u201cwatched an H-bomb to be loaded into new ICBM
column14: \u201d KCNA said. \u201cAll components of the H-bomb were homemade and all the processes ... were put on the Juche basis
column15: thus enabling the country to produce powerful nuclear weapons as many as it wants
column16: he said.\u201d
column17: Juche is North Korea\u2019s homegrown ruling go-it-alone ideology that is a mix of Marxism and extreme nationalism preached by state founder Kim Il Sung
column18: the current leader\u2019s grandfather.
column19: Kim Jong Un \u201cset forth tasks to be fulfilled in the research into nukes
column20: \u201d KCNA said
column21: but it made no mention of plans for a sixth nuclear test.
column22: North Korea last year conducted its fourth and fifth nuclear tests
column23: saying the fourth in January 2016 was a successful hydrogen bomb test
column24: although outside experts questioned whether it was a full-fledged hydrogen bomb.
column25: The fifth nuclear test in September 2016 was measured to be possibly North Korea\u2019s biggest detonation ever
column26: but the earthquake it caused was still not believed to be big enough to demonstrate a thermonuclear test.
column27: U.S. officials have told Reuters that while North Korea has had parts in place for a nuclear detonation going back several months
column28: no new activity has been seen recently at its known nuclear test site in Punggye-ri in its northeastern region.

column1: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/hurricane-harvey-mental-health_us_59a9f092e4b0354e440a7b3f?ncid=fcbklnkushpmg00000013&utm_campaign=hp_fb_pages&utm_source=politics_fb&utm_medium=facebook&section=politics|<h1 class="headline__title">From The Mental Health Wreckage Of Katrina
column2:
Lessons To Help Harvey's Victims|[

As Texas begins to rebuild its buildings and roadways in the wake of Hurricane Harvey
column3: survivors of the catastrophic storm
column4: along with the medical professionals who treat them
column5: may face psychological trauma from displacement and the loss of homes
column6: property and
column7: especially
column8: loved ones.
column9: The link between a hurricane and mental health struggles has been documented through research on the survivors of Hurricane Katrina
column10: which devastated Louisiana in 2005. A year after the storm
column11: the Resilience in Survivors of Katrina (RISK) Project found that nearly half of the 392 low-income parents they studied reported symptoms consistent with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). An associated study concluded that the rates of probable serious mental illness in low-income parents in New Orleans doubled in the aftermath of the hurricane
column12: a rise that\u2019s likely to be reflected in southeast Texas.
column13: \u201cThere\u2019s a great deal of fear and anxiety about the future. And so we\u2019re seeing a lot of very anxious people who are not sure what they\u2019ll find when they return to their homes
column14: \u201d said Annalee Gulley
column15: the director of public policy and government affairs for Mental Health America of Greater Houston. She has been working to coordinate the mental and behavioral health response at the George R. Brown Convention Center in Houston
column16: where thousands of Harvey evacuees are still sheltering.
column17: Gulley explained to HuffPost that the mental health responders at the center are facing the challenges of helping people with existing mental health diagnoses continue to get treatment and responding to new trauma caused by the storm.
column18: Many evacuees were unable to grab medications when they rushed to safety
column19: so CVS
column20: Walgreens and Walmart have made donations to help people who have mental health diagnoses. For those who may have suffered new trauma
column21: clinical social workers walk the halls of the convention center
column22: where signs are posted that show the symptoms of PTSD.
column23: After Hurricane Katrina
column24: mental health professionals were able to learn more about how disasters affect mental health
column25: lessons that they are now applying to help the survivors of Hurricane Harvey.
column26: Dr. Melissa Allen
column27: the medical director of the UTHealth Harris County Psychiatric Center
column28: has been working to care for survivors of the storm. She said that
column29: while people\u2019s reactions to disasters are very individual
column30: there were indications of higher rates of substance abuse
column31: anxiety and depression among Katrina survivors. People who were exposed to disaster zones for longer and received less support afterward were more likely to suffer mental health problems.
column32: One of the biggest lessons of Katrina
column33: Allen said
column34: was that it was crucial to have resources ready before the disaster hit. In the aftermath
column35: even basic needs \u2015 clothes
column36: shoes
column37: toothbrushes \u2015 can help restore survivors\u2019 sense of safety.
column38: Like many of the faculty in the hospital
column39: Allen\u2019s house was flooded
column40: and she had to evacuate with her children.\xa0She said that working in the hospital has actually distracted her from dwelling on the destruction in the city.
column41: \u201cIt allows us to be of use in a situation where many of us are feeling kind of helpless
column42: and just being able to give back and do something is a very positive thing
column43: \u201d she told HuffPost.
column44: In the wake of major traumatic events
column45: such as Harvey and Katrina
column46: survivors may begin to experience symptoms including intense or unpredictable feelings
column47: changes in thought and behavior
column48: trouble sleeping and a sense of isolation. Allen said that some of her patients were struggling with anxiety
column49: confusion
column50: a sense of loss or depression
column51: but she added that survivors could have a wide range of emotions and that early intervention could help mitigate the psychological effects.
column52: Children
column53: in particular
column54: are vulnerable. The trauma of the storm itself might be combined with the stress of dislocation and the disruption of routines. Children may become more worried
column55: fearful
column56: aggressive or withdrawn.
column57: \u201cIn children
column58: the loss of their normal routine and their sense of safety is really disruptive
column59: and it can be a very confusing time
column60: \u201d Allen said. \u201cSo it\u2019s important to re-establish a sense of normalcy as soon as possible
column61: and to talk with a child who has been through something like this and see what it is they need
column62: what they feel like happened
column63: and just be there to reassure that they are in a safe place now.\u201d
column64: In order to provide a space where children can feel safe to have such conversations
column65: Mental Health America of Greater Houston has set up two children\u2019s zones in the convention center. Children can go into the areas to play
column66: feel secure and to talk to professionals about their experiences.
column67: \u201cWe\u2019re asking licensed clinical social workers
column68: licensed marriage and family therapists
column69: and other medical professionals to go in and make sure that these children still have the ability to be kids while they\u2019re here in the shelter
column70: \u201d Gulley said. \u201cAnd also to begin to have the conversations regarding what they\u2019ve experienced
column71: what they\u2019ve seen
column72: and what their families might be facing in the days and months to come.\u201d
column73: Although the psychological effects of hurricanes are undeniable
column74: being aware of the problems and responding appropriately can make a difference. In the face of destruction
column75: Allen said
column76: it is important for people to take time to mourn their losses. That could mean anything from losing possessions to losing loved ones
column77: including those who have died
column78: are missing or have had to relocate far from family. It is also important for survivors to ask for help when they need it.
column79: Allen explained that helping with the community recovery effort and listening to survivors\u2019 needs is crucial. The American Red Cross is calling on mental health professionals to volunteer to help storm survivors. The National Alliance on Mental Illness is providing hotlines for people affected by the storm.
column80: \u201cThe more people that are available to help out
column81: the easier it is to reestablish a sense of normalcy
column82:
\u201d Allen said. \u201cSo don\u2019t be afraid to ask for support from your community and those around you.\u201d

]

Trump Congratulates Texas Governor On Harvey Recovery So Far

President Donald Trump congratulated Texas Gov. Greg Abbott (R) on Saturday and praised relief efforts in the state as he visited with people affected by Hurricane Harvey.
column2: Trump visited a shelter at Houston\u2019s NRG Center
column3: where he met with families and helped hand out lunch with first lady Melania Trump. More than <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/hurricane-harvey-live-updates_us_59a60034e4b063ae34d9ce8f?g92" target="_blank">32
column4: 000 people have been displaced by the storm
column5: and the death toll is feared to be as high as 46.\xa0The number of people in shelters and people without power has declined in recent days
column6: but remains in the tens of thousands.
column7: Speaking with reporters after he met with families
column8: Trump said: \u201cThey were just happy. We saw a lot of happiness. It\u2019s been really nice. It\u2019s been a wonderful thing. As tough as this was

column12: Trump said the recovery effort could take years

Tennessee Attorney General Backs Off Threat Over DACA Protections For Dreamers

|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 One of the 10 state attorneys general who threatened President Donald Trump with legal action over protections for young undocumented immigrants rescinded his threat on Friday and is now urging Congress to pass legislation to give so-called Dreamers a path to citizenship.
column2: Tennessee Attorney General Herbert Slatery III (R) wrote in a letter to the state\u2019s Republican senators
column3: \xa0Bob Corker and Lamar Alexander
column4: that he will no longer challenge the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program
column5: or DACA
column6: which gives two-year work permits and deportation protections to young undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children.
column7: Prompted in part by a Sept. 5 deadline set by states attorneys general \u2015 including Slatery \u2015 to either terminate DACA or face legal action
column8: \xa0Trump is currently weighing whether to end the program. He will announce his decision on Tuesday
column9: according to the White House.
column10: Slatery said that while he believes a legal challenge to DACA will prevail
column11: he won\u2019t join one.
column12: \u201cThere is a human element to this ... that is not lost on me and should not be ignored
column13: \u201d he wrote. \u201cMany of the DACA recipients
column14: some of whose records I reviewed
column15: have outstanding accomplishments and laudable ambitions
column16: which if achieved
column17: will be of great benefit and service to our country.\u201d
column18: Slatery went on to urge Corker and Alexander to give \u201cserious consideration\u201d to the Dream Act
column19: a bill that would allow young undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children to gain legal status and eventually become eligible for citizenship. Slatery specifically referenced the bill
column20: introduced by Sens. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) and Dick Durbin (D-Ill.)
column21: and said it was \u201cnot a comprehensive answer to our immigration policy challenges
column22: but ... would be a very good start.\u201d
column23: \u201cIt is my sincere hope that the important issues raised by the States will be resolved by the people\u2019s representatives in the halls of Congress
column24: not in a courtroom
column25: \u201d Slatery wrote.
column26: As Sept. 5 approaches
column27: more Republicans have said Trump should leave DACA in place and seek a legislative fix instead. House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) said Friday that the president should not end DACA and that Republicans were \u201cworking on\u201d a bill to address Dreamers.
column28: The Dream Act is only one of the legislative options available. The Recognizing America\u2019s Children
column29: or RAC
column30: Act was introduced in the House as a Dream Act alternative that would also grant Dreamers a path to citizenship
column31: but with more restrictions on eligibility. Sen. Thom Tillis (R-N.C.) is working on similar legislation. There is also a stopgap bill called the Bridge Act that would extend DACA-like protections on a temporary basis.
column32: While Slatery has backed off his threat of legal action
column33: other attorneys general have not. Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton (R)
column34: who led the effort
column35: has remained firm on the ultimatum.
column36: Attorneys general from Alabama
column37: Arkansas
column38: Idaho
column39: Kansas
column40: Louisiana
column41: Nebraska
column42: South Carolina and West Virginia
column43: as well as Idaho Gov. C.L. \u201cButch\u201d Otter
column44: joined Paxton and Slatery on the letter threatening legal action.
column45: Immigrant rights advocates plan to protest in some of those states to pressure their attorneys general to similarly back off the legal threat.\xa0
column46:
Slatery previously declined to file a suit against the government over refugee resettlement after the Tennessee state legislature voted to approve one in 2016. The legislature had to hire an outside firm to initiate the suit instead.\xa0

]

column2: \xa0according to several reports.
column3: In the above video that emerged this week
column4: Alex Wubbels
column5: the head nurse at the University of Utah Hospital\u2019s burn unit
column6: keeps her cool while Detective Jeff Payne insists that he be given permission to collect the blood sample of a patient \u2015 despite not having a warrant.
column7: The July 26 footage
column8: filmed on Payne\u2019s body camera
column9: captures Wubbels explaining that \u201cthree things that allow us to [give blood samples]\xa0are if you have an electronic warrant
column10: patient consent or patient under arrest
column11: and neither of those things\u2026 the patient can\u2019t consent. He told me repeatedly that he doesn\u2019t have a warrant and the patient is not under arrest.\u201d
column12: \u201cSo
column13: I\u2019m just trying to do what I\u2019m supposed to do
column14: that\u2019s all
column15: \u201d she adds.
column16: Wubbels appears professional throughout the exchange and has her supervisor on speakerphone so the detective can listen.
column17: You can hear the supervisor telling Payne that he\u2019s making a \u201chuge mistake\u201d in threatening Wubbels and by claiming that she\u2019s interfering with his police duties when she\u2019s simply following protocol.
column18: The supervisor barely finishes what he\u2019s saying when Payne shouts
column19: \u201cWe\u2019re done!\u201d\xa0repeatedly at Wubbels. He then chases her down and handcuffs her.
column20: A sobbing Wubbels\u2019 screams \u201cHelp me!\u201d and \u201cYou\u2019re assaulting me!\u201d while being pushed out of the hospital and toward a police car.
column21: As The Washington Post noted in its report Friday
column22: the U.S. Supreme Court \u201chas\xa0explicitly ruled\xa0that blood can only be drawn from drivers for probable cause
column23: with a warrant.\u201d Wubbels appeared to do everything correctly.
column24: For Payne\u2019s part
column25: he was reportedly\xa0explicitly told by his lieutenant to arrest Wubbels if she refused to let him take a sample of blood
column26: according to The Salt Lake Tribune.
column27: Since the horrifying arrest
column28: Payne has been suspended from the department\u2019s blood draw unit. He was expected to remain on active duty as the investigation is conducted.
column29: Wubbels has not been charged. She said in a news conference Thursday
column30: accompanied by her lawyer Karra Porter

column32: \u201cI just feel betrayed

This Pilot Rescued More People In Harvey Than In The Rest Of His Career Combined

|[

ELLINGTON FIELD JOINT RESERVE BASE
column2: Texas\xa0\u2015 At 3 a.m. on Sunday
column3: Jason Brownlee
column4: a pilot with the U.S. Coast Guard
column5: woke with a start. His phone was ringing.
column6: While he was asleep
column7: Hurricane Harvey had slammed into the greater Houston area
column8: bringing extreme winds and heavy rainfall. His bosses wanted him back at the U.S. Coast Guard Air Station Houston \u2015 ASAP.
column9: There was one problem
column10: though. Brownlee
column12: was already flooded in.
column13: \u201cEvery road that I could take to get in was impassable
column14: \u201d he said. So his team pulled the maneuver they knew best: They scrambled a rescue aircraft and picked him up in an elementary school parking lot near his house.
column15: \u201cI came in
column16: put my uniform on
column17: grabbed my gear
column18: a crew
column19: a helicopter
column20: \u201d and took off
column21: he said
column22: flying the first of what would be many rescue missions in the days to come.
column23: The full extent of Harvey\u2019s devastation is still unknown. More than 32
column24: 000 residents have sought refuge in shelters after being displaced from their homes
column25: and at least 38 people have died. But many more were saved \u2015 including by pilots like Brownlee. So far
column26: more than 72
column27: 000 people\xa0have been rescued. According to a U.S. Coast Guard spokesperson
column28: at least 744 aerial rescues in the greater Houston area have taken place since the storm began.
column29: On Friday
column30: one week after Harvey made landfall in Texas as a Category 4 hurricane
column31: Brownlee\u2019s unit took HuffPost reporters on a reconnaissance mission to survey flooding around Port Arthur and Beaumont
column32: two cities among those hit hardest. Much of the area surrounding these towns is still underwater
column33: and rescue efforts are ongoing.
column34: The sky was sunny and clear as the MH-65 Dolphin helicopter took off \u2015 a far cry from the flying conditions that Brownlee battled during the storm. On Monday
column35: he flew a search and rescue mission through a torrential downpour
column36: the worst weather he\u2019d ever witnessed as a pilot. He couldn\u2019t see anything except the ground directly below the nose of the aircraft.
column37: \u201cWe were using Google Maps to fly above highways
column38: because we know that there are no towers over the highways
column39: \u201d he said. \u201cI don\u2019t think I\u2019m ever going to forget that experience.\u201d
column40: Seen from the sky
column41: the destruction caused by Harvey was on full display. Mile after mile brought scenes of dramatic flooding
column42: with entire fields and neighborhoods swallowed up by water.
column43: Cows congregated on tiny sections of dry land
column44: surrounded by water. Interstate 10
column45: a major connecting highway
column46: was a river. Tractor-trailer trucks stood abandoned along the road.
column47: Eric Cybulski
column48: a flight mechanic who has been with the Coast Guard for 19 years
column49: kept his eyes trained on the ground
column50: looking for anyone in need of rescue.
column51: The destruction
column52: he said
column53: reminded him of the 11 days he spent responding to Hurricane Katrina in New Orleans
column55: \u201cWe would get the smells from downtown \u2015 the winds would shift and the smell of death would come
column56: \u201d he said. \u201cBeing here
column57: it brings back the emotions
column58: for sure.\u201d
column59: The only thing they had to drink during the Katrina mission was blue Gatorade
column60: he said. To this day
column61: he can\u2019t stand the stuff.
column62: In Beaumont
column63: a line of cars snaked around the block
column64: waiting for supplies at a distribution center. Outside a housing complex
column65: a high-water vehicle pushed through deep water. Another Coast Guard helicopter flew past
column66: transporting a victim who\u2019d just been rescued.
column67: Coast Guard rescue workers had been working nonstop since the hurricane made landfall. Many of them left families behind. One serviceman\u2019s wife was in labor as he worked to aid his community. Several Guardsmen at Ellington Field lost homes and vehicles of their own
column68: while others
column69: such as Cybulski
column70: were initially unable to get to the air base to help because of severe flooding.
column71: \u201cThis one caught a lot of people off guard
column72: \u201d Cybulski said. \u201cI don\u2019t think the Houston area was expecting something of this magnitude \u2015 this much rain.\u201d
column73: Brownlee said he was humbled after flying over Houston early on in the storm. He didn\u2019t see any damage
column74: and although he was ready to act at a moment\u2019s notice
column75: he figured the worst was over. Hours later
column76: he\u2019d wake up to a call demanding that he get back to his chopper.
column77: \u201cMy famous last words were
column78: \u2018Hurricane Harvey is going to be nothing
column79: \u2019\u201d he said.
column80:
He would save 20 lives over the course of the next few days \u2015 three times as many people as he\u2019d rescued since he became a pilot three years ago.\xa0\xa0

]

Trump Requests $7.8 Billion From Congress For Harvey Relief

|[

President Donald Trump officially submitted a request to Congress for an initial $7.85 billion in emergency funding for Harvey relief efforts in Texas and Louisiana late Friday night.
column2: The request
column3: sent in a letter signed by White House budget director Mick Mulvaney
column4: includes giving $7.4 billion to supplement the Federal Emergency Management Agency\u2019s disaster relief fund and $450 million to finance a disaster loan program for small businesses affected by the devastating storm.
column5: Earlier this week
column6: Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said the state would need \u201cfar more than $125 billion\u201d in federal funding to help the state recover from the massive flooding in Houston and surrounding areas.

column8: The WH just put in the request to Congress for $7.85 billion for the disaster response to #Harvey: pic.twitter.com/H6WvAYUWss

column10: Trump was expected to request nearly $6 billion in immediate aid
column11: followed by another request for $6 billion
column12: according to The New York Times.
column13: Friday\u2019s letter
column14: addressed to House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.)
column15: said that the requested amount of\xa0$7.8 billion \u201cwould enable the affected States to address disaster response and immediate recovery needs in the areas most affected by Hurricane Harvey
column16: \u201d including \u201clife-saving response and recovery missions\u201d and \u201caddressing housing repair costs unmet by insurance; and provide low-interest loans to businesses and homeowners.\u201d

I got family in Lake View. His house is 15 feet off the ground and they\u2019re saying it has water... We\u2019re going to survive it. The good Lord blessed us with our lives.\u201d

Tennessee Attorney General Backs Off Threat Over DACA Protections For Dreamers

|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 One of the 10 state attorneys general who threatened President Donald Trump with legal action over protections for young undocumented immigrants rescinded his threat on Friday and is now urging Congress to pass legislation to give so-called Dreamers a path to citizenship.
column2: Tennessee Attorney General Herbert Slatery III (R) wrote in a letter to the state\u2019s Republican senators
column3: \xa0Bob Corker and Lamar Alexander
column4: that he will no longer challenge the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program
column5: or DACA
column6: which gives two-year work permits and deportation protections to young undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children.
column7: Prompted in part by a Sept. 5 deadline set by states attorneys general \u2015 including Slatery \u2015 to either terminate DACA or face legal action
column8: \xa0Trump is currently weighing whether to end the program. He will announce his decision on Tuesday
column9: according to the White House.
column10: Slatery said that while he believes a legal challenge to DACA will prevail
column11: he won\u2019t join one.
column12: \u201cThere is a human element to this ... that is not lost on me and should not be ignored
column13: \u201d he wrote. \u201cMany of the DACA recipients
column14: some of whose records I reviewed
column15: have outstanding accomplishments and laudable ambitions
column16: which if achieved
column17: will be of great benefit and service to our country.\u201d
column18: Slatery went on to urge Corker and Alexander to give \u201cserious consideration\u201d to the Dream Act
column19: a bill that would allow young undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children to gain legal status and eventually become eligible for citizenship. Slatery specifically referenced the bill
column20: introduced by Sens. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) and Dick Durbin (D-Ill.)
column21: and said it was \u201cnot a comprehensive answer to our immigration policy challenges
column22: but ... would be a very good start.\u201d
column23: \u201cIt is my sincere hope that the important issues raised by the States will be resolved by the people\u2019s representatives in the halls of Congress
column24: not in a courtroom
column25: \u201d Slatery wrote.
column26: As Sept. 5 approaches
column27: more Republicans have said Trump should leave DACA in place and seek a legislative fix instead. House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) said Friday that the president should not end DACA and that Republicans were \u201cworking on\u201d a bill to address Dreamers.
column28: The Dream Act is only one of the legislative options available. The Recognizing America\u2019s Children
column29: or RAC
column30: Act was introduced in the House as a Dream Act alternative that would also grant Dreamers a path to citizenship
column31: but with more restrictions on eligibility. Sen. Thom Tillis (R-N.C.) is working on similar legislation. There is also a stopgap bill called the Bridge Act that would extend DACA-like protections on a temporary basis.
column32: While Slatery has backed off his threat of legal action
column33: other attorneys general have not. Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton (R)
column34: who led the effort
column35: has remained firm on the ultimatum.
column36: Attorneys general from Alabama
column37: Arkansas
column38: Idaho
column39: Kansas
column40: Louisiana
column41: Nebraska
column42: South Carolina and West Virginia
column43: as well as Idaho Gov. C.L. \u201cButch\u201d Otter
column44: joined Paxton and Slatery on the letter threatening legal action.
column45: Immigrant rights advocates plan to protest in some of those states to pressure their attorneys general to similarly back off the legal threat.\xa0
column46:
Slatery previously declined to file a suit against the government over refugee resettlement after the Tennessee state legislature voted to approve one in 2016. The legislature had to hire an outside firm to initiate the suit instead.\xa0

Inside The 'Impossible' Mission To Rescue 33 Kids Desperate For Dialysis During Harvey

|[

HOUSTON \u2015 By Monday evening
column2: Dr. Michael Braun
column3: chief of the pediatric nephrology center at Texas Children\u2019s Hospital
column4: was getting nervous. Hurricane Harvey had flooded the city
column5: leaving many roads impassable and stranding thousands of people in their homes.
column6: It had already been three days since the storm hit. For\xa0dozens of his young patients
column7: \xa0going multiple days without treatment could be deadly.
column8: Braun\u2019s center is one of the country\u2019s largest clinics for children with kidney failure
column9: providing care for babies through young adults. His patients rely on dialysis
column10: a treatment that filters blood to remove waste and excess fluid
column11: to stay alive. They need the treatment three to four days a week
column12: with a maximum of two days between sessions. And without it
column13: they can suffer severe consequences: hypertension
column14: headaches
column15: chest pain
column16: vomiting and ultimately death.
column17: He called Dr. Rita Swinford
column18: the medical director of the pediatric dialysis unit at Children\u2019s Memorial Hermann Hospital
column19: which is located just four blocks away in an area of southwest Houston known for its medical facilities. Swinford was also panicking. Between their two units
column20: they cared for virtually every child on dialysis in southeast Texas.
column21: Braun\u2019s patients had gotten their last treatment on Saturday
column22: before the worst of the storm hit the city; Swinford\u2019s had been treated on Friday. Time was running out
column23: and they needed a plan. Thirty-three of their patients were critically overdue for dialysis and desperately needed to get to a unit. They\u2019d have to find a way to transport those children and their families
column24: who were spread all over the region
column25: to the centers
column26: in just one day.
column27: \u201cMany
column28: many families were flooded in
column29: either their homes were flooding or flooded
column30: or they were trapped in their neighborhoods and they couldn\u2019t get out
column31: \u201d Braun said. Six of the patients were under age 2. Some of them were on ventilators
column32: and others had medical complications beyond kidney failure.
column33: He called the Coast Guard and gave them a list of patients
column34: addresses and phone numbers. Their mission was to track down all 33 and help them get to the hospital for dialysis \u2015 before it was too late.
column35: Lt.\xa0Brad Bryan
column36: the Coast Guard liaison to the Texas State Emergency Operations Center
column37: said they immediately started working\xa0with the Texas Department of Emergency Management to create a map of Houston that pinpointed the location of each child
column38: with color coding based on their criticality.
column39: \u201cWe very quickly realized that we had 33 children randomly scattered all across Houston in locations that were basically islands surrounded by rapidly rising flood waters
column40: \u201d Bryan said.\xa0<span style="font-weight: 400;">\u201cThis was mission impossible
column41: because it was such a logistical nightmare.\u201d
column42: But they were quickly able to deploy a sweeping rescue effort that included first responders from the Houston police and fire departments
column43: the Coast Guard
column44: \xa0a Federal Emergency Management Agency rescue team and the United States Air Force.\xa0
column45: One of the patients they were able to save was 16-year-old Inesty Thomas. By Monday evening
column46: she had been waiting for treatment for two days
column47: and she was feeling weak and achy. Thomas
column48: her mother and her siblings had been forced to evacuate from their rapidly flooding home in Crosby over the weekend and were staying at her aunt\u2019s house in Channelview
column49: Texas.
column50: Her mother
column51: Rachel Richard
column53: said she was beginning to feel hopeless. She didn\u2019t know how she would get her daughter to the center for much-needed dialysis.
column54: \u201cI called the Coast Guard
column55: the National Guard
column56: the news
column57: \u201d she told HuffPost from a hotel room on Thursday. She even tried taking her daughter to a dialysis unit for adults
column58: but they were unable to help her.
column59: By Tuesday evening
column60: Thomas hadn\u2019t had dialysis in more than\xa0three\xa0days \u2015 longer than she\u2019d ever gone without treatment. Then they got a call: A medevac helicopter was on its way. They walked outside to find the rest of the neighborhood was already there
column61: waving their flashlights to get the attention of pilots.
column62: \u201cThese people didn\u2019t even know my daughter
column63: \u201d Richard said through tears. \u201cWhen I saw them all outside waving
column64: I started crying.\u201d
column65: One harrowing helicopter ride and a trip in an ambulance later
column66: Thomas was back at Texas Children\u2019s Hospital getting the life-sustaining dialysis she desperately needed.
column67: By 2 p.m. Wednesday
column68: every single dialysis patient had made it back for treatment at the two centers
column69: Braun said \u2015 either through a daring rescue like that of Thomas
column70: or because the roads eventually opened up and they were able to drive there.
column71: \u201cWhat these families have been through
column72: it\u2019s mind-boggling
column73: \u201d he said. \u201cThese are parents who are extremely resilient
column74: they are used to dealing with difficulties and complex medical care issues. They were all aware that if they couldn\u2019t get to us
column75: potentially their children could die.\u201d
column76: For the Coast Guard servicemen who coordinated the rescues
column77: the news that their mission was successful was worth every sleepless minute. Both\xa0<span style="font-weight: 400;">Bryan and Coast Guard Ensign James Gardner
column78: who spent hours on the phone with the families throughout the mission
column79: \xa0are planning to meet up sometime next week with the children whose lives they helped save.
column80: Gardner
column81: who has been in the Coast Guard for only six months
column82: turned 24 on Tuesday
column83: as the daring rescue mission was still rapidly unfolding.
column84: \u201cHearing all these kids were going to be with their parents
column85: and they are going to survive
column86: is the best gift I ever could have got
column87: \u201d he said.
