Blackwater's Erik Prince On How He Got Into The White House

|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 Last week at Fort Myer military base in Virginia
column2: President Donald Trump gave a speech outlining his new policy in Afghanistan
column3: which was in fact not so very different from the previous administration\u2019s policy in Afghanistan.
column4: \u201cMy original instinct was to pull out. And historically
column5: I like following my instincts
column6: \u201d Trump said. \u201cBut all my life I\u2019ve heard that decisions are much different when you sit behind the desk in the Oval Office \u2015 in other words
column7: when you\u2019re president of the United States.\u201d
column8: He went on to say that he would be sending more troops \u2015 estimates have suggested around 4
column9: 000 \u2015 without committing to any deadlines for pulling out.
column10: Trump\u2019s U-turn came as bad news to Erik Prince
column11: founder of the private security company formerly called Blackwater
column12: whose employees were accused of committing a number of crimes during the Iraq War
column13: including the killing of 14 Iraqi civilians in Nisour Square
column14: Baghdad
column15: on Sept. 16
column16: 2007. The incident sparked numerous federal investigations
column17: and Prince sold the company in 2010.
column18: Now he\u2019s the chairman of Frontier Services Group
column19: a logistics company based in the United Arab Emirates
column20: and he feels newly emboldened by Trump\u2019s election. In May
column21: the 48-year-old former Navy SEAL wrote an op-ed for The Wall Street Journal advocating a completely different solution in Afghanistan. Prince\u2019s five-point plan suggested that
column22: instead of sending U.S. troops
column23: \xa0private contracted soldiers \u2015 including U.S. and NATO veterans
column24: Prince has said elsewhere\xa0\u2015 should be used alongside U.S. Special Forces troops.\xa0They would serve under the command of a \u201cviceroy
column25: \u201d who would coordinate all military strategy and report to the president.
column26: \u201cThere are too many cooks
column27: \u201d Prince wrote
column28: outlining the financial waste (approximately $1 trillion) and the massive damage to U.S. lives (around 2
column29: 000 deaths and 20
column30: 000 injuries) since the war began 16 years ago.
column31: Prince\u2019s views are popular with some inside the White House and on Capitol Hill
column32: where he is scheduled to meet with 50 members of Congress next week. I met with him on Monday in Washington
column33: D.C.
column34: to discuss how close he came to convincing the administration to go his way and what he plans to do for the rest of Trump\u2019s tenure. This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.
column35: Your Wall Street Journal piece got a lot of attention in Washington. Did you ever speak to the president about it?
column36: We didn\u2019t meet about it
column37: but he read it
column38: and I\u2019m told he circulated it around. I wrote it for an audience of one
column39: and it worked.
column40: This was after [national security adviser] H.R. McMaster had asked for 70
column43: 000 troops. McMaster basically wanted a redo of the Obama surge
column44: where we have tens of thousands of Americans come back to Afghanistan and do the fighting there. I think that\u2019s a bad idea. I think the president did
column45: too.
column46: So Trump reads it. Then what happens?
column47: Well
column48: I get calls from McMaster and from [then-White House chief strategist] Steve Bannon. They say
column49: \u201cHey
column50: the president saw your article. Please come in and tell us what you were thinking.\u201d So I came in
column51: and I gave a presentation [to Bannon
column52: McMaster and then-White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus] that fleshed out more of the points made in the op-ed and hit the notion of vetting contractors and all the rest.
column53: Your use of the word \u201cviceroy\u201d in the op-ed stirred up a lot of controversy
column54: raising questions of colonial power and accountability. Surely
column55: the Afghans would not want to answer to a viceroy?
column56: To be very clear
column57: when I say a viceroy
column58: that is not to rule over Afghanistan
column59: but rather to harmonize what has been a very chaotic U.S. policy. Between the Department of Defense
column60: the Department of State and the CIA in Afghanistan and Pakistan
column61: there has been no unity of commands. Seventeen commanders in 16 years. Come on. It\u2019s a joke. It\u2019s embarrassing.
column62: Talk me through the timeline. You write the piece. You get called in to talk with McMaster and Bannon and Priebus and \u2026
column63: And H.R. automatically hates it.
column64: Does he say that to you?
column65: Pretty much.
column66: In other words
column67: he\u2019s called you in because the president is interested in your ideas
column68: not because he wants to meet you.
column69: Correct. I went through the slides
column70: and he completely discounted it. The nature of the questions he asked made it clear that it was going to be an all-Army solution
column71: period.
column72: Give me an example.
column73: I pointed out the challenge of deploying U.S. troops the way they had been for 16 years
column74: where they go for six or nine months and they leave and all that local knowledge leaves with them.
column75: Here\u2019s the thing. Every U.S. trooper is statistically at the highest risk for the first 60 days they\u2019re in country
column76: because most of those guys
column77: it\u2019s their first deployment and they\u2019re figuring it out. Meanwhile
column78: the same Taliban that have been there for 16 years
column79: the ones that have survived
column80: are the smartest
column82: They see the Americans come and go every six to nine months. They know exactly how they patrol. They know exactly how they clear mines. They know exactly how they communicate. They know exactly the response times for aircraft. They know the deal
column83: so doing the same thing for another 16 or 17 years means the outcome is going to be the same. It\u2019s like the last two kids that were killed two weeks ago
column84: blown up in a roadside bomb in their fully armored vehicle. Terrible. What a loss. What a waste.
column85: What was McMaster\u2019s response to that argument?
column86: He largely just refused to answer
column87: and I wasn\u2019t there to debate him. I was there to pitch an idea.
column88: What happened after the meeting?
column89: Steve and Reince liked the concept. They saw it as something the president would or should consider. A couple weeks later
column90: I got a call from Steve saying
column91: \u201cOK
column92: lay it out. Figure out what that costs. And tell me exactly because the typical Beltway pundits will discount a low number.\u201d
column93: So I did a very hard number: 91 aircraft
column95: 000 flight hours
column96: all the food
column97: fuel
column98: ordinance
column99: man days
column100: insurance
column102: 200 ground mentors [Special Forces members or contractors who attach to Afghan army battalions]
column103: the whole thing. It comes out to about five and a half thousand personnel. It was 7 percent of what they\u2019re spending now
column104: way less than $4 billion.
column105: Still
column106: if you got what you suggested
column107: you\u2019d get a big cut from that
column108: no?
column109: What I\u2019d say is that Elon Musk advocates for private space flight. Is he demonized for that? I would be very happy to compete for a solution that saves American lives and saves the taxpayers $40 billion a year. I will not apologize for that in any way. \xa0
column110: You wrote about the vulnerability of air power in Afghanistan. Presumably you also mentioned that in your meeting?
column111: Yes. The U.S. has completely failed to deliver on this. There is no adequate Afghan air force
column112: ranging from maintenance deficiencies to pilot training shortages to operational support capability.
column114: we used to have 26 aircraft in Afghanistan doing that kind of support for the U.S. Army. So even as large as the U.S. military is \u2015 and it\u2019s the most expensive military in the world \u2015 they still had a requirement for extra aviation capacity. So they rented it from the private sector. I thought
column115: Why don\u2019t they let the Afghans do the same thing?
column116: The premise of what I\u2019m laying out with ground mentors and with the air package is that they serve as an adjunct in the Afghan forces
column118: Afghan rules of engagement. The premise of this is a true Afghan-ization.
column119: One big question is what happens if something goes wrong
column120: like it did in Iraq with Blackwater. Who is accountable?
column122: if the guys do an evil act
column123: they can be held to account under the Uniform Code of Military Justice with a trial held in Kabul. I thought long and hard about that. A cell of JAG [Judge Advocate General] lawyers can be detailed to handle this for the contractors that are there
column124: just like they\u2019re there for any active duty forces.
column125: I assume your position on this is related to the yearslong case against a few Blackwater contractors for the killing of 14 people in Iraq.
column127: a week and a half ago
column128: the appeals court threw out the murder conviction [of Nicholas Slatten
column129: who had been sentenced to life in prison]
column130: and they threw out the sentences of the other guys. It was a pretty stinging review of the federal government. They still have to be resentenced. I think they\u2019ll get time served.
column131: The issue there was this: If the government had asked us
column132: we would have preferred to be under the Uniform Code of Military Justice [which regularly tries military crimes where they occur]
column133: because all the guys that were doing that job were former military veterans. They know the deal. Having the trial close to battle makes way more sense than [having it] 7
column134: 000 miles away in a D.C. courtroom with people who have fortunately never seen the aftereffects of a car bomb. But the State Department prohibited that because they didn\u2019t want their people [civilian government employees] held under that standard.
column136: Don\u2019t get me started on the State Department.
column138: It was a turf issue between the agencies. Leave it at that.
column140: back to your discussions with the administration. After Bannon and McMaster and Priebus
column141: who did you talk to next?
column142: I saw [Defense Secretary Jim] Mattis three weeks after that first meeting at the White House
column143: and he just fired away with questions \u2015 practical questions \u2015 for an hour. They were questions like: How could the men operate? Under what authority? How would they be accountable? Basically
column144: how would this actually work? He is a historian. He gets it
column145: He was not as quick to discard [my ideas] as many in the Pentagon bubble would be.
column146: But he also pushed back. He said
column147: Why do you say we have to change the rules of engagement [so a viceroy could have greater autonomy]? I showed him pictures of open-air Taliban victory parades in Afghanistan
column149: hundreds of Taliban fighters with their Taliban flag beating their chests
column151: I later heard from multiple people at NSC [the National Security Council] that Secretary Mattis said at a national security Cabinet meeting that I gave the best analysis of the root problems that have to be fixed in Afghanistan of any he\u2019s seen.
column152: Who were you picturing as a viceroy? A civilian? A military person?
column153: Absolutely not a general. We have enough generals. I was thinking about a guy who had a military and intelligence background in his early career
column154: who spent a long time in business
column156: and who\u2019s also done something very senior in the intelligence community.
column157: It\u2019s not for everybody because that job will
column159: be vilified. You\u2019re making difficult decisions. He\u2019s going to leave a life of total luxury here and go live in a place where he\u2019s worried about being blown up.
column160: Do you know many people like that?
column163: I\u2019ll just say that I floated a name to Steve [Bannon]. He liked it. I took him in and he met him.
column164: You took the viceroy candidate to the White House?
column170: but the president knows him and his wife pretty well. And we\u2019ll have to leave it at that.
column171: The weekend before Trump made his Afghan announcement
column172: he went to Camp David with many members of his Cabinet and national security teams. I heard you were supposed to be there
column174: I was called by three or four reporters saying they wanted comment because they heard I was supposed to go. That was news to me. We were actually at that time hosting a bunch of wounded veterans at my family\u2019s ranch out in Wyoming.
column175: But I think it was a sliding door moment because my concern is that the only people in that room who challenged the consensus were Attorney General [Jeff] Sessions
column176: who I understand spoke passionately about the need to just leave because it\u2019s a mess
column177: and [Office of Management and Budget director] Mick Mulvaney
column178: who as the budget guy said
column179: \u201cDon\u2019t keep signing up for $50 billion forever.\u201d If there\u2019d been another voice there who could have spoken rationally on a cheaper way to accomplish the mission without having to have a whole bunch of uniform forces to do it
column180: it might have carried the day. If Steve Bannon had not been fired
column181: he would have been the voice.
column182: Why do you think the president made the decision he did on Afghanistan?
column183: I think it was partly because of the fiasco in Charlottesville and all the media heat from that. I don\u2019t think the president wanted to take any more pounding doing anything different in Afghanistan
column184: so he went with the most establishment-type position. [Republican Sens.] Lindsey Graham and John McCain are praising him for it. That\u2019s pretty much the Beltway establishment.
column186: We\u2019ll narrow the scope of the interview and leave that out of it. I\u2019m not going to give you multiple avenues to attack me. I still remember that recorder\u2019s running.
column187: Do you think that Trump will ever change course in Afghanistan?
column188: I think the Afghan war has largely been ignored for the last eight years
column189: and now that it\u2019s Mr. Trump\u2019s war
column191: every loss of an Afghan base will be reported
column192: and they will hang it around his neck.
column193: So the door isn\u2019t closed for you and your ideas?
column196: the president needs to figure out how to end this thing. It\u2019s his supporters who are doing the fighting and dying. I just saw a study that said that casualties were one of the big issues that swung voters to Trump in districts in Wisconsin
column197: Michigan and Pennsylvania. They liked that he was outspoken. \u201cHey
column198: let\u2019s stop the same insanity we\u2019ve been doing.\u201d
column199: Did you and Steve Bannon ever talk about using private contractors in areas beyond Afghanistan?
column202: That\u2019s for next time. I\u2019ll just say that there are a lot of places [where]\xa0the fires of insurgency have to be put out because these constant failed states export terrorism and refugees. That\u2019s bad.
column204: I\u2019ve met him. I certainly met him during the transition. It was at an event; it was not preplanned. But I never met him on this.
column205: What are your feelings about his presidency so far?
column206: I still have high hopes that as a businessman who has restructured problematic or failing efforts
column207: that he\u2019s still going to come to the right conclusion on this.
column208: Let\u2019s move to the report in The Washington Post that claimed that the UAE
column210: set up a meeting in the Seychelles in January between you and someone close to Putin
column211: with the idea that you\u2019d create a \u201cback channel\u201d between the incoming Trump administration and Russia.
column212: That was honestly a private business meeting that came about because [a Middle Eastern businessman I was talking to]\xa0said
column214: there\u2019s this Russian guy you should meet.\u201d I had a beer. I think he had a vodka. It was a quick meeting. I can drink a beer fast.
column215: So the allegations of you setting up secret back channels \u2026
column217: totally baseless. The bizarre thing is
column218: it\u2019s connected to the left\u2019s whole fantasy about this Trump-Russia election collusion
column219: right? So I met with some Russian investment manager whose name I don\u2019t remember in January
column220: which is two months after the election. So if this grand conspiracy is true
column221: why the hell would I need to meet with any Russians for any back channel stuff?
column222: And the thing that really bothers me about it is the only reason The Washington Post got the story \u2015 and I have zero doubt about this \u2015 is from signals intelligence that the Obama administration was leaking. [Editor\u2019s note: No proof of this has been reported.]
column223: I don\u2019t want to live in a bureaucratic super state with unlimited surveillance powers. There should be certain rights and privileges a citizen enjoys
column224: and having your private business communications leaked by the security apparatus by a political party for political ends
column227: There are some electrons not worth wasting.
column228: You seem very aware of the fact that you became a villain during the Iraq War.
column231: the hard-core anti-war left went after the troops. In Iraq
column232: they went after the contractors. It was politics. Blackwater represented everything they loved to hate and I was the sole owner. I didn\u2019t have a board with a bunch of former generals. I didn\u2019t pay all the Republican Party and the Democratic Party fundraising apparatuses
column233: but it was a business group that executed exactly what the customer needed us to do. We grew and performed. It was actually built on merit
column235: It seemed as if you disappeared after the war \u2015 at least until the WSJ op-ed.
column236: Here\u2019s the thing. In the Obama administration
column237: I stopped trying. There was no point. Now
column238: there\u2019s a chance for a fair hearing.
column239: You must enjoy feeling like you\u2019re back in the game.
column241: I put everything else on hold to push a different approach in Afghanistan
column242: and it\u2019s been a big goose egg so far.
column243: Do you think you\u2019d revive Blackwater domestically?
column244: Maybe. I still own the name. But I have no plans to start a U.S. defense contracting business.
column246: I would encourage any objective observer of all the insurgencies going on around the world to ask which one of them has the U.S. actually
column247: directly assisted in ending. Which one?
column248: Let the record show the witness said zero.

Trump To Donate $1 Million To Hurricane Harvey Relief Funds

UPDATE:\xa0Sarah Huckabee Sanders said during a Friday press briefing that the president still hadn\u2019t decided which organization he\u2019d give his million dollar donation to.

as well as Louisiana.\xa0

A Third Of Americans Say They Know Someone Affected By Harvey

|[

More than a third of Americans say they or someone they know has been affected by the flooding in Texas caused by Hurricane Harvey
column2: according to a new HuffPost/YouGov poll
column3: which finds a generally positive initial reaction to the response by President Donald Trump and the federal government.
column4: Four percent of those polled say they\u2019ve been directly affected
column5: 12 percent that someone in their family has been affected
column6: and 22 percent that someone else they know has been. With some people falling in multiple categories
column7: that adds up to a total 34 percent who know someone who\u2019s felt the impact of the storm. In the South
column8: that total number is 40 percent.
column9: For some
column10: the effect has been tangential or relatively minor. Some say they or a relative have been forced to postpone a trip
column11: have temporarily lost power or have been unable to get to work in the past several days.
column12: Others say the effects on them or their loved ones have been far more serious.
column13: \u201cMom\u2019s house in Rockport was destroyed. She\u2019s 84 years old so we will have to figure out her insurance
column14: and apply for assistance
column15: \u201d wrote one Texas man. \u201cMy father-in-law lived in Port Aransas
column16: Tx. He is still unsure of the condition of his home. They are all staying with us 100 miles north.\u201d
column17: \u201cOur daughter may have water damage to her house
column18: \u201d another Texas resident wrote. \u201cA friend does have water damage. My husband and I were up all night watching the water level at our house
column19: our daughter\u2019s house and our friend\u2019s house.\u201d
column20: Asked how his family had been affected
column21: one man wrote simply: \u201cHave not been able to get hold of them.\u201d
column22: A 51 percent majority of Americans say they approve of the federal government\u2019s efforts to handle the flooding in Texas
column23: the survey finds
column24: with just 16 percent disapproving
column25: and the remaining third unsure. Opinions of Trump\u2019s performance are also positive
column26: with 42 percent approving
column27: 24 percent disapproving and the rest uncertain. (The survey was conducted almost entirely prior to Trump\u2019s visit to Texas on Tuesday
column28: during which he praised the turnout for his event and
column29: according to pool reports
column30: made little mention of the victims of the storm.)
column31: Perhaps unsurprisingly
column32: Americans\u2019 ratings of Trump\u2019s performance were far more polarized than their opinions about the federal government overall. Among those polled who were asked about the federal government\u2019s response
column33: voters who supported the president in last year\u2019s election were 35 points likelier than those who supported Hillary Clinton to approve. Among those asked specifically about Trump
column34: the gap in approval between Trump and Clinton voters was twice as big.
column35: Brock Long
column36: Trump\u2019s pick to run the Federal Emergency Management Agency
column37: \xa0has decades of experience in emergency management and\xa0has been hailed by a former FEMA official as \u201cprobably one of the best prepared (people) that the country could ask for.\u201d
column38: \u201cFEMA is going to be [in Texas] for years
column39: \u201d Long said Sunday in an interview with CNN. \u201cThis disaster is going to be a landmark event. ... While we\u2019re focused on response right now and helping Texas respond
column40: we\u2019re already pushing forward recovery housing teams. We\u2019re already pushing forward forces to be on the ground to implement the National Flood Insurance Program policies and doing the inspections that we need. We\u2019re setting up and gearing up for the next couple years.\u201d
column41: Americans are split on how much the nation currently spends on disaster relief\xa0\u2015 32 percent say it spends too little
column42: while 33 percent say it spends the right amount. Just 6 percent say the country spends too much.
column43: They\u2019re generally confident
column44: if not deeply so
column45: about their own areas\u2019 abilities to withstand a disaster. A near-majority
column46: 49 percent
column47: say they think their state government would be at least somewhat well-prepared to handle a disaster
column48: although just 13 percent say they\u2019d be very prepared. About three in 10 say their state would be not very or not at all well-prepared.
column49: The survey also finds that 47 percent of the public believes climate change played at least a somewhat important role in causing the flooding in Texas
column50: with just under a third believing it played little or no role.
column51: Use the widget below to further explore the results of the HuffPost/YouGov survey

Hurricane Harvey Response At Risk If Congress Misses Looming Deadlines

|[

As Hurricane Harvey continues to wreak havoc on the Houston area
column2: national politicians have promised they will be there to help those affected by the storm.\xa0
column3: But they don\u2019t have much time. Congress returns to work on Sept. 5. Lawmakers will then have less than a month to meet several crucial deadlines affecting whether the federal government will actually be able to help out.\xa0
column4: The big deadline is Sept. 30.\xa0Congress needs to pass legislation to keep the government funded beyond that date. Otherwise
column5: it will shut down. That day is also when the National Flood Insurance Program\u2019s authorization expires.
column6: When the government shuts down
column7: federal workers are divided into two categories: essential and non-essential. Those in the former category are allowed to continue working
column8: while people in the second are furloughed until the government reopens.\xa0
column9: The Federal Emergency Management Agency would continue to lead rescue operations for Harvey in the case of a shutdown
column10: with many of its employees fitting into the essential category. But that doesn\u2019t mean FEMA won\u2019t be affected.\xa0
column11: Daniel Watson was the spokesman for FEMA in 2013
column12: the last time the government shut down. At the time
column13: the agency was helping Colorado recover from massive floods. Watson said the agency\u2019s response work was not impacted
column14: but FEMA did have to devote resources to dealing with the shutdown
column15: rather than focusing all its attention on disaster relief.\xa0
column16: \u201cThe biggest impact was FEMA needing to take all these additional steps that you don\u2019t usually have to do \u2015 identifying
column18: does this person need to be here or not
column19: \u2019 rather than just doing the job
column20: \u201d Watson said.\xa0
column21: The bigger issue with FEMA is what happens with its Disaster Relief Fund
column22: which could soon run out of money unless Congress appropriates more.\xa0FEMA gives out two types of assistance: public (which goes to governments) and individual (checks directly to individuals to cover damages). All that money comes from the Disaster Relief Fund.\xa0
column23: According to FEMA\u2019s most recent report
column24: issued in early August
column25: the fund will have between $1.3 billion and $1.5 billion at the end of September. That likely will not be nearly enough for Harvey.
column26: As a comparison
column27: about a month after Hurricane Sandy hit the East Coast
column28: FEMA had already sent out around $1.9 billion.\xa0
column29: \u201cIn the event of a government shutdown
column30: FEMA will continue to support survivors and communities affected by Hurricane Harvey
column31: \u201d agency spokeswoman Justine Whelan told HuffPost. \u201cFEMA makes payments for Individual Assistance and Public Assistance
column32: until funds are no longer available in the Disaster Relief Fund.\u201d
column33: FEMA also operates the National Flood Insurance Program
column34: which is already more than $24 billion in debt. If it expires Sept. 30
column35: millions of homeowners may be without coverage. The program has a $30 billion borrowing limit
column36: and with massive new claims coming in from Harvey
column37: congressional action will be needed to raise the ceiling. (Congress did the same thing after Hurricane Katrina.) In Houston alone
column38: more than 1 million people have federal flood insurance coverage.\xa0
column39: Lawmakers on both sides of the aisle say they want to reform the program\xa0\u2015 it pays out far more than it collects in premiums \u2015 but there isn\u2019t much time to figure something out before the next reauthorization.
column40: \u201cDetails are still being worked through
column41: but the flood insurance program will be reauthorized
column42: \u201d said AshLee Strong
column43: spokeswoman for House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.).\xa0
column44: A senior Democratic aide
column45: who requested anonymity to speak openly
column46: said he was less certain that reauthorization would happen
column47: predicting that a short-term extension was more likely either on its own
column48: or as part of a continuing resolution to keep the government open \u2015 in part because Republicans aren\u2019t unified on what to do.\xa0
column49: A big sticking point is what to do about the flood insurance program\u2019s billions in debt. Rep. Maxine Waters (D-Calif.) has proposed legislation forgiving the debt
column50: arguing that it\u2019s unlikely to be repaid unless the program ends up being actuarially sound and starts making money. In other words
column51: Congress would need to change the structure of the program.
column52: \u201cThe current level of debt is wholly unsustainable
column53: \u201d Waters said in a statement last year. \u201cNot only is the NFIP spending billions of dollars just to pay off this debt
column54: but it is increasing fees on policyholders that are already struggling with rising premiums. Congress must forgive this debt so that we can begin to approach broader reauthorization efforts with a clean slate and provide residents in flood-prone areas with a stable
column55: affordable program in the wake of unexpected disasters.\u201d
column56: Finally
column57: there\u2019s the issue of emergency aid legislation allocating money to help people affected by Harvey. These measures used to be easy and noncontroversial
column58: but not any longer. The big questions\xa0now are whether the funding will be offset by cuts to other government programs
column59: and whether unrelated items will be attached to the legislation.\xa0
column60: Texas Republicans are in a tough spot
column61: likely wanting as much aid for their constituents as possible \u2015 but also having to justify the fact that the vast majority of them opposed emergency aid after Hurricane Sandy.
column62: Democrats have said they would not go along with any Republican attempts to offset Harvey relief funding.
column63: \u201cRepublicans must be ready to join Democrats in passing a timely relief bill that makes all necessary resources available through emergency spending
column64: \u201d House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) said in a statement. \u201cWith the National Flood Insurance Program expiring at the end of September
column65: House Republicans must also move swiftly to ensure that affordable flood insurance continues to be available to communities across our country.\u201d
column66: A final potential stumbling block could be President Donald Trump. The president has threatened to block government funding legislation and shut down the government if he doesn\u2019t get Congress to approve funding for his border wall \u2015 which he continues to insist Mexico will eventually pay for anyway.\xa0

GOP Illinois Governor Signs Major Voting Reform Into Law

|[

Illinois Gov. Bruce Rauner (R) signed a law Monday authorizing different state agencies to automatically register voters when they interact with them
column2: marking a huge victory for voting advocates after Rauner vetoed similar legislation a year ago.
column3: Illinois is the 10th state to adopt automatic voter registration
column4: a process by which people are automatically registered to vote or have their information updated on the rolls when they interact with the state\u2019s motor vehicle agency or some other state agencies. Oregon was the first state to adapt automatic voter registration in 2015
column5: and advocates say\xa0the reform can significantly strengthen voting rights.
column6: While it\u2019s too early to assess the overall impact of automatic voter registration
column7: early indications\xa0suggest that it could significantly bolster voter participation.
column8: In Illinois
column9: Rauner\u2019s signature is particularly significant not only because he is a Republican \u2015 most of the places that have adopted automatic voter registration are heavily Democratic \u2015 but because he vetoed\xa0automatic voter legislation in August of 2016. At the time
column10: he said it would open the door to voter fraud.
column11: After the state\u2019s legislature failing to override his veto
column12: voting advocates brought up the measure again this year. They tweaked the language making it so that voters had to affirm they were eligible to vote when they registered and giving them the option to opt-out at the time of a transaction with the state agency. The new law also allows the state to verify voter rolls using data collected from state agencies participating in automatic voter registration
column13: something that will significantly improve accuracy
column14: according to Abe Scarr
column15: the director of Illinois PIRG
column16: which was a member of the Just Democracy coalition that pushed for automatic voter registration.
column17: The retooled legislation passed both chambers of the Illinois legislature unanimously.
column18: Advocates appealed to legislators by emphasizing the ways the new law would save money and improve the accuracy and security of voter rolls
column19: Scarr said.
column20: \u201cWe kind of came in thinking the efficiency and saving taxpayer dollars would be a real big selling point and it was fine
column21: but it was often the accuracy and security message that worked both with Republican legislators and more broadly with the public
column22: \u201d he said.\xa0
column23: Andy Kang
column24: legal director of the Chicago chapter of Asian Americans Advancing Justice
column25: another member of the coalition
column26: said Republicans and immigrants were able to find common ground on concerns over election security.
column27: \u201cWe don\u2019t want to see accidental voter registration to ineligible folks
column28: either. There are very severe immigration consequences
column29: \u201d Kang said. \u201cWe were very careful and put in a lot of thought about addressing how this automatic process would work to make accidental [registration] much less likely
column30: to have cleaner lists of eligible voters and have a more accurate system long term.\u201d
column31: \u201cI think when we were able to find that common ground there
column32: we had that same concern
column33: same goal \u2015 maybe we\u2019re coming at it a little bit differently \u2015 that was something we could think about when talking to Republicans
column34: \u201d he added.
column35: Scarr said advocates also accepted a request from Rauner\u2019s office to include the Department of Natural Resources and Department of Financial and Professional Regulation to be agencies that offered automatic voter registration.
column36: \u201cThis was never stated
column37: but they\u2019re more symbolically Republican agencies
column38: you know
column39: hunters
column40: fishers
column41: small business people
column42: \u201d Scarr said.
column43: For voting rights advocates
column44: who want registration in as many state agencies as possible
column45: it was easy to accept.\xa0
column46: Even though Rauner\u2019s office said in May he intended to decide on the legislation
column47: he had been largely silent on it since then. Former Missouri Secretary of State Jason Kander (D)
column48: who is now leading a voter advocacy group called Let America Vote
column49: had\xa0penned an op-ed\xa0earlier in August speculating that Rauner might veto the legislation to prevent new voters from getting registered in hopes of boosting his election chances next year.
column50: But Rauner\u2019s signature on Monday will immediately allow Illinois election officials to begin to develop guidelines for implementing the law.
column51: Automatic voter registration at motor vehicle agencies will start on July 1
column53: and a year later at other state agencies.
column54: \u201cPassing a law is not the end of a campaign
column55: it\u2019s an opportunity and so it\u2019s very important to us that we stay engaged with the implementing agencies which are numerous
column56:
\u201d Scarr said. \u201cWe\u2019re very excited and proud of where we\u2019ve gotten to but it\u2019s not done until the law goes into effect and has the outcomes that we\u2019ve promised and advocated for the last two years.\u201d

Trump Does His Dirty Work|[

As a Category 4 hurricane rapidly approached the coast of Texas on Friday night \u2015 causing millions to run for their lives and worry for their homes
column3: their pets
column4: their family photos
column5: their property and their livelihoods \u2015 President Donald Trump\xa0escaped to Camp David
column6: where he unleashed his own storm of controversial news
column7: seemingly hoping no one would notice.
column8: Trump signed a memo\xa0banning transgender individuals from newly enlisting in the military and pardoned a former sheriff with a history of racist actions. One of his most controversial advisers resigned
column9: and his administration teased they\u2019d end a program that could put many young undocumented immigrants at risk of deportation. These controversial announcements all came as Hurricane Harvey bore down on the Texas Gulf Coast.
column10: The barrage of news coming from the White House
column11: with each story notable in its own right
column12: illustrated both an administration prone to crisis and ill-equipped to handle them
column13: whether natural or self-made.
column14: The U.S. news was largely dominated by Hurricane Harvey throughout the day Friday
column15: as the storm quickly escalated from Category 2 to Category 4
column16: with winds escalating to 130 miles per hour. Millions of Texans were urged to flee their homes
column17: with Republican Gov. Greg Abbott encouraging people to evacuate even if it wasn\u2019t mandatory.
column18: \u201cIt is not hyperbole to say that if the forecast verifies
column19: Texas is about to experience one of the worst natural disasters in the history of the state
column20: \u201d Abbott said Friday in a written request for Trump to declare a major disaster.
column21: Trump wished Texans \u201cgood luck\u201d as he departed the White House on Friday for Camp David in Maryland. But he and his administration seemed eager to use the natural disaster as a distraction.
column22: Just after 6 p.m. EDT Friday
column23: Military Times reported\xa0that Trump signed a memo banning transgender men and women from enlisting in the military.\xa0The presidential memo also tasks Defense Secretary Jim Mattis with determining whether to remove already enlisted transgender individuals from service
column24: and it bars the military from funding gender confirmation surgery.
column25: Trump\u2019s initial announcement that transgender individuals wouldn\u2019t be allowed to serve
column26: made in a July 26 series of tweets with no input from the Department of Defense
column27: was widely criticized by military officials
column28: members of the armed forces and lawmakers from both sides of the aisle.
column29: Then
column30: just after 8 p.m.
column31: the White House issued a statement that Trump had pardoned Joe Arpaio
column32: the former sheriff of Maricopa County in Arizona. Arpaio had been found in contempt of court for violating a judge\u2019s order and unlawfully detaining individuals his officers claimed might be in the country illegally. He became infamous for making inmates in his jails wear pink underwear and sleep in tents\xa0when temperatures at times topped 110 degrees.
column33: Trump and Arpaio worked together to try to disprove Barack Obama\u2019s ability to serve as president
column34: with Arpaio leading an \u201cinvestigation\u201d\xa0into the authenticity of Obama\u2019s birth certificate that Trump once praised as \u201csuccessful.\u201d In his statement Friday
column35: Trump called Arpaio a \u201cworthy candidate for a Presidential pardon
column36: \u201d the first of Trump\u2019s presidency.
column37: Trump does have the constitutional authority to issue pardons
column38: but the timing of Arpaio\u2019s pardon caused many to question Trump\u2019s priorities.
column39: Trump\u2019s pardon
column40: given to a man widely seen as racist
column41: came at a time when many are still criticizing the president\u2019s response to the white supremacist protests in Charlottesville
column42: Virginia. Trump\u2019s\xa0initial unwillingness to explicitly condemn racists\xa0was so widely panned that Trump felt a need to defend his responses in a\xa020-minute rant\xa0at a Phoenix rally Tuesday.
column43: And according to WTSP\u2019s Noah Pransky\xa0and CNN
column44: Trump deliberately timed the announcement of Arpaio\u2019s pardon to come Friday evening \u2015 Arpaio\u2019s lawyer found out about the pardon at 6 p.m. Eastern Friday
column45: and the announcement wasn\u2019t made until 8 p.m. Eastern time
column46: a full two hours\xa0later and a mere 30 minutes after Hurricane Harvey was upgraded to a Category 4 storm.
column47: Trump teased the pardon of Arpaio on Tuesday night at the Phoenix rally but said he wouldn\u2019t grant the pardon then because he didn\u2019t \u201cwant to cause any controversy.\u201d\xa0
column48: Also late Friday
column49: it was announced that Sebastian Gorka
column50: a controversial adviser to Trump
column51: had left his White House job.
column52: There were also reports throughout Friday afternoon that Trump was considering ending the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program (DACA)
column53: which would strip legal work permits from hundreds of thousands of undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children.\xa0
column54: In any other administration
column55: any one of these announcements could have dominated the news cycle for days. In the Trump era
column56: however
column57: it appears every action was taken to ensure these decisions would be buried by Saturday
column58: when the destruction of Harvey takes over.

Venezuela Holds Nationwide Armed Forces Exercises After Trump Threat

|[

CARACAS
column2: Aug 26 (Reuters) - Venezuela held nationwide armed forces exercises on Saturday
column3: calling on civilians to join reserve units to defend against a possible attack after U.S. President Donald Trump warned that a \u201cmilitary option\u201d was on the table for the crisis-hit country.
column4: Trump made the threat two weeks ago and on Friday he signed an order prohibiting dealings in new debt from the Venezuelan government or its oil company
column5: a move to hobble financing that Trump says is fueling socialist President Nicolas Maduro\u2019s \u201cdictatorship.\u201d
column6: \u201cAgainst the belligerent threats of the United States
column7: all Venezuelans between the ages of 18 and 60 are required to contribute to the integral defense of the nation
column8: \u201d said an announcement broadcast early on Saturday on state television.
column9: Maduro used Trump\u2019s threat to try to energize his political base
column10: broadcasting images of rifle-carrying civilians negotiating obstacle courses and learning hand-to-hand combat. The government created the hashtag #EsHoraDeDefenderLaPatria
column11: which translates as \u201cIt\u2019s Time To Defend The Homeland
column12: \u201d to promote the exercises.
column13: TV images showed Venezuelans young and old entering military reserve registration centers. But there was no evidence that registration reached far beyond government employees and Maduro\u2019s Socialist Party loyalists.
column14: Scenes were aired of camouflaged sharp-shooters firing their weapons while military commanders gave fiery speeches at \u201canti-imperialist\u201d rallies. More exercises were scheduled for Sunday.
column15: Opposition figure and former presidential candidate Henrique Capriles sent a tweet dismissing the weekend training program as an expensive farce. He said Maduro should focus instead on bringing down Venezuela\u2019s high crime rate.
column16: Diplomatic tensions increased last month when a legislative superbody called the constituent assembly was elected at Maduro\u2019s behest. It has the power to legislate
column17: bypassing the opposition-controlled congress.
column18: Maduro says the new assembly is Venezuela\u2019s only hope of restoring peace after months of deadly anti-government protests.
column19: Leaders of the fractious opposition coalition boycotted the July 30 election of the assembly
column20: branding it an affront to democracy. They called for an early presidential election
column21: which Maduro would likely lose as his popularity sinks along with an economy blighted by triple-digit inflation and food shortages.
column22: Trump\u2019s threat of military action played into Maduro\u2019s hands by supporting his oft-repeated assertion that the U.S. \u201cempire\u201d has been waging economic war on Venezuela and wants to invade the country to steal its vast oil reserves.
column23: The idea had been laughed off as absurd by opposition and U.S. officials before Trump said on Aug. 11 that \u201ca military option is certainly something we could pursue\u201d as a way of ending Venezuela\u2019s crisis.

President Donald Trump\u2019s pardon of former Arizona sheriff Joe Arpaio amounts to\xa0an endorsement of the idea of concentration camps
column2: says a journalist who has reported on the global history of the deadly facilities.
column3: Arpaio referred to his own county jail as a \u201cconcentration camp.\u201d\xa0For over two decades
column4: he operated \u201cTent City
column5: \u201d where detainees were kept in brutal conditions
column6: including temperatures soaring well above 100 degrees Farenheit. They were also forced to work on chain gangs and to wear pink undergarments as a form of humiliation. Arpaio was convicted in July of criminal contempt for ignoring a court order prohibiting the detention of people based on mere suspicions about their legal status.
column7: In an email to HuffPost Saturday
column8: Andrea Pitzer
column9: the author of One Long Night: A Global History of Concentration Camps
column10: \xa0defined a concentration camp as a \u201cmass civilian detention outside the standard legal process
column11: usually on the basis of race
column12: ethnicity
column13: or political activity.\u201d While Pitzer said Tent City was a prison technically constructed to hold those convicted by law
column14: it bore familiar elements to a concentration camp
column15: including \u201cbrutal dehuminization.\u201d
column16: \u201cOnce Arpaio began neighborhood sweeps and traffic stops deliberately targeting Latinos
column17: and then detaining them without charges
column18: his whole enterprise tilted further toward being a concentration camp for that set of detainees
column19: \u201d she wrote. \u201cAnd even for those who had been convicted of crimes
column20: it was a harrowing
column21: often deadly experience.\u201d\xa0
column22: Pitzer said Trump pardoning Arpaio legitimized the 85-year-old former sheriff\u2019s operation.
column23: \u201cWhen it was just Arpaio and his deputies doing it
column24: it was a freelance
column25: loose-cannon operation. What happened yesterday is that the President of the United States put his position behind it and used executive power to bless these tactics
column26: \u201d she wrote. \u201cHistorically
column27: when this kind of thing has happened
column28: it\u2019s encouraged other people to take up the same tactics. I think we need to hear from the Department of Justice whether official guidance is forthcoming about the use of these strategies by law enforcement.\u201d
column29: The White House said Friday Arpaio deserved a pardon because of his history in law enforcement. Trump has faced widespread criticism for his decision to pardon Arpaio
column30:
including from Sen. John McCain\xa0(R-Ariz.).

Texans Ride Out The Fury Of The Storm Inside A La Quinta Inn

VICTORIA
column2: Texas \u2015 When the mandatory evacuation order for this southeastern Texas town came Thursday
column3: the first thing Sabrina Hallam thought about was where to send her guests. The La Quinta Inn in Victoria
column4: where she works as a general manager
column5: was fully booked with people who had evacuated from towns along the coast.\xa0
column6: But once the guests were gone
column7: Hallam \u2015 along with some other staff members and the hotel\u2019s owner

column9: \u201cWe were thinking
column10: \u2018When this thing is over

column17: Those who stayed had faced a rough night Friday

column20: kicking up sparks as it went.
column21: One wall of a tower atop the beige
column22: four-story hotel was completely ripped off as of Saturday
column23: and some of the surrounding wood was charred. \u201cI don\u2019t know what happened to the tower
column24: but we could hear it
column25: \u201d Hallam said. \u201cIt sounded like someone drove a truck into the building.\u201d\xa0
column26: Inside
column27: the 70-some people
column28: including members of Hallam\u2019s family
column29: were still waiting for the worst of Harvey to pass. They\u2019d lost power overnight
column30: but a generator allowed them to keep their phones charged and a portable gas stove in the kitchen allowed them to cook. \xa0

column35: presenting a high risk of catastrophic flooding
column36: according to the National Hurricane Center.\xa0
column37: Shane Castillo and his fianc\xe9e
column38: Cristina Narajano
column39: were among the people gathered at the hotel Saturday.
column40: The couple had been living on the streets for the last six months
column41: after Castillo lost a job in construction right before an emergency back operation. Their luck had finally changed three days ago
column42: when they moved into a five-room house that they were helping the landlord refurbish.\xa0
column43: But the storm winds knocked a big tree onto the house
column44: tearing open the roof
column45: Castillo told HuffPost. They stayed as the rain poured inside until around 6:30 a.m.

column47: \u201cWe were just coming out here and by God\u2019s grace these people let us in
column48: \u201d Castillo said. \u201cIf it wasn\u2019t for this hotel
column49: I don\u2019t know where we\u2019d be right now.\u201d\xa0
column50: They said they were uncertain what they would do once the storm passed and the flood waters receded. \u201cIt was hard enough finding help in the first place
column51: \u201d Narajano said
column52: referring to the couple\u2019s previous housing struggles. \u201cNow
column53: everyone\u2019s going to need help.\u201d\xa0\xa0\xa0
column54: Hallam\u2019s father
column55: Morris Maretick
column56: who had come inland from his farm to ride out the storm

column58: but couldn\u2019t pass through a series of downed electric poles.\xa0
column59: Hallam said she\u2019d already heard that one of her employees lost her home: \u201cThe apartment is gone
column60: but she\u2019s safe so far.\u201d
column61: Trees and power lines were down across many of the roadways in Victoria
column62: making some of them impassable. Windows were boarded up or taped over
column63: and gas stations
column64: stores and restaurants remained closed. Yet a number of vehicles were driving around.\xa0The Texas National Guard was out assessing the damage here.
column65: There was no widespread flooding
column66: but some low-lying streets were already under water
column67:
with more rain expected to continue overnight.\xa0

He also asserted that NAFTA was the \u201cworst trade deal ever made\u201d.

The Inside Story Of How Congress Sent The Stock Market Tumbling

|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 Nearly nine years ago
column2: the country was sliding into the Great Recession. Wall Street banks were collapsing. Everywhere
column3: \xa0people were losing their homes to foreclosure. The unemployment rate was spiking. The Bush administration
column4: hobbled by the Iraq War and the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina
column5: was desperate to put together an economic relief bill that could
column6: for the moment
column7: stop the bleeding. Congress was loath to trust then-President George W. Bush and bail out Wall Street \u2015 especially on the eve of a presidential election.
column8: All of this came to a head in early September 2008
column9: when the House of Representatives was set to vote on a\xa0$700 billion relief bill.
column10: This week\u2019s episode of HuffPost\u2019s \u201cCandidate Confessional\u201d podcast is about that fateful
column11: failed vote
column12: which sent the stock market plummeting and embarrassed both the White House and Congress. It is told through a joint interview with two key House staffers who witnessed it all: Michael Steel
column13: who was the press secretary for then-Minority Leader John Boehner (R-Ohio)
column14: and Brendan Daly
column15: the communications director for then-Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.).\xa0
column16: \u201cThis is another shit sandwich that we\u2019re going to have to eat on behalf of the administration
column17: \u201d Steel said
column18: describing how the House GOP caucus felt when the bill was first introduced. \u201cBoehner referred to it explicitly in those terms. And it was absolutely clear that this was going to be a totally politically toxic vote.\u201d
column19: Convincing reluctant members to vote for a $700 billion bailout of banks that figured prominently in the economic collapse was always going to be a tricky endeavor. But things took a turn for the bizarre when Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.) suspended his presidential campaign to come to Washington
column20: as Steel described it
column21: to try and look busy.
column22: \u201cIt was bizarre
column23: \u201d Steel said. \u201cHe\u2019s a candidate
column24: so he couldn\u2019t just go to his Senate office
column25: so he comes to Boehner\u2019s office and basically spends several hours hanging out in the minority offices on the House side of the Capitol. At this point
column26: various members are coming in to talk to him about the crisis and what they think ought to be done
column27: but there wasn\u2019t like a vetting process or a procedure
column28: so it was sort of any member with the gumption or the thought that maybe I contribute something to the situation.\u201d
column29: Instead of being informed
column30: McCain looked to be out of his depths. He barely spoke when a bipartisan group of leaders met to discuss matters in the White House. At that point
column31: it had become clear that Republican factions were rebelling against the idea of giving the Bush administration more money. But Democrats were
column32: of course
column33: skeptical of anything Bush touched
column34: too.
column35: \u201cEven though everyone agreed that we needed to do something
column36: we weren\u2019t just going to give a blank check
column37: \u201d Daly explained.
column38: Despite misgivings within both parties
column39: there was an understanding among leadership that each side would bring enough votes
column40: so that the bill would pass
column41: since the alternative \u2015 failure \u2015 was unthinkable. But when the legislation reached the floor
column42: the numbers just didn\u2019t materialize. Republicans blamed a speech from Pelosi that cast blame on them for getting into this mess. Democrats
column43: led by then-Rep. Barney Frank (D-Mass.)
column44: mocked the idea that hurt feelings had compelled Republicans to tank the economy.
column45: Both sides were stunned as the Dow stock market index kept falling.
column46: \u201cYou\u2019re like
column47: \u2018What the hell just happened?\u2019\u201d Daly said.
column48: There was no Plan B.
column49: \u201cHouse Republican leaders went back into Boehner\u2019s office\u201d after the vote
column50: Steel recalled. \u201cBoehner fired up a Camel and said
column51: \u2018What next?\u2019 And we talked about how we needed to do a press availability. We had to offer an explanation for why the vote failed. \u2026 And at that point
column52: we didn\u2019t have a plan for what was next.\u201d

Donald Trump Says He's The Best Dealmaker. Negotiation Experts Say Otherwise.

|[

WASHINGTON \u2015 Donald Trump is the best at making deals. The best! He\u2019ll tell you himself by tweeting unsolicited advice on how to win in a negotiation or bragging about his book\xa0The Art of the Deal (which he didn\u2019t actually write
column2: but whatever).
column3: Now we can see for ourselves how the president puts his deal-making skills to work. Last week
column4: The Washington Post released transcripts of two phone calls Trump had with foreign leaders in January \u2014 one with Mexican President Enrique Pe\xf1a Nieto and another with Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull. It\u2019s a rare window into how Trump works his magic with people one-on-one when he doesn\u2019t think anyone is watching.
column5: There were no deals made on either call. Trump threatened Pe\xf1a Nieto
column6: a top U.S. ally
column7: with tariffs on Mexican goods and then warned he\u2019d never meet with him unless he stopped saying publicly that Mexico won\u2019t pay for Trump\u2019s promised border wall. In a heated exchange with Turnbull
column8: also a key U.S. ally
column9: Trump vented about the \u201cstupid deal\u201d the United States had made with Australia to accept refugees into the country. He all but hung up on Turnbull in the end.
column10: Is this as bananas as it sounds? Or maybe Trump is deploying clever
column11: art-of-the-deal tactics that casual observers might miss?
column12: We asked experts in business and diplomatic negotiation to weigh in.
column13: \u201cHis skills are few
column14: \u201d John Oesch
column15: an associate professor at the Rotman School of Management at the University of Toronto
column16: said in an email. \u201cHe has relied on power (or perceived power)
column17: threats
column18: and treating people very poorly to get what he wants. Most negotiation scholars agree that power is an unsustainable way to resolve conflict and a poor negotiating technique
column19: unless you want only to take from the other party and not create any value for either side.\u201d
column20: Anthony Wanis-St. John
column21: an associate professor at the School of International Service at American University
column22: said Trump\u2019s approach was \u201cvery transactional
column23: \u201d a style that may have served him well in commercial real estate but will flop in international relations.
column24: \u201cHe\u2019s treating Pe\xf1a Nieto as if he were a merchant and he were a souvenir purchaser haggling for a price
column25: \u201d said Wanis-St. John. \u201cThis is ill-suited for complex policy decisions that require much more persuasion and problem solving. It makes Trump look a little venal
column26: a little weak. Not like the president of a great power.\u201d
column27: But some saw a deeper level of negotiation taking place
column28: even in a constructive way. Daniel Shapiro
column29: an associate professor of psychology at Harvard Medical School and director of the Harvard International Negotiation Program
column30: said if you look past each leader\u2019s stated position and consider his underlying interests
column31: there\u2019s a lot of overlap.
column32: With the border wall
column33: for example
column34: Trump and Pe\xf1a Nieto disagreed on everything about it
column35: but both worried about losing credibility if they budged in their positions. As for accepting refugees from Australia
column36: Trump worried about looking foolish for taking them in after imposing his travel ban
column37: and Turnbull didn\u2019t want to be strong-armed into breaking a U.S.-Australia agreement. The common denominator
column38: says Shapiro
column39: is saving face.
column40: \u201cNobody wants to feel taken. Effective negotiators recognize that once we understand each other\u2019s underlying interests
column41: we can truly invent options for mutual gain
column42: \u201d said Shapiro
column43: who wrote the book Negotiating the Nonnegotiable: How to Resolve Your Most Emotionally Charged Conflicts. \u201cThese leaders behind closed doors need to feel comfortable sharing information with one another so they can start figuring out options that address each of their constituency\u2019s interests.\u201d
column44: There\u2019s no question
column45: though
column46: that Trump\u2019s default is bullying people to get his way. One of the first stories he tells in The Art of the Deal is about a call he made to a bank executive to try to help an older woman
column47: Mrs. Hill
column48: whose farm was facing foreclosure. Her husband had killed himself in the hopes his life insurance would save the farm
column49: but it turned out it wasn\u2019t enough. The bank executive told Trump the bank was moving ahead with auctioning off the farm
column50: and there was nothing he could do about it.
column51: \u201cThat really got me going
column52: \u201d Trump writes. \u201cI said to the guy
column53: \u2018You listen to me. If you do foreclose
column54: I\u2019ll personally bring a lawsuit for murder against you and your bank
column55: on the grounds that you harassed Mrs. Hill\u2019s husband to death.\u2019 All of a sudden the bank officer sounded very nervous and said he\u2019d get right back to me. Sometimes it pays to be a little wild.\u201d
column56: His belligerent approach to negotiating is an example of what experts call distributive bargaining \u2014 making outrageous demands and hoping the other side gives ground in a zero-sum situation
column57: says Fen Osler Hampson
column58: a distinguished fellow at the Centre for International Governance Innovation in Canada. The problem with applying this tactic to something like
column59: say
column60: threatening tariffs on Mexican imports is that it would damage the U.S. economy
column61: too
column62: by driving up prices of products.
column63: \u201cAs we\u2019ve heard from American companies who do business across the border
column64: it\u2019s going to hurt U.S. jobs. You don\u2019t negotiate by shooting yourself in your own foot

said in a statement to HuffPost. \u201cWe look forward to working together to producing real change that will grow manufacturing jobs in the United States.\u201d

Lawsuit Claims|[

A New Orleans judge accused of forcing defendants to pay to get out of jail before trial without considering their financial situation was sued Tuesday by civil rights groups challenging unconstitutional \u201cwealth-based bail practices\u201d across the country.
column3: The lawsuit against Orleans Parish Criminal District Judge Harry Cantrell alleges that he refuses to consider non-financial conditions of release
column4: instead requiring many poor defendants charged with low-level crimes to pay unnecessarily high bail amounts. Under this scheme
column5: Cantrell imposes \u201cde facto orders of pretrial detention for those unable to pay
column6: \u201d which can lead to defendants being jailed for weeks or months before trial
column7: the suit claims. The complaint alleges that Cantrell has a financial incentive to set high bonds
column8: because a portion goes into the court\u2019s general fund.
column9: The suit
column10: brought by attorneys from the MacArthur Justice Center and Civil Rights Corps
column11: was filed on behalf of two plaintiffs now jailed in Orleans Parish on misdemeanor drug charges. The court has not determined that either poses a substantial flight risk or a danger to the community. They remain behind bars only because they can\u2019t afford to pay the bail Cantrell has set
column12: according to the complaint.
column13: Cantrell routinely refuses to set bail below $2
column15: regardless of the facts of a case or a defendant\u2019s ability to pay
column16: the suit claims. In most cases
column17: the judge forces defendants to seek the services of a commercial bail bondsman
column18: which in Orleans Parish charge a non-refundable 12-percent or 13-percent fee on the total bond amount.
column19: \u201cWe don\u2019t go any lower than $2
column20: 500 in this court
column21: \u201d Cantrell told one defendant\u2019s attorney. \u201cThis court never goes any lower than $2
column23: \u201d he said in another case. \u201cI don\u2019t got any lower than $2
column24: 500 on my bonds
column25: \u201d he said in yet another. In one instance
column26: he told a lawyer he was going to set bond at $2
column28: regardless of what information the lawyer provided.
column29: The suit provides examples of Cantrell threatening to hold defense attorneys in contempt of court for asking that their clients be released on their own recognizance
column30: rather than on financial conditions. In one case
column31: Cantrell pushes back against an attorney\u2019s request by warning that he\u2019ll revoke a previous release order for another of the attorney\u2019s clients.
column32: \u201cDefense counsel is placed in the impossible position of having to weigh her own personal freedom against her obligation to advocate for her client\u2019s constitutional right to a meaningful bail hearing
column33: \u201d the complaint says. \u201cThe threat of jail time in retaliation for an attorney\u2019s basic oral advocacy would have a chilling effect on even the most zealous advocate and constitutes a gross abuse of authority.\u201d
column34: Cantrell
column35: the father-in-law of mayoral candidate and New Orleans City Councilwoman Latoya Cantrell
column36: owed the federal government more than <a href="http://www.nola.com/crime/index.ssf/2014/08/court_finds_orleans_judge_cant.html" target="_blank">$600

column40: Cantrell also ran a complex for elderly and disabled people\xa0that had more than two dozen federal violations and was deemed \u201cdangerous\u201d by Department of Housing and Urban Development officials.
column41: The Orleans Parish Criminal District Court collects $1 million each year on fees assessed on bonds defendants pay through commercial bail bond companies
column42: according to the suit. That money helps pay for salaries and benefits for court employees
column43: travel to official events
column44: office supplies
column45: building maintenance
column46: legal research and other day-to-day expenses.
column47: \u201cThe infrastructure of [Cantrell\u2019s] court \u2014 from the salary of his staff to the paper in his printer \u2014 depends upon the continued generation of money from for-profit commercial surety fees

column49: \u201d the suit reads.

Secretary of State Rex Tillerson\xa0has signed a pledge calling for timely action to address climate change during a meeting of nations with a vested interest in protecting the Arctic. \u201d the report urged.

Congress Targets California’s Groundbreaking Retirement Program

|[

Originally published on www.capitalandmain.com
column2: By Bill Raden
column3: A landmark
column4: IRA-type retirement savings program created for millions of Californians
column5: came under threat last week when House Republicans passed a joint resolution aimed at blocking states from setting up such payroll savings plans. The resolution
column6: which now moves to the Senate for consideration
column7: targets Department of Labor rules designed to expand the number of working Americans with access to IRA-styled savings accounts.
column8: Created last August
column9: these rules had paved the way for California Secure Choice
column10: the state-managed individual retirement account program that is on track to provide retirement nest eggs for nearly seven million Californians whose employers don\u2019t offer pensions or 401(k) plans. Signed into law by Jerry Brown only last September
column11: it isn\u2019t scheduled to begin enrollment until 2019.
column12: The August rule changes to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) clarified ERISA\u2019s broad preemption for state laws that cover private-sector employee pension benefit plans. The changes
column13: according to the DOL
column14: were intended to fill gaps in the nation\u2019s employer-provided retirement savings system that has left nearly 39 million private-sector workers \u2014 some say the number is as high as 55 million \u2014 without a job-provided retirement plan. The DOL also noted that less than 10 percent of all workers contribute to a plan outside of work.
column15: But HJR 66 and HJR 67
column16: joint resolutions introduced earlier this month by Republican Representatives Tim Walberg (MI) and Francis Rooney (FL)
column17: put the new federal rules that allow such state-sponsored plans on a kill list of regulations that govern the Affordable Care Act
column18: environmental safety and consumer protection through the rarely used Congressional Review Act.
column19: The resolutions were both prompted and cheered by the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and the mutual funds industry
column20: which had strenuously opposed Secure Choice because of longstanding industry concerns that state-sponsored programs could compete with their own products.
column21: \u201cThis is not new for the large financial institutions and insurance companies
column22: \u201d Secure Choice oversight board member Yvonne Walker told Capital & Main. \u201cThey have a long history of fighting against state efforts to expand retirement savings options for everyday workers. They say
column24: well we don\u2019t want to be in competition with the states.\u2019 But the reality is there are multiple retirement savings plans on the market
column25: and the truth of it is that overall
column26: working people can\u2019t afford to purchase retirement savings plans on their own.\u201d
column27: The passage of HJR 66 and 67 unfolded against a 35-year backdrop of stagnant wages and the dismantling of the traditional employer-sponsored
column28: private-sector retirement savings pillar in the U.S. \u2014 the defined-benefit pension plan \u2014 that has left nearly half of all Americans with nothing saved for retirement. At the same time
column29: critics have pointed out that the IRA industry has never seen much profit in marketing retirement plans to the low-wage workers and small-workforce businesses that Secure Choice would most benefit.
column30: \u201cIn California there is a brewing retirement crisis where you have our large aging population and
column31: at the same time
column32: we\u2019ve got the first baby-boom generation going into retirement
column33: \u201d explained Nari Rhee
column34: the Retirement Security Program manager at the University of California
column35: Berkeley Center for Labor Research and Education. \u201cNationally about 45 percent of households have nothing saved for retirement and the median retirement account balance right now is about $3
column36: 000 at the household level. Social Security is not going to be enough.\u201d
column37: The ERISA rule change had proved key to state Senate President pro Tem Kevin de Le\xf3n (D-Los Angeles) mustering legislative support for California Secure Choice. Even fervently pro-business groups within the state
column38: like the California Chamber of Commerce and the California Manufacturers and Technology Association
column39: eventually withdrew their opposition to a program that sponsors reasoned could eventually save California taxpayers billions of dollars by keeping retiring workers off Medicare
column40: food stamps and other badly strapped safety-net programs
column41: with little risk or cost to employers.
column42: Currently
column43: the plan is scheduled to be gradually phased in until it requires all California employers with five or more employees that don\u2019t already provide a retirement plan to either begin to offer a retirement plan or provide their employees access to Secure Choice\u2019s IRA-like payroll deductions. Though individual workers may opt out
column44: studies have shown that automatic enrollment results in up to 90 percent higher participation than when enrollment is voluntary
column45: particularly for low-wage workers.
column46: \u201cTwo-thirds of California\u2019s small business owners support the creation of a state retirement savings program and nearly three-fourths said such a program would give their business a competitive edge
column47: \u201d de Le\xf3n noted in an email to Capital & Main.
column48: One small business owner is childcare provider Nancy Harvey
column49: who employs a small staff at Lil\u2019 Nancy\u2019s Primary Schoolhouse
column50: which she has operated out of her West Oakland home for 15 years. Harvey
column51: who is 54 and previously taught elementary school
column52: explained that childcare jobs in the Bay Area typically attract workers well past retirement age.
column53: \u201cPeople cannot afford to retire
column54: \u201d she said by phone. \u201cAnd that is not a good thing when folks are taking care of children
column55: because at some point
column56: to be perfectly honest
column57: it becomes a safety issue. We have providers in their 70s still providing care for children
column58: and I\u2019m sure at some point they want to be able to retire. But because of the way the system has been set up
column59: it just simply does not allow for that.\u201d
column60: The House resolutions
column61: if passed by the Senate and signed by President Trump
column62: would permanently nullify the relatively obscure clarifications to ERISA that have raised the retirement-security hopes of millions of low-wage workers both inside and outside California. Seven other states are in various stages of creating and implementing similar state-run auto-enrollment retirement programs
column63: including Oregon
column64: where the OregonSaves payroll retirement savings plan is scheduled to go online in July.
column65: No hearings are required for resolution votes and
column66: under the Congressional Review Act
column67: once a rule is struck down
column68: the federal agency that issued it is barred from enacting similar regulations again in the future.
column69: \u201cIt\u2019s a huge slap in our face
column70: \u201d added Harvey bitterly. \u201cI feel that they just don\u2019t understand how average Americans truly live. You hate to say that it\u2019s evil-spirited
column71: but it almost seems like it is.\u201d
column72: A February 10 poll by the nonprofit
column73: nonpartisan National Institute on Retirement Security found that three-fourths of Americans believe that state efforts to provide working Americans access to individual retirement accounts are a good idea \u2014 up from 71 percent in 2015. It also found that the support was strongly bipartisan
column74: with 72 percent of Republicans and 83 percent of Democrats approving of the plans across gender
column75: income and age divisions.
column76: De Le\xf3n
column77: who personally lobbied House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy of Bakersfield before the conservative Republican cast his vote to scuttle the rule
column78: has vowed to press ahead with Secure Choice regardless of what Congress does. Though supporters maintain that California Secure Choice was drafted around the \u201csafe harbor\u201d already written into ERISA before the Obama rule change
column79: de Le\xf3n has said he\u2019ll do whatever it takes to legally implement the program
column80: including putting it before voters as a statewide ballot measure.
column82: retirement and labor groups like AARP and Service Employees International Union Local 1000
column83: whose president is Secure Choice oversight board member Yvonne Walker
column84: are pulling out all the stops to see that the Republican resolutions are stopped in the Senate. (Disclosure: Walker\u2019s union is a financial supporter of this website.)
column85: \u201cYou have ordinary working Americans who are faced with the choice of working until they die or retiring into poverty
column86: \u201d Walker said. \u201cAnd in America
column87: where you work hard and play by the rules
column88:
that cannot be the choice that working Americans should have to face.\u201d

]

Ohio Moves To Ban Abortion After 6 Weeks Of Pregnancy

|[

WASHINGTON\u2015 Ohio\u2019s Republican-led House and Senate passed legislation Tuesday night that would ban abortions as soon as a fetal heartbeat can be detected\u2015 as early as six weeks into a pregnancy.\xa0
column2: The measure was attached at the last minute as an amendment to an unrelated child abuse bill. It has no exceptions for rape or incest.
column3: If it\u2019s passed into law
column4: physicians could face a year in prison if they perform an abortion after a heartbeat is detected or if they fail to check for one before a procedure.
column5: The measure is the most extreme abortion restriction in the country
column6: effectively banning the procedure before most women even realize they\u2019re pregnant
column7: pro-abortion rights advocates said.
column8: \u201cAfter years of passing anti-abortion laws under the guise of protecting women\u2019s health and safety
column9: they lay bare their true motives: to ban abortion in the state of Ohio
column10: \u201d said Dawn Laguens
column11: a spokesperson for the Planned Parenthood Action Fund.\xa0
column12: Ohio lawmakers have been trying to pass the \u201cheartbeat bill\u201d since 2011
column13: \xa0but some activists feared that it was so extreme and unconstitutional that it could lead courts to overturn other
column14: less stringent abortion restrictions. The Supreme Court refused to review Arkansas\u2019 12-week abortion ban earlier this year
column15: which lower courts had blocked. The high court ruled in Roe v. Wade in 1973 that states are not allowed to prohibit abortions before the fetus is viable
column16: usually around 22 to 24 weeks into the pregnancy.\xa0
column17: Republicans said they now feel emboldened to pass the bill because President-elect Donald Trump is likely to appoint anti-abortion conservatives to the Supreme Court.\xa0
column18: \u201cA new president
column19: new Supreme Court appointees change the dynamic
column20: and there was consensus in our caucus to move forward
column21: \u201d Ohio Senate President Keith Faber (R-Celina) told the Columbus Dispatch.
column22: The bill now moves to the desk of Gov. John Kasich (R). He has not indicated whether he will sign it.
column23:
Clarification: Language has been changed to reflect more accurately the point in a pregnancy when a heartbeat is detectable.
