Judge Reprimanded For Telling New Citizens To Leave Country If They Don't Like Donald Trump

|[

A federal magistrate judge in Texas has been permanently removed from overseeing naturalization ceremonies after he said new U.S. citizens could leave the United States if they don\u2019t like President-elect Donald Trump. The judge subsequently said he plans to retire next year.
column2: Five district court judges unanimously agreed Monday to remove Judge John Primomo from overseeing the ceremonies
column3: said Orlando Garcia
column4: chief judge for the United States District Court for the Western District of Texas. The district court judges are responsible for appointing and overseeing federal magistrate judges. Primomo\u2019s removal\xa0was first reported by the San Antonio Express-News.
column5: \u201cGiven the obvious inappropriate remarks made at a recent proceeding
column6: the district judges thought it best that he not handle these proceedings any longer
column7: \u201d Garcia said in an interview.
column8: On Tuesday
column9: Primomo said in a letter to U.S. district court judges in Texas and to the 5th Circuit in New Orleans that he intends to retire next year
column10: before his current term is complete
column11: the Express-News reported.\xa0
column12: During a naturalization ceremony last week
column13: Primomo said anyone who didn\u2019t like Trump needed to go to a different country.
column14: \u201cI can assure you that whether you voted for him or you did not vote for him
column15: if you are a citizen of the United States
column16: he is your president
column17: \u201d he said. \u201cHe will be your president and if you do not like that
column18: you need to go to another country.\u201d Primomo also criticized recent protests in which athletes have kneeled during the national anthem.
column19: Garcia said he had never heard comments like these from Primomo
column20: who was appointed to the position in 1988
column21: or any other judge.
column22: \u201cIt\u2019s very uncharacteristic. Johnny Primomo actually is a good judge and good man. I don\u2019t know what led him to do this. This has never happened before. Otherwise we certainly would have heard about it
column23: \u201d he said. Garcia added that when he heard about Primomo\u2019s comments he was \u201cquite upset and very puzzled by the whole affair.\u201d
column24: \u201cWe had a very frank discussion and he readily agreed that it was a poor choice of words and he readily accepted the fact that he would no longer be handling these proceedings and that was the end of that
column25: \u201d Garcia said.
column26: The 5th circuit will also review a complaint filed by Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund against Primomo because of his remarks.\xa0
column28: the Express-News reported that Primomo had <a href="http://www.expressnews.com/news/local/article/Naturalized-U-S-magistrate-here-has-minted-5675261.php" target="_blank">helped nearly 100
column29: 000 people become new citizens. The judge
column30: who has said his comments were taken out of context and were meant to be unifying
column31: did not immediately return a request for comment.

WASHINGTON \u2015 Washington State and South Dakota voters gave a split decision on Tuesday on sweeping ballot initiatives that would reform campaign finance
column2: lobbying and ethics in their respective states. The initiative in South Dakota won while the initiative in Washington lost.

column5: the lead national reform group supporting the initiatives

column9: The initiative language was packaged to attract this bipartisan consensus. This included tying together public campaign financing with strong lobbying and ethics reforms and transparency rules.

column11: \u201d providing each registered voter with a certain number of $50 credits to use as campaign contributions to candidates who choose to participate in the publicly funded system. Voters in Seattle approved a ballot initiative that created such a system for the city\u2019s elections in 2015.

column13: the main political arm of the billionaire Koch brothers
column14: to win in a conservative Republican state.
column15: \u201cVoters are sick and tired and want to embrace solutions
column16: \u201d said David Donnelly
column18: which also supported the initiatives.
column19: These weren\u2019t the only campaign finance or lobbying reforms on the ballot on Tuesday. Voters in Howard County
column20: Maryland
column21: and Berkeley
column22: California
column23: approved the creation of a small-donor public financing system. In San Francisco
column24: voters enacted an initiative to implement new lobbying and ethics rules. In Missouri
column25:
voters passed an initiative to reinstate campaign contributions limits. And in California and Washington state voters passed referendums calling for the overturn of the Supreme Court\u2019s Citizens United decision.

Aetna CEO Threatened Obamacare Pullout If Feds Opposed Humana Merger

|[

The big health care news this week came from Aetna
column2: which announced on Monday it was dramatically scaling back\xa0participation in the Affordable Care Act \u2015 thereby reducing insurer competition and forcing customers scattered across 11 states to find different sources of coverage next year.
column3: Aetna officials said the pullout was necessary because of Obamacare\u2019s problems \u2015 specifically
column4: deep losses the insurer was incurring in the law\u2019s health insurance exchanges.
column5: But the move also was directly related to a Department of Justice decision to block the insurer\u2019s potentially lucrative merger with Humana
column6: according to a letter\xa0from Aetna\u2019s CEO obtained by The Huffington Post.
column7: Paired with some looming rate increases for next year\u2019s health plans
column8: the abrupt departure of Aetna has triggered new worries that Obamacare \u2015 a subsidized public-private system of health insurance plans competing for beneficiaries \u2015 is in serious trouble and may even be unsustainable.
column9: That\u2019s despite millions who have obtained coverage through these marketplaces
column10: contributing to a historically low uninsured rate. It\u2019s also despite optimism about Obamacare from at least some insurers and experts \u2015 optimism that Aetna\u2019s own leaders had expressed just a few months ago.
column11: Publicly
column12: Aetna representatives this week framed their about-face as a reaction to losses the company was taking on Obamacare customers
column13: and in particular figures from the second quarter of 2016 that the company had just analyzed
column14: showing them to be sicker and costlier than predicted.
column15: When reporters on Monday asked whether Aetna was also reacting to the administration\u2019s attempt to thwart its merger with Humana
column16: company officials brushed off the questions
column17: according to accounts in the Hartford Courant
column18: Politico\xa0and USA Today.
column19: But just last month
column20: in a letter to the Department of Justice
column21: Aetna CEO Mark Bertolini said the two issues were closely linked. In fact
column22: he made a clear threat: If President Barack Obama\u2019s administration refused to allow the merger to proceed
column23: he wrote
column24: Aetna would be in a worse financial position and would have to withdraw from most of its Obamacare markets
column25: and quite likely all of them.
column26: Bertolini penned the letter
column27: which The Huffington Post obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request
column28: on July 5 \u2015 16 days before the Justice Department announced it would fight the Humana deal. The department had asked Aetna how
column29: if at all
column30: a decision on the proposed merger would affect Aetna\u2019s willingness to offer insurance through the exchanges.
column31: Bertolini responded bluntly. Aetna supported the law\u2019s goal to expand coverage and planned to increase its exchange offerings next year
column32: in the hopes that the exchanges would stabilize as enrollment grew
column33: he wrote.
column34: But if the Justice Department were to block the merger
column35: Bertolini warned
column36: Aetna could no longer sustain the losses from its exchange business
column37: forcing it to sharply change direction:
column38: [I]f the deal were challenged and/or blocked we would need to take immediate actions to mitigate public exchange and ACA small group losses. Specifically
column39: if the DOJ sues to enjoin the transaction
column40: we will immediately take action to reduce our 2017 exchange footprint .... [I]nstead of expanding to 20 states next year
column41: we would reduce our presence to no more than 10 states .\u2026 [I]t is very likely that we would need to leave the public exchange business entirely and plan for additional business efficiencies should our deal ultimately be blocked. By contrast
column42: if the deal proceeds without the diverted time and energy associated with litigation
column43: we would explore how to devote a portion of the additional synergies ... to supporting even more public exchange coverage over the next few years.
column44: To Obamacare critics
column45: Aetna\u2019s retreat is proof the law is failing. To supporters
column46: it shows the company was using its participation in Obama\u2019s signature domestic policy initiative as a bargaining chip in order to secure approval of a controversial business deal.
column47: Advocates on both sides can cite at least some evidence to support their views. While some insurers are making money on Obamacare
column48: most of the large
column49: publicly traded national insurers now offering coverage on the exchanges are losing money
column50: basically for the same reasons that Aetna cites. Aetna\u2019s shift in strategy followed similar maneuvers by UnitedHealth Group
column51: \xa0Humana and some smaller insurers.
column52: If the exchanges do not attract more participants who are in relatively good health
column53: then companies will likely have to keep raising rates\xa0\u2015 to the point where some people who have to pay for insurance directly
column54: especially those who receive little or no federal subsidies
column55: would decide it\u2019s too expensive.
column56: Notably
column57: however
column58: Anthem and Cigna
column59: two other health insurance giants whose pending merger the Justice Department also opposes
column60: have not said they plan to alter course on the exchanges next year
column61: despite financial struggles.
column62: Anthem is a major player in this market segment
column63: and Cigna intends to offer plans in more states that it currently does. Of course
column64: investors may pressure those companies to reconsider in response to the moves by Aetna
column65: Humana and UnitedHealth Group.
column66: Furthermore
column67: Aetna\u2019s posture on the exchanges changed pretty radically after the Justice Department announced that it was suing to block the Humana merger.
column68: As recently as April
column69: Bertolini told investors that Aetna could sustain losses on the exchanges for the time being
column70: because participation still represented a relatively cheap way to acquire new customers \u2015 particularly since the program was bound to have kinks in the early years.
column71: Bertolini defended Aetna\u2019s exchange business at the time:
column72: We see this as a good investment
column73: hoping that we have an administration and a Congress that will allow us to change the product like we change Medicare every year
column74: and we change Medicaid every year. But we haven\u2019t been able to touch this product because of the politics.
column75: Since that earnings call
column76: Aetna officials have warned that their assessment of the financial returns from the exchange business was dimming
column77: even as the firm\u2019s other lines of business \u2015 such as employer-provided health benefits
column78: Medicare and Medicaid \u2015 continued to thrive. On Monday
column79: they pointed to that new information as a reason for pulling back on the exchanges.
column80: T.J. Crawford
column82: reiterated that argument in an email to The Huffington Post Tuesday.
column83: \u201cWe gained full visibility into our second quarter individual public exchange results
column84: \u201d Crawford wrote
column85: \u201cwhich \u2015 similar to other participants on the public exchanges \u2015 showed a significant deterioration. That deterioration
column86: and not the DOJ challenge to our Humana transaction
column87: is ultimately what drove us to announce the narrowing of our public exchange presence for the 2017 plan year.\u201d
column88: Aetna\u2019s shift in strategy
column89: whatever the reasons
column90: underscores the difficulties facing this new market for people who don\u2019t get health insurance through their employers or from a government program like Medicare and Medicaid.
column91: The departures of health insurers from some states
column92: along with the collapse of most of the nonprofit co-op plans created under the Affordable Care Act
column93: also means many consumers will see fewer choices when sign-ups begin in November for 2017 coverage.
column94: At the same time
column95: other insurers
column96: including regional Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans in states like Florida
column97: Michigan and New Jersey
column98: along with companies like Molina Healthcare and Centene that previously specialized in covering Medicaid beneficiaries
column99: are either profitable already or say they plan to continue their investment in this market. \xa0
column100: As Bertolini indicated in April
column101: strengthening these marketplaces and making coverage more secure for the low- and middle-income people who rely on it likely will require changes in the law. Given the relentless political toxicity afflicting anything Obamacare-related
column102: legislative solutions aren\u2019t likely in the near term.
column103: Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton has proposed a number of fixes for the health insurance market
column104: including the creation of a government-run public option plan that would be available everywhere
column105: and allowing pre-retirees to buy Medicare coverage. Clinton also has called for offering more generous subsidies to cover families with high health care costs.
column107: the GOP White House nominee
column108: follows the party line on the Affordable Care Act
column109: which is that it should be repealed and replaced with some other set of reforms that he has barely defined. House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) released a broad outline of a GOP health plan
column110: but it doesn\u2019t seek the same goals as Obamacare\xa0\u2015 especially when it comes to the uninsured and people with pre-existing conditions.
column111: Indeed
column112: the aim of Trump and Ryan in repealing Obamacare would result in roughly 20 million people losing their coverage
column113: which would cause disruption on a far greater scale that Aetna\u2019s decision.

column1: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/congress-ethics-office-steve-pearce_us_575afb96e4b00f97fba83080?utm_hp_ref=politics&ncid=fcbklnkushpmg00000013&section=politics|<h1 class="headline__title">Congressman Thinks Ethics Office Too Tough
column2:
So He Tries To Cut It|[

WASHINGTON -- A vote to slash funding for the independent office that reviews and investigates allegations of misconduct by members of Congress and their staff failed in the House on Friday.
column3: Rep. Steve Pearce (R-N.M.) was originally pushing to completely defund the Office of Congressional Ethics
column4: eliminating its roughly $1.4 million budget. He settled instead for a vote on an amendment to stop a $190
column5: 000 increase in OCE funding. That measure went down to defeat
column7: Last year
column8: the ethics office looked into allegations of misconduct by one of Pearce\u2019s staffers. That didn\u2019t sit well with the congressman
column9: despite the fact that the charges were ultimately dismissed. When the ethics office dismisses allegations
column10: they remain confidential
column11: so no one likely would have known had Pearce not made them public in his attempts to restrict the agency's authority and cut its funding.
column12: Pearce said his amendment was meant to \u201cgive notice to OCE that we are watching what you\u2019re doing.\u201d
column13: In an brief interview with The Huffington Post after the vote
column14: the congressman argued that the ethics office is \u201cduplicative\u201d and \u201cnot transparent.\u201d But he wouldn\u2019t say his attempts to rein in the agency were in direct response to its investigation of his staffer.
column15: Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz (D-Fla.) criticized Pearce's efforts on the chamber floor.\xa0\u201cThe OCE is crucial to ensuring accountability and transparency in this body
column16: and any attempts to cut its budget would only serve to erode our constituents' trust and faith in Congress
column17:
she said.

,

Asked if any agency at all should be tasked with holding members of Congress accountable for potential ethics violations, Pearce pointed to the House Ethics Committee. That panel is run by the lawmakers themselves.

,

\u201cWe have the House Ethics Committee, and if we\u2019re not willing to do our job, then shame on us,\u201d he said.

,

Friday's vote was not Pearce's first unsuccessful stab at the Office of Congressional Ethics. Last year, he tried to restrict its powers\xa0by adding stringent new language to the rules governing both the OCE and the House Ethics Committee. The changes would have reaffirmed that those being investigated by the OCE can be represented by a lawyer -- as the rules already allowed --\xa0and would have prohibited either entity from taking action that would deny a person the "right to protection provided under the Constitution."
column18: The Campaign Legal Center
column19: a nonprofit government ethics group
column20: issued a statement denouncing Pearce's latest effort.\xa0
column21: "Rep. Pearce\u2019s motivation is clear
column22:
the group said. He has had several interactions with the OCE and this effort is nothing more than sour grapes."

]

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/hillary-clinton-federal-reserve-plan_us_57363ac4e4b08f96c1833ad3?ncid=fcbklnkushpmg00000013§ion=politics|

Here's Why Hillary Clinton's Federal Reserve Plan Is A Big Deal

|[

On Thursday
column2: Hillary Clinton endorsed a banking reform idea that is more progressive than anything she backed during her long primary battle with Bernie Sanders. Compared to high-profile proposals like breaking up the banks
column3: the plan Clinton backed is a narrow change
column4: but an important one that nerdy liberal activists have been championing for years. Put simply
column5: Clinton wants to shift the balance of power at the Federal Reserve away from private banks in favor of democratic accountability.
column6: The Fed is the most powerful economic institution in the world
column7: and perhaps the strangest. The central bank's Board of Governors in Washington
column8: D.C.
column9: is a government entity run by presidential appointees who must be confirmed by the Senate. But the 12 regional Federal Reserve Banks that perform the bulk of the central bank's grunt work -- handling and processing reserves -- are technically owned by banks. This ownership doesn't mean much in terms of direct earnings; the banks can't sell their Fed stock
column10: and the regional Fed banks don't turn a profit.
column11: The trouble is that the regional Fed banks have a lot of power over the Federal Open Market Committee -- the key panel that sets interest rates
column12: directing a tremendous amount of U.S. economic activity. Private banks do have a lot of influence over who manages the Fed's regional outposts through board of director positions. Directors selected by bankers help choose the president of each Fed outpost. These presidents
column13: in turn
column14: serve on the key committee that sets interest rates. On Thursday
column15: Clinton called for getting bankers out of that process.
column16: If it all sounds terribly complicated
column17: it is. But the bottom line is that Clinton called to replace one form of banker influence over public policy with a system of democratic accountability. That would be a concrete
column18: progressive change to the status quo. And despite her rhetoric on the campaign trail
column19: \xa0the key element of Clinton's financial platform has been to implement existing law.
column20: The battle between banker influence and political control at the Fed has been going on since before the central bank was even founded
column21: as journalist and author Roger Lowenstein discusses in the latest episode of the HuffPost politics podcast "So
column22: That Happened." Lowenstein's latest book
column23: America's Bank: The Epic Struggle To Create The Federal Reserve
column24: details more than a decade of early 20th-century political combat between Democrats and Republicans
column25: populists and progressives
column26: agrarians and urbanites that culminated in the formation of the U.S. central bank. It sounds
column27: in other words
column28: quite a bit like contemporary politics -- with the caveat that Congress did actually get something done at the end.
column29: "When I started this book
column30: it was right after
column31: in the aftermath of our most recent disaster with mortgages and bailouts and everything
column32: Lowenstein said. I wanted to know how we came through a somewhat similar crash a century ago without a Fed
column33: and why it was that we didn't have one. Because even at that time
column34: we were the only nation in the developed world that was trying to run their economy on this extreme laissez-faire basis."
column35: Listen to Lowenstein's comments in the podcast embedded above. The discussion begins at the 37:00 mark.
column36: Nobody in his or her right mind would design the Federal Reserve system from scratch as a way to manage the economy. And Lowenstein shows that nobody
column37: in fact
column38: did such a thing. Creating the Fed was both a political dogfight and a balancing act
column39: with different factions being placated in different ways
column40: resulting in a bizarre public-private hybrid that somehow seems to work.
column41: But the battle to shape the Fed didn't stop once the system got up and running. The American central bank has been overhauled several times
column42: most notably during the Great Depression
column43: but also during the 1980s and after the 2008 crash.
column44:
Clinton's call for further changes is just the latest in a century of struggle over how to govern the world's most potent economic power.

]

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/supreme-court-nominee-poll_us_56e9724ce4b0b25c9183fd33?ncid=fcbklnkushpmg00000013§ion=politics|

Americans Think Republicans Should Give Obama's Supreme Court Nominee A Fair Hearing

|[

President Barack Obama officially put forward a Supreme Court nominee\xa0on Wednesday to fill the vacancy created by Justice Antonin Scalia
column2: escalating a battle with Senate Republicans who vow to continue ignoring any Obama nominee.\xa0
column3: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) was quick to respond
column4: \xa0reaffirming the party's intention\xa0to withhold hearings until next year.\xa0
column5: \u201cThe American people may well elect a president who decides to nominate Judge Garland for Senate consideration
column6: he told the press Wednesday. The next president may also nominate someone very different. Either way
column7: our view is this: Give the people a voice in the filling of this vacancy."
column8: Recent polls however
column9: show that Americans largely disagree with that stance and -- with some variation -- say they want the Senate to hold hearings and consider Obama's nominee.\xa0
column10: According to an ABC News/Washington Post poll conducted in early March
column11: 63 percent of Americans agree
column12: 44 percent strongly
column13: \xa0that the Senate should hold hearings and vote on a nominee. Thirty-two percent disagree and say the Senate should not hold hearings.\xa0
column14: Similarly
column15: a recent NBC/WSJ poll finds that 55 percent of voters disapprove of the Senate's decision to "not consider" an Obama nominee
column16: with 45 percent saying they strongly disapprove. Just 28 percent said they approve.\xa0
column17: A plurality of respondents in the NBC/WSJ poll -- 48 percent -- say that the Senate should vote on a Scalia replacement this year. A minority of 37 percent think they should leave the position vacant and wait until next year.\xa0
column18: A YouGov/Economist poll\xa0found slightly less support
column19: with 49 percent of Americans saying the Senate should hold hearings. One-fifth say they should not hold hearings
column20: and one-sixth say the decision should depend on who the nominee is.
column21: Although the polls do exhibit some variation -- likely because of differences in question wording -- a clear picture does emerge: Americans want Senate Republicans to hold hearings
column22: whether the legislators approve of a nominee or not.
column23: Despite an overall consensus on the issue
column24: polls also show a clear divide along party lines. Over half of Republicans in the NBC/WSJ poll support leaving the seat open and not considering any nominations
column25: a decision nearly 8 in 10 Democrats disapprove of.\xa0
column26: Republican leadership is counting on the partisan support to carry out their plan and benefit from it come election time. Last week Politico reported the GOP leaders were circulating a poll that showed Republicans were more worried about a liberal justice being chosen than about the seat remaining open until next year.\xa0
column27: However
column28: Obama's nominee
column29: <a href="http://www.npr.org/2016/03/16/126614141/merrick-garland-has-a-reputation-of-collegiality-record-of-republican-support" target="_blank">Merrick Garland
column30: is considered to be a moderate choice\xa0who has a history of Republican support and a resume that could appeal to many conservatives.\xa0
column31: Furthermore
column32: other polling conducted in the last several weeks disputes that a decision to refuse nomination hearings would be politically advantageous for Republicans in November.
column33: A Quinnipiac poll finds a majority of voters in the swing state of Ohio
column34: where Sen. Rob Portman (R) is up for re-election and currently trailing against his Democratic rival
column35: want the Senate to hold hearings.\xa0
column36:
The Democratic polling firm Public Policy Polling\xa0also finds that a majority of voters in other swing states where Republicans are up for re-election approve of hearings.

]

How People In San Francisco Are Saving Water

|[

The San Francisco Public Utilities Commission provides water to 2.6 million customers. We talked to the director of water resources
column2: Paula Kehoe
column3: about how the agency is enabling onsite water reuse systems
column4: drilling new groundwater wells and achieving some of the state's lowest per capita water use.
column5: San Francisco has an enviable water system. Almost completely gravity-fed
column6: it funnels snowmelt from pristine waters high in the Sierra Nevada mountains. The water is brought to homes and businesses in San Francisco by the San Francisco Public Utilities Commission(SFPUC)
column7: which also functions as a water wholesaler for the Bay Area.
column8: About 2.6 million customers receive water from the SFPUC\u2019s system
column9: the heart of which is the Hetch Hetchy reservoir in Yosemite National Park. Of that number
column10: one-third are in San Francisco and the rest receive water provided by water agencies in Alameda
column11: San Mateo and Santa Clara counties.
column12: It\u2019s a big system to run \u2013 the third largest in the state. To better understand its challenges and accomplishments (SFPUC has been a leader on conservation and water recycling
column13: among other things)
column14: we spoke to Paula Kehoe
column15: the SFPUC\u2019s director of water resources.
column16: Water Deeply: How has the SFPUC been weathering the drought so far?
column17: Paula Kehoe: Our primary water source
column18: the Hetch Hetchy reservoir has actually performed well in the drought. And that\u2019s thanks to our storage system
column19: which relies on a coordinated operation of all of our reservoirs. We have several reservoirs in our system
column20: as well as a water bank account in the Don Pedro reservoir
column21: which is downstream from Hetch Hetchy.
column22: This water bank account allows us to store water in Don Pedro reservoir during wet years for future releases to local irrigation districts during dry years. This banking system allows us to store some of our precious drinking water during dry years. During this drought
column23: we filled or nearly filled our Hetch Hetchy reservoir every year while we were drawing down our water storage bank account.
column24: Water Deeply: It must help that San Franciscans are generally pretty low water users
column25: right?
column26: Paula Kehoe: We are also under a state mandate. Our reduction that the state assigned to San Francisco was 8 percent. In 2013 that was a challenge for us because San Francisco already uses less water than almost anyone in the state
column27: averaging around 45 gallons per person
column28: per day. And that is due to our conservation program that has been in place for decades.
column29: We started off at a low residential per capita rate in response to the drought and we also asked our customers to help us through the drought and voluntarily reduce their consumption by 10 percent; we asked our irrigation customers to reduce their consumption by 25 percent and that was actually a mandate for those customers.
column30: We put in place a number of drought restrictions and we had a tremendous response here in San Francisco. We saved 14 billion gallons of water by the end of November 2015; our goal was 10 billion gallons by December 2015
column31: so we achieved that goal even sooner than we expected. And today our residential per capita continues to decline and we\u2019re on about 41 gallons per person per day. That is among the lowest per capita rates in the state of California.
column32: Water Deeply: Do you know how customers are saving water?
column33: Kehoe: What we plan to do [this month] is conduct a survey of San Francisco customers and consumers to find out what action they took during this drought period to really understand more about those specific actions that people took to get us down to 41 gallons per person per day.
column34: And then we want to ask them if they will continue these actions and behavioral practices in the future. So we will have a better understanding of how sustainable our 41 gallons per capita is and if will we see any rebound in that. Historically
column35: in previous droughts
column36: we\u2019ve seen the per capita went down and there was a slight rebound but it never went back to the consumption rates we saw prior to drought periods.
column37: We are happy that we live in a community where people are responding and really helping us manage our way through the drought.
column38: Water Deeply: What\u2019s your biggest focus right now?
column39: Kehoe: We are working hard on many different levels. We have a local water program here that is geared toward continuing our conservation efforts as well as developing new water supplies in San Francisco. That really provides us with additional flexibility to meet our diverse water needs by using the right type of water for the right use here in the city.
column40: With our conservation program
column41: it\u2019s been our focus for decades; since the early 1990s we have provided incentives to replace 80
column42: 000 toilets and 30
column43: 000 clothes washers
column44: and conducted over 100
column45: 000 water audits \u2013 that really has paid off as our per capita has gone down but population has increased.
column46: Really
column47: we have seen an over 20 percent decrease in water consumption in 10 years despite modest population growth. We also have been doing studies to see how many inefficient fixtures are still left in San Francisco in homes and businesses. We completed that study and found that really our conservation programs have been so effective that we believe that 70 percent of all the toilets are water efficient. At least 50-60 percent of all residential clothes washers are efficient.
column48: But that doesn\u2019t mean our job is done.
column49: Water Deeply: How are you working to expand the water supply?
column50: Kehoe: Currently we are installing new wells in San Francisco. We will have six groundwater wells in the city and we will pump that and blend it with our surface supply
column51: which will be available day in and day out. We will be able to produce approximately 4 million gallons a day and that will increase our water supply here in San Francisco.
column52: Our other focus is continuing to look at future droughts. We anticipate that we will have more droughts
column53: so we are actively working on a project south of San Francisco by installing 13 groundwater wells to produce an additional 7 million gallons of water for drought purposes only.
column54: Water Deeply: You\u2019ve also done a lot with water recycling
column55: how is that going?
column56: Kehoe: We know the best investment for recycled water here for us in San Francisco is to address large-scale irrigation such as parks and golf courses. Harding Park and Fleming Park golf courses currently use recycled water for their irrigation and later this year we plan to start construction on a recycled water plant on the west side of San Francisco to irrigate Golden Gate Park
column57: Lincoln Park golf course and portions of the Presidio. That\u2019s another big focus to get that plant up and going.
column58: We are also using non-potable water to clean our streets in San Francisco.
column59: When it came to building our new headquarters we incorporated our own onsite water treatment system and rainwater harvesting system as well as the living machine that enables us to save 65 percent of potable water that we\u2019d otherwise be using to flush our toilets and urinals.
column60: We came across a number of other developers who wanted onsite water treatment in their buildings and districts in San Francisco so we created a non-potable water program to allow that. The creation of that program really allowed us to align our governmental policies to create a process for private owners to install these systems.
column61: And today we have over 40 buildings that are proposing to collect and treat their own water on site and to use that for non-potable applications such as for toilet flushing and irrigation. We\u2019ve been learning and working with others throughout the country to show that you can successfully integrate decentralized onsite water treatment systems into your broader
column62: centralized infrastructure to reduce the use of potable water.
column63: Water Deeply: Are there any policy changes that you think would help?
column64: Kehoe: Most water issues are local. We all have different water systems. We all have different sources of water
column65: different demands
column66: different growth rates. Most folks are also working on developing their own local water supplies for local control and that\u2019s what San Francisco is doing and many others throughout California.
column67: I think what\u2019s helpful to us is grant funding
column68: financial assistance
column69: state revolving fund loans that have low interest rates. Those are helpful tools to provide to the utilities who know their water systems best
column70: know their communities best
column71: to help them implement these kinds of projects.
column72: Water Deeply: You recently helped to fund a report
column73: "Managing Drought: Learning from Australia
column74:
about drought lessons in Australia. Why did you get involved in that project?

,

Kehoe: We were excited about that because we wanted to learn what worked and didn\u2019t work in Australia. If there were things we could apply here. I think one of the major conclusions of the study is that conservation and demand management programs are very key to dealing with drought and to be doing those programs all along in advance. That has been San Francisco\u2019s experience. We\u2019ve been doing it for decades. It\u2019s helped us through this drought.

,

Water Deeply: A lot of water agencies are having revenue problems because residents are conserving water so well \u2013 has that been an issue for you?

,

Kehoe: Yes, that\u2019s the downside of folks responding to our call. Our call was to our customers and consumers to help us through this drought and they did a great job and helped us. The unfortunate part is that it does impact our revenue and that is a situation that we are dealing with and are addressing. We\u2019ve had to take some actions here. We\u2019ve had 5 percent cuts throughout the agency. We\u2019ve had to limit certain activities and things we are doing.

,

We are looking at different kinds of options, possibly revisiting our rates, although they are approved through 2017.

,

Water Deeply: Anything else you\u2019d like readers to know?

,

Kehoe: I think that we\u2019re all in this together. There is the role of the utility \u2013 we are developing recycled water and new groundwater projects. There is a role for consumers and customers to take on changing out their toilets and clothes washers and having efficient fixtures to help us respond to drought. There is a role for business with non-potable water programs. Developers are installing these systems. I think it\u2019s a collective and we\u2019re all working together and toward the same goal.

,

Our work is never done and that\u2019s a good thing. We are in a very uncertain time when it comes to climate and we want to be prepared for the future.
